Clever. Looks like an AI glitch now. Long enough to make his escape before he's found out, anyway. It must hurt, leaving all that kit behind, but who knows what this place does to cheaters?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Try to outrun the bot cont'd.

You change tactics, using the pillars to your advantage. Biting back pain, you begin hobbling from pillar to pillar, keeping the robot in a steady, square chase pattern. It hurts like hell, but at each corner, you get a brief respite as you wait for the bot to clumsily navigate around the pillar.
It's a boring pursuit, and the audience voices as much. Shouts of "Boo!" and "Next!" rise from the crowd, and a horn blows. You've managed to buy your life with boredom, for once. That, and a nasty gash on your leg.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Ready this time, you prepare to counterattack. The arm launches forward again. This time, you quickly sidestep and grapple the lower segment, just above the claw. It sweeps to the side again, retracting with jarring speed. Your body flails out and slams into the unit's chassis. Clenching your jaw, you fight back the pain, and maintain your grip.
The arm lashes forward and back, like it were stuck in some kind of loop. You desperately cling to it, trying not to slide underneath where the joint would crack you like a walnut. Each time the armature flies forward, you hear servos strain under the load. The arm was likely meant for brief, crushing grabs and quick strikes, not for extended lifting.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Another fling forward, and you hear something crack, then grinding metal. The arm falls limp, draped over the chassis, and pinching you between metal parts. You lose your grip, falling under the legs, and hear the rotor clutch disengage.
Shouting through the pain, you launch from under the robot, and pull yourself up onto the chassis. The blade stops again, and the robot just stands in place, arm servos grinding against something inside the joint.
Just as happy to see robot thrashed as human, the crowd is shouting and rattling the mesh atop the pit's walls. You were exactly what they paid to see today.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Unsure what to do, you watch as the robot approaches. Those radial legs look pretty dangerous, and so does the armature. You can't hide underneath either. Starting to panic, you run the other way.
It takes little time for the robot to close the gap, however. You turn to face it, waiting to see what its next move is. Faster than you can react, the arm launches forward, punching you into the wall. You slump down, holding your aching gut, and you hear the crowd's volume rise.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Audibly disappointed, the crowd's roar settles back into a babbling noise, and the pit's guards open the gate. You decide to make your exit before they have a chance to call another lucky "winner."
Bouncing your way back towards the door, you step into brightly lit trailer, and present your chit to the guard.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
He locates the bin with your chit's number, retrieves your things, and amazingly, they're all still there. Though a sign on the wall warns:
"UNCLAIMED ITEMS BECOME THE PROPERTY OF ZOM ZOM'S -MANAGEMENT"
Better make sure you empty that locker while you have the chance.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
While no doubt less gory than they're used to, the audience lets out a cheer of approval. Something got destroyed, and that's all that matters.
The pit gates open, and as a clean-up crew enters the field, you decide to make for the door, before you get lucky and win another lotto.
Forcing your way back towards the door, you step into brightly lit trailer, and present your chit to the guard.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Audibly disappointed, the MC does his best to distract the booing crowd as the robot is deactivated and cleared from the field.
The pit guards open the gates, and for a moment, you worry you'll be pressed into another fight. However, nothing happens for a few moments, so you decide to make for the door while you can.
Pressing through the crowd, you fish out your chit, and present it to the guard at the weapons check.

table.name: encounters
table.column: A Happy Crowd is a Safe Crowd

The audience lets out a roar of approval. Somebody got gored AND a robot thrashed. Good day at the pit!
The pit gates open, and as a clean-up crew enters the field, you decide to make for the door, before you get lucky and win another lotto.
Forcing your way back toward the door, you step into brightly lit trailer, and present your chit to the guard.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Audibly disappointed, the MC does his best to distract the booing crowd as the robot is deactivated and cleared from the field.
The pit guards open the gates, and for a moment, you worry you'll be pressed into another fight. However, nothing happens for a few moments, so you decide to make for the door while you can.
Pressing through the crowd, you fish out your chit, and present it to the guard at the weapons check.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Gore is gore. And while televised gore isn't as exciting as live gore, this is a fight few get to see, even in this pit. The crowd's cheers of approval continue well after the footage ends.
The pit gates open, and as a clean-up crew enters the field, you decide to make for the door, before you get lucky and win another lotto.
Forcing your way back toward the door, you step into brightly lit trailer, and present your chit to the guard.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You decide this place is a worse idea the longer you're here.
Pressing your way back towards the door, you step into brightly lit trailer, and present your chit to the guard.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Plodding onward, all seems still again. You begin to wonder if what you saw was your mind playing tricks on you. Or maybe you passed into and then out of a creature's territory?
Your thoughts are interrupted when you notice something a ways off to your side. It's humanoid in shape and wearing clothes, but it also has a face as white as plaster, with raccoon-like blackness where its eyes should be.
It's staring right at you, and it makes your neck chill.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You realize, now, why there is such fervor for this barbecue. Each bite seems to simultaneously satisfy your hunger, and fill you with anxiety about how little is left.
You finish your skewer guardedly.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Trying not to tip the scales toward hostilities, you call out to it.
In return, it raises a hand, palm towards you. Several more appear simultaneously in a wide circle around you, seemingly from nowhere.
"Stranger," says the first, "you have entered protected lands. What are your intentions?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You offer your item, which she stashes in a metal locker.
"Hand," she demands, reaching for a stamp as you present your hand. She applies a symbol and number, then nods to another grizzly merc, who checks you for weapons. He tosses your confiscated items into a numbered bin, and ushers you down the trailer.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Returning to the forest surrounding the ATN, it doesn't take long for the Nooke warriors to intercept you.
However, this time, you are taken to an area nearby, where a small group of travelers has assembled. This group is then led through the ATN perimeter forest towards the village.
Your guides lead you, probably intentionally, near enough to see a pitfall being excavated, and then warn you not to stray.
The group stays close, not wanting to wander into a snare, and close to an hour later, you begin hearing the sounds of the village.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Without pausing, the bot starts closing in on the human who, to his credit, has given up rattling the gate and is now facing the more immediate danger. He starts circling left, leading the bot to one side of the pit, then dashes right as fast as he can, bypassing the bot.
The move buys him a few seconds, as the bot spins in place on its treads, but he ends up in the same situation on the reverse side of the arena. This continues for a few laps, with the human visibly wearing down.
Perhaps realizing his error, he switches tactics, and leads the robot towards a support column, and allows it to get close before ducking around behind it. The bot starts turning in place, but the tread gets hooked on the pillar, and for a moment, it appears to be stuck. You can sense the tingle of hope in the man, as he watches the bot rock to and fro for several seconds.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Dude, let's get out of here," he says, "I don't want you puking on my coat." He turns away, and starts weaving towards the garage door. Dizzy with sickness, you stumble after him, placing a hand on his shoulder for stability.
"No no nononono." He quickly turns and removes your hand. "Here," he hands something to a patron, says something to him, then places your hand on the patron's shoulder instead. The three of you make your way toward the garage door. This exchange just keeps getting more bizarre.
Arriving at the massive doorway, the patron removes your hand, collects his fee, and heads back into the crowd. You stare after him in confusion a moment, the nausea slowly abating, and you pivot back to fur coat guy weakly.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Relax, I don't work here. In fact, I'm gonna try to make sure you don't, either. C'mon." He turns and heads toward the garage door. Since that's away from the arena's human-sized gate, you decide to follow. You get the sense he's a patron, too, or at least not with the management, as neither guard nor patron seems to pay him much attention.
"A little bird told me," he shouts over the crowd and music, "you might know a thing or two about cryogenics." He talks over his shoulder as he walks, as if tossing words your way. "I know a guy who's looking for some heavy-duty cooling units. He maaay be willing to trade for some info on where to score a few."
You arrive at the massive garage door, and the cool air seems tinged with ozone. "His name's The Stoat. C'mon, dude, I'll introduce you."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Sticking around a bit longer, you wait for the pit to be cleared.
The music drops out, and the announcer's hateful voice resounds.
"Can you count, suckas!" The ritual is starting again. "I said, can you count, suckas!" The chorus of madness ensues.
"Raise those numbers!" You raise your fist once more. The music changes, lights switch to UV, numbers appear.
You hear him call another number. A very low number. You feel some anxiety when it occurs to you they may run out of "stock" to call on. If they do, who's next?
Not wanting to find out, you decide this is a good time to make for the door, while everyone else is preoccupied with the fight.
Pressing your way back towards the door, you step into brightly lit trailer, and present your chit to the guard.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Unsure what to do, you wait in the crowd, looking around the room anxiously.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Unsure what to do next, you look around the room anxiously, waiting for something to happen.
"Word is, you've got a good medical plan." The voice startles you, even amidst the shouting crowd, and you turn to find a young man with an old face. He looks to be of Asian descent, with hair like a mop, big aviator glasses, and an improbably white fur coat.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Climbing a barren hill, you notice a trail heading off into a narrow ravine. Moisture-loving slime clings to the walls. Plastic detritus eddies and swirls.
Off to one side, you notice a pile of bones. The large, cracked skull reminds you of a moose- at least that's what you think it is.
Ragged, battered bones. Bleached. A pair of men's trousers snagged on a bush nearby. Died eating tainted meat?
Wouldn't be the first to fight the maggots for a piece of rotting animal flesh, you'd wager.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The ravine walls pinch in like the lips of an angry, disapproving spouse. Ducking under an overhanging rock, you realize how vulnerable you are. Trapped in the narrow gut of the ravine and unable to climb the slippery, slime-covered walls, you are easy prey.
Maybe that's how they got the moose?
Then you notice the sign. Hard not to. Hand-painted letters on weathered board, head height and hammered onto a rustic door:
"Isotope Mine. Beware of the Tiger!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You shout ahead, asking if anyone's home.
You receive no response. There are definite sounds of activity inside, but nobody appears to have noticed that you're there. Gingerly, you push open the door.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You sneak up to the door, and reach forward to push the door open.
This door hasn't seen oil for a long time, as the hinges groan louder than your belly. Hopefully those inside mistook it for the wind. Cursing the ailing hinges, you push the door back closed, and creep forward.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide to not press further, and leave the ravine instead.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Yell out you're armed and dangerous!

You call out that you're armed and mean business.
Nobody replies. No bullets come hammering through the door, either. They're probably all hiding under the table. You yell again, louder this time. Best to make it clear to any scum lurking inside that you aren't in the mood for taking prisoners.
Hefting your weapon, you savagely kick the door in. Wood fractures and splinters. Sure taught that door a lesson.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The lobby is rectangular. Empty. Rough-hewn rock walls ooze discolored water that drips down into stagnant pools on the floor. The lighting is poor, but you can easily make out another door at the far end, as a bright light peeks out from under. There appear to be a lot of dark stains on the ground and decaying organic matter plastered to the walls.
And it smells bad.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Moving across the lobby, you notice a hidden alcove. You freeze upon the realization that a large animal lurks within.
Its eyes look strangely dead, though. The overlong fangs protruding from its mouth remind you of a prehistoric documentary you once saw as a child. Woolly mammoths roamed the planet in all their 3D, holographic glory. Roamed far and wide. Kept roaming until a saber-toothed tiger pack clawed up their backs and brought them crashing to the ground.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Springing forward in a burst of adrenaline, you sprint for the door. Mid-stride, you're forced to swerve as a large animal unexpectedly lunges towards you from a concealed alcove.
Desperately trying to sidestep its slashing fangs, you briefly wonder if you've fallen down the rabbit hole. That's a damn saber-toothed tiger!
Feet skidding on the wet floor, you trip and slam into the angular wall. Momentarily stunned, you fling yourself backwards as the tiger, mouth agape, lashes at your throat.
Regaining your footing, still dazed, you violently half run, half stumble for the door. Behind that door is the light. Safety. Must reach the door!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Carefully, silent footfall by silent footfall, you tiptoe along the shadowy far wall. You strain to sense movement in whatever space lies beyond. Squinting, you try and discern the light that emits from under the bottom of the door, providing the only source of illumination in the forbidding dimness of the mine lobby.
Which is why you fail to spot the lurking predator nearby, in a concealed alcove. As your peripheral vision fills with bulk and fangs, you immediately duck and roll forward.
Spine jarring on a protruding rock, you come up into a crouch as the predator slams into the wall, scurrying its feet in a frenzy of movement, readying itself to leap once more.
Unsure whether it's the roar of the animal or the pounding in your head, you throw yourself forward in a desperate dive for the door.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Assuming a combat crouch, you move forward, eyes peeled. If anything lives down here, it's in for a rude awakening.
You notice the tiger the moment it comes racing out of the concealed alcove. Confidently, weapon raised, you aim for that special spot between the eyes.
Whoof! All the air gets knocked out of you as you are slammed to the floor, the tiger on top of you, slashing at your throat.
Snap rolling sideways, you wonder if you're fighting a beast or a vampire. The size of its fangs! Elbowing it in the side of the head, you gain enough time to jump to your feet, with what feels like a broken limb. Man, that tiger has a tough hide! You decide that it might be best to live to fight another day, and run helter-skelter for the door.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A gentleman never runs. Nor does he sneak through the dark like a common thief. He walks, straight and tall, purposely towards his destination. Sadly, there are few gentlemen left in the wastelands.
Which is why you find yourself running hell for leather towards the far door, as a large animal comes leaping out of a concealed alcove, fangs agape. It's a- no, couldn't be. Head down, eyes bulging, you concentrate on putting in an Olympic performance as a large tiger bounds towards. You notice the fangs. Enormous fangs. Size of steak knives.
The door looms large before you. Noise. Lots of Noise. Right behind you. Stretching forward, you reach for the door knob...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The lobby is rectangular. Empty. Rough hewn rock walls ooze discoloured water that drips down into stagnant pools on the floor. The lighting is poor, but you can easily make out another door at the far end as a bright light peeks out from under. There appear to be a lot of dark stains on the ground and decaying organic matter plastered to the walls.
And it smells bad.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Player Makes It to the Door

Sweaty palms grasp at the door handle and madly yank it open. Falling through, you kick out wildly, and the door slams shut just as the saber-toothed tiger crashes into it.
Panting, gasping, you concentrate on staying still and calming your racing heartbeat.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As your hand reaches for the door handle, you feel sharp fangs rake your backside. Roughly shouldering the door open, you stagger into the next room, slamming the door behind you.
You look down at your wound, and it's pretty bad. Dizzy, you momentarily lose your balance and crash to the floor.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Bodily slammed face-down into the ground, you struggle for breath. The full weight of the tiger bears down on your back.
Panicking, you thrash wildly but can't dislodge it. Worse, your face is forcibly mashed into the ground and you can no longer see.
No need. You feel the fangs penetrate into the back of your neck. Feel them tear your larynx, rip your trachea asunder.
There is no subtlety involved. No finesse. You are being savaged. Powerfully. Viciously. Hot arterial blood spurts onto your chin. You clench your jaw in a futile attempt to fend off the inevitable. With a brutal snap, your spine severs. The lights spark, fizzle. Die.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Looking around, you are surprised to find yourself in a large, clinically white, well-lit room. Dials, shelves, and instrumentation are arrayed in neat rows along the walls. Dishevelled signs of human habitation everywhere else.
Before you is a short, owlish man dressed in a dirty laboratory coat, peering through coke-bottle glasses. Radiation dosimeters cover his chest, all tinted deep red.
Bending, he offers you an oil-stained hand. Struggling to your feet, you gather your thoughts.
"Bob," says the radiated mole, introducing himself. "Damn tiger ain't been working proper fer days. Bad fer business." Bob seems more concerned with the tiger than your well-being.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Ol' Gertrude's mine. Saber-toothed tiger. Made 'er myself." Bob waves his hands, encompassing most of the well-equipped room. "Surprising whatcha can rig with the right kit and plenny of time on yer hands. Saw a fancy version once. In a museum. Made myself a copy. Metal version.
"Trouble is, certain folk jus' don't get it. Get that I provide a desirable service to the locals. Don't like what I do." Bob picks up a modified soup can and tosses it over to you. "See that? RTG power cell. Couple a thermocouples hooked up to a pew two-three-eight isotope. Hot bricks, I call 'em. Enough power there ta keep the lights on 'til winter."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Dubiously, you inspect the can. You can see wires inside. A standard power connection on the base. It feels warm to the touch. Pu 238? As in plutonium?
"That's right. Some customers don't like the side effects. I tell 'em that I live here. Ain't done me no harm. Made me an ani-mah-tronic tiger to deal wit' the angry ones. The Avon Lady don't knock on my door no more! Know what I mean?" Bob bursts into a fit of wheezing, asthmatic laughter.
"So tell me, fella, why are YOU here? Huh? Want wonna my hot bricks?" His voice darkens, "or you out ta take what's mine? Huh?" He rests a hand on a nearby rifle. "Had plenty of those type lately. Looters. Bandits. 'Course, none of 'em made it past Gertrude out there."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Or maybe yer one of those good Samaritan types, then? Can't see no halo, though."
Bob peers at you suspiciously. "Sure ya ain't wonna those guva-munt people?" Bob becomes nervous, eyes bulging. "That thor-e-um reactor downstairs? Never touched it. Never will. All that radiation therapy stuff? Still there." His tone becomes more agitated. "YOU covered this place up and abandoned it! So I might have borrowed some isotopes? What of it?"
Eyes about to pop, Radiation Bob wields the rifle, pointing it menacingly. "Huh, buddy, whatchu gonna do about it? Ain't got no time for no guva-munt!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Hurriedly, you reassure Bob that you aren't a customer, looter, nor government agent. In fact, you inform him, in your most sincere, placating voice, that you're here to help.
"That so?" Like a punctured balloon, Radiation Bob visibly deflates. "You'll have to excuse my country manners then. E'er since I collected up those isotopes from downstairs, haven't been myself." He taps the dosimeters pinned to his chest. "That big ol' reactor's leaking, I reckon. Had to weld the door shut to protect my manhood."
"Say, ya wouldn't happen to know anything about computers, would ya? I think Gertrude's brains are scrambled. Outside a my exper-teese."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Up close, the tiger looks more like a junkyard dog than an infamous predator.
"Power cell in the butt," explains Bob, pointing. "Prox' sensor in the snout. She scans the lobby until the sensors pick up a mobile object, then she hunts them down like the sorry-assed varmints they are."
You put as much distance between you and the power cell as possible, just in case. Looking at the head...the fangs. Can't take your eyes off them. Razor-sharp metal. Covered in dried blood and human viscera.
Tapping the head of the beast, Radiation Bob explains, "All the computerized trickery is in here. Software ain't my thing. You'll see that once you're in there." He hands you a laptop and a set of connections, and leaves you to get on with it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Offer to do what you can.

Radiation Bob introduces you to Gertrude. It looks even scarier up close. All sharp metal angles and crazy welds. Fangs that look like they'd slice through diamond.
Bob squints at you suspiciously. "Sure you know 'bout 'puters? That little tool you got don't look like no terminal to me."
Reassuring Bob that you indeed do know your way around sophisticated high-end technology, you bend to the task, trusty pliers in hand. A skeptical Bob wanders off, asking you to inform him when the job's done.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Bob is unhappy that you can't fix his malfunctioning tiger. When you ask him about the bevy of maxed-out rad meters pinned to his chest, he gives a fatalistic shrug of his shoulders. "What can I do? I live in a room full of plutonium. With a bit of luck I'll become resistant."
Sadly, you tell him, this isn't likely, but you happen to have a top-of-the-line nano medkit with you. Ignoring his protests, his abysmal personal hygiene, and your strong desire not to use a precious nano charge, you treat Bob.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "That's a real shame. Kinda hoping you could help. But you're decent alright, so tell you what I'll do. You hand over that fancy talisman hanging 'round your neck, I'll give you my shooter. Used ta feed myself off local game, but they're all gone, so ya may as well have it. Even let you have my scope."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Time passes. Bob was right: the code has all the structure of a plate of spaghetti. You figure he just kept adding instructions until Gertrude attacked more intruders than walls. At least the software only needs to handle this one room.
Back aching, eyes sore, you secure the cranial cover and go next door to tell Bob that his beast is now fully functional.
"No kiddin'?" He looks genuinely hopeful. "Know all about how ta build it, wire it, and clean the crap off it, but can't find my way around a program if I tried. Thanks, fella, that's a big help."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Bob reaches into a nearby cupboard and pulls out a strange object which he passes to you. "A fella like you might find a use for this one day."
Staring at it, you doubt it. Your days of playing with dolls are long gone. The dolls of your childhood were all action figures, not strange-looking mechanical contraptions like this one.
Still, a gift is a gift. You thank Bob and get on your way, hoping you didn't pick up too many rads from that tiger.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Offer to do what you can cont'd.

Ten minutes later you begin to feel warm. Twenty minutes in and you're so hot that sweat is starting to roll down your cheeks and drip, drip, dripping onto the inner workings of the tiger. Investigating, you determine that the heat is emanating from the rear of the beast. Opening a hatch cover, one of Bob's 'hot bricks' peeks cheekily out at you.
With a start, you remember. A jury-rigged soup can, power cell full of plutonium isotopes. Bad. Disastrously bad.
Disgusted, you give the beast a hefty kick and leave, searching for Bob to tell him that he'll have to fix it himself. Still angry, you wonder if you have Bob to thank for cancer now.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Can't say I feel any different. Can't feel my hair growing back. Sure that gizmo is working?"
You assure Bob that he is now a healthier man and will live to see next Christmas.
"No kidding? Gizmo is that good, huh? Well that's mighty fine of you to help. Tell you what, here's a little something in return." Bob hands across an average-sized doll. A mechanical, not particularly attractive, doll. "Don't be put off by its ugly mug; could come in handy one day."
Underwhelmed by Bob's generosity, you get the distinct feeling that you've been had. Of course, so might he.
"Come again," gushes an effusive Bob, shaking your hands. "Always welcome. Who knows, I might need another shot from the gizmo one day. Let me walk you out. Don't want ol' Gertie thinking you're a damn guva-munt agent, do we?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask Bob why he wants your talisman.

"Saw a buncha these up where I got the idear fer Gertrude. Old jewelry and such on display. Folk artifacts, I 'spect. Some good metal in these bits. Use 'em in my hot bricks."
Bob points at your talisman. "Prolly copper in that symbol. You'd get a decent price for it, sure, but nobody'd give ya a rifle for it. 'cept me," he grins.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Exchange the talisman for the rifle.

"Hey, that's real generous of you. Here, may as well take this extra box of ammo too. Could be helpful out there. Promise you'll save a bullet for any guva-munt agents you cross. Aim for their peckers!" Bob doubles up in another spasm of asthmatic laughter. Recovering, he turns suddenly serious.
"You need ta head ta the DMC, fella. Safer. Go straight there. The black marsh to the south'll kill ya dead, and the north ain't much better. Head straight for the gates. I've heard bad things happen to those that take the scenic route."
Bob shakes your hand and wishes you well. "I'll deactivate Gertrude so you can leave. Be seein' you."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Boy, try ta be nice to a fella, and whaddya get? Kicked in the goolies, is what! Best you left now before I lose my sense of humor. Don't bother coming back, either. You ain't welcome."
Bob hefts the rifle and makes it clear that he is willing to use it.
Reluctantly taking your leave, you gingerly open the door to the mine lobby. It appears to be empty. No sign of Gertrude.
"Don't worry," says Bob, behind you, "I've deactivated 'er."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Soooo, treasure seeker, eh?" His eyes narrow a bit. "Cuts into my trade, it does. Not sure I wanna do that."
"Course," he muses, "a bird in hand, as they say. Saves me a trip, too." He straightens his posture again. "Tell ya what. The talisman fer the rifle, or fer the location. Won't do both, though."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Exchange the talisman for the location.

"Alright. Deal's a deal. Yer lookin' fer the Allegan Fairgrounds. A bit northwest of here. Can't miss it. Acres and acres. Even got a ferris wheel." Then he mocks a frightened look, "Just watch fer clowns!" Bob doubles up in another spasm of asthmatic laughter. Recovering, he turns suddenly serious.
"Serious now, don't dally there for long. Get watcha need and get out. Best bet is ta head ta the DMC, fella. Safer. And when ya do, go straight there. The black marsh to the south'll kill ya dead, and the north ain't much better. Head straight for the gates. I've heard bad things happen to those that take the scenic route."
Bob shakes your hand and wishes you well. "I'll deactivate Gertrude so you can leave. Be seein' you."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Half walking, half running, you head for the exit. Suddenly, Bob slams the door shut. A muffled voice shouts, "Feedin' time!"
Terrified, you glance at the alcove, expecting the tiger to leap out at you at any moment. Time to run. Fast. Very fast.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
But no tiger appears.
You make it to the door, shoulder it open without breaking stride, and keep running along the ravine trail until you've lost sight of the Isotope Mine.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
But not fast enough.
With a wobbly, mechanical pounce, the saber-toothed terror is upon you. Knocked sideways, you feel sharp metal fangs rake across your back, but you retain your feet and manage to stagger out the entrance door. You can hear the tiger ricocheting off the walls back in the mine lobby.
Despite the pain, you run the length of the ravine, putting the Isotope Mine out of sight and out of mind. You finally come to a halt at the head of the trail and attempt to do something about the gaping wounds in your back. It's not the loss of blood or the flapping flesh that worries you; it's infection.
Those fangs looked about as sterile as a bucket full of flyblown moose gizzards.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Volte a entrar na camara Cryo.

De volta a camara cryo, voce ainda sente um eco do panico que o agarrou quando acordou aqui. Isso deixa voce se sentir desconectado.
No entanto, esse tempo passou. Talvez seja hora de olhar novamente?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Do lado de fora da camara de Cryo, ha um corredor cheio de detritos que parece estar um pouco destruido. Voce subiu sobre pilhas de lixo e escombros e encontra uma porta que esta bloqueada. Uma placa na parede esta escrito:
"Exame Rm 17"
Forcando a barricada de lado, voce olha para o que parece uma sala de exames clinicos.
Embora pareca haver pouco valor de saque, esta sala parece ser um otimo acampamento.
Sala de Exame 17 foi adicionada aos acampamentos deste hex

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You recall that standard practice is to have a crash kit nearby in facilities like this, and check for emergency cabinets around the room.
Sure enough, there's one just by the door, and it still has a medical kit in it!

table.name: encounters
table.column: Voce vai para fora de Cryo-Facility.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The dust on the ground makes it easy for your trained eye to pick out one set of tracks in particular.
They seem to belong to a humanoid dragging something, probably a mantle or cloak. It was here fairly recently, probably in the past 24 hours. It entered through the doorway, walked to your stasis tank, went to the control console, and then left.
You'd bet good money that it wasn't the dogman you just faced.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Something catches your eye as you scan the room. Obscured in the shadows behind tank #2 is something small and metallic lying on the floor.
Upon closer inspection, it appears to be a multitool pocket knife. Probably left behind by maintenance personnel ages ago, and nobody saw it since.
Whoever left it here, you're pretty sure they don't need it as much as you, so you decide to take it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Procurou no console para obter registros.

Voce verifica o console, em busca das informacoes dos pacientes, e encontra tres registros:
Tank #1: Anton Blubber Committed 2012-11-11 Emergency contact: Angela Blubber, 45 Campbell St., Detroit, MI, 48210 Billing info: Angela Blubber, 45 Campbell St., Detroit, MI, 48210
Tank #5: Philip Kindred **NO DATA** **NO DATA** Billing info: Account #20141117 Detroit Savings Bank
Tank #6: Lloyd Blankcheck Committed 2008-10-18 Emergency contact: Meyer & Meyer LLP, 304 South Broadway, Detroit, MI, 48226 Billing info: Meyer & Meyer LLP, 304 South Broadway, Detroit, MI, 48226

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A sala de exames nao e muito para se olhar. Mas e seguro e protegido dos elementos.
Parece que as luzes podem funcionar, se voce puder descobrir o curto na fiacao.
Alem disso, o HVAC parece estar bombeando ar. Provavelmente ainda e alimentado por tudo o que corre nos tubos na outra sala. Alguem util com maquinas pode arrumar para aquecer um pouco o ar que esta entrando.
Com um pouco de trabalho, este quarto seria um lugar decente para dormir.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Sim. E para a Ventilacao.
Claro, seria bom se uma dessas pessoas de mecanica e manutencao estivesse por perto.

table.name: encounters
table.column: O circuito esta bastante queimado. Isso levaria alguem com algumas habilidade em ser eletricista para ate imaginar se poderia ser reparado.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Hm, this thing's still operational.
The air's cool now, but it looks like you could reroute some of the airflow across some power conduits to warm it up a bit.
You'd need something to divert the air, like a tarp. Plus some small parts to fasten it, and something to crimp the fasteners.
Yep, this looks doable.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Parece que a iluminacao ainda esta em boa forma, mas a fiacao esta explodida.
Se voce pudesse tocar o canal de alimentacao adjacente, isso pode faze-los funcionar novamente.
No entanto, voce precisaria de alguns pedacos de fiacao, pequenas pecas e uma ferramenta para faze-lo funcionar.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Approaching Gyges Cryo Facility strikes you with a pang of anxiety.
The creature you encountered there, will there be others? The dark windows offer no answers.
You gather your courage, and climb back through the window.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Walking down a ruptured pavement, treading carefully over jagged piles of rubble, you hear a woman screaming. Investigating, you happen upon a plaza, a conga line of rusted cars that appear to have concertinaed into one another at high speed.
Heavily armed slavers have herded a group of downcast people into a corner. Negotiations are underway with potential buyers. A terrified young woman, still screaming, is directly in front of you. There are enough rusty vehicle carcasses that you might, just might, be able to reach her unseen.

table.name: encounters
table.column: No one should be abandoned to such a fate. Damn the risk, help her!

What with all the noise, and the cover of the cars, reaching her is a breeze. The moment you put your hand on her shoulder, though, it all goes pear-shaped.
Tearing herself away from your touch, she trips over her shackles, and falls face first into the rubbish. Writhing and jerking before you on the ground, you barely manage to leave before being discovered.
Pretty sure you dropped something on the way out, but there's no way you can go back now.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Her life is over. From here on in, it's all downhill. Sneak closer, and attempt to pass her some food. It's the least you can do.

Crouched low, you move forward, and throw a rock her way to get her attention. Bouncing noisily through the mess of canned rubbish, it hits her firmly on the ankle. She glances behind her, and catches your eye.
Her actions are immediately noticed by one of the slavers, who beats her viciously with his stick. Disheartened, you stay long enough to watch the woman double up in pain before leaving. Haunted by the image of those blue eyes.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It's bad, but what can you do? Walk away, and do your best to forget about the girl.

Just as you're considering the best option for exit, you're spotted!
Shots are fired. Without a backward glance, you run helter-skelter away from the plaza. Hard to tell if you've been hit or not.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It's bad, but what can you do? Walk away, and do your best to forget about the girl.

Just as you're considering the best option for exit, you're spotted!
Shots are fired. Without a backward glance, you run helter-skelter away from the plaza. Hard to tell if you've been hit or not.

table.name: encounters
table.column: If she weren't such a screamer, you'd be willing to help. Sure you would. But you can't help a screamer. Keep moving.
You can still hear her shrill voice yelling as you turn the corner. Man alive, some people are like that. Painful, that's what it is, painful. You've accepted your life as it is, why can't she?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Slavers. Herding a mixed group of enclavers down the middle of a wide boulevard. All of the meat is roped together, with slavers beating those who are dragging their feet.
Suddenly, the frayed rope snaps. A crooked-nosed woman at the end sprints for safety in the nearby ruins. Slavers start hollering, bullets whacking the pavement around the woman.
She makes it to the nearest building. The one you're hiding in.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Break cover. Yell out to her to head your way.

She sees you, changes course, and heads directly towards you. Her arms and legs pumping. But she goes down face first right in front of you, slapped down hard by a bullet in her back.
Choking blood up from her mouth and nostrils, her eyes glazed. You rush over and grab her, but she's dead weight. The body shudders as another bullet rips through her torso.
Dropping her, you sprint back to cover and escape. There's blood all over your chest. Is that yours or hers?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Break cover. Yell out to her to head your way.

She sees you, changes course, and heads directly towards you. Her arms and legs pumping. But she goes down face first right in front of you, slapped down hard by a bullet in her back.
Choking blood up from her mouth and nostrils, her eyes glazed. You rush over and grab her, but she's dead weight. The body shudders as another bullet rips through her torso.
Dropping her, you sprint back to cover and escape. There's blood all over your chest. Is that yours or hers?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wave from cover. Hope that she sees you as she runs past.

It is, admittedly, a fairly subdued wave. The kind royalty might give to the masses as they pass by in their queenly carriage.
The woman, unsurprisingly, misses it. Runs helter-skelter into a nearby doorway, pursued by a handful of fast-gaining slavers.
You've done your best. Time to go.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Sit tight and keep quiet. Don't want to attract any attention.

You'd like to help her. She's in a lot of trouble, and on any other day, you'd do whatever you could to help someone in distress. But you're tired and hungry. Didn't sleep well last night. Not at your best. She'll be okay.
Boy, can she run! If they ever have a Wastelands Olympics, your money is on her!

table.name: encounters
table.column: Roll a rock in front of her. She might trip and provide enough distraction for you to get out of there.

Nobody notices the rock. Not the slavers, not the woman. She trips and sprawls headlong into the dirt.
It's a bad tumble. Bad enough for the slavers to reach her before she can regain her feet. They proceed to knock her senseless. A lesson to their other captives.
By the time they stop pummelling the crooked-nosed woman, you've left the area. You didn't know her. Not your business.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There are three of them. Viciously beating a man and woman with sticks. Cowering their captives into a state of mute submission. Slavers don't mind messing up the goods if it means they do as they're told.
Job done, the captives are roped and readied for the long trek. Two of the slavers duck out of sight, claiming they need a nature stop. You peer down at the remaining slaver from a hole in a wall, two stories above.
It would be no trouble at all to drop that lump of concrete onto his head. Might give the man and woman a chance to escape.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Heave ho! Squash him like a bug.

Oomph! Took some doing, that. Was heavier than it looks.
Right on target, though. Slaver took it square on the top of his skull. Crumpled quietly to the ground with a whoosh of expelled air.
The man and woman don't waste time, either. Off and running before you can call to them. Oh well, you've done your good deed for the day. Standing, you wince in pain. Hope it's only temporary.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Heave ho! Squash him like a bug.

Oomph! Took some doing, that. Was heavier than it looks.
Right on target, though. Slaver took it square on the top of his skull. Crumpled quietly to the ground with a whoosh of expelled air.
The man and woman don't waste time, either. Off and running before you can call to them. Oh well, you've done your good deed for the day. Standing, you wince in pain. Hope it's only temporary.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Give it a push, but don't overdo it. Don't want to overexert yourself.

Hey, you tried. That big ol' piece of concrete was just too heavy.
The two missing slavers return, and your window of opportunity closes. Shame that you're such a wimp.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Man, that concrete looks heavy. Pushing that might give you a hernia. Just sit tight.

You worry the strain might hurt you. And so you should be. Have you seen the size of that lump of concrete? Probably weighs more than your own body weight. People should realize that you're not Superman.
You sit still, and wait for the slavers to return. Once they've rounded up and left, you make your way out of the building.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Don't want to attract unnecessary attention. Best let it be.
How many times do you have to repeat to yourself that all being a hero does is get you a front row seat at the next funeral? Yours. So there is some bad stuff happening? Suck it up and keep moving.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The sound of moaning comes from an open doorway. Cautiously, you peer inside. The multi-story building is visibly crumbling. A dirty, long-haired man is lying in a corner, his leg trapped under a metal beam. His companion, clad in torn leathers, straining at the beam, looks up as you enter.
"Help out us here, buddy. It's too heavy to lift on my own." It's not hard to see that moving the beam would risk a further collapse.

table.name: encounters
table.column: If you grab hold of the end, there's a chance that the wall won't fall on you. Help them out.

With an eye on the crumbling wall, you bend to the task of lifting the beam. Slowly, with brick dust cascading down upon you, the beam shifts. Damn, it's heavy! Grunting, you put your all into the effort.
The trapped man pulls free, and crawls clear. The second man suddenly lets go of the beam to assist, leaving you supporting its entire weight alone. Spasms running up and down your back, you drop it with a resounding crash. Miraculously, the wall stays upright. You turn to check the men, but they have already left.
Your conscience is pleased, but that barely makes up for the energy you've expended on those ingrates.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Give the trapped man a drink. He looks thirsty. Beyond that? No thanks.

Picking your way carefully through the rubble, you hand over a recently scavenged drink bottle. The trapped man gulps it down. His companion mutters a few words of thanks before pulling out a pistol, and shooting him between the eyes.
Stunned, you stand back, mouth agape.
"Wasn't going to be any good to us back at the enclave with that busted leg. Lazy and stupid even before this happened." He stands upright. "Could have given me the drink, you know?"
He holsters the weapon, and brushes past you, disappearing out the exit.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Not worth the risk. Walk away.
It's a tough call, but out here you do what you have to in order to stay alive. Stupid idiots shouldn't have been scavenging in a building like that. Blind fool could see that it's on its last legs.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Here's an opportunity. Offer to help, then whack the man over the head while he is bending over the beam. Loot both men, then leave.

The first man goes down hard, his skull making an audible crunching sound as it ricochets off the cold, hard beam. You dodge a rock that the trapped man throws at you.
Next thing you know, he's yelling and hollering abuse. Loudly. Tell-everybody-in-the-neighborhood loud. Which makes it time to go. Fast. You can already hear the distant sound of running feet.
Sliding into the nearby shadows, you concentrate on leaving the area, which helps takes your mind off your frustration. Almost.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Crumbling, collapsing buildings. Dangerous places. Don't people ever learn? You recall the long-haired man trapped under the beam. The one who wanted help.
Like this one. On his own, pinned from the waist down by a pile of rubble. Doesn't look like he's going to make it. Moaning. Pleading for help. Nothing but a slow, painful death before him.
The trouble is that there is enough of the shaky, trembling wall remaining that you risk ending up the same way if you try and assist. Still, what if it was you clawing at the immovable weight grinding your groin into the ground?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Give the man some comfort. Carefully. S-l-i-d-e over there. No sudden movements.

The least you can do is sit down and talk to the man. Maybe he would like the last rites? Perhaps a friendly voice would be enough?
All of which are now academic, because the damn wall just caved. Can't even see him through the rubble and dust. Buried alive. You think you might have taken a hit, too. That brick hit you pretty hard. Hope it's okay.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Give the man some comfort. Carefully. S-l-i-d-e over there. No sudden movements.

The least you can do is sit down and talk to the man. Maybe he would like the last rites? Perhaps a friendly voice would be enough?
All of which are now academic, because the damn wall just caved. Can't even see him through the rubble and dust. Buried alive. You think you might have taken a hit, too. That brick hit you pretty hard. Hope it's okay.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go over to him and investigate. Do what has to be done.

It's as bad as you thought it would be. The man's asking for your help, but there is nothing you can do.
Quietly, you bend over and cradle his neck. Say a few words of comfort before you suddenly snap his vertebrae in two. It's for the best.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Too dangerous. "Tough luck, buddy, I can't help you."

The golden rule of survival is that you look after yourself before all else. Dead heroes aren't any use to man or dog.
Without a backward glance, you leave the scene. Give it a day or so, and the rats will have sorted it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: He's a goner. Stand back and throw rocks at his head until he croaks. You're doing him a favor.

He's going to die. Let's make it quick. It takes a while for you to get your eye in, though. The man's squawking up a storm, asking what the hell you think you're doing.
Eventually, you find your line and length, and he stops making any noise. Still breathing, though. More of a gurgling sound. You wince as one of your rocks shatters his teeth. No more gurgling. Hard to tell if he's still alive.
Just to make sure, you hurl rocks at the dodgy wall until it collapses on top of him. Stray shards of brick pelt you. Boy, that hurt!

table.name: encounters
table.column: He's a goner. Stand back and throw rocks at his head until he croaks. You're doing him a favor.

He's going to die. Let's make it quick. It takes a while for you to get your eye in, though. The man's squawking up a storm, asking what the hell you think you're doing.
Eventually, you find your line and length, and he stops making any noise. Still breathing, though. More of a gurgling sound. You wince as one of your rocks shatters his teeth. No more gurgling. Hard to tell if he's still alive.
Just to make sure, you hurl rocks at the dodgy wall until it collapses on top of him. Stray shards of brick pelt you. Boy, that hurt!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Ruined buildings are unpredictable. A minor tremor, a brief, violent gust of wind, or random vibrations, and before you know it, you're pinned and skewered worse than an insect in a museum display case.
You've already crept past the teetering overhead slab. The three scavengers, moving in behind you unawares, are underneath. Their rapid digging into the rubbish and rubble is bound to tip the slab off balance.
You could warn them. But squinting through the gap makes it hard to tell if they are friendly.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Yell out a warning. Doesn't matter who they are, you're obligated to help them.

Heads instantly swivel in your direction. Rubble scum! Time to go. Quickly.
As you run off, you have the consolation of having saved three humans from a nasty death. The fact that they'd happily kill you if they caught you doesn't detract from your achievement. I bet the good Samaritan didn't have to deal with this kind of shit.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw a rock in their direction. Get their attention. Hopefully they'll move out of the way.

The rock did the trick. They stop scavenging and look around. But as they stand there, puzzled, the slab finally achieves negative equilibrium. CRASH!
Sometimes, trying to help people only makes it worse. A terminal outcome for them, and a doubtful one for you. Hard to tell, but that stray piece of concrete shrapnel might have done some damage.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw a rock in their direction. Get their attention. Hopefully they'll move out of the way.

The rock did the trick. They stop scavenging and look around. But as they stand there, puzzled, the slab finally achieves negative equilibrium. CRASH!
Sometimes, trying to help people only makes it worse. A terminal outcome for them, and a doubtful one for you. Hard to tell, but that stray piece of concrete shrapnel might have done some damage.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hunker down and watch the hamburger show roll on.

If in doubt, sit tight. Don't give your position away. Especially when there is an interesting outcome in the offing.
Which, unfortunately, doesn't transpire. Reluctantly, you give up on the hope of cheap entertainment, pick up your gear, and depart the area. You wonder if you would have actually heard them get squished.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw as many rocks as you can onto the slab. Scavengers are bound to be bad. Squash 'em all.

It took a good half dozen tries. The damn slab didn't want to go. The last rock did it, though, and down it came. Bang!
Only got two of them, however. The third had time to get out of the way. Charging straight for you, eyes demented, meat cleaver raised high. You manage to get out of there in time, but bang into a door sill as you leave. Youch!

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw as many rocks as you can onto the slab. Scavengers are bound to be bad. Squash 'em all.

It took a good half dozen tries. The damn slab didn't want to go. The last rock did it, though, and down it came. Bang!
Only got two of them, however. The third had time to get out of the way. Charging straight for you, eyes demented, meat cleaver raised high. You manage to get out of there in time, but bang into a door sill as you leave. Youch!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Stumbling out of a nearby alley, a middle-aged woman, coughing spit and sputum in all directions, weaves towards you.
She's wearing a blue sash. Church of the Blue Frog. You've been seeing Church graffiti all around here. Their enclave must be nearby. Help the woman, and they might help you. But jeez, she doesn't look good. Might be contagious.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Any friend of the Frog is a friend of yours. Do whatever you can.

Quickly covering your mouth and nose, you calm the woman and assess her situation. Hard to tell, but it looks like she has pneumonia.
Rummaging around in your gear, you search for some antibiotics. You ask where the Church's enclave is so you can get her safely home. Unfortunately, in her fevered condition, she isn't making any sense.
With a tremendous sneeze all over you, she stumbles off before you can render any more assistance. Hope you didn't catch anything.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Any friend of the Frog is a friend of yours. Do whatever you can.

Quickly covering your mouth and nose, you calm the woman and assess her situation. Hard to tell, but it looks like she has pneumonia.
Rummaging around in your gear, you search for some antibiotics. You ask where the Church's enclave is so you can get her safely home. Unfortunately, in her fevered condition, she isn't making any sense.
With a tremendous sneeze all over you, she stumbles off before you can render any more assistance. Hope you didn't catch anything.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Better keep your distance, just in case. You place something helpful on the ground and back off.

Carefully putting some recently scavenged food down in her path, you stand back. The woman stumbles erratically towards it. Treading on it, she keeps heading in your direction, coughing and sneezing. Probably delirious.
Exercising discretion, you leave.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Better keep your distance, just in case. You place something helpful on the ground and back off.

Carefully putting some recently scavenged food down in her path, you stand back. The woman stumbles erratically towards it. Treading on it, she keeps heading in your direction, coughing and sneezing. Probably delirious.
Exercising discretion, you leave.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Typhoid Mary is nothing but a germ factory. Turn and run.
Getting sick out here in the wastelands can be a death sentence. Germs can't run as fast you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: She's a biohazard. Do the right thing and put her out of her misery with the big rock over there.

People coughing up all kinds of crap like that shouldn't be left to spread disease around. The woman is oblivious to you coming up behind her. You don't even stop to loot the corpse. Who knows what you might catch?

table.name: encounters
table.column: She's a biohazard. Do the right thing and put her out of her misery with the big rock over there.

People coughing up all kinds of crap like that shouldn't be left to spread disease around. The woman is oblivious to you coming up behind her. You don't even stop to loot the corpse. Who knows what you might catch?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Two of the Blue Frog's disciples are curled up in a flower bed. Bright blue sashes stained with vomit. You recall the sick woman from before. She was a Frogger, too. Must be something contagious swirling through the congregation.
Not surprising. Wherever large groups of people gather, the third horseman isn't far behind.
You intended on leaving the two sick Froggers behind, but one of them has grabbed you by the ankle, pleading for help.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tend to the disciples. Do what you can to help.

Bending down, you check their vital signs.
Both of them appear to be with fever, and possessed of pulse rates that are so fast that they could set lap records. About all you can figure is that they are both highly contagious, and that their needs are beyond your available resources.
Stepping away from them, you regret having got so close. Whatever disease they have, you really don't want to catch it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tend to the disciples. Do what you can to help.

Bending down, you check their vital signs.
Both of them appear to be with fever, and possessed of pulse rates that are so fast that they could set lap records. About all you can figure is that they are both highly contagious, and that their needs are beyond your available resources.
Stepping away from them, you regret having got so close. Whatever disease they have, you really don't want to catch it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Promise you'll pass their plight onto the next Church members you see.

You state your intention to help them, but they don't give any sign of hearing it.
Reluctantly, you explain further, enunciating loudly and slowly, that you'll organize friends to come and get them. You would have, too, if they didn't just vomit all over you. Jeez!
Wiping the gunk off yourself, you get the heck away from them. What if you catch whatever disease it is that they have?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Promise you'll pass their plight onto the next Church members you see.

You state your intention to help them, but they don't give any sign of hearing it.
Reluctantly, you explain further, enunciating loudly and slowly, that you'll organize friends to come and get them. You would have, too, if they didn't just vomit all over you. Jeez!
Wiping the gunk off yourself, you get the heck away from them. What if you catch whatever disease it is that they have?

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Damn Sickos!" Step back, fast. Shake the germs off your legs. Keep moving.

Shouldn't have gone near them in the first place. Nobody has a health plan these days. Get sick with the kind of disease this pair has, and your days are numbered.
You'll have to wash your feet in the next dirty pool of water you find. Better to have wet toes than a tribe of lethal germs crawling up your leg.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Man, who left them here?" Froggers. Kick them to death.

You don't like Froggers. And sick Froggers are nothing but a blight on the landscape. An aberration.
Being careful to avoid the blood spatter, you systematically kick them both in the head until you hear an audible snapping sound.
One of them coughs up a lungful of blood and mucus before they expire. Hope it wasn't contagious.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Man, who left them here?" Froggers. Kick them to death.

You don't like Froggers. And sick Froggers are nothing but a blight on the landscape. An aberration.
Being careful to avoid the blood spatter, you systematically kick them both in the head until you hear an audible snapping sound.
One of them coughs up a lungful of blood and mucus before they expire. Hope it wasn't contagious.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The trouble with the Froggers is that they don't take kindly to non-believers.
Even the crazed, fevered man before you, holding onto the door in order to remain upright, insists that if you don't purify yourself for the Great Blue Frog, you'll be skinned alive. Which is a heck of a thing considering he's burning up with whatever ails all the Froggers you've been meeting of late.
Trouble is, you need to get through that door.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Humor him. Bow down and worship the Great Blue Frog.

Trying to maintain a straight face, you kneel down and go through the motions of appeasing the Great Blue Frog. Make a bit of a show about it. Hopefully your efforts at worshipping the big, warty pond dweller will get the man to step aside and let you through.
Sadly, no. Yelling "Blasphemy!" the man grabs you by the hair and starts slapping you around. Knocking him aside with ease, you regain your feet and duck through the door, leaving him thrashing around behind you.
The Great Blue Frog, you decide, needs to chill his congregation out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Humor him. Bow down and worship the Great Blue Frog.

Trying to maintain a straight face, you kneel down and go through the motions of appeasing the Great Blue Frog. Make a bit of a show about it. Hopefully your efforts at worshipping the big, warty pond dweller will get the man to step aside and let you through.
Sadly, no. Yelling "Blasphemy!" the man grabs you by the hair and starts slapping you around. Knocking him aside with ease, you regain your feet and duck through the door, leaving him thrashing around behind you.
The Great Blue Frog, you decide, needs to chill his congregation out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask him politely if he'd be kind enough to step aside.

Well, you tried. First-class manners have no impact on him at all. Uncouth bastard.
Grabbing him by his dirty T-shirt, wet with drool, you hoist him out of the way before passing through the door. Hopefully he's kept his germs to himself.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask him politely if he'd be kind enough to step aside.

Well, you tried. First-class manners have no impact on him at all. Uncouth bastard.
Grabbing him by his dirty T-shirt, wet with drool, you hoist him out of the way before passing through the door. Hopefully he's kept his germs to himself.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Kick the door out of the way and stand back as he collapses to the floor.

Down he goes. Thunk! Doesn't look like he'll be getting up in a hurry, if at all.
Stepping over his oddly contorted body, you leave him in your dust. How the heck was this weakling ever going to skin you alive? Maybe he had a food processor in his pocket.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Damn Froggers! Spreading disease all over creation." He's weak. Kill him.

Indiscriminate killing isn't good for the soul. But this is a Frogger. And a sick one, at that. Also, he's in your way. Wasn't that a threat that he made, skin you alive? There is a clear and present danger. Your conscience is clear.
Doesn't take long. Must've been on his last legs. Shame about all the blood on your hands. Going to take a while to clean off.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Damn Froggers! Spreading disease all over creation." He's weak. Kill him.

Indiscriminate killing isn't good for the soul. But this is a Frogger. And a sick one, at that. Also, he's in your way. Wasn't that a threat that he made, skin you alive? There is a clear and present danger. Your conscience is clear.
Doesn't take long. Must've been on his last legs. Shame about all the blood on your hands. Going to take a while to clean off.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Kids.
You're glad you don't have any. They'd have only ended up like the malnourished urchin before you.
"Please, mister, can I have some food?" Must've seen you pulling Blinkies from the ruined truck.
The poorer enclaves use their kids as beggars. It's risky, 'cause lots of times, they don't make it home. Folks probably figure that they can't feed them anyway, so may as well send them out scavenging. Weed out the weak.
But what about this particular kid? Bound to be a group of them watching from nearby. Feed her, and you'll have to feed the rest.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Do what you can. Feed the lot. Use all the food you've just found. If there's going to be a future, we'll need the kids.

Six of them! All weedy, dirty, and half-starving. They hungrily devour the cache you found only minutes before. Must be a badly managed enclave to have this many surplus kids. Got to match births with deaths; otherwise you end up with kids you can't feed.
A real shame. Probably good kids. They'll want to watch which strangers they talk to, though. Some eat kids for breakfast. Literally.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Give this kid something and bring your weapon to the ready. You aren't feeding the others.

There's a limit to your generosity. Only so much one man can do in the face of devastation.
The girl chomps down the food, while the rest of them watch. To make your point, you strike the least friendly pose possible.
None of them take the hint, though. In the end, you've got to throw rocks to get rid of them.
Did you do good? Who knows? At least you get to keep most of the food cache you've just found.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Pack of urban rats. They aren't sponging any food off you.

Pushing the girl away, you snarl at the rest of them, as they crest the nearby fence. Food's precious. If their own enclave can't feed them, then it's not your responsibility. Besides, you want to hang on to all that food you just found.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Grab the kid. Threaten her with violence, unless she tells you where their enclave is.

An enclave with kids like this is bound to be weak and poorly protected. Ripe for the plucking.
You grab the girl. Unwashed and stinking, she slips from your hands. Like trying to grab hold of a grease ball. She runs off as the rest of the urchins hurl rocks at you to discourage pursuit.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Grab the kid. Threaten her with violence, unless she tells you where their enclave is.

An enclave with kids like this is bound to be weak and poorly protected. Ripe for the plucking.
You grab the girl. Unwashed and stinking, she slips from your hands. Like trying to grab hold of a grease ball. She runs off as the rest of the urchins hurl rocks at you to discourage pursuit.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A minute is all it took.
You'd stopped in the shelter of an old cinema foyer. Enough structure remaining for you to get out of the wind. Old posters fraying at the edges of movies long forgotten. While inspecting one, it frustrated you that you couldn't recall the faces. They seemed famous even before your big sleep.
Just then, you turned around to see a feral kid trying to steal your food. Man trap got him. A blur of arms, legs, and rope, and there he is, dangling from the ceiling, upside down.
Pure luck you hadn't tripped it yourself. Slavers won't be far away. What to do with the kid?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Cut him down, and let him keep the food. We need to take care of the kids.

He's done you a favor; could've been you in that trap. So what if he stole from you? All he's doing is trying to survive.
You cut the little fellow down and watch as he bends down, scoops up your humble offerings and sprints out the nearest exit.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Cut him down, but give him a belting. Teach him that stealing is wrong.

What kind of world is it where kids think they can steal willy nilly from anyone? You're one of the good guys. Kid needs to learn right from wrong.
Of course you went easy on him. Knocked him around just enough to get the message across. Asked him if he was okay before he took off.
Man, lucky break that he tripped the man trap, and not you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Leave him. Gather up your gear and get out of there before the slavers arrive.
Hey, live by the sword, die by the sword. That's how the world works now, kid. You've struck out. Not my problem. Have fun in hell.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Leave him. Give him a proper thrashing before you leave. Kid should have known not to mess with you.

Every man and his dog is picking on you. Now it's a runty kid. Time to take a stand.
You punch the kid hard in the gut as he hangs upside down, leaving him gasping for air and swinging violently from side to side. Restraining yourself from doing more, you get your gear, and leave him. Little demon managed to reach over and bite you before you left. Had to punch him again.
Didn't the kid get the message first time around?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Department store. One of the long-forgotten big chain stores. Been worked over many times, but you manage to find a stash of unopened soup cans hidden under a collapsed counter.
Three kids were already there before you, trying to shift the counter on their own. Too weak, though. That's what brought you over: the commotion.
The kids are nothing but skin and bones. Looking up at you now with anguished eyes. Worried that you'll take it all for yourself. It was their find.
Fact is, only three cans to be had from the lot. Flipping them over, you notice that two are damaged, their contents likely contaminated.
Bet the kids don't know that, though.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hand over all three cans. Warn them about the contaminants.

You point out the contaminated cans to the disappointed kids. Tell them to be careful not to eat soup from those cans. Explain to them that they'll have to share the remaining can among themselves. They scuttle off, grateful for your generosity.
You carefully search the area for any more food, but fail to find any. Is that the sound of your stomach rumbling?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Two for you, one for me. Keep the good can, give them the others. Maybe they can empty the cans and find a use for them?

Hope they have enough sense not to eat from those cans. Probably die from food poisoning. With a bit of luck there'll be a responsible adult nearby when they open the cans.
Sure there will.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Keep the lot. You'll need the two dodgy cans for noise traps. The kids can whistle dixie.

You're not a mobile one-man soup kitchen. These cans belong to you.
These kids, on the other hand, don't. They could be from anywhere. Even rubble scum offspring. Bug off.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You spot a small group huddled in a dark corner. Smart folk have found protection in numbers, behind walls. This family looks to be outcast, their enclave likely overflowing. Made all the families draw straws.
Or maybe the father crossed the wrong person? The man's got that hangdog look about him, knows he's in trouble.
At any rate, a family on their own in the wastelands doesn't last long. He's pleading for a weapon. Anything. Wants a chance.
You found a meat cleaver not long ago. Maybe that would help?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Yeah, why not? Give him the meat cleaver. That's your good deed for the year.

You hand over a weapon. It's the least you can do. You show them how to use it as they aren't oozing confidence. Tell 'em the way you came in, as it's going to be the safest way out.
Good luck, guys.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Trade them the cleaver for some food.

It's taking food from their mouths, but it's the best you can manage. If they can't defend themselves, they won't live long enough to starve.
You try and avoid taking in the pitiful state of the family. After all, you've done something. That's gotta count.

table.name: encounters
table.column: They aren't going to make it whichever way fate casts the dice. Leave them to it.

One person leaves the safety of the enclave, and it's not going to end well. Bring a whole family, and we're talking first class seats on the fast train to hell.
Best thing you can do with a mess like this is to not get involved. Walk away.

table.name: encounters
table.column: They're goners. Bet they've got some food, though. Threaten the man. Hand over your food!

Yeah, you weren't expecting that, were you buddy? The sooner you learn about the law of the jungle, the quicker you're going to wise up.
You tell the family to pipe down. Too much noise attracts attention here. And hurry up with that food!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The house looked inviting. Intact, paint just starting to peel. Sure, there were burn marks here and there, but no more than expected. There was even a crowbar hidden behind the front door.
Should've known someone else would have the same idea. In the bedroom, you find another family of exiles. Politics this time. Competing factions. They had no other option but to leave the safety of their enclave and find a new home.
Which is here, by the looks of it. All their food and gear is stockpiled in the corner. A man's lying on the mattress, badly wounded. A woman and some kids are gathered anxiously around him.
Good on 'em for surviving whatever caused his wounds, but with his dead weight, they're ripe for plucking by the first predator that happens along.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Damn, what a mess. There are a lot of rags on hand. Patch up hubby as best you can.

You do what you can to stem the bleeding. He's in bad shape, and you doubt if he's going to make it.
You hand over the crowbar you just found to his wife. Tell her to use it if anyone else comes into the house. Show her how to change the bandages and tell her to give him plenty of liquids.
Who knows, maybe he'll pull through?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Give the wife the crowbar you've just picked up. She'll know what to do.

You heft the crowbar, and silently pass it over.
The woman looks you straight in the eye. It's unspoken, but you can tell she knows. It's not just for self-defense.
Hoisting your gear, you take one last look at the scene before departing. Some people get dealt all the bad cards. In another life, there'd be charity organizations that would drop everything to help out.
Not here.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Offer to guide them back to their enclave. Have to leave Dad behind, though.

You offer to lead them back home, but the woman is adamant. Refuses point-blank. Says the enclave won't have them back and, anyway, she isn't going to leave her husband to die alone.
What more can you do? You leave the crowbar you just found on the table in the living room. The wife is slight, but determined. Might be able to fend off the predators for a short while with the 'bar. It's something.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Grab some of their gear. Who's going to stop you?

The woman offers no resistance. Too drained, and likely has bigger things on her mind.
The two kids, on the other hand, both try to claw and scratch you as you rifle through their pile of equipment. Takes one and a half arms just to protect your face. Vicious little vermin.
In the end, you only manage to score a tarp, deciding to leave with that and the crowbar before your luck turns.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Grab some of their gear. Who's going to stop you?

The woman offers no resistance. Too drained, and likely has bigger things on her mind.
The two kids, on the other hand, both try to claw and scratch you as you rifle through their pile of equipment. Takes one and a half arms just to protect your face. Vicious little vermin.
In the end, you only manage to score a tarp, deciding to leave with that and the crowbar before your luck turns.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You could be looking at ancient Voortrekkers.
A family, hauling a makeshift cart, is slowly making their way down the patchwork road. Wife and kids acting as human mules, while husband acts as human target out front, rifle at the ready.
Then, the cart rolls into a deep pothole, shedding a wheel. You can't hear it, but you can feel their sudden despair. Changing a loaded wagon's wheel is a tough job any day, a job for the whole family.
But there's no way they can do that and pull guard duty simultaneously. You can see the husband's unwilling to turn his back on the surrounding buildings for even a second, rifle at the ready. Visibly twitchy.
They're stuck out in the open. Vulnerable. You could break cover and help.

table.name: encounters
table.column: They need your help. Give it, and damn the consequences!

You break cover slowly, hands in the air, and slowly move to the cart. The man, after an initial hesitation, lowers his rifle and acknowledges your offer of assistance.
The cart takes some lifting, but you manage to hold it long enough for the woman to refit the wheel back on the hub. With the pin back in place, the family wastes no time, and is soon moving down the road, waving at you as they go.
By the time you retrieve your gear, you've got your breath back, but only just. That really knocked you around.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run out and lift the cart. Give them ten seconds to fix the wheel, then get out of there, fast.

Have to be quick. That's the only way. Dawdle around in the open too long, and odds are that you'll caught up in the soon-to-be family massacre.
Running onto the road, you hope the wife is smart enough to figure out what's happening and get the wheel ready. You aren't staying past the count of ten.
Bam! The husband, misunderstanding your good intentions, fires. The bullet forcibly twists you around.
Barely keeping your feet, you stagger back into cover. There's blood spurting from the wound. Damn! Now *you've* got a crisis.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Watch and wait. The train wreck is coming. Bound to be something worth grabbing once the dust settles.

Five minutes is all it takes.
A gang of rubble scum arrive, and swarm the husband. He manages to take a couple out with the rifle, but the rest overwhelm him. The wife and kids, well, that's not pretty, either.
After a while, the scum leave with the cart in tow, having repaired the wheel. It's clear that anything worth stealing's gone with them.
All that's left, out there on the cracked tarmac, are four torn and abused bodies. What a mess.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Why wait? Run out, grab one of the kids, and threaten to snap their neck unless they give you food.

Not a bad plan. You pride yourself on adapting to circumstances. Thinking on your feet, which are rapidly taking you straight toward the nearest kid. Won't know what hit 'em.
Neither do you, unfortunately.
Quick on the draw, the father nails you with a bullet. Swerving, ducking, and dodging, you weave back into cover. Damn.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
An old lady staggers into view, and collapses to the ground, exhausted. Her tattered robe is torn and blackened. Her eyes haunted, her face gaunt.
"Water," she gasps. "Please, some water."
