It's hard to miss her shaved head and tattooed scalp. Few enclaves around here want the elderly. They think the elderly consume resources and produce nothing. A burden.
And once they're marked, nobody's allowed to help them. No food, no medicine. Nothing.
Which is a problem, in your situation. Help her, and there could be ramifications. Bad ones. The walls have eyes around here.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Enclave protocols don't apply to you. Help her, consequences be damned.

She's not long for the world, but at least you can help her find a measure of peace. If you have to knock on heaven's door, best to do so with a full stomach. Will cost you the water bottle and food that you spotted, but hey, so what? You stay with her until it's over.
Unexpectedly, something sharp suddenly whacks into your side. What was that? Who's there? You've been spotted! Getting to your feet, you wisely decide to make a run for it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Enclave protocols don't apply to you. Help her, consequences be damned.

She's not long for the world, but at least you can help her find a measure of peace. If you have to knock on heaven's door, best to do so with a full stomach. Will cost you the water bottle and food that you spotted, but hey, so what? You stay with her until it's over.
Unexpectedly, something sharp suddenly whacks into your side. What was that? Who's there? You've been spotted! Getting to your feet, you wisely decide to make a run for it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: A bottle of water won't hurt, right?

She knows you can't help, and signals her appreciation for the water. Only half of it manages to make it down her throat, the rest spilled by shaking, geriatric hands. As her eyes close for the last time, you take your leave.
Lucky you did. The rock that just sailed past you looked sharp and heavy. The next one, not so lucky. At least it doesn't do much harm.
Time to go, though, before one does.

table.name: encounters
table.column: A bottle of water won't hurt, right?

She knows you can't help, and signals her appreciation for the water. Only half of it manages to make it down her throat, the rest spilled by shaking, geriatric hands. As her eyes close for the last time, you take your leave.
Lucky you did. The rock that just sailed past you looked sharp and heavy. The next one, not so lucky. At least it doesn't do much harm.
Time to go, though, before one does.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The only safe haven around are the enclaves. Somebody sees you helping, and you're blacklisted. Keep moving.

Damned if you're going to hand over your recently gained water and food.
You turn your back on the old woman. She doesn't even bother to call out to you. Just lies there, panting. Dying. You've seen worse.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Granny is a goner. With a bit of luck, they're watching. Might keep you off the enclave blacklists if you finish her off.

The rock crunches into her skull before bouncing off. Hm, tougher than she looks. No matter. She won't be getting up again.
You place your foot on her scrawny throat, and press down hard. Best to be sure. Hope somebody was watching.
Gathering up the food and water you recently found, you leave. She won't be needing them.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The wavering voice calls out from a nearby alleyway. An old man, lying against a pile of fetid rubbish. Dying. Another tattooed scalp. You know the story.
He's alone, slowly fading away amongst the stink of putrid food and crawling maggots. He knows the score, has no illusions about his future. Asks that you finish him off. Doesn't want to linger on in pain. Rats have chewed through one foot already, ragged flesh and exposed bones a testament to their ferocity.
"Kill me," he pleads, "just do it."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Man, that's sad. Comfort the old guy.

He isn't interested in your kind words. He's fixated on you killing him.
You explain that you aren't that type of guy, and ask if he'd like some food or drink? "No, no," he stammers, "just kill me!"
Why does he want to die, he's still got one good foot? You mumble words of encouragement, but he is way beyond "where there's life, there's hope". He's rat food and he knows it.
"What are you waiting for?" he insists again, "just kill me!"
Confused and unsettled, you back away, not willing, nor able, to carry out his wishes.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You haven't got it in you. Keep walking.

There are worse ways to die than being eaten alive by rats. Another day or so, and it'll all be over.
Admittedly, it's a grim situation for the old man, but who elected you judge, jury, and executioner? He'll just have to hang in there until the rats chew through something vital.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Take a look at his foot, you might be able to help.

What's left of it is already infected. Protruding bones are limp and disjointed without the aid of their supportive ligaments. Blood is slowly oozing out of severed veins in his lower leg.
Using filthy, torn rags from the rubbish pile, you cover up the ragged stump. The old man slumps back onto the ground, muttering nonsense about you killing him here and now. Surely he's delirious.
You tell him you'll check up on him tomorrow morning, see how things are, bring some food and water. Both of you know that you'll be doing no such thing.
Leaving, you feel the warm buzz that comes from helping someone. You're the original good Samaritan. A hell of a guy.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Kill the old codger. That's what he wants.

Grinding down on your teeth, you kick him hard in the back of the head. Aiming for the spot where his spine connects with the base of his skull.
Done. Do you feel any better? Did you do the right thing? Doesn't feel like it. In fact, you feel ashamed that you couldn't do more to help the old man. How can you justify killing another human being in cold blood? "But he asked for it!" you argue to yourself.
Angrily, you shrug your shoulders. "Who the hell knows?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
In another age, the hunched, cowled old woman before you could've been called a witch. They used to burn them at the stake. These days, they slap a tattoo on their forehead, and expel them from their enclave. Excess to requirements.
The old woman, limping through the door with the aid of a branch, hasn't yet given up. She whispers through cracked lips that she's found a cache of food and ammunition. She needs your help, though. Promises you the bullets if you leave her the food.
A winning proposition, only trouble being the group of armed enclavers on the street outside. They aren't aware of your presence, but you know the rules. They catch you helping the tattooed elderly, and you're dogmeat.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It's a deal! Ignore the enclavers and follow the old lady to the cache.

You follow her out the rear door. The trouble is, she can't keep quiet to save herself.
Stumbling from one obstruction to the next, it isn't long before the enclavers come around to investigate the racket. They find you with a supporting arm helping the tattooed old lady. Angrily, they close in. Grandma sure as hell can't run. There's nothing for it but to leave her to them.
Breaking free from the mob, you manage to make it around the corner and out of sight, but your arm hurts. One of the enclavers managed to get in a lucky blow. Felled grandma and side swiped you.
Cursing silently to yourself, you sneak off. You should have known not to help her.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It's a deal! Ignore the enclavers and follow the old lady to the cache.

You follow her out the rear door. The trouble is, she can't keep quiet to save herself.
Stumbling from one obstruction to the next, it isn't long before the enclavers come around to investigate the racket. They find you with a supporting arm helping the tattooed old lady. Angrily, they close in. Grandma sure as hell can't run. There's nothing for it but to leave her to them.
Breaking free from the mob, you manage to make it around the corner and out of sight, but your arm hurts. One of the enclavers managed to get in a lucky blow. Felled grandma and side swiped you.
Cursing silently to yourself, you sneak off. You should have known not to help her.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You give her a noncommittal response. "Take me to the cache, and we can share what we find." As if.

The old witch is onto you. Her pupils contract into pinholes. She hisses and snarls, more alley cat than human.
Then, out of nowhere, she yells. A piercing, wild, feral yell that instantly gets the attention of the group of enclavers. You can see them pointing up at you through the ravaged window.
That's torn it. The old witch is smarter than she looks. Knows that you can't be seen helping her, so she's using the enclavers to chase you away. Or worse.
By the time you sprint out the back door, they are already zinging bullets around you. One of them tugs at you, hopefully just tagging your clothing.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You give her a noncommittal response. "Take me to the cache, and we can share what we find." As if.

The old witch is onto you. Her pupils contract into pinholes. She hisses and snarls, more alley cat than human.
Then, out of nowhere, she yells. A piercing, wild, feral yell that instantly gets the attention of the group of enclavers. You can see them pointing up at you through the ravaged window.
That's torn it. The old witch is smarter than she looks. Knows that you can't be seen helping her, so she's using the enclavers to chase you away. Or worse.
By the time you sprint out the back door, they are already zinging bullets around you. One of them tugs at you, hopefully just tagging your clothing.

table.name: encounters
table.column: No. You don't trust the old hag. She's hustling you.

Too risky. Help her, and the enclavers will be onto you. Besides, who's to say that she isn't just luring you into a trap? Hard to imagine, but it pays to be wary. The thought of an ammo cache is tempting, but it's not enough to overcome your unease. Leave her to it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Grab her by her scrawny throat, and force the location of the cache from her cracked lips.

She crumbles fast. Croaks out the cache location without any more unpleasantness.
Pushing her forcibly back into the debris in the corner, you duck out the door before she can attract anyone's attention. It isn't difficult to find the cache, as it's directly under an old statue. Greek? Roman? Probably fake. Had the heck knocked out of it, whatever it is. Only one limb remaining.
Plus a box. The old hag wasn't lying. Well done, her. Prying the box open you say a silent prayer that the aging ammunition is still usable.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Birth? How hard can it be?
The baby arrives, with its umbilical cord wrapped around its neck, not breathing. These men are too squeamish to watch, and the woman's preoccupied.
Normally you'd untangle the baby and fire it up, but this is a feral kid. Possibly destined for a life of rape and pillage. It'd be easy as pie to delay just long enough for oxygen deprivation to kick in. A brain-damaged kid isn't going to make it in this world.
You could walk away without anyone knowing.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It's a baby. A human. Who are you to judge its future life trajectory? Do the right thing.

Quickly, you untangle the cord and massage the baby's heart into life.
The woman, exhausted, takes the child and grants you a quiet smile. The guards slap you on the back as you leave.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Life's hard. Why make it any harder? Let nature take its course.

The baby takes a while to start breathing. You almost left it too long. Whatever brain cells are in there have been well and truly fried.
You avoid the woman's grateful eyes as you leave. Outside, the men are relieved, and thank you for your help as you walk away. It's a tough world. You call it as you see it.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A trio of rubble scum surprise you while you're attending to your bowels. Hard to keep watch while you are bent over and straining. No way out.
Standing, pulling up your pants, and rolling your shoulders, you resolve to go down fighting.
"Hey! It's the midwife!" yells one of them, pointing at you. The limo. The pregnant woman. Same bunch of rubble scum. You wonder if it'll make any difference. Wonder how the baby is.
Do you care?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask about the baby and the mother. You do care. Guilt does that to you.

You feel bad about what happened at the birth. It was a close call, and you had no right to even think of cutting it closer. Feeling guilty, you ask if the woman and her child are both healthy.
The trio must have sensed your embarrassment, because they move aside and let you pass, ignoring your question. You ask again, but all you receive are hostile stares. Taking the hint, grateful for the reprieve, you leave.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Trade one favor for another. You delivered the kid, they can let you go in return.

If you have to negotiate from a position of disadvantage, always do so from the front foot. Sage advice that you read from the torn pages of an a tattered magazine recently.
The trio must have read the same crappy periodical, because they don't appear to appreciate your demands. Downright hostile, in fact. Telling them that their kid is only there because of you doesn't help.
The three of them close in, and belt the bejesus out of you. Work you over thoroughly, leaving you grovelling in the dirt. Didn't kill you, didn't take any of your gear, just wanted to make a point.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Amazing if that kid is still alive. Bet it's struggling. Tell them you're a special kid doctor. You can help.

Since when do doctors dress like you? When was the last time you had a bath or a shower?
"Hey, buddy, where's your stethoscope?" calls one of them.
They aren't buying your story. The kid's probably doing okay, and they don't have any need for your services. Or your lies, for that matter.
Five minutes later, they leave. You lost count of how many times they kicked you. Why didn't they kill you? Steal your gear? Midwife duty must have counted for something.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell them that their kid is a mutant. Possessed of a brain the size of a peanut. Get them angry, distracted.

You explain to them that the kid is probably retarded.
Was that a smart move? Probably not. Sure, they're angry as a nest of suicidal hornets, but instead of blinding them with anger, they're just angry and focused. And there's nowhere to run.
Damn, insulting their kid is shaping up to be a really dumb move. What if it was my kid? How would I react? Not well.
Neither did they. Knocked you down. Took all your gear. Left you with nothing, not even clothes or shoes. Buck naked in the wastelands. How much longer are you going to last?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's the woman. The one from the limo. She's washing it in a bowl of water. Rubble scum are guarding the entrance points.
You're up high, looking down, and a big bunch of rough-types is moving in from the south. On a collision course. By the looks of 'em, the baby may be their dessert.
You could shout out a warning to the rubble scum. Save the baby. But the cannibals won't appreciate your intervention. Might try and hunt you down. Easy to get cornered in this building.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Risk it. Save the mum and bub. Yell out a warning!

That worked. The mother briefly catches your eye before bundling up her baby and quickly leaving with the others. She might have smiled at you. Then again, she might not have.
Right now, however, you're busy with other matters. The cannibals are running to seal off the exits to the building you're in. You're cornered.
Almost. There's the roof. Damn scary leap, but you might just make it across to the next building with a decent run up.
You backpedal a half dozen paces, and spring into the air over the gap. The cannibals don't see it happen. Just as well, as you land badly. Scraped a fair bit of skin off.
But you're safe. It's worth it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw a rock. Hope they take the hint and see the cannibals in time.

Actually, you threw two. All you could risk doing before the cannibals arrived.
Your rocks weren't noticed by anyone. You blame subsequent events on the poor hearing of the rubble scum. If they'd been a bit more alert, they'd still be alive.
You watch as the cannibals lead the mother and baby away. Barbecue tonight.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Stay low. Stay quiet. Watch it all shake out below.

Stay low. Always a decent fall back plan in the wastelands.
Not today, though. Cannibals fluffed their approach, spooked the rubble scum. Where did they run to? Into your building. You hear them pounding up the stairs below. The distressed crying of the woman and her baby. Cannibals in hot pursuit.
Unable to stay, you head for the roof. No option but to try jumping to the next building across. Pushing off with all your legs' strength, you make it, but only just. Had to haul yourself up and over the lip. Very nearly roadkill.
Once clear, you have to do a gear check to see what you dropped.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Stay low. Stay quiet. Watch it all shake out below.

Stay low. Always a decent fall back plan in the wastelands.
Not today, though. Cannibals fluffed their approach, spooked the rubble scum. Where did they run to? Into your building. You hear them pounding up the stairs below. The distressed crying of the woman and her baby. Cannibals in hot pursuit.
Unable to stay, you head for the roof. No option but to try jumping to the next building across. Pushing off with all your legs' strength, you make it, but only just. Had to haul yourself up and over the lip. Very nearly roadkill.
Once clear, you have to do a gear check to see what you dropped.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wave at the cannibals. Get their attention. Point down to where the baby is. They'll be more interested in it than the likes of you.

Heck of a thing, but they wave back at you.
Just before splitting into two groups: one charging into the rubble scum, and the other into your building. Some days just don't go to plan.
Making your way rapidly to the roof, you take a deep breath, and jump the gap to the adjoining building. Descending the next building, you find, purely by accident, a bottle of water. How about that?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Gunshots! Behind that building. Cautiously peering around the corner, you see someone curled up in agony amongst swirling plastic and empty cans. Blood is coagulating on the rubbish around him, probably from the wound in his side.
His face is covered in strange, painted geometric shapes. No equipment, though. Probably taken in the attack. Nothing left but his clothes.
This one's going to bleed to death if you don't do something.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You can't let a man die. Even a stranger. Stem the bleeding. Tear up his T-shirt for bandages.

He doesn't protest as you bandage him up. It's a nasty wound, and he'll need more help than you can provide. Grasped in his curled fist is a lighter.
Borrowing it, you light a fire, and heap plastic detritus onto it. That's a smell that's bound to attract attention. Hope it's the right kind. Good luck, fella.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Rip off the bottom of his T-shirt, hand over the impromptu bandage, and leave him to it.
You throw the bandage within easy reach, and get out of there. If you heard the shots, others might have as well.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You don't like make-up. Can't trust a painted face. Leave him to rot.

Guy must have something to hide. All that face paint.
Let the maggots take care of him.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Time to do some vermin control. Finish him off.

You hope somebody is keeping score. Maybe that's how you get to heaven? Squash enough bugs and you get a free pass?
Damn, now you've got blood all over your jeans.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It took over an hour. The screaming lasted almost as long. A squad of mercs in patterned face paint, torturing a man to death. And taking their time doing it.
Pulling out his nails, slicing off his appendages. Hung, drawn, and quartered.
Once he stopped screaming, there wasn't much enthusiasm to continue. You watch them kill him, and they depart. Left him dangling, a piece of raw, bruised, and violated meat. The heck of it is, that you knew him. Helped you out yesterday.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Give the poor man a decent burial. It'll take a while, but one good deed deserves another.

There's a piece of scrap wood that does poor service as a spade. You plug away at it for an hour, but fail to make much impression in the hard ground.
In the end, you throw old bricks and rubbish onto him. It's a poor excuse for a burial, and you know that the rats will be eating into him before long.
Still, you feel an obligation to do what you can. After all, the man got you out of a sticky situation yesterday. You heave a few more rocks up onto him. Frustrated, knowing you can't do him justice, you give up, exhausted.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Say a few quiet words to ease his passing, and be on your way. Too risky to do all that digging. Might get jumped.

"Dust to dust, ashes to ashes." It's about all you can remember.
Burial services were never your strong suit. Five-star burials have gone out of fashion, anyway. Lucky if anybody bothers to hang around these days. Death in the wastelands is so commonplace, who wants to be reminded of their own nebulous mortality?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Another one bites the dust. If you can't look after yourself, who else will? Leave him.

It was very generous of him to help you out like he did. One stranger assisting another, not asking for anything in return.
Look what happened to him. Too busy saving the world, and not busy enough saving himself. There's no cure for stupidity. Let him hang.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Maybe, just maybe, you can sneak a piece of meat away. Nobody's watching, are they?

It's going to be rough trade, but it's still food. Normally you wouldn't do this kind of thing, but nobody is watching. And you're desperate.
What you're looking at, dangling before you, is squirrel. Yep, that's what it is. Squirrel meat. Very tasty squirrel.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Junk can be worth a lot of money in the hands of the right people. But you have to factor in gangs.
The wrong people.
There's an impromptu roadblock up ahead. Thugs are frisking travelers for contraband. Being rough about it. Not afraid to ruffle feathers.
You see an enclave trading party heading straight for them. Unaware. They're well-armed, but not well enough.
Could be juicy pickings afterwards for those who watch and wait.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Warn them of the danger. Hope that the thugs don't hear you doing it.

Nobody likes highway robbers. Parasites.
The enclavers appreciate your timely warning, and give you some food in return. Everybody had enough sense to keep quiet, and you're pretty sure that the thugs are totally unaware of your or the enclavers' presence.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Silently wave. They'll see you, and the thugs won't know you're there.

What's with your silent wave? Can't anybody see it?
The enclavers walk right past your hidden position. A sharp volley of fire breaks out, interrupting your thoughts. Time to go.
As you duck out the back door, a stray bullet ricochets off the wall and thumps into your arm. How unlucky is that? Is that blood?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Silently wave. They'll see you, and the thugs won't know you're there.

What's with your silent wave? Can't anybody see it?
The enclavers walk right past your hidden position. A sharp volley of fire breaks out, interrupting your thoughts. Time to go.
As you duck out the back door, a stray bullet ricochets off the wall and thumps into your arm. How unlucky is that? Is that blood?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Do nothing. Get ready to run in and speed loot the bodies once it's all over.

So much for that.
Dopey enclavers walk straight into an ambush. Wiped out to a man. Thugs are all over the bodies like a bad rash. Nothing left for the likes of you.
If you don't get out of there fast, you'll be next on their list.

table.name: encounters
table.column: If you're fast, you can do a deal with the highway robbers, in return for some of the leftovers.

Not so easy, dealing with irrational people.
For a moment there, you thought they might try and frisk you, too. But no, you quickly come to an arrangement.
Ducking down behind the roadblock, you watch the enclavers get gunned down as they round the corner. Sure enough, they had the goods. The robbers are elated. Judging that now is a good time, you ask for your reward.
One measly packet of Gelli Bears thrown your way. Had to scrabble for them. How humiliating.
Guns are pointed in your direction. You get the distinct impression that you're no longer welcome. That's the last time you'll be doing business with that lot. A deal's a deal, where are the their ethics?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Cooking smells! Mmm, roast meat.
Following your nose has led you to a hidden recess in a huge pile of rubble. A two-person scavenging party are cooking a squirrel over a small fire. Or is it a rat? Hard to tell, looking down from a second-floor window.
Which is good, 'cause it means you can also see a gang of rubble scum approaching, homing in on the same irresistible olfactory tracer. The enclavers have left their weapons on the ground while they concentrate on their cooking. Do you throw a rock and warn them about the approaching bandits? There's nothing in it for you but, hey, these are the good guys.
But then, there's the risk of revealing yourself...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw the rock. Humanity has to stick to together. Hope the bandits don't notice you.

That got their attention.
But not fast enough. The rubble scum are close enough to cover the only entrance. One of the roughnecks, armed with a rifle, sits back while the others move in for the kill. You can see the fear on the faces of the cornered enclavers.
Before they can see you and call out for help, you melt into the shadows and leave. Nothing good is going to happen here now.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Move back into the shadows and watch it unfold. None of your business.

The enclavers must have been starving. It's the only reason you can think of as to why they would be so stupid as to cook meat here in the ruins. Stupidity doesn't pay. Not in the wastelands.
As the blows rain down and the blood spatters, you quietly take your leave. The bandits won't leave anything behind.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You remember the enclavers who got caught out cooking. Roasting meat over a fire is a sure way to flag your location to everybody within a one-mile radius.
Trouble is, you still have to cook. Somehow. Somewhere. Preferably not in the urban jungle. Too many predators.
Not that the enclavers in the building up ahead are that concerned over uninvited guests. They've got other worries. Their cooking fire has spread. Flared into a major conflagration. All that combustible rubbish. Now they're trapped, hemmed in by a fire of their own making.
You can see, from your vantage point, a way out the back. The running feet, and hooping and hollering of the rubble scum, means you're about to have lots of company.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Move fast! Run down to ground level and across to where the enclavers are. Show them the way to safety.

You're quick, but not quick enough.
You meet the running gang of rubble scum halfway to the building. A meat cleaver takes a chunk out of you before you can disengage and get out of their way. Once you make it to the safety of a dark alleyway, you listen to the screams of the enclavers as they burn alive, trapped within by the rubble scum.
Damn, that gouge hurts!

table.name: encounters
table.column: Move fast! Run down to ground level and across to where the enclavers are. Show them the way to safety.

You're quick, but not quick enough.
You meet the running gang of rubble scum halfway to the building. A meat cleaver takes a chunk out of you before you can disengage and get out of their way. Once you make it to the safety of a dark alleyway, you listen to the screams of the enclavers as they burn alive, trapped within by the rubble scum.
Damn, that gouge hurts!

table.name: encounters
table.column: Lean out the window, and yell at the enclavers. Point to the only safe exit. It'll be close, but you should be able to avoid the rubble scum.

They hear you. Get the message, too.
One of them ventures into the thick smoke, following your directions, and finds the way out of the building. Moments later, the others follow. The gang of rubble scum see what you've done, and they aren't happy.
Like sharks in a feeding frenzy, they switch targets to the nearest available prey: you. Leaping away from the window, you hurtle down the stairs, fall, tumble, recover, keep moving.
Out the back door, just in the nick of time. It's only when you clear the area that you check to see if you dropped anything valuable.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Lean out the window, and yell at the enclavers. Point to the only safe exit. It'll be close, but you should be able to avoid the rubble scum.

They hear you. Get the message, too.
One of them ventures into the thick smoke, following your directions, and finds the way out of the building. Moments later, the others follow. The gang of rubble scum see what you've done, and they aren't happy.
Like sharks in a feeding frenzy, they switch targets to the nearest available prey: you. Leaping away from the window, you hurtle down the stairs, fall, tumble, recover, keep moving.
Out the back door, just in the nick of time. It's only when you clear the area that you check to see if you dropped anything valuable.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Fire can spread quickly with all the rubbish strewn around. Best get the heck out of there. Let them burn.

You're not the fire department. Or a one-man emergency response team. Out here in the wastelands, if you get yourself into trouble, then you'll have to get yourself out of it.
The enclavers will just have to hope for the best, 'cause you're on the fast train out of here. Don't want to get hemmed in by rubble scum and a fast-moving fire.

table.name: encounters
table.column: If anyone stumbles out of the fire, there could be some pre-cooked meat available shortly for those who are patient.

A tinge of guilt overcomes you, but when your stomach is rumbling, you're willing to overlook some things. You cross your fingers and hope that the enclavers don't choose to sit tight. You like your meat medium, not charcoal briquette.
You hang around long enough for it to all play out. With an empty stage, the actors dead or dispersed, you prowl around, looking to salvage a meal out of the mess.
You reluctantly chow down on some dubious piece of burnt meat, but it only ends up on the ground in front of you, swimming in a pool of vomit.
Man, that was the worst thing you've ever eaten. Should have known.

table.name: encounters
table.column: If anyone stumbles out of the fire, there could be some pre-cooked meat available shortly for those who are patient.

A tinge of guilt overcomes you, but when your stomach is rumbling, you're willing to overlook some things. You cross your fingers and hope that the enclavers don't choose to sit tight. You like your meat medium, not charcoal briquette.
You hang around long enough for it to all play out. With an empty stage, the actors dead or dispersed, you prowl around, looking to salvage a meal out of the mess.
You reluctantly chow down on some dubious piece of burnt meat, but it only ends up on the ground in front of you, swimming in a pool of vomit.
Man, that was the worst thing you've ever eaten. Should have known.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Enclavers. Friendly ones. They're offering you food.
But they can't understand that they shouldn't light a fire here. Don't believe you when you tell them that the smell of roast rat will inevitably seep out from the basement and up into the streets.
They're too happy, cheerful. You notice an empty whiskey bottle. They light the fire, despite your protests.
Moments later, there is rat fat dripping down onto the blaze, and your taste buds are salivating. Plenty of meat for all. Another five minutes and you'll be wolfing down qual- well, protein. But this basement is a deathtrap.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hey, it's a party. Get with the spirit. Wait for your rat burger. Ask if there's any more whiskey?

Yeah, baby, boogie on down. When was the last time you had the opportunity for some fun? That curvy enclaver over there is giving you the look. You casually sidle on over, hoping her body odor is no worse than yours.
There's a loud "bang!" as bandits crash the party.
Crazed, swirling movement. Hard to tell friend from foe. Yells, screams, grunts. Bullets zip zinging around the close confines of the basement.
You're trapped. The inebriated enclavers go down fast, leaving you alone facing who knows how many blood-crazed thugs. Your last thought before your skull caves in is that this is a hell of a price to pay for a bit of harmless fun.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Kick dirt over the fire. If the enclavers are too drunk to care, you'll have to be the responsible adult.

Funny, they don't appreciate your help. Nor do they appreciate their rat meat being smothered in filthy dirt and gunk.
Four of them set to, and express their displeasure in a more physical manner, before carrying you up the stairs and heaving you face first out onto the grimy street.
Groaning in pain, aching all over, you claw yourself upright by hanging onto a bent and rusty lamp post. You push away, and notice blood. Damn, must've sliced skin open on the rusty, sharp-edged metal.
Your only consolation is that you've still got all your gear. If you can manage to carry it. You slowly limp off down the street.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell them to keep a rat burger for you, and stand guard at the street entrance.

It's not easy standing up there in the cold, while the sounds of merriment waft up from the basement. Did they remember to save anything for you? Doesn't sound like it.
You notice the pack of bandits prowling your way, and yell a warning down the stairs. Nobody answers. All you can hear is laughter, and what sounds suspiciously like moaning.
As the bandits home in on the smell of cooked meat, you sidestep into the darkness of the next building. You've done what you can. There isn't time to run down the stairs, not unless you want to get trapped with the rest. The only outstanding question is whether the enclavers will be massacred or rounded up to be on sold to the slavers?
Not your concern. Not anymore.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Trapped rats come to mind. Get out of there now. Right now.

It's tempting. Juicy rat burgers, whiskey, and free love.
But you know full well you can't afford to succumb to those kinds of urges out here unless it's in a rare, safe environment. And a single-exit basement in the middle of a predatory urban zone isn't your idea of safe.
Without a backward glance, you run up the stairs, and melt into the nearest shadows. You can still hear the catcalls of the men, and the cooing seductiveness of the drunken women, as you warily make your way down the street.
You wonder if you made the right decision.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There's a loud splash! It's an old sewage treatment pond. Full of rain water, floating rubbish, and dead rats. Somebody thrashing around in there, unable to swim.
If you're quick, real quick, you might just be able to pull them out before anyone else arrives.
Have to strip, though. Looks awfully cold in there. They're thrashing around so much, that even up close you can't tell who it is. If you're going to dive in and save them, it has to be now.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Dive in! You can't stand back and let somebody drown.

Whoa! Temperature shock. This is freezing!
You reach the person, and they wrap their arms around your body, vice-style. Both of you sink below the surface. Desperate, your arms pinned, you bite clean through their ear.
It's enough.
You kick frantically to the surface, as they grab at your legs. Reaching the edge, you climb out of the tank, shivering violently.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Look around for something long enough for them to grab onto. Might not be the best option, but you don't want to get wet.

You find an old antenna, but it's brittle and snaps when you lift it from the ground.
Too late, anyway. The thrashing sounds have diminished. All you can see now are bubbles. Hope it was one of the cannibals. One less wouldn't hurt.
You keep that thought uppermost in your mind. Best not to think about what you actually saw. They really should teach kids to swim these days.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Too cold. Sorry, buddy. Next time, try drowning in a heated pool.
It takes a minute, but they soon sink below the surface, arms floundering as they go. Nobody gets to die old in the wastelands.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Who knows who I'll be helping? Ignore them, and scout the perimeter of the tank for any items they may have left.

Damn! Nothing. You would have thought they had the decency to leave something useful behind.
Frustrated, you hurl a jagged piece of concrete at the swirling pool of bubbles that mark their last living moments.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Nobody wants to bathe these days. Never know who will be watching, waiting for you to get buck naked and shivering. Easy prey.
Like these two. Sewer dwellers bathing in an old storm drain. Rarely seen in the daytime. It's almost dark down here, so not a bad spot, actually. And with running water that's lost its muddy tinge.
But nowhere is safe, even down here. One of them slips on the slime and falls, knocking herself unconscious, head underwater, her friend panicking.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Help out. The friend is hysterical. If you don't step in and help her out of the water quickly, it'll be too late.

You almost make it. Slipped on the same slime-covered sewer surface as the drowning woman. Banged your knee pretty hard.
By the time you recover, it's too late. Pulling her out of the water, you try to revive her. All you get for your troubles are a mouthful of secondhand water. Her friend is yelling up a storm. Completely lost the plot.
It isn't going to be long before you have company. No way to tell if it's going to be friendly or otherwise. Best to get out of there now.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Sewer dwellers aren't your concern. There might be more of them arriving soon, attracted by the commotion. Leave.

All that noise. One thing you've got a low tolerance for, and that's panicky hysterics. Don't they know that all they're doing is broadcasting their location to everyone who still has two ears? You'll take quiet and calm any day.
Either way, you're not going to hang around and wait to see who turns up. The storm drain's looking a little too linear for your liking. Sorry, lady, but you've got to go.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Let her drown. That'll only leave one of them. Easier to deal with. Bound to be something worth looting.

You give it a couple of minutes. Standing there in the dark, watching her until her muscles relax.
Then, you approach the survivor. Quietly. Silently. Darkness and her full-on panic attack, both a big help. A solid whack to the back of her head, and she's down.
Made sure that she was out of the water, of course. You're not a murderer.
You quickly flick through the pile of clothes, the footsteps approaching from the dark depths of the storm drain urging you to hurry.
Nothing but T-shirts and jeans. Crap. Might be handy for bandages, anyway.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Looks like an old swimming pool. Stagnant water, with algae bloom covering the surface. What looks like a crate of whiskey is floating in the middle of all the muck.
Two bandits have noticed it as well. Paddled out in a makeshift raft. Now they are sinking, their raft slowly disintegrating. It's pretty obvious that neither of them can swim.
They're yelling at you to throw in the big plank at your feet. Something for them to grab hold of, and kick themselves to safety.
You notice that the whiskey has already disappeared, lost from sight. Nothing left but a couple of drowning roughs in a stinking pool. Lifeguard duty is starting to look unattractive.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The plank isn't enough. You'll have to strip down and swim it out to them. Help them both to safety.

Man, why did they pick this damn awful pool full of gunk to drown in? This is really going above and beyond the call of duty. Probably come down with leprosy.
You strip off and jump in. Stroking manfully through the floating muck, you get close enough to push the plank across to them. One of them gurgles and sinks before he can reach it, but the other latches on to it with a grip that'd snap steel.
Careful to stay clear of Mr. Hang On Tight, you grab the other end of the plank, and tow him to the edge of the pool. Even had to help lift him out.
As he lay there, coughing up pools of water, you kneel beside him, doing the same. You manage to recover first, get dressed, and get out of there. A bandit, even a rescued bandit, is still dangerous.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The plank isn't enough. You'll have to strip down and swim it out to them. Help them both to safety.

Man, why did they pick this damn awful pool full of gunk to drown in? This is really going above and beyond the call of duty. Probably come down with leprosy.
You strip off and jump in. Stroking manfully through the floating muck, you get close enough to push the plank across to them. One of them gurgles and sinks before he can reach it, but the other latches on to it with a grip that'd snap steel.
Careful to stay clear of Mr. Hang On Tight, you grab the other end of the plank, and tow him to the edge of the pool. Even had to help lift him out.
As he lay there, coughing up pools of water, you kneel beside him, doing the same. You manage to recover first, get dressed, and get out of there. A bandit, even a rescued bandit, is still dangerous.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw them the plank. Nobody deserves to drown unnecessarily, not even the roughs.

It's a big pool, and the plank's heavy. You do your best, but it comes to rest halfway between you and them. Sorry, fellas.
Desperately, they both attempt to thrash and splash their way over to the security of the plank. One slips under, then the other. Bubbles and muck all intermingle in testament to the violent underwater struggle for life.
Eventually, it all subsides. The plank, propelled by the disturbance, drifts back over to where you are. If you were a philosopher, you'd make something of that.
But you aren't.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It's your off-duty day. Sorry. Got to run.

They're bandits. The whiskey is gone. What's in it for you? No way are you swimming through that cesspool to rescue a couple of roughs.
Hey, if you run into a lifeguard, you'll let them know.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Yell at them to swim. It's obvious they can't, but you may as well have some fun.

"This is how you do it. Reach out with your hand. Gentle, sweeping stroke. Easy on the kick. Hey, are you listening guys? Where are you?"
Gone. Both of them. Drowned. What can you say? Poor listeners, and slow learners. Not your fault. If there's one thing you pride yourself in, it's in giving a top-notch swimming lesson. They should have paid more attention.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Sitting on a decaying park bench, aiming his gun at your chest, is a scarred, flint-eyed man. From the kit and camo clothing, you can tell he's ronin. A gun for hire. He's airing his feet, one profusely bleeding from a recent gash. Probably the same gash that caused that rip through the sole of his shoe. A lot of sharp metal around these parts.
The pain must be affecting his grip on the rifle. It's wavering. Maybe enough for you to safely dive off to the side. He's not saying anything. Just sitting there, staring.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Who he is doesn't matter, the man's in pain. You're here to help.

You approach, indicating your peaceful intentions. The ronin cautiously lowers his rifle. You inspect his damaged foot, and bandage it up using a few old rags nearby.
Job finished, you wait for your reward. His stare doesn't waver. Hey, even a word of thanks would help, but no, he lowers the rifle to your chest once more and lets it be known that he'd like some personal space.
As you back away, he reaches into a pocket and says, "Catch."

table.name: encounters
table.column: How much help do you give a killer? Throw him a stray shoe and get the heck out of there.

You toss him the shoe you recently found. It's a charity. He clearly won't be able to walk without one.
But the charity fails to register. At least you think that's the case. You'd have to have a conversation with a human to know for sure. It appears this guy has more in common with a statue, however.
Having done your good deed, you head off, his ice-cold stare boring into your back.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Duck, dodge, and roll. You're a ghost. You're gone.

You drop left, and dive for cover.
Man, he's quick! Gets a shot off as you're moving. Might be nothing, but could be a flesh wound. Fortunately, you're quicker. A ghost. One moment there, next moment gone.
And no matter what, that shot's bound to attract attention. Time to go.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Duck, dodge, and roll. You're a ghost. You're gone.

You drop left, and dive for cover.
Man, he's quick! Gets a shot off as you're moving. Might be nothing, but could be a flesh wound. Fortunately, you're quicker. A ghost. One moment there, next moment gone.
And no matter what, that shot's bound to attract attention. Time to go.

table.name: encounters
table.column: That's a nice-looking rifle he has. Probably best if you looked after it for a while. Hopalong Cassidy won't be needing it.

Faking an offer to help, you reach into your pack for something medical-looking. You hold it up to one side, jiggling it around, just a touch. Enough to maintain his attention away from the chunk of stone hidden in your other hand, as you move in.
Straight onto the barrel of his rifle, his dark eyes boring into you. Smiling, feigning surprise, you ease back. Then, you throw the rock as you duck under the shot, and body roll sideways out of sight.
Luckily, he missed. Wait, did he? Is that blood?

table.name: encounters
table.column: That's a nice-looking rifle he has. Probably best if you looked after it for a while. Hopalong Cassidy won't be needing it.

Faking an offer to help, you reach into your pack for something medical-looking. You hold it up to one side, jiggling it around, just a touch. Enough to maintain his attention away from the chunk of stone hidden in your other hand, as you move in.
Straight onto the barrel of his rifle, his dark eyes boring into you. Smiling, feigning surprise, you ease back. Then, you throw the rock as you duck under the shot, and body roll sideways out of sight.
Luckily, he missed. Wait, did he? Is that blood?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The chaos of the wastelands breeds its share of rivalries. Freelance mercenaries fill in the gaps.
Mercs. Muscle for hire. Everybody uses them, even the enclaves. You can make a career out of killing out here. Admittedly, it's not a long career. Usually ends with your entrails twisted around your ankles.
Problem is, when people pay you to kill, they expect you to do the dying for them as well. Probably the case with this merc you've been watching from the safety of a garbage skip. The delegation of enclavers he's negotiating with are probably offering a suicide mission. And negotiations are not going so well.
The merc is quietly reaching behind his back, unsheathing his knife...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Paid killers aren't your friends. Yell out a warning to the enclavers.

Hired death merchants are nothing but parasites sucking blood out of a decent world. The ronin you met previously didn't look like ambassador material, and you're betting this one's no better.
You shout a warning to the enclavers. The merc, realizing he can't prevail, backs off, and slinks away.
The enclavers show their appreciation by placing food and water on the ground before leaving. Not totally convinced you're on their side, but willing to give thanks for your warning.

table.name: encounters
table.column: There's enough violence in this world already. Intervene and ask everybody to chill out.

Great idea. When was the last time you threw yourself between two armed parties in a dispute? How did that work out?
In a blur of movement, the merc takes advantage of your presence, and manages to stab both the lead enclavers before running off. Nobody who's left appreciates your pleas for compassion and understanding.
Things get ugly, and you barely make it around the corner. Might've even taken a hit. Though was it the merc or the enclavers?
Either way, next time you see a dove, you're going to kick it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: There's enough violence in this world already. Intervene and ask everybody to chill out.

Great idea. When was the last time you threw yourself between two armed parties in a dispute? How did that work out?
In a blur of movement, the merc takes advantage of your presence, and manages to stab both the lead enclavers before running off. Nobody who's left appreciates your pleas for compassion and understanding.
Things get ugly, and you barely make it around the corner. Might've even taken a hit. Though was it the merc or the enclavers?
Either way, next time you see a dove, you're going to kick it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Your money is on the merc. Could be interesting. Who says he can't take out the lot?

Sit tight and let it happen. Can't argue with that logic. In a hostile wasteland, he who doesn't get involved, doesn't get hurt.
Besides, you would have lost your bet. The enclavers are not as naive as they appeared.
The merc tries to grab the head enclaver, looking to hold a knife to his throat. Probably hoping to negotiate from a position of strength. Doesn't work, though. Enclavers must've had a hidden marksman on overwatch. Drilled a bullet straight through the merc's forehead.
Now you're extra glad you didn't break cover. You never know who's watching.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tight-fisted enclavers deserve what they get. Distract them. Give the merc an edge.

Enclavers can be a cliquish, self-righteous lot at times. "We are the future" wears thin after after a while. It's a convenient phrase used to excuse all manner of unpleasantness.
You jump up and windmill your arms. You start hollering the verse to an old rock song, but your memory's too scrambled. So you ramble on freestyle. Anything to take their eyes off the merc. He'll teach them a lesson.
Bang! Sniper. Enclavers must have a man in hiding watching the meeting.
Ducking, you scurry out of sight. Damn, might've even been tagged.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tight-fisted enclavers deserve what they get. Distract them. Give the merc an edge.

Enclavers can be a cliquish, self-righteous lot at times. "We are the future" wears thin after after a while. It's a convenient phrase used to excuse all manner of unpleasantness.
You jump up and windmill your arms. You start hollering the verse to an old rock song, but your memory's too scrambled. So you ramble on freestyle. Anything to take their eyes off the merc. He'll teach them a lesson.
Bang! Sniper. Enclavers must have a man in hiding watching the meeting.
Ducking, you scurry out of sight. Damn, might've even been tagged.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's that ronin with the crooked foot. The one that wanted a shoe. How'd he get here? He's leading a conga line of raiders through the rubble and ruins.
But you can tell he isn't going to get paid today. The raiders are almost through the labyrinth. No need for an armed guide now. Plus, they're eyeing up his rifle, closing in tight, ronin seemingly unaware.
Suddenly, a blur of movement, noise, action. All over. The raiders are gone, the ronin sprawled in the dirt, bleeding out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: He doesn't deserve your help, but how can you walk away from a dying man? Help him.

He's a mess. Blood everywhere.
Tearing strips off his T-shirt, you do what you can. You doubt if he's going to make it, but he looks like he's all gristle and muscle.
It's an effort, but you roll him over to get the wounds on his back. You find a concealed pocket in his belt. There's some money there. At least that's something for your trouble. He'll understand.

table.name: encounters
table.column: He doesn't deserve your help, but how can you walk away from a dying man? Help him.

He's a mess. Blood everywhere.
Tearing strips off his T-shirt, you do what you can. You doubt if he's going to make it, but he looks like he's all gristle and muscle.
It's an effort, but you roll him over to get the wounds on his back. You find a concealed pocket in his belt. There's some money there. At least that's something for your trouble. He'll understand.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Pick up that dirty rag over there, and put it where he can reach it. Best you can do.

Don't want to get any of that blood on you. Could be infectious.
"Here, fella. Have a dirty, crusty rag. How about I just leave it over here? Not talking again? Just lying there, bleeding. Boy, do you look bad!"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Didn't like him back then, don't like him now. Let him bleed.

There's enough blood on the ground to fill a bucket. Nothing you can do, so why bother?
Live by the sword, die by the sword.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Only thing better than a nearly dead ronin is a dead one. Finish him. Otherwise, he might recover.

Rock to the head. Man, did he have to splatter so much blood onto you? It's like he wanted to spite you one more time.
Hope he didn't have any of those nasty blood borne diseases.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Only thing better than a nearly dead ronin is a dead one. Finish him. Otherwise, he might recover.

Rock to the head. Man, did he have to splatter so much blood onto you? It's like he wanted to spite you one more time.
Hope he didn't have any of those nasty blood borne diseases.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A man with more gold bangles than hair drags a scared young woman toward you, yelling out, "I've got damaged goods here, man. Needs fixing!"
Up close, you notice the bangles are fakes, and the man's pockmarked face displays a larcenous streak. He's sized you up as an agent of good. You can't really extend him the same courtesy, though.
Besides, he's got rotten breath.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ignore the pimp, and patch his girl up. She's bleeding. There are old rags nearby.

The pimp can't stop talking.
You bandage up the girl, and check she's okay, but the damn pimp just keeps rabbiting. Dude's driving you to distraction. Talking ten to a dozen.
The girl remains mute, sullen-eyed, and accepting of her fate. At least she won't bleed to death now.
Motor mouth generously pays you for your services before leaving.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ignore the pimp, and patch his girl up. She's bleeding. There are old rags nearby.

The pimp can't stop talking.
You bandage up the girl, and check she's okay, but the damn pimp just keeps rabbiting. Dude's driving you to distraction. Talking ten to a dozen.
The girl remains mute, sullen-eyed, and accepting of her fate. At least she won't bleed to death now.
Motor mouth generously pays you for your services before leaving.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell the pimp he can keep his goods. Get somebody else to fix them. Leave.
Bad luck about the girl, but you're not into that scene. Get caught up in other people's troubles, and you end up dead.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask the pimp how much for some fun? It's been a while.

Pimp doesn't miss a beat and starts on his sales pitch. Pointing out the girl's better features, like she was a tame piece of meat.
You lose interest fast. Bad idea in the first place. Except the pimp won't take "no" for an answer. Demands you pay him for the trouble and inconvenience you've caused. "Embarrassed his girl" now.
"What's the matter, man? She too ugly?"
In the end, the only way to get rid of them is to raise your weapon. The pimp's nothing but a blur as he draws a concealed knife and slashes you. He and his "goods" run off before you can react.
Didn't that go well?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask the pimp how much for some fun? It's been a while.

Pimp doesn't miss a beat and starts on his sales pitch. Pointing out the girl's better features, like she was a tame piece of meat.
You lose interest fast. Bad idea in the first place. Except the pimp won't take "no" for an answer. Demands you pay him for the trouble and inconvenience you've caused. "Embarrassed his girl" now.
"What's the matter, man? She too ugly?"
In the end, the only way to get rid of them is to raise your weapon. The pimp's nothing but a blur as he draws a concealed knife and slashes you. He and his "goods" run off before you can react.
Didn't that go well?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Girl on a mattress, not fully dressed. Some gap-toothed man savagely beating her.
He turns as you enter the room. "Didn't get my money's worth, man!"
Looks like the same girl you met before. The one with the pimp. Must move around a lot.
Her unhappy customer turns back, and slaps her so hard her head recoils into the concrete floor. He's all mean streak and muscles. Not happy. No, sir.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Teach him a lesson. Use that iron bar over there.

"Pick on someone your own size, buster!"
The iron bar slips from your sweaty, nervous grip as you swing it and thumps onto his foot, audibly breaking bone as it does so.
Leaving the howling, manic muscle man behind, you grab the girl and get out of there. Running out of the building, you slam straight into the pimp.
"Got my girl, hey, that's real nice of you, man. Thanks." He grips the woman's arm, and pulls a knife with his free hand.
Backing off, you decide that you've had enough excitement for one day. It was good of the girl to slip you her takings, though.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Try and engage him in conversation, give the girl a chance to escape.

He's just the sort of fellow who looks like he'd appreciate a decent conversation...
Bam! A fist the size of a pumpkin crashes into you. Your legs fail you as you slump to the ground, unconscious.
When you regain consciousness, they're both gone. You wiggle your fingers and toes, checking for injuries. Why are your feet so cold? Pumpkin Fist, it seems, liked your sense of fashion. Or maybe it was the girl? Were you even wearing shoes? Hard to remember anything with a headache this bad.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Where's the girl's pimp? This is his job. Won't be much left of his girl if he doesn't hurry up.

Where's her pimp, anyway? Wait, that must be him running up the hallway.
You make sure you are well clear as he slithers into the room, knife at the ready.
He's a serpentine little dandy, all darting speed and slitty eyes. Watching from a nearby doorway, you see him leading the girl away. You wait some time before investigating further. Mr. Muscles is dead, his guts ripped open, throat slashed. Nothing left of his gear except a couple of dirty T-shirts. Blood-soaked.
No thanks.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell Mr. Muscles that the girl has a disease. Wait until he's really busy before stealing his clothes.

You clear your throat, and mention she's not as clean as she claims.
That did the trick. He grabs the girl by her throat, lifts her from the ground, and shakes her violently. Judging that this is as good time as any, you dart in, and grab his pile of clothes. Need to check the pockets for useful items.
Mr. Muscles, as it turns out, can multitask. He notices you, and lashes out with his foot, trying to trip you. Realizing that you're going to be trapped, you spin around, and dive out through the open door.
It's a rough landing. But you stagger groggily to your feet, and run down the hallway before he can catch up.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's the traveling pimp. The one with the rotten breath. He's hustling for business up the street. The girl must be nearby.
Before you can move, he spots you. Predictably, he starts hitting you up for medicines, food, and money. Times haven't been good, apparently.
You shoulder him off, but wonder about the girl. Probably in the abandoned apartment over there. You noticed some foot traffic going in an out. Rough-looking ones among them.
Probably not a clever move to investigate. Still, you feel some obligation to check up on her.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Take a look. The girl's had it rough. You owe it to her to at least check that she's okay.

Carefully, cautiously, you creep in the back way. You find your way over to a vantage point covering the room's entrance, and wait until her customer leaves. There's a brief window before the next one arrives.
The girl is glad to see you. She knows she's trapped in a living hell, but she appreciates your concern.
She thrusts some money at you, and waves you away. She's doing a poor job of hiding tears, but there isn't time to console her before the next customer walks in.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Take a look. The girl's had it rough. You owe it to her to at least check that she's okay.

Carefully, cautiously, you creep in the back way. You find your way over to a vantage point covering the room's entrance, and wait until her customer leaves. There's a brief window before the next one arrives.
The girl is glad to see you. She knows she's trapped in a living hell, but she appreciates your concern.
She thrusts some money at you, and waves you away. She's doing a poor job of hiding tears, but there isn't time to console her before the next customer walks in.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask the pimp about the girl. Inquire about her health. Can you do anything to help?

You ask if there's anything you can do to help the girl.
Sure you can help her! Food, water, medicines, money. Anything and everything. The pimp is jumping up and down with excitement as you rummage through your things.
He refuses to allow you to see the girl, though. But he insists that he'll pass whatever he can to her. After expenses, of course.
Disgusted, you stop looking, and take your leave.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The pimp and his "goods" have bought you enough trouble already. Keep walking.

Nothing but trouble. You keep walking, and don't look back.
Should have done this a while ago. Let the pimp and his girl sink to the bottom of the cesspool. Do you care?

table.name: encounters
table.column: That "special" mushroom you came across, give it to the pimp. Tell him that it'll fix his girl.

You'd almost forgotten about it. Not even sure where you got it from. One of those special mushrooms that have you talking to the fairies, right before you drop dead from toxic shock.
However, it's emetic. Most people would vomit it up before this happens, but not if you grind it down and mix with water first. You tell the pimp to make sure he gives it an extra good stir before handing it over. Guaranteed to cure anything.
Walking off, you count the money he's paid you for your "cure".

table.name: encounters
table.column: That "special" mushroom you came across, give it to the pimp. Tell him that it'll fix his girl.

You'd almost forgotten about it. Not even sure where you got it from. One of those special mushrooms that have you talking to the fairies, right before you drop dead from toxic shock.
However, it's emetic. Most people would vomit it up before this happens, but not if you grind it down and mix with water first. You tell the pimp to make sure he gives it an extra good stir before handing it over. Guaranteed to cure anything.
Walking off, you count the money he's paid you for your "cure".

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A skinny, shadowy figure calls out to you from a doorway as you walk past, demanding something to eat. His bare arms are covered in track marks. Whatever he's on, it isn't good.
Dealers. Selling homemade hooch and dubious drugs to all comers. He's not the first that you've run into today. Seedy, skinny, and sick, the lot of them. That's what happens when you partake of your own goods. Hunching your shoulders, you keep moving.
"Hey, man, if you won't help me, how about my kid? He's real hungry." Turning, you see a sickly young boy peeking out from behind the dealer's legs.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask the kid to approach you. Give him all of the food cache you just found.

The kid eagerly approaches you, but then doesn't want to leave. Thinks you're a better bet than his flaky dad. So do you, but you aren't in the kid-minding business.
Fending him off with more food, you take your leave. At the last moment, the boy dashes up to you, gives you a hug of thanks, and drops something into your pocket, out of sight of his deadbeat dealer dad.
Walking off, you wonder what it was.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask the kid to approach you. Give him all of the food cache you just found.

The kid eagerly approaches you, but then doesn't want to leave. Thinks you're a better bet than his flaky dad. So do you, but you aren't in the kid-minding business.
Fending him off with more food, you take your leave. At the last moment, the boy dashes up to you, gives you a hug of thanks, and drops something into your pocket, out of sight of his deadbeat dealer dad.
Walking off, you wonder what it was.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw some food the kid's way. You've found some extra. Hope the dealer doesn't take it.

The dealer grabs the food, and immediately devours it, leaving the boy nothing. You pause, trying to hold down your rising anger. The dealer grabs the boy, and deliberately belts him, needling you even more.
Suppressing your feelings with difficulty, you cautiously back away. He's deliberately trying to provoke you. Probably has an ace up his sleeve.
Each time he hits the boy, you wince. Once you're far enough away, you turn your back in disgust, and leave. The hell is up with this place?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hey, feed your own kid, fella. Keep walking.

There's plenty of kids in need: kids without parents, kids starving, kids dying of disease. What do you want me to do, help them all?
Not my problem.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go back and punch the pathetic dealer to the ground. That's no way to treat kids.

You knew it was a mistake the moment you neared the dealer. He didn't exhibit any signs of fear. Not even a flinch.
No, the snake was smiling. An evil, predatory smile. Kid's already gone, and it's too late to change course.
Your punch misses, the dealer's knife finding soft flesh. Recoiling backwards, you fend off another stabbing blow. The dealer's more agile than fragile.
You're cut twice more before finally connecting. Dazed, he staggers long enough for you to get clear.
He's hurt you. Badly.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go back and punch the pathetic dealer to the ground. That's no way to treat kids.

You knew it was a mistake the moment you neared the dealer. He didn't exhibit any signs of fear. Not even a flinch.
No, the snake was smiling. An evil, predatory smile. Kid's already gone, and it's too late to change course.
Your punch misses, the dealer's knife finding soft flesh. Recoiling backwards, you fend off another stabbing blow. The dealer's more agile than fragile.
You're cut twice more before finally connecting. Dazed, he staggers long enough for you to get clear.
He's hurt you. Badly.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Another dealer. This one hasn't got any sick kids. The last one was slight, but wiry. Gave you the heebie jeebies.
This one looks suitably undernourished to be innocuous. He's trying to interest you in a hit of A-juice. Never heard of it.
"Blend of distilled whiskey and red algae," says the man. "Guaranteed to turn your frontal lobe into mush." The sales pitch sounds really wooden, not to mention unappealing. Is this guy for real?
"Not your scene," you inform him. You walk on, keeping a watchful eye on him. But something's wrong. He's silently mouthing words at you, over and over. "Help. Help me!"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hard to tell what kind of mess he's got himself into. It's a big ask, but you're willing to help.

He stands there, alternatively repeating his sales pitch and then switching to the silent "Help me"s. Crazy? Pumped full of his own concoctions?
To satisfy you own curiosity, you walk around to the side of the building and peer through a broken window. Your view is partially blocked, but you see enough to realize that he's rigged to blow. Wired up to an iSlab that's connected to a lump of something big enough to rip the house apart. Looks like his feet are the key. Move them and he'll trigger the bomb. Why has somebody gone to all that trouble? Pretty extreme for a lowly door dealer, isn't it?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hard to tell what kind of mess he's got himself into. It's a big ask, but you're willing to help.

He stands there, alternatively repeating his sales pitch and then switching to the silent "Help me"s. Crazy? Pumped full of his own concoctions?
To satisfy you own curiosity, you walk around to the side of the building and peer through a broken window. Your view is partially blocked, but you see enough to realize that he's rigged to blow. Wired up to an iSlab that's connected to a lump of something big enough to rip the house apart. Looks like his feet are the key. Move them and he'll trigger the bomb. Why has somebody gone to all that trouble? Pretty extreme for a lowly door dealer, isn't it?

table.name: encounters
table.column: So he's got problems? Who doesn't? Keep walking.

You fail to think of a single reason why you'd want to help a drug-dealing door scum like him. It's not an especially difficult decision, that one. By the time you make it to the next intersection, you've already forgotten him.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Drug-dealing scum, makes you sick. Tell him what you'll do if he doesn't get out of your face.

You angrily tell him how his teeth will soon be on a one-way journey out of another, darker part of his anatomy if he doesn't stop bothering you. Up close, you notice that he is all sweat and twitches. Gross.
Remembering the last devious door dealer, you step back carefully, before turning and getting the heck out of there. Can't be too careful.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Man's probably psychotic. A danger to all. Lay him out with the hardest punch you can manage.

You head straight for him, and he offers no resistance. Just a look of stunned horror as he topples backwards from your right hook.
There's a brief moment where you hear him scream before all other noise is blotted out by a tremendous explosion that picks you up, and hurls you bodily down the street.
Slamming into the broken pavement, you lie there as all manner of flying rubble lands on top of you. You stand, head buzzing, only to wince in pain. Something might be broken. So painful you almost black out. Holy heck, what just happened?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Dealers. Nothing but trouble. When you see this one collapse halfway through his spiel, you don't give it another thought, and leave. Let him die where he lies, blood oozing from his nostrils.
Well, you would've left. Still could, if it weren't for the kid. Imploring you to help his daddy. Tugging at your arm. Pulling you in.
Why is it that the bottom dwellers always have such cute kids?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Well, shucks. You're a sucker for kids. Yeah, okay, you'll see what you can do for Daddy.

Can't be sure, but it looks like Daddy has ODed on some very heavy medicine. Not much you can do for him.
The kid is another matter. You're pretty sure he's already reached the same conclusion. And he won't let go of you. Looks like he's chosen you to be his surrogate parent.
Reaching down, you pat him on the head, and say a few soothing words. The situation, though, is becoming tricky. How the heck are you going to look after a kid, when you can barely manage to look after yourself? The kid, sensing your unease, bolts back into the house.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Well, shucks. You're a sucker for kids. Yeah, okay, you'll see what you can do for Daddy.

Can't be sure, but it looks like Daddy has ODed on some very heavy medicine. Not much you can do for him.
The kid is another matter. You're pretty sure he's already reached the same conclusion. And he won't let go of you. Looks like he's chosen you to be his surrogate parent.
Reaching down, you pat him on the head, and say a few soothing words. The situation, though, is becoming tricky. How the heck are you going to look after a kid, when you can barely manage to look after yourself? The kid, sensing your unease, bolts back into the house.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Well, shucks. You're a sucker for kids. Yeah, okay, you'll see what you can do for Daddy.

Can't be sure, but it looks like Daddy has ODed on some very heavy medicine. Not much you can do for him.
The kid is another matter. You're pretty sure he's already reached the same conclusion. And he won't let go of you. Looks like he's chosen you to be his surrogate parent.
Reaching down, you pat him on the head, and say a few soothing words. The situation, though, is becoming tricky. How the heck are you going to look after a kid, when you can barely manage to look after yourself? The kid, sensing your unease, bolts back into the house.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Well, shucks. You're a sucker for kids. Yeah, okay, you'll see what you can do for Daddy.

Can't be sure, but it looks like Daddy has ODed on some very heavy medicine. Not much you can do for him.
The kid is another matter. You're pretty sure he's already reached the same conclusion. And he won't let go of you. Looks like he's chosen you to be his surrogate parent.
Reaching down, you pat him on the head, and say a few soothing words. The situation, though, is becoming tricky. How the heck are you going to look after a kid, when you can barely manage to look after yourself? The kid, sensing your unease, bolts back into the house.

table.name: encounters
table.column: One thing's for sure, this is a story that ain't going to have a happy ending. Sorry kid, got to go.

Stick around, and the situation is only going to get complicated. Sure, it's hard to leave the kid there crying over his daddy, but what can you do? No matter what, don't get involved. Let somebody else deal with it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Best thing you can do for Junior is give him some tough love. Daddy's a goner. Give it to him straight.

The kid doesn't appreciate the hard facts of life. He bursts into tears when you explain that Daddy's going to heaven.
Of course, you know full well that Daddy's going straight to whatever far off corner of hell they reserve for scumbag drug dealers, but you keep that part to yourself.
"Learn to live with the pain, kid."
You hope the kid can take care of himself. Jump straight into the deep end, that's the best way to learn. When you next see him, he'll probably be flogging noxious chemicals for profit, just like dear ol' Daddy.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Damned kid. Get out of here! Kick him away from you. Doesn't he know you don't like people touching you?

The kid's too fast. Every time you try to kick him clear, you end up connecting with nothing but swirling eddies of air. He's still clutching onto your leg, too. Bloody annoying.
You reach down, scruff him by the hair, and heave him back inside the door.
He lands in a bundle of arms and legs, and doesn't reappear. Got the message, thankfully. But he left you a present: sneezed blood all over your face. Turns out he was bleeding from the nose.
Just like dad.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Damned kid. Get out of here! Kick him away from you. Doesn't he know you don't like people touching you?

The kid's too fast. Every time you try to kick him clear, you end up connecting with nothing but swirling eddies of air. He's still clutching onto your leg, too. Bloody annoying.
You reach down, scruff him by the hair, and heave him back inside the door.
He lands in a bundle of arms and legs, and doesn't reappear. Got the message, thankfully. But he left you a present: sneezed blood all over your face. Turns out he was bleeding from the nose.
Just like dad.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Enclaver chained to a gas pump.

Gas stations have all been drained of their liquid gold. This one may have been empty before the crash, by the looks of it. Barely any working cars left to tell whether gas or fuel cells were the mainstay.
The pumps are still there, though. A man in a tattered, filthy suit is chained to the nearest one. Calls out to you to free him. Says they've left him like this. He's worried the crows will peck out his eyes, once they figure out he is immobile.
Pinned to his chest is a sign in big, visible letters: "Don't touch. Property of Martha's Army!"
You ask him what he did to upset them. "Had a trolley full of iSlabs. Was taking them to the market," he replies.
Peculiar tone of voice. Equal parts indignant, proud, and demanding. You get the feeling that he's trouble.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Unchain him. Might take a while as it doesn't look like you can pick the locks.

You try to unbind him, but he's been chained in such a manner that you can't get any purchase. Not without risking breaking bones in the man's body, anyway.
He makes it abundantly clear that you should release him "forthwith without any harm or disfigurement". There is an unspoken assumption of "or else".
Who talks like that out here? And you idly wonder what the heck "or else" could be when he's stuck here, chained to a gas pump.
In the end, you have to give up. Sometimes helping people just isn't in the cards.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Talk to him. Find out more about his situation. Help if it's warranted.

You try to talk to him. But the conversation isn't reassuring. Mostly threats. He knows people. They'll come after you. He's an important official in an enclave. Why aren't you helping him? His family has a long memory.
You say little, taking it all in. Eventually, you ask him if he'd like you to help.
