A simple please would have sufficed. Maybe even a reply in the affirmative. But no. More threats.
Nothing but hassle, this one. As you leave, he viciously kicks out and catches you in the back of the knee. Caught off-balance, you fall heavily onto the ground.
You pick yourself up, the sign on his chest his only shield from your wrath. You hope that the limp isn't permanent.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Talk to him. Find out more about his situation. Help if it's warranted.

You try to talk to him. But the conversation isn't reassuring. Mostly threats. He knows people. They'll come after you. He's an important official in an enclave. Why aren't you helping him? His family has a long memory.
You say little, taking it all in. Eventually, you ask him if he'd like you to help.
A simple please would have sufficed. Maybe even a reply in the affirmative. But no. More threats.
Nothing but hassle, this one. As you leave, he viciously kicks out and catches you in the back of the knee. Caught off-balance, you fall heavily onto the ground.
You pick yourself up, the sign on his chest his only shield from your wrath. You hope that the limp isn't permanent.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Walk on. You don't want to mess with Martha's Army.
Nope. Not today. You only play hero on Fridays. Tough luck, guy.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Steal his shoes. He won't be needing them, and you could do with a pair.

You get to work on his shoes. His invective doesn't let up until you've stripped his feet bare. Hard to find decent shoes these days. All that's about are coarse-haired, hand-woven crap made out of varmint fur. Itch you to death.
These are manufactured from way back when. The synthetic fiber's still strong. Thanks, man.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Enclave honcho in a garbage heap.

It's rare that the movers and shakers in the enclaves leave the safety of their walls. Mostly, they send out their foot soldiers to carry out the dangerous, dirty work.
But politics forces them into the wastelands sooner or later. When there aren't any phones, the only way to do deals with your neighbours is face-to-face. And some don't make it back alive.
Like suitman chained up at the gas station. Or the one you've just spotted crawling into a dark cave of garbage, gasping for air. It's easy to tell he's a powerful enclaver from his gear. All top notch.
But he isn't going to make it. Not with the blood trail he's leaving behind him.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It's going to be a big job, but if you're patient, and careful, you might be able to ease him out into the open and patch him up.

You decide to give him a hand.
However, the decision sounded better at the time. It's not looking so appealing, up close. The man has crawled into such a tight spot that all you can do is grab him by a leg and try to haul him out of there.
You can tell by the groaning that he's still with it, but he's unable to assist. Nothing but a dead weight that gets stuck the moment his waist breeches the entrance. It's not your fault that he's wearing so many clothes.
You tug and pull, but it's clear that he's jammed up tight. Can't even push him back in. There he is, head stuck firmly in the dark, legs flopping around in the open.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It's going to be a big job, but if you're patient, and careful, you might be able to ease him out into the open and patch him up.

You decide to give him a hand.
However, the decision sounded better at the time. It's not looking so appealing, up close. The man has crawled into such a tight spot that all you can do is grab him by a leg and try to haul him out of there.
You can tell by the groaning that he's still with it, but he's unable to assist. Nothing but a dead weight that gets stuck the moment his waist breeches the entrance. It's not your fault that he's wearing so many clothes.
You tug and pull, but it's clear that he's jammed up tight. Can't even push him back in. There he is, head stuck firmly in the dark, legs flopping around in the open.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw some dirt over the blood trail. Let the man die in peace.

You absently kick dirt over the blood trail.
Should you help the guy, or not? Peering into the darkness of the cavity, you can barely make out the figure of a man. He doesn't answer when you call, nor move when you prod him with a long stick.
He's either dead, or close to it. And crawling in there to check doesn't look appealing. Besides, if you went in, you might not be able to get out again.
Sorry, guy.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Lots of blood around. Won't take the rubble scum long to find him. Them's the breaks. Keep moving.
You're going to die in there, buddy. Hope you manage to do it before they find you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Another uppity enclaver boss. Seal up the cavity entrance. Entomb him. Return for his gear once he's dead.

The problem with being boss of an enclave, is that you've got virtually unlimited power over your small domain. Tends to bring out the worst in people. How many poor enclavers have you met that have been exiled for one reason or another, just because the big boss guy said so?
He won't last long, once you seal him in. Give it a day or so, and he'll be dead. And if you hide him well enough, you can come back then to grab his gear.
Piling the rocks and rubble up over the entrance, you mutter to yourself. He's very quiet in there. You sense some movement, though, as you plunk down a particularly big rock.
Bang! Bastard has a gun in there!
Your instincts were sure right with this one. He deserves to be buried alive. Shame you can't risk finishing the job.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Another uppity enclaver boss. Seal up the cavity entrance. Entomb him. Return for his gear once he's dead.

The problem with being boss of an enclave, is that you've got virtually unlimited power over your small domain. Tends to bring out the worst in people. How many poor enclavers have you met that have been exiled for one reason or another, just because the big boss guy said so?
He won't last long, once you seal him in. Give it a day or so, and he'll be dead. And if you hide him well enough, you can come back then to grab his gear.
Piling the rocks and rubble up over the entrance, you mutter to yourself. He's very quiet in there. You sense some movement, though, as you plunk down a particularly big rock.
Bang! Bastard has a gun in there!
Your instincts were sure right with this one. He deserves to be buried alive. Shame you can't risk finishing the job.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Given your recent experiences, you'd prefer to have nothing to do with big shots from the enclaves.
But this one's right in your face, insisting that you help. He got separated from his protection detail, and lost in the urban jungle. Wants you to guide him out of here.
He promises that he, Sheriff JJ, will compensate you for your trouble.
Sounds reasonable, but the man just won't stop talking. Damn mobile jabberbox. Might as well start letting off fireworks to tell everybody where you are.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Sure, guide the sheriff back to safety. With luck, nobody will hear him.

You've already asked him twice to be quiet, but he just keeps on jabbering away. All about his enclave, and how they need a firm hand. Says he comes from a long line of lawfolk.
He's in the middle of explaining how he came to be sheriff when, bam! A bullet penetrates his right eyeball.
Down he goes. Ducking, you grab whatever you can, and bolt off into the ruins as fast as you can. Sheriff JJ won't be needing these any more.
You wonder how somebody who talked that much managed to survive this long? No wonder he had a protection detail.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Give him directions, then leave him to it.

You start explaining the route, but he won't stop talking long enough to listen to what you're saying.
Repeating the directions for a third time, you're just about to give up, when the firing starts. Bullets whack into the dirt all around you.
Sheriff JJ takes one in the chest, and slumps to the ground. You feel something tug at your side as you dive for cover.
JJ reaches over and grabs you, frightened and badly injured. And the bullets keep coming. That, you tell him, is what happens if you make too much noise around this part of town.
You dash behind cover, and leave him behind.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Give him directions, then leave him to it.

You start explaining the route, but he won't stop talking long enough to listen to what you're saying.
Repeating the directions for a third time, you're just about to give up, when the firing starts. Bullets whack into the dirt all around you.
Sheriff JJ takes one in the chest, and slumps to the ground. You feel something tug at your side as you dive for cover.
JJ reaches over and grabs you, frightened and badly injured. And the bullets keep coming. That, you tell him, is what happens if you make too much noise around this part of town.
You dash behind cover, and leave him behind.

table.name: encounters
table.column: So the law is in trouble? You'll help, for a fee.

Happy to help, but it'll cost that bottle of whiskey poking out of his pack.
Reluctantly, the good Sheriff agrees, and then spends the next five minutes loudly berating you for your lack of public spirit, even as you lead him through the maze of streets. He's threatening to have his "deputies" arrest you, just as soon as you can take him to them.
"Sure, buddy, just be quiet."
But he won't. Keeps going on and on. If there is anyone in the town who hasn't yet heard Sheriff JJ, you'd be very surprised.
Reaching a corner, you tell him that all he has to do is walk down the street, and he's home and hosed. He isn't, of course, but you've had enough. From here on in, the Sheriff walks alone.

table.name: encounters
table.column: This way, Mr. Sheriff. Down that street and to the right. The cannibals will make you feel welcome.

He's pleased with your help. So pleased that he can't stop slapping you on your back and telling you what a heck of a guy you are. Promises to deputize you if you ever want a job.
Off he goes, still shouting words of encouragement back at you. Once he reaches that far intersection, that gang of cannibals you noticed earlier will have no trouble hearing him.
Sheriff, huh? Since when are the enclaves run by self-appointed sheriffs? He'd better be packing a six gun. He's going to need it.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The crazies. Most of them die off fairly quick. No sense of self-preservation. Occasionally you find one that knows how to look after himself. Unless they get in the way, everybody just ignores them. Safer that way.
Which is what a really smart operator would want you to think. Someone able to move through the urban jungle at will, invisible in plain sight.
Could be the case with this one, talking on his phone. Yakking away, loudly, to an imaginary friend. You're pretty sure there hasn't been a working cell net out here since the big one went down.
He holds up a rolled paper cigar. "Hey, mister, can you give me a light?" Then, you notice them: scalps. Tied to his belt. Small ones. Children?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Back away. Draw your weapon, and make it clear you are prepared to use it.
The psycho ones are the worst. More dangerous than an angry mob of gangers. It doesn't take long 'til he gets the message: you aren't an easy target. Easier pickings elsewhere.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Give the man a light. Carefully. Cautiously.

Man, he's fast! King Cobra fast.
A knife flashes out of his coat before you can react. He goes down when you kick him, but you've been hurt. You break clear, and head for somewhere safe where you can inspect the wound.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Give the man a light. Carefully. Cautiously.

Man, he's fast! King Cobra fast.
A knife flashes out of his coat before you can react. He goes down when you kick him, but you've been hurt. You break clear, and head for somewhere safe where you can inspect the wound.

table.name: encounters
table.column: He's a kid killer. Do him. Now.

It's a harsh world, but you know in your bones that there's no future without children.
His act is good, but yours is better. Dumb and slow is your specialty. Gives people a false sense of confidence.
Once it's over and you've wiped the blood off, you rifle through his garments. There's at least one decent multitool.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask how much he wants for a scalp.

You nod towards the scalps and ask, "How much?"
Apparently they aren't for sale. It's obvious now that you shouldn't have even mentioned them. Extremely protective of his scalps, this one. His blank eyes narrow, shoulders hunching. He's a predator about to lunge.
Stepping back, you trip over the curb. Before you know what's happening, he's upon you, knife at your throat, crazed eyes inches from your own.
Terrified, you tense for the end. You open your eyes, and he's gone. You can barely stand from all the shaking, and you wonder: why he didn't kill you?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Another crazy.
You tense up. Been here before. This one thinks he's the postman. Mailbag, uniform, the whole nine yards. Doing the rounds to all the local enclaves. And he's asking if you have anything you'd like to mail? Maybe a friend you'd like to drop a "hello" to?
You stare at him. Who the hell's got any friends these days? Postman Pat, when you tell him that you aren't interested, drops to the ground and starts sobbing. A regular Niagara.
All he wants to do is deliver your mail. Can't you find one measly piece of mail to give?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hand him the scrap of paper you picked up recently. Tell him you'd appreciate it if he could give it to your cousin.

You fish for a scrap of paper, and hand it over.
You don't have a cousin. The scrap is a recipe for gutting and cleaning squirrels. There's no envelope. No address. None of it matters.
The crazy postman gathers up, bounds to his feet, salutes, and promptly marches off. His head high, he starts whistling.
Weird.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Pat him on the shoulder. Console him. Hey, buddy, it's not all bad.

Laying a gentle, compassionate hand on his shoulder has the same effect as jabbing him with an electric cattle prod.
Leaping to his feet, he yells at you to get the heck out of his personal space. Stop touching him, and BACK OFF! Good advice, which you don't hesitate to follow.
With a crazed snarl, he jumps straight at your throat. You fend him off with your forearm, but then he latches on with his teeth. It takes a couple of solid punches before his teeth tear out of your flesh.
Stunned, he flops backwards. Without hesitation, you get out of dodge, cursing your lack of distrust.
Man, hope he didn't have rabies.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Pathetic. What a dope. Tell him to man up and get a life!

Nothing worse than wimps. Of course, it's none of your business. But you feel obliged to help out where you can. Inject some moral fortitude into this loser hunched over on the ground before you.
Except, he's no longer hunched. A uniformed hand shoots out faster than a striking cobra, and latches onto a delicate part of your anatomy. Yanking, twisting, you try to disconnect it from your body.
In total agony, you punch and pummel his head, but he ignores it and concentrates on turning your flesh into squashed vegetable matter. In a last desperate move, you karate chop him in the side of head.
That does the job. The lights go out, and he slumps sideways, unconscious. Painfully, you hobble away.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Kick him while he's down. Hard. Bound to be something useful in that mailbag of his.

He looks like an easy mark. You shift your weight to give him a good boot.
You weren't expecting him to grab your foot, though. Pulling hard on your leg, he topples you to the ground. Before you can recover, he's all over you. Teeth latch onto you, biting some flesh clean off!
Terrified, you try and wriggle away from the madman, but he sinks his teeth into you again. You can feel him straining, trying to bite through the gristle and bone. You manage a lucky punch, and he collapses onto you.
Shoving him off in disgust, you hurry to your feet, and start running. What a nutter! Your hand holds onto your flapping skin. Blood pours out from ragged holes. What has he done to you?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Car salesman up ahead. Offering you a great deal on a one-owner, low-mileage Caddy. He's jumping out of his own skin with excitement. Pawing the rusty hulk enticingly. Telling you he'll arrange finance, and take care of the paperwork. One c-note, and you can drive it away now!
Another crazy. This one's moving fast and erratically. Holding your attention. You envision freewheeling out of the lot in a car with no engine, no wheels, no doors. No nothing.
Can't trust the crazies, so you swivel around. Fast enough to grab the kid who has just picked your pockets.
The crazy is closing in as the kid wriggles up a storm.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Let the kid go. She can have whatever she took. Smile at the crazy. Tell him you'd love to buy his car.

"Get out of here, kid!"
You've got enough trouble on your hands dealing with the crazy car salesman. The kid sprints off, taking your stuff with her. The crazy is momentarily halted by your sudden show of consumerism.
You ask him about features, how many airbags, are the seats leather, can it do a quarter mile in under ten seconds. Crazy's lapping it up like a kitten at a milk bowl.
Meanwhile, you're backing up, getting as far away from him as possible, while appearing to inspect his "hottest set of wheels this side of Motor City".
You remember the postman and cellphone talker. No way you're going to risk letting him get close.
As soon as you've got enough of a head start, you run away. Far away.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw the kid at the crazy, and get out of there.

You swing the kid around, but she doesn't want to be thrown. Like trying to throw an angry octopus. Just won't let go.
The salesman closes in while you're distracted. Next thing you know, there's a sharp pain. Damn crazy has stabbed you!
With a mighty heave, you dislodge the brat, and throw her at the crazy car salesman. Both of them tumble to the ground in a confusion of arms and legs.
By the time they recover, you're gone.

table.name: encounters
table.column: King hit the kid, drop her. Whatever she took, you want back. Threaten the crazy with violence.

Bammo! It's a solid punch that drops the kid like a sack of potatoes.
Crazy Car Salesman's not liking it. You get the feeling that he and the kid are related. So now you're dodging a furious knife-wielding maniac.
You manage to stay out of the way of the sharp end, until you trip over the bundle of skin and bones at your feet. Damn, forgot all about her. The maniac moves in, and slashes you. But then you bring him down with a kick to his knee.
Scrambling out of his way, you put some serious distance between the two of you. Who cares what the kid took from you? Right now, you just want to get clear.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Grab the kid by her scrawny neck. Use her as a shield. Snap her neck if need be.

You try to bring her to bear like a shield, but the kid hasn't read the play book. It's like trying to grab hold of a bag full of eels. With the crazy car salesman moving in fast, you've got no choice but to quiet down scrappy. Forcibly.
You wrench what you can get a hold of, and there's a cracking sound. It startles you, in fact. Hadn't heard that before.
Crazy howls in fury as you power down his kid. Rushes straight at you, knife outstretched. Manages to dig into you so deep, the knife gets stuck as he attempts to withdraw it.
You head butt him into submission, and get out of there. Once clear, you sit down, and carefully work the knife out of your flesh. Luckily it was only a multi tool. Could've been much worse.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The man's skin is covered in red, weeping pustules. The fever is tearing into him. Lying on a stinking mattress, shivering, delirious.
He's gaunt. Malnourished. His body unable to resist the disease that's consuming him. The flesh on his bare feet is torn and rotten. Oozing ulcers dot his lower legs.
It's clear that he's been abandoned. Might explain that bottle of water you stumbled across. Nobody wants to be near a dying man, especially an infected one.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Mercy killing is the only option here. Trick is to be able to do it without getting infected yourself.

In the end, you use an old, dusty pillow. Can't risk the blood spatter. In one swift move, you press it over his face.
For a dying man, he sure has a lot of energy! He's thrashing around like a shark in a bathtub. Oh, gross, there's pus flying everywhere. You wipe yourself off as best you can.
You notice a pill bottle near the mattress. Empty?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Mercy killing is the only option here. Trick is to be able to do it without getting infected yourself.

In the end, you use an old, dusty pillow. Can't risk the blood spatter. In one swift move, you press it over his face.
For a dying man, he sure has a lot of energy! He's thrashing around like a shark in a bathtub. Oh, gross, there's pus flying everywhere. You wipe yourself off as best you can.
You notice a pill bottle near the mattress. Empty?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Leave the man the bottle of water you just found. Doesn't have to be purified, he won't care...

You place the bottle alongside the mattress. You're not sure if the man registers it, but at least you tried.
There's a sudden spasm, and his arm bumps into you.
Yuck. Hope you don't catch anything.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Leave the man the bottle of water you just found. Doesn't have to be purified, he won't care...

You place the bottle alongside the mattress. You're not sure if the man registers it, but at least you tried.
There's a sudden spasm, and his arm bumps into you.
Yuck. Hope you don't catch anything.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Can't stand ill people. Gives you the heebie jeebies. Get out of there.
Smallpox? Maybe. Either way, you aren't taking any chances. You're gone. Instantly.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Looks mighty infectious. If you could scrape some of that yellow pus off and put it in a bottle... Could come in handy.

The moment you try to get a scraping, his arm spasms out at you.
Where it made contact, there's a smear of dirty blood. Terrified of what you might catch, you abandon all thoughts of the sample.
Ugh. You need to get out of here and get some water on that. Or sandpaper.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Looks mighty infectious. If you could scrape some of that yellow pus off and put it in a bottle... Could come in handy.

The moment you try to get a scraping, his arm spasms out at you.
Where it made contact, there's a smear of dirty blood. Terrified of what you might catch, you abandon all thoughts of the sample.
Ugh. You need to get out of here and get some water on that. Or sandpaper.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Everyone thinks that the rubble scum have got your number. If not them, then slavers will cart you off to a life of servitude.
No one realizes that the biggest threat out here in the wastelands is disease. Persistent filth, nonexistent sanitation, and people huddled together for safety add up to bug heaven.
Enclaves in particular are ruthless. The moment you show a rash, you're out the gate. On your own. It's the only way to limit the contagion.
You could be wrong, but you thought the last one you saw had smallpox. This one, who knows? He's sweating rivers, coughing blood, and shivering.
But he's going to give you an entire crate of ammo if you help him. He's sitting right on it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Help the man. If you don't, who will?

"Thanks, buddy," he croaks, as you ease him into a more comfortable position, "that's real kind of you."
While you stand there considering what else you can do, he presents with his jaundiced hand a small parcel. "Take it, I'm not going to last much longer."
Opening it, you find a number of ammunition clips bundled up in an oily rag. After another bout of rasping coughs, the man taps the box he's sitting on. "Nothing here, it's empty. Better get out of here before you end up like me."
You don't need any encouragement.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Help the man. If you don't, who will?

"Thanks, buddy," he croaks, as you ease him into a more comfortable position, "that's real kind of you."
While you stand there considering what else you can do, he presents with his jaundiced hand a small parcel. "Take it, I'm not going to last much longer."
Opening it, you find a number of ammunition clips bundled up in an oily rag. After another bout of rasping coughs, the man taps the box he's sitting on. "Nothing here, it's empty. Better get out of here before you end up like me."
You don't need any encouragement.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're more worried about catching something than humanitarianism. Leave him to cough up a storm on his own.
Anyone looking like that is bound to be contagious. He could be sitting on the crown jewels for all you care. Keep moving.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Knock him off the box of ammo. He won't put up any resistance.

A kick is overkill. A stiff breeze would've done it.
No matter. He's sprawled, coughing and bleeding, and you're free to crack open that big box of goodies.
Except it's empty. Typical. A lesser man might have taken his frustrations out on the two-faced sicko, but you're made of sterner stuff. Instead, you kick the crap out of the box before walking off.
Life isn't fair. No, sir.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Knock him off the box of ammo. He won't put up any resistance.

A kick is overkill. A stiff breeze would've done it.
No matter. He's sprawled, coughing and bleeding, and you're free to crack open that big box of goodies.
Except it's empty. Typical. A lesser man might have taken his frustrations out on the two-faced sicko, but you're made of sterner stuff. Instead, you kick the crap out of the box before walking off.
Life isn't fair. No, sir.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw rocks at the sicko until he gets off the box and leaves.

It doesn't take much. A couple of well-aimed rocks to the head, and he gets to his feet and stumbles off, leaving a mess of blood and muck behind.
You claw open the ammunition box, only to find that it's empty. You've been conned. Something is wrong with the world when sick people lie to you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You've stumbled across a couple. Not looking healthy, either. Though the woman is pregnant.
They insist that they've recovered, and want your help to make it back to their enclave. They've been hiding in the ceiling crawl space, waiting for a friendly face. It's been a while since you looked in a mirror. Are you that unimposing?
Sensing that they can trust you, they're all hopeful smiles. In between coughs, that is. If their enclave has expelled them, it must have been for a reason. Might be contagious.
"No, no," they say. "We're over it. We want to live. Help us."

table.name: encounters
table.column: They say that they aren't contagious? They look like decent, honest people. Do what you can.

The man is able to lower himself to the floor, but the woman's going to need all the spare hands on offer.
Hit by a sudden spasm of coughs, she's unable to stand on her own. She doubles over in pain, supported by her husband. Backing off, you edge slowly to the door.
You're happy to help the healthy, but these two don't qualify. The man, noticing your movements, asks that you at least leave him the crowbar that you found outside. Reluctantly, you lay it down on the ground, before surging out into the clean air.
Hey, what's that glinting in the sunlight over yonder?

table.name: encounters
table.column: They say that they aren't contagious? They look like decent, honest people. Do what you can.

The man is able to lower himself to the floor, but the woman's going to need all the spare hands on offer.
Hit by a sudden spasm of coughs, she's unable to stand on her own. She doubles over in pain, supported by her husband. Backing off, you edge slowly to the door.
You're happy to help the healthy, but these two don't qualify. The man, noticing your movements, asks that you at least leave him the crowbar that you found outside. Reluctantly, you lay it down on the ground, before surging out into the clean air.
Hey, what's that glinting in the sunlight over yonder?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Their cough doesn't sound that bad. Give them directions to get out of town safely.

It takes a while for them to lower themselves down. Lots of plaster dust swirling around, and both of them are coughing up a storm.
Wisely, you choose to wait outside. When they finally emerge, you hastily give them directions. "Got that?"
Dazed eyes. Pallid skin. Still coughing. Doubtful.
You're about to run through it once more, when you are forced to sidestep as the woman unexpectedly vomits. A seething mass of parasitic worms, searching for a new host, cover the ground in front of her.
Ugh! That's going to be nightmare fodder for a few. You're outta there.

table.name: encounters
table.column: When was the last time you met people who'd recovered from a bout of disease? This pair sound like another germ factory. Get out of there.

Judging by the pair of insipid, drawn faces peering down at you, these two are about as healthy as the rotting cow carcass you passed earlier.
Holding your breath, you head for fresh air.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Yeah, you can be trusted. Sure you can. "Come on down, folks. Let me help you." Don't mind that big iron bar behind my back.

You keep the crowbar well out of sight. Wait until her husband, who comes down first, turns to help her.
Whack. Whack.
Standing on their still-twitching bodies, you hoist yourself up into the cavity, searching for loot. Nothing but a ragged old blanket, barely intact. Well, at least you get to keep the crowbar you found.
Stepping over the bodies, you head out the door. Rule number one in the wastelands: don't trust anyone. Especially not you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A tank. Long since out of juice. Hexagonal holes here and there give away the adaptive camouflage, pried off by enterprising tinkerers.
Nobody's bothered to collect the inert hulk. But then, why bother? The wars are over, nobody left here to fight them.
A wall has collapsed onto it. You can still see the turret, the imposing barrel bent downward by the force of the rubble. You run your hand over the hull. It has the texture of a hardened LCD screen.
There's a noise inside. You tap the side of the turret, and muffled yells respond. People are inside! Squatters trapped when the wall fell? It's too old a wreck to be the crew.
You size up the task. It's big. There's a lot of rubble to shift on your own. You'd be visible and vulnerable while working on it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You might not have enough energy or time to rescue them, but you have to try. Hopefully you won't be seen.

An hour into the task, and you're worn out. There's just too much rubble to move. It isn't going to work. The hammering from inside the tank is starting to fade as the initial excitement wears off.
How do you tell them? Do you even bother telling them? What would it be like being buried alive, knowing that your only hope has given up?
Confused and frustrated, you sit down and try to figure out a plan. You're interrupted by a gang of slavers. On the prowl for new stock. Time to go. You glance back at the tank full of condemned people. Bad dreams tonight, guaranteed.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You might not have enough energy or time to rescue them, but you have to try. Hopefully you won't be seen.

An hour into the task, and you're worn out. There's just too much rubble to move. It isn't going to work. The hammering from inside the tank is starting to fade as the initial excitement wears off.
How do you tell them? Do you even bother telling them? What would it be like being buried alive, knowing that your only hope has given up?
Confused and frustrated, you sit down and try to figure out a plan. You're interrupted by a gang of slavers. On the prowl for new stock. Time to go. You glance back at the tank full of condemned people. Bad dreams tonight, guaranteed.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tap out some made-up morse code on the turret. They'll puzzle over it for days, but you'll leave them with hope.

You could be telling them that they've won the lottery for all you know.
No matter. You bet they're as ignorant of proper morse code as you are. It'll cheer them up, anyhow. Keep them going another couple of days. They're probably in there thinking that you've gone off to organize a work gang, or hire a damn bulldozer.
Mr. Happy, that's you. Bringing cheer into other people's miserable lives.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Walk away. You're not spending the next week digging.

Going to be short of liquids in there real fast. Isn't 70% of the human body water?
With that lot, survival is a qualified term. Someone in there may survive, at least a little longer than the person they slurped from.
You're glad that you don't have to watch it happen. It's going get ugly.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ram rubbish down all the air intakes. Seal it off. A quicker death would be doing them a favor.

The pile of rubble is just too big. It isn't going to be shifted this side of the next apocalypse. Imagine what you'd feel when faced with a long, anguished death? Asphyxiate quickly, or linger on in your own private hell for days?
You try to ignore the frantic hammering coming from inside as you jam the intakes, one by one.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You hear voices. Calling. Shouting. Coming from under your feet.
A building toppled just moments earlier. Took out more on its way down, like falling dominoes. You narrowly escaped being hit by flying debris. Decided to head straight into the billowing cloud of dust. Best place to hide from others moving in to investigate.
Standing there ,coughing up cement dust, you estimate four of them. Trapped beneath the rubble in an air pocket.
Kneeling, you can just barely see them, and it wouldn't take that much work to free up a crawl way. But it's risky. Dust cloud won't last forever.
There are other voices out there in the cloud. Hostile ones.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Start digging! Nobody deserves to be buried alive.

You wish you had a handkerchief handy. That dust is really annoying.
Digging fast, you make it about halfway before another tremor interrupts you. The crawl space collapses, and you are barely able to make it out in time.
Lungs bursting, you sit there drawing in huge breaths of cloying concrete dust. Muffled voices call, imploring you to take up your digging once more. But you can't. It's not those voices you are listening to. There are others, and it sounds like they've formed a skirmish line that's heading in your direction.
Leaving good people buried alive isn't one of your better moments, but what can you do? The gadget you found in the rubble is small consolation.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Who do they think you are? Getting out of the dust cloud without being seen is going to be challenging enough.

You can hear the hostiles spreading out, circling the dust cloud. If you don't move fast, you'll be trapped.
Without hesitation, you head off. The dust clears unexpectedly, revealing a ganger right in front of you. He lands a blow before you can react. It's painful, but you manage to stay on your feet, and dodge past him.
There are others. Running, you make it to a side street, out of sight before you get tangled in a hopeless fight.
Damn! If it wasn't for those trapped gophers, you'd have been well clear before those gangers arrived.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Call out to them. Help is on the way. All they have to do is make noise to pinpoint their location. As much noise as possible. You'll need a distraction to escape.

You call out, and that does the trick. They're hollering and shouting loud enough to be heard, even through the layers of rubble. All you need now is to judge which way the predators are coming from, and head in the opposite direction.
You're sure that whoever arrives shortly will take care of the trapped enclavers. One way or another.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell them you need something to dig with. Can they poke that rifle out to you? You promise you'll dig like a demented dog, just as soon as they hand it over.

You ask for the rifle, to help with the digging.
It's a struggle. For a moment, it doesn't look like it's going to fit. But some enthusiastic hammering and teamwork later, it breaks through the gap in the rubble.
Rifle in hand, you urge them to move back while you get to digging. Which will be just as soon as you've had a refreshing cup of coffee.
Now, where did you leave your mug? Must be over there. Hang in there, people!
Once you make it to safety, clear of the dust, you check the rifle. It always pays to check your equipment.
Damn! The barrel is bent!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Tremors roll through the ruins every now and then. Collapsing infrastructure, sinkholes, and battle are always a threat, even today.
A gaping hole in the plaza ahead shows signs of a big one in the past. Footprints lead straight to the edge of the fissure. Probably someone on night maneuvers, and whammo! Likely never saw it coming.
You lie down, and peer over the edge. There's a man sprawled on a ledge. A fair way down, too. He waves at you, and indicates a broken leg. There's a vine here. The damn things grow like weeds these days. Literal urban jungle.
It might be long enough to reach him. But it could also take a while. And the middle of the plaza's not good for cover.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Lower the vine, and climb down. Hang on, guy!

Lowering yourself gently over the rim, you test the strength of the vine.
Snap! It's a blind scramble to grab anything you can. White-knuckled, you pull yourself up and out. Even Tarzan wouldn't have trusted life and limb to such a flaky piece of vegetation.
The man peers up at you from the dark, resigned to his now inevitable fate. Without a word, he pulls something from a pocket, and throws it up to your outstretched hands. An ammo clip.
Nodding your thanks, you quickly depart the exposed plaza. It's not often you find honor out here. Too bad a little bit dies with him down there.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Not sure about the vine, but you lower it anyway. He'll have to climb it himself.

He gets points for trying.
He latches onto the lowered vine, and he starts hauling himself up, hand over hand.
But the vine snaps. He thumps back down onto the ledge, and cries out in pain. You can see his broken leg, trapped under his body, the angle all wrong. He's making a lot of noise, even from down there.
You can't afford to stay in the exposed plaza. It's a mess. You'll be back, you promise.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Help him? Way out there in the open? With your head down a hole? No thanks.

There's no point exposing yourself to danger in order to help a lost cause. You don't like walking away from someone in need, but that's what it takes if you want to stay alive.
Maybe one day you'll meet your maker and pay the price. But not today.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Lower the vine. Not all the way. Three-quarters should do it. He'll have to jump, broken leg or not. Strive to succeed, guy. Strive to succeed.

What people in dire straits really need, you realize, is company and a goal. Something to take their mind off their terrible predicament, and their imminent, looming death.
Well, that must make you Mr. Fabulous, because you're covering all the bases: shouting out encouragement, and jiggling the vine just out of reach.
"Come on, guy. Jump!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You watch three enclavers climb down a sewer manhole, one by one. None climb back out, and each is visibly distressed before entering. There are two left now, and they're agitated.
You peer down into the sewer. The three enclavers who climbed down are lying at the bottom of the ladder, unconscious. Or worse.
Your nose wrinkles in disgust. Rotten egg smell.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Take a long, deep breath, and climb down. The least you can do is check to see if they're alive.

Rotten egg smell. Probably hydrogen sulfide, from all the bacteria eating fetid, rotten sewage.
You make it to the bottom of the ladder, but you're not sure how long you can hold your breath. The risk is for naught, though, if you don't at least check for a pulse.
Twenty seconds later, and you know they're goners. Your lungs are bursting. The ladder looks impossibly high. With your vision starting to blur, you focus on putting your hand on the next rung. Don't know if you're going to make it.
You black out, unsure if you are out of the sewer or still inside...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Take a long, deep breath, and climb down. The least you can do is check to see if they're alive.

Rotten egg smell. Probably hydrogen sulfide, from all the bacteria eating fetid, rotten sewage.
You make it to the bottom of the ladder, but you're not sure how long you can hold your breath. The risk is for naught, though, if you don't at least check for a pulse.
Twenty seconds later, and you know they're goners. Your lungs are bursting. The ladder looks impossibly high. With your vision starting to blur, you focus on putting your hand on the next rung. Don't know if you're going to make it.
You black out, unsure if you are out of the sewer or still inside...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Convince the remaining enclavers to slide the manhole cover back in place. Their friends are gone. Climbing down is a death sentence.

Hydrogen sulfide. Deadly stuff. The three men down there are gone already. Anyone else climbs down, and they're goners, too.
Best thing to do is to cover up the manhole. Don't want anyone else coming along, thinking there's something interesting down there.
The remaining enclavers reluctantly agree. Tears streaming down their faces, they head off, but not before leaving you with one of the dead men's food.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell them the gas is dissipating, and to try in a few minutes.

You tell them the gas is blowing over, but you know better. There isn't any ventilation down there. It's a death trap.
The first enclaver climbs hastily down to help his friends, and only succeeds in immediately losing consciousness. The remaining enclaver distracted, you shove him down the manhole, too.
Before you can grab their packs, though, a trio of cannibals round the corner. You're spotted!
Damn. Have to leave those packs behind. Too heavy.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell them that they'll be okay if they move fast, and don't take their packs. You'll stand by and keep a lookout.

Taking your word on the gas, and grateful that you're prepared to help, the enclavers slide down the ladder to rescue their friends.
You watch them die. It's so easy, you almost feel giddy. Their packs are heavy, but you drag them off into a nearby building so you can loot them in safety.
You pick the wrong building, though. A couple of rubble scum come boiling out of a supply room just as you enter. Rushing you with crowbars raised, it's all you can do to drop the packs and run. Even that's not quick enough.
You take a hit as you leave. It aches, but you've got to keep moving.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell them that they'll be okay if they move fast, and don't take their packs. You'll stand by and keep a lookout.

Taking your word on the gas, and grateful that you're prepared to help, the enclavers slide down the ladder to rescue their friends.
You watch them die. It's so easy, you almost feel giddy. Their packs are heavy, but you drag them off into a nearby building so you can loot them in safety.
You pick the wrong building, though. A couple of rubble scum come boiling out of a supply room just as you enter. Rushing you with crowbars raised, it's all you can do to drop the packs and run. Even that's not quick enough.
You take a hit as you leave. It aches, but you've got to keep moving.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Cries for help waft faintly out of a storm grate. Kneeling, you strain to hear better. Distress. Definitely somebody in distress. A woman?
You test the grate, and it's loose. Easily removed. The dark entrance down into the sewer system awaits. You vividly recall the enclavers who climbed down a similar ladder. The bodies piled high at the base.
Not all sewers are full of toxic gas, though. Your nose gives a tentative all clear, but there are other dangers. Met a man once who swore there were rats down there, big as hogs.
The woman's scream loudly intrudes. She's moving closer.

table.name: encounters
table.column: She needs a hand. Don't hesitate.

As soon as you're down in the sewer, you realize you've made a mistake. The woman, running erratically out of the dark depths, is blind with terror. One of her arms is missing, the severed stump raw and streaming blood. You push her roughly up the ladder, urging her to hurry up. As you reach the final rungs, you feel a rush of air on your legs.
Against your better judgement, you glance down, and almost lose your grip. The eyes. Awful, searing, red-tinged eyes.
It misses, and you scrabble onto the surface, slamming the grid shut. You haul as many heavy objects as you can find onto it. By the time your frenzy of adrenaline is over, the woman has, unfortunately, bled to death.
Exhausted, shaking like a leaf, you search the corpse for loot before staggering away.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You shout down into the sewers. "This way, lady, this way!" If she can make it to the ladder in time, she'll be safe.

You call down to her, and she hears you. She's terror-stricken, but audibly relieved.
You keep shouting, guiding her to the ladder. There she is! She grabs the lower rungs, giving you a brief look of gratitude, then she shudders, and her face goes blank with surprise.
She's still there, looking upwards. But from the waist down, there's... nothing. A mess of entrails and blood.
Blinking, you try and recall what you just saw. But you can't. Even though you were looking directly at her when it happened, you're struggling to remember anything moments later. Was what you saw so terrifying that your mind has blanked it out already? Holy shit.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Huge rats, huh? That'd be something to see. If you stay quiet and still, you might just get a glimpse.

Quietly, you watch the scene unfold.
She's terrified. Panicking. And almost in sight. You peer down into the murky pool of light at the base of the ladder. You can't wait to see what's chasing her.
Hold on, what's that? The woman is suddenly silent. A strange noise is all you can hear. Like a dog biting through a slab of meat in a bucket of water. A sloshing, moist, crunching sound. Shaking sounds. A dog shaking off the water?
A sense of uneasiness washes over you. Dogs don't make that amount of noise. Not unless they are the size of Volkswagens.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Cover the grate. Haul that big slab of bent metal over it. Can't have anything climbing out of there. Who knows what's chasing her?

No way you're letting anything out of that grate. You find the biggest, heaviest thing you can.
A distorted transaxle fits the bill. It's heavy. One of those land-crawler jobs, full of gearing, but you manage. You drag it over the grate. And just to make sure, you sit on top of the slab.
The woman, who is now right beneath you, yells and tugs at the grate. Even manages to jostle you and the axle a little. Man, how did she manage that? Must have muscles the size of cantaloupes!
A final, prolonged scream, and then quiet, thankfully, prevails. Ah, quiet. One of life's underappreciated qualities.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You hate being in the sewers. Didn't have a choice, though. Either dive into the darkness, or be front and center at a gang inquisition.
You've managed to find your way to another exit. A manhole up a ladder. And somebody's been using this sewer alcove as a hideaway. Big stash of food and gear at the base of the ladder. Toys, too. Probably a family laying low until they can make it out of town.
On the surface, the lid is well-camouflaged. You spot a marauding group of rubble scum immediately. They're heading your way, so you'll have to move fast.
The lid's too heavy to quickly flip back into place.

table.name: encounters
table.column: If the lid isn't replaced, the family will be robbed. That wouldn't be right, would it?

Man, this thing is heavy! No time to gradually ease it back in place, either. It's a fast lift and drop or nothing.
Clang! You've done it, but when you go to stand upright, your back protests. You force your body into motion anyway. If you don't get out of here quickly, you're toast.
Arrrgh! This hurts! What you wouldn't do for a chiropractor.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Leave the lid, and cover the hole with rubbish instead. Maybe the rubble scum won't notice.

It's pretty flimsy camouflage. Bits of broken timber and torn plastic, hastily arranged. The lid is still there, visible to all. But it's the best you can do.
Sprinting off into cover, you peer through a crack. The rubble scum aren't paying much attention to anything other than a bottle of whiskey they're sharing. One of them walks right onto the lid, stubbing his toe on the heavy metal. Cursing, he keeps moving, not wanting to miss his share of hooch.
There's a tap on your shoulder. The family. Hiding in the same building, watching the whole show. They hand over a can of soup. An expression of their gratitude. It's a rare moment when a good deed gets rewarded in the wastelands. You savor it. Maybe you'll make it to heaven after all.

table.name: encounters
table.column: All you want to do is get away from the sewers. To heck with the lid and the family. Run!

The sewers. Ugh. You barely managed to keep it together while creeping around down there. Constantly glancing over your shoulder. Sure, some people live down there. But so do the creatures. You vividly recall the woman.
There's probably a way to tell which sewers are safe, and which aren't. But as far as you're concerned, the whole lot of them are nightmare county. The family can fend for themselves, you're gone.

table.name: encounters
table.column: With luck, the rubble scum will climb down the ladder, and you can seal them in. Won't end well for the family, but hey, you'll be safe.

The rubble scum turn up half drunk. Been sharing a whiskey bottle. One of them manages to fall down the open manhole. Broken bones, by the sound of the ruckus.
The others stand around the manhole, debating. And laughing.
Five minutes later they're still at it, passing the bottle back and forth, and ribbing their injured compatriot. You give up. Nothing for it but to try and leave out the back of the building. At least they're not paying attention to their surroundings.
Nor are you. Somebody has pilfered your gear while you were concentrating on the party outside. Damn.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You've found a disused correctional facility. Heavy metal cell doors, bars, and utilitarian furniture still bolted to the floor.
Doesn't take long to see that you aren't alone. One full block of cells is occupied. Guards lounging around, all wearing torn leathers. Gangers. Met them before. They're meat market dealers. Deal mostly in slaves. All kinds. Breeders, workers, prostitutes.
Sometimes the eatin' kind. Always a big demand for those.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Whoever's in the cells needs your help. Creep closer and investigate. Risky, but maybe you can save somebody.

You manage to crawl to an old vent window near the roof, giving you a good view of the entire block. It takes a while, but you realize there is no way you are going to be able to reach the cells.
The slavers appear casual and unconcerned over possible security breaches, but you can see that it's just a facade. An elaborate trap to fill up the cells. You become concerned that the vent might be booby trapped or alarmed.
Cautiously wriggling your way back out, you manage to exit safely, but not before happening on a box taped to the roof. Must have missed it on the way in.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Looks too well-guarded. Nothing you can do here. Leave.

Slaves and slavers. Nothing new here. Anyone released from the cells is bound to be in poor condition, and unable to evade the guards.
Shrugging your shoulders, you leave. But not before snagging your foot on a protruding bolt in the floor. Like the other ones holding down the prison decor.
Man, that hurt!

table.name: encounters
table.column: Looks too well-guarded. Nothing you can do here. Leave.

Slaves and slavers. Nothing new here. Anyone released from the cells is bound to be in poor condition, and unable to evade the guards.
Shrugging your shoulders, you leave. But not before snagging your foot on a protruding bolt in the floor. Like the other ones holding down the prison decor.
Man, that hurt!

table.name: encounters
table.column: A lot of plastic rubbish around. Might be able to snag that lighter and start a fire. The toxic fumes may take care of the lot.

Plastic fumes, when there are enough of them, can knock out whole armies of slavers. If nothing else, they'll be coughing up blood for the next few days. The slaves, too, but their life is already a big pile of misery, so it won't matter.
It takes longer to get the fire going than you thought. You're not even sure if it'll crank out enough smoke. But you can't wait around to find out. Let whatever is going to be, happen. Que sera.

table.name: encounters
table.column: If you deal direct, maybe you could swing a good deal on a slave. Resell them for a profit.

Good plan. Wrong time. The moment you show your face, the slavers come a-running. And they don't look to be in a negotiating mood.
Fleeing for the exit, you make it in time, but you've had to shed some gear.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Slavers. Saw them before, at that prison. This time, they've taken over a police station. The same one you've inadvertently stumbled into.
Now you're stuck. Safely hidden, but definitely stuck. Roving guards have cut off your escape. You need a diversion.
There are cells nearby. Full ones. You can hear the slavers working over a huddle of children. The cupboard you're in is full of old cleaning chemicals and cleaning rags. And a lighter.
You hesitate. Start a blaze, and it could easily spread out of control. What about the kids?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Save them all! Start the fire, and free the kids in the resultant confusion.

You'll be a hero! Just set the fire, and round up the kids!
Unfortunately, the fire doesn't cooperate. It spreads too quickly, the chemicals combining unpredictably. You realize, too late, that you've inadvertently created a powerful accelerant.
Forced back by flames and smoke, you're unable to reach the kids.
Well, that's not strictly true. You could've, but you don't like being on fire. The only police station you could recall had one entry point into the cells. And there's lots of burning going on.
Reluctantly, you exit the building-cum-fireplace, knowing you've condemned any number of children to a fiery death. Anguished, you insist that your intentions were honorable.
But who are you kidding? Face it, you acted without thinking, and their death is now your responsibility.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Nix the fire. Too risky. Sneak out of there, quiet as a mouse.

It's touch and go, sneaking through the station. Had to duck into nearby rooms on several occasions. Took ten minutes of nervous waiting before you could climb out an open window.
Would have been a lot easier if you'd had that distraction. The kids kept making a lot of noise, but it wasn't enough. You feel bad about leaving them behind, too, but realistically, what could you have done?
You put your hand in your pocket, checking it's still there. Palmed a decent pick-up on the way out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Not sure about the fire. Unpredictable. Maybe just a little one? Enough to get you out of there.

You should've known better. No such thing as a little fire. Definitely not when dealing with chemicals.
Before you know it, the cupboard is ablaze, toxic fumes pumping throughout the station. Coughing up who knows how many carcinogens, you stumble down the hallway, and out the front door.
Nobody stops you. The slavers are too busy with self-preservation. The screams of the children, trapped in their cells, echo down the corridor behind you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Burn, baby, burn! Set the whole station alight.

You slosh all the chemicals into one big cocktail. The combo starts fuming even before you toss in the lighter.
Whoosh! The sudden eruption knocks you forcibly out of the cupboard, your eyebrows and hair badly singed. Luckily, you're bald.
The fire spreads almost as fast as you can move. Everybody's hollering and screaming. Running out of the nearest exit, you keep going until you're clear of the chaos and confusion.
You look back, and see roaring flames and thick clouds of greasy, toxic smoke. Would anyone still be alive in there? What about the kids in their cells?
To heck with them. Your skin feels raw. You've been burnt.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A deal is going down. Gangers are off-loading a dozen crying youths to some cannibals. You grimace at their fate. Pangs of guilt stab you viciously in the gut. You don't want a repeat of the police station, but there is nothing you can do.
Or is there? There's a jerrycan with some aging gas here, along with a spare lighter. You're two stories up. Jam that rag in it, and you've got an incendiary cocktail. From up here, it's bound to do some damage.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Do it. A few of the kids are bound to survive. Might even escape. You owe it to them.

Difficult to discriminate with a jerrycan full of gas. Not a precision weapon.
Down it flies. When it hits the ground, gas jets out the nozzle, instantly alight. Like an uncontrolled garden hose squirting flame and fuel in all directions. Humans running hither and yon, frightened, confused, surprised.
You notice a couple of kids sprint off into the ruins. You've done some good. It's hard, but you do your best to blot out the screams of the rest. Young flesh burns just as easily as old.
Pocketing the lighter, you leave.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Heave the jerrycan cocktail over to one side. It'll miss most everybody, but maybe the gangers will run off in fright.

Well, nobody got splashed with your homemade napalm. It caused a brief shockwave through the gangers. But not enough for any of the kids to escape.
Though you likely blew your only chance to help. You can hear the angry gangers swarming up the stairs.
Grabbing the lighter and rag, you get out of there.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Don't do it! You can't justify maiming some kids in order to save others.

Haven't you already killed enough kids? You sit back, and watch the deal proceed. The slavers get a good price for their dozen young captives. You try not to conjure up the kind of fate that awaits them.
Perhaps killing them would have been a small mercy? Torn at your own indecision, confused at whether you did the right thing, you leave, ignoring the lighter and rags.
One thing's for sure, you won't be lighting any fires for a while.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Jam the rag in really tight. That's not a cocktail, it's a bomb. Drop it out the window into the midst of them all.

Down it goes. It hits the ground, does a dead cat bounce, then BANG!
Pieces of jerrycan fly outwards in a thick atomized fog of burning fuel air mixture. Everybody gets a taste. Only those who were shielded by the bodies of the others come out of it relatively unscathed.
It's not pretty, but they were all going to die a horrible death. Or, in the case of the gangers, deserved one. You aren't overly fussed.
Sure, you might have advanced the schedule a little, but it was worth it to see the explosion.

table.name: encounters
table.column: That rusted chair's got some loose springs. Put them in those plastic bags and tie them to the handles of the jerrycan. Shrapnel. Shred everybody.

It's improvised and flaky, but hey, it worked! What a buzz. Pieces of jerrycan and heavy gauge wire shred clothes and people alike, just before they're sprayed with liquid fire.
You'd be over the moon with excitement, if it wasn't for the head wound you got. Flying spring nailed you as you leaned out the window to watch. You should have waited until it had gone off, but there is something visceral and primeval in watching explosions go.
As you tentatively poke your bleeding scalp, you feel the excitement ebb from your body. The escalating smell doesn't help.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
This place used to be one of those indoor amusement arcades. Skee ball, prize claws, and the like. It's been transformed into a carnival of blood now, though. So many bodies here, you've lost count. Even the pinball machines are draped in them. Tags on the walls are just as prevalent. Blue Frogs.
The Church of the Blue Frog. This place is probably where they torture the "heretics". The whole parlor's nothing but a mass grave.
You notice movement. A man twitches violently as he hangs. Froggers must've strung him up minutes ago, and left him to die. They could be back at any moment.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Cut him down. It's a risk if the Froggers catch you.

You start unfastening him. He's still breathing. Choking and coughing, but alive.
Supporting him, you manage to guide him into cover. You can't stay here, though. The Froggers will cordon off the parlour once they notice him missing.
You offer to help him leave the area, but he refuses, waving you away. He can't talk, but he thrusts something into your hand, and nods his head in appreciation.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Put him out of his misery. Quick as you can, before getting out of there.

Finishing him isn't too hard. Physically, anyway. You climb up, and give the hangman's rope a hefty jerk. Snap.
Sliding back down, you leave without a backward glance, stepping carefully wherever you can find bare floor. Sure, you could have cut him free, but the Froggers would've just rounded him up again, so what was the point?

table.name: encounters
table.column: You'd like to help, but it's too risky. Leave him dangling.
You can't help everybody. It's not a pleasant way to die, but what way is?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Not your concern. Concentrate on frisking the corpses.

You start surveying the corpses, but you don't get the opportunity to do much more. Froggers turn up, and you're forced to duck to the perimeter, out of sight.
They start throwing rocks at the man, accusing him. Taunting him. It takes a while before he stops jerking on the rope. Eventually, the cultists move on to other things. He might have been faking it, but you're not going to stick around and risk checking.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The Church of the Blue Frog doesn't have much room for unbelievers, judging by that arcade you saw a while back.
But this is new. A muscular Frogger's bull-whipping half a dozen unfortunates, held fast in makeshift stocks. He's bellowing all manner of nonsense about purity bringing light through pain. This one's a fanatic. Going to whip the flesh right off his victims' backs, until their spines show bone white.
He's one tall, powerful man. But preoccupied, with his back to you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Move in fast with that rock, and he won't know what's hit him.

Thwack! He goes down in a heap, like a crumbling high-rise. By the sound of it, you might've cracked his skull open. May have even killed him.
Stepping around him, you work your way along the line of improvised stocks, freeing everyone in double time. All six of them hobble off, supporting each other. Clearly getting out of dodge as fast as possible. Froggers rarely work alone, so you decide to do the same.
Before you leave, you frisk the immobile body of the fanatic whipper. Finding something in his pocket, you realize why he was so healthy.
And yes, you've killed him.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw the rock as hard as you can. If it hits, it'll really hurt.

He's got the neck of a bison, and he's thick of skull. A real Neanderthal.
The rock glances off his shoulder. Uh-oh. Spinning around effortlessly, he brings his whip down with an almighty CRACK!
Youch! That really hurt! Before he can entwine you in his whip, you run off, nursing your injury. By the time you are clear, the screams have started up again.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw the rock as hard as you can. If it hits, it'll really hurt.

He's got the neck of a bison, and he's thick of skull. A real Neanderthal.
The rock glances off his shoulder. Uh-oh. Spinning around effortlessly, he brings his whip down with an almighty CRACK!
Youch! That really hurt! Before he can entwine you in his whip, you run off, nursing your injury. By the time you are clear, the screams have started up again.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You don't want to mess with a fanatic Frogger. He can do his...thing, and you'll mind your own business.
Fanatics are dangerous. If the Great Blue Frog wants to whip the skin off the back of these poor unfortunates, then who are you to interfere? Keep moving.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Whipping someone? Never tried that. Tie that blue rag on, and introduce yourself. All praise to the Great Blue Frog!

The makeshift sash does the trick. "Sure," says the muscular Frogger, "have a go. Whip some purity into these heathens."
Hoisting the whip, you do your best to emulate Mr. Muscles, but succeed only in opening up a nasty gash on the head of the nearest unfortunate. The Frogger, appreciative of the help of a fellow worshipper, offers to show you how.
He asks you to kneel, and say the rites first. Let the Great Frog guide your arm. Unfortunately, you don't know any Froggy rites or rituals, and realize, too late, that you're in way over your head.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You've come across an ancient eighteen-wheeler. On closer inspection, you notice blood dripping from within. Holding your breath, you peer inside.
It's a cavernous trailer. Naked bodies are spread all over. Blue Frog tags, scrawled on the sides of the truck, indicate what was probably an impromptu inquisition. Took everything worth taking, and then killed them all.
But not everyone. You can hear whimpering coming from deep inside. Somebody's still alive. It's not going to be easy to get them out of there. Or quick. Worse, you'll be trapped if the Froggers return while you're in here.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Do it. Forget consequences, any enemy of the Frog is a friend of yours.

Stepping gingerly through the dead, you home in on the low moaning. Right at the back, under a pile of bleeding bodies. A middle-aged woman, barely conscious. Pulling the lukewarm bodies off her, you ask if she can stand.
No response. She's breathing, but that's about it. Doesn't register your presence at all. Glancing around, you wonder how the heck you're going to physically move her through all this stacked-up carnage?
You won't. Not without her assistance. Frustrated, you bend down and try, once more, to stir some life into her. No luck.
Reluctantly, you leave, but not before taking the bottle of painkillers that had rolled into a far corner during the massacre. Man, is there any part of you that isn't covered in blood?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Do it. Forget consequences, any enemy of the Frog is a friend of yours.

Stepping gingerly through the dead, you home in on the low moaning. Right at the back, under a pile of bleeding bodies. A middle-aged woman, barely conscious. Pulling the lukewarm bodies off her, you ask if she can stand.
No response. She's breathing, but that's about it. Doesn't register your presence at all. Glancing around, you wonder how the heck you're going to physically move her through all this stacked-up carnage?
You won't. Not without her assistance. Frustrated, you bend down and try, once more, to stir some life into her. No luck.
Reluctantly, you leave, but not before taking the bottle of painkillers that had rolled into a far corner during the massacre. Man, is there any part of you that isn't covered in blood?

table.name: encounters
table.column: You really don't want to get trapped in there if the Froggers return. Call out, let them know you're a friend. Ask them to come to you.

Quietly at first, then with increasing volume, you let them know you're there, and that you're a friend.
There's no response. Nada. All you can hear is the occasional subdued moan. The truck has more bodies in it than a football team. How the heck are you going to find them in all that? Do you really want to risk getting caught inside the truck?
No, you don't. Bye, stranger.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Poking around a truck full of dead, naked people isn't appealing. You've got better things to do.

The wastelands are full of sad stories. Try to help everybody, and you end up as one more chapter of woe.
Somebody once said, "Life is like drawing a picture without an eraser." Well, nowadays, if you can keep any ink flowing at all, you're ahead of the game. Good or bad, any picture is better than nothing at all.
Which is why you keep moving, ignoring a fellow human in obvious distress.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Close the doors. Dog them down tight. Whoever's still alive can stay there.

Nothing worse than listening to random moaning. It grates. Upsets your equilibrium. Makes you feel guilty. Inspires dangerous urges to help.
A whole lot easier to just lock those doors shut. Nice and tight. See? No more moaning sounds. You are at one with Zen and the art of problem solving.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's the smell that got your attention. A distinctive smell that's hard to forget.
Three ragged-looking types, roasting a small corpse over an open fire in a bank lobby. A horrified woman clutches her baby, staring vacantly past the fire from the smashed remains of a teller's cage.
The bandits appear unconcerned over your presence, and hold up a piece of cooked meat. But that's not what you're looking at. It's the anguished mother and her baby.
"You want 'em?" drawls a bandit. "Gonna cost ya."

table.name: encounters
table.column: There's a line. You're on the side that says "Human". Pay any price.

Handing over a king's ransom in gear, you begin to reassure the woman.
"Hey! Not so fast," barks a roughneck. "You didn't say the magic word!"
Puzzled, you stare at him. Does he want you to say "please"? Laughing uproariously, the bandits poke you in the ribs with the hilt of a knife.
"Sorry, man, these are our goods." His smile fades. "You heard that right. The lady, the kid, and your generous donation." He points at the pile of gear you just offloaded.
"Tell you what. You get to live, since you're such a good sport." The woman implores you to help her and her child, but there is little you can do unarmed.
"You're a gentleman, you know that?", yells a bandit as you leave the bank. Howls of laughter echo after you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Where there's life, there's hope. You can't save the baby, but maybe you can buy the woman her freedom?

To your surprise, they sell the woman cheap. You realize why, though, a minute later.
Even untied from the cage, the woman just will not go. Not without her child. You explain that the two of you together have a better of chance of survival. That she's doomed if she stays. But she ignores you, and holds onto her baby like it's the last chopper out of Saigon.
The bandits suddenly lose patience, and threaten to pike you with the roasting stick if you don't leave now.
Walking away, it takes a long time before you can no longer hear the woman screaming.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're open to new culinary experiences. Might help you to decide.

You've eaten a lot of strange things of late. You might even be able to go for seconds. But that idea is firmly refused.
"Get moving, man, or we'll lose our sense of humor."
You make a point of not looking at the woman as you leave. You've got enough bad dreams already.

table.name: encounters
table.column: There appears to be an overabundance of protein. Perhaps, if you offered to take care of the preparation, there'd be enough for all?

The three bandits look at each other and shrug. Without even blinking, one of them suddenly swivels around and cracks the woman's skull open with a crowbar.
What happens next isn't worth mentioning, apart from the feed. You can't remember how long it's been since you've eaten that well.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
These Bad Muthas must have a sense of humor. They've set up shop in the ruins of an old burger joint. Looks like a recruiting drive, too. Offering high-protein food for anyone willing to join them.
All the divider glass has long gone, so you can see what's cooking in the back. Humans. Some kids, too. They like those the best. Same setup as before, back at the bank. Spit-roasting over an open fire.
You've been watching a while, seeing people come and go. The Bad Muthas seem fairly relaxed. You could probably stroll in under false pretenses, and claim a burger.
Take out, of course. Can't stick around.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Disgusting! Look around. There must be a way to destroy McKid, or die trying!

Walking around the back, you decide the only way to do the job is to raze the hellhole to the ground.
Halfway through stacking up piles of rubbish, you're spotted.
"Hey." Your face starts to burn with fear. "Hey!" A lot of very angry people start appearing from all around. "Hey, is that the dude who napalmed the brothers?"
Corralled and cornered, you're unable to escape in time. You're dragged inside the ancient burger shop, and dumped at the feet of...head Mutha? Head chef? Whatever he is, you try and kick him, bite him, anything to provoke him into hurting you.
The Bad Muthas, you know, like their meat fresh and untainted. Unfortunately, all that happens is that you are restrained, with your head held over a sink, neck outstretched. They're going to bleed you alive. Before they-
Oh god...

table.name: encounters
table.column: You don't stoop that low. Keep moving.

So the Bad Muthas are starting a McKid franchise? You're smart enough to steer clear of that. Or emotions in general.
When you're focused on survival, feelings only get in your way.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Line up, and ask if you can get fries with that. Of course, you're not going to eat it. Just curious.

Man, this place sure is popular. Do all these people know what they're buying? Given that the kitchen is in full view, it's hard to imagine anyone claiming ignorance.
Maybe it all comes down to damn tasty food. At the front of the line, you allow yourself only a few seconds to look at it before stepping aside.
Mmmmm. Awful tempting.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Your stomach is telling you to order a double. You never argue with your stomach.

This isn't cannibalism. No sir. This is the green shoots of free enterprise, flourishing in a hostile environment. Entrepreneurial spirit needs to be encouraged.
So it isn't your average burger stand. So what? Isn't innovation what made America great? That's why you're getting the biggest burger you can order.
Why bury dead humans? Use them to kick-start the American dream! All they need to do now is figure out how to make decent fries.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The thing about the cannibals is that none of them look skinny. All that human flesh they eat buffs them up.
But you can smell it on 'em. A particular stink that oozes out their pores. Start chowing down bits of other people, and you're going to need an industrial-strength deodorant. Get a group together, and it's an aroma minefield.
Like this place. Half a dozen cannibals, flaked out and asleep, their bellies distended. The remains of their binge eating session still by the fire. They've left a leg. Small, shapely. Might've been a young girl.
Their noise traps aren't hard to evade. You could sneak in and be gone before they know it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: How about you sneak in and cut all their throats? Animals. So what if there are six of them?

You grab a knife they had lying next to the fire.
But they must've worn the blade blunt, 'cause the first cannibal's throat was like slicing a slab of rubber with a stick. The knife didn't cut as much as tear, thrashing the carotid artery so badly that blood geysers all over the rest of them. Might as well have zapped them all with a jet of cold water.
Now you're in a room full of five very awake, very angry cannibals.
You manage to stab the nearest, sharpness not a problem for a full-frontal thrust into the chest. He goes down in a gurgling gush of bubbles and blood. Deserves it, too, the evil bastard. You've got enough time to form that thought before four sets of arms and legs beat you into blackness.
One has to stand for something, even if they die doing it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: There's too many of them to deal with, and you aren't into eating human flesh. Get out of there.

You might have handled one or two of them, but not a pack this size. They ain't well-fed for no reason.
You're gone.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Scream as loud as you can, then hide around the corner. Circle around once they've all left. Easy pickings.

You decide to distract them. Send 'em on a wild goose chase. Nobody wakes from a deep slumber thinking clearly, especially if it's a piercing, eye-watering scream that snaps them into life.
The cannibals come running out the door helter-skelter. By the time they've stopped slashing air, you've moved into the room via the back door. Grabbing the leg from the hot coals, slowly sizzling away from the dripping fat, you beat a hasty retreat.
You fully intend to bury it. Well, most of it. Say a few words. Put whoever owned it to rest. They should give you a medal for denying your hunger and willingly wasting valuable protein.
Well, for denying, anyway.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Already cooked! Man, you're salivating. Take it!

Being the sneaky son of a gun you are, you manage to creep in, and carefully extract the roasted limb from the fire. Score!
Turning, you kick a blunt knife lying next to the fire. Your enthusiasm deflates as quickly as it appeared. Damn.
Abandoning stealth, you run out the door, out the corridor, and out of the building. You've got enough of a head start to make it, provided you keep moving fast.
