The leg slips greasily from your hand as you run through a pile of stinking rubbish. Annoyed, you stop to grab it firmly by the haunch and keep going.
So it's food that's been picked off the ground. It's still food, and you're still hungry.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Already cooked! Man, you're salivating. Take it!

Being the sneaky son of a gun you are, you manage to creep in, and carefully extract the roasted limb from the fire. Score!
Turning, you kick a blunt knife lying next to the fire. Your enthusiasm deflates as quickly as it appeared. Damn.
Abandoning stealth, you run out the door, out the corridor, and out of the building. You've got enough of a head start to make it, provided you keep moving fast. The leg slips greasily from your hand as you run through a pile of stinking rubbish. Annoyed, you stop to grab it firmly by the haunch and keep going.
So it's food that's been picked off the ground. It's still food, and you're still hungry.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The whimpering tells you that this dog is hurting bad. It limped up behind you when you sat down for a rest. Now it won't leave.
Cute dog, though.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Do what you can for the dog. Use the rags and that standing water over there. Maybe he'll make it?

While taking care of his wound and refreshing his thirst, the dog gets a case of the crazies. He snaps at your hand, and backs off, scared.
Dog's probably been treated pretty rough, so you're not surprised. Still, you can't keep the dog if it's going to take chunks out of you. Hope it hasn't got rabies.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Do what you can for the dog. Use the rags and that standing water over there. Maybe he'll make it?

While taking care of his wound and refreshing his thirst, the dog gets a case of the crazies. He snaps at your hand, and backs off, scared.
Dog's probably been treated pretty rough, so you're not surprised. Still, you can't keep the dog if it's going to take chunks out of you. Hope it hasn't got rabies.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Give him a pat and leave him behind. You don't need a dog.
Sit boy, sit. Stay here until somebody else comes along. I can't help you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Crippled dogs aren't any use to you. Throw rocks until he limps off into the distance.

A dog with four good legs might have been useful. Could have helped scout and scavenge.
Unfortunately, dog usefulness doesn't scale linearly with number of legs. It takes a few direct hits before the dog gets the message.

table.name: encounters
table.column: He might be crippled, but there's enough meat left on him for a decent meal. Kill, gut, and skin him. Looks tasty.

A dog that trusting wouldn't have lasted long anyway. It doesn't take you long to get him ready for cooking. You light a small fire, and throw him straight on.
Even though the wind's strong enough to dissipate the smell, you move quickly, not wanting to hang around. It's hard to tell if the meat's cooked through, but you're willing to take the chance.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You plead with the butcher, and explain that it must be some mistake. You don't kill humans for meat, honest!
Giving you a sidelong stare, the butcher considers your plea. "If I ever," he points a carving knife at you, "and I mean EVER, see you in here offloading that stuff again..." His knife jabs point-first into a cutting board, nearly splitting the wood.
"Now get that slab off my counter, or else!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You remember the last dog. Cute, like this one. Trouble with being a dog these days is that people tend to see them as a meal on legs. Good protein is hard to find.
This one's young. A puppy. Damn thing is licking you, too. It looks well-fed, so somebody must have been caring for it.
You haven't got any need for a rambunctious, tail-wagging puppy. Can't be sure, but you've heard they attract Dogmen like blood attracts sharks.
As the puppy rubs up against your leg, you can't help but notice how much meat there is on him.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Poor little fellow. Maybe you can carry it over to that building. Round up some rations and water.

"Come on boy, I'll find you a happy home."
Trouble is, the building doesn't offer anything except for exposed, cancerous concrete. Nor does the next one. The more you hold the puppy, the less you want to put it down. It's curled up asleep in your arms, its little heart beating away, contented. Awww.
While you are leaning up against a broken wall, trying to figure out a plan, rubble scum appear. Scrambling to your feet, you drop some gear along with the puppy, who, waking, yelps loudly and runs off in fright.
Straight into the grasping hands of the rubble scum. It's a split-second decision, take on the gang of scum and rescue the puppy or run like heck?
Bye, boy.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Thing'll probably end up pissing on your foot! Kick it away!
Don't kick it away, and it'll be hanging around forever. Besides, who wants to stink of dog urine?

table.name: encounters
table.column: A puppy on his own is only going to end up in somebody's stomach. Time for a mercy killing.

Picking it up, you give it a friendly pat before grabbing it by the scruff of the neck and twisting hard.
Snap.
Try as you might, you can't bring yourself to eat it. Nor do you want to waste time giving it a proper burial. In the end, you heave it over your shoulder. The rats can have it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Heard puppy is a delicacy. You're not one to waste a tasty treat.

The rumors, you decide, hold true.
Gutted and skinned, the puppy is a few squirrels worth of meat. But wow, squirrels don't look that appetizing. Can't wait to get a fire going.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you're cleaning two rat corpses, you notice a dog up ahead, pawing at the ground, barking. Trying to get your attention. Judging by the disturbed rubble, there's been a recent collapse. You walk over and investigate.
Sure enough, a foot is poking out from under the pile of concrete and rusted rebar. The dog's owner must have been caught. By the bluish tinge to the toes, the owner's long dead.
Dog's not willing to let go, though. And all that barking will attract trouble soon.
You pat her on the head. Scrawny dog, but possessed of a fine, long-haired pelt.

table.name: encounters
table.column: A dog that won't leave her owner is admirable. Hand over the rat carcasses. She deserves it.

You weren't expecting to catch anything, but your snares managed to entangle two wily black rodents. Shame to give them to Lassie, but it's the least you can do. Hopefully, once she's had a decent feed, she'll give up on her dead master. With a final pat, you wish her well.
But she won't let you go! Growling, tugging at your leg. Wanting you to dig out her master, ignoring your offering. You bend down and explain to her that this isn't possible, and that she needs to look to her future. You've always been good with animals.
Except this one. She growls, snarls, and suddenly sinks her teeth into you!
Kicking her away you back off, hurting. Damn dog!

table.name: encounters
table.column: A dog that won't leave her owner is admirable. Hand over the rat carcasses. She deserves it.

You weren't expecting to catch anything, but your snares managed to entangle two wily black rodents. Shame to give them to Lassie, but it's the least you can do. Hopefully, once she's had a decent feed, she'll give up on her dead master. With a final pat, you wish her well.
But she won't let you go! Growling, tugging at your leg. Wanting you to dig out her master, ignoring your offering. You bend down and explain to her that this isn't possible, and that she needs to look to her future. You've always been good with animals.
Except this one. She growls, snarls, and suddenly sinks her teeth into you!
Kicking her away you back off, hurting. Damn dog!

table.name: encounters
table.column: Try and calm her down. Lead her away from her owner. Dog should be smart enough to realize you've got to move on.

Dog should've been smart enough to move on, but isn't. She starts howling.
Desperate to quiet it down, you feed it the two rat carcasses. It momentarily does the job. But then she starts back up with the howling. Nothing you can do seems to break her stride. If you don't get out of there quickly, you'll be meeting unexpected company.
Well, hope Lassie makes it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Too much noise. Leave the dog to the predators, you're out of here.
You don't even bother talking to the dog. Bet Lassie's a goner by sunset. Not your problem.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Can't be much of a dog if she let his owner get squashed. Finish her off. Keep the pelt.

You approach softly, comfortingly. "Good girl. Good dog." CRACK!
Dog might as well do some good in the afterlife. You yank the pelt off her scrawny carcass. Long, flowing dog hair. Didn't come off in one neat piece, but you don't have the advantage of time and tools, so you're willing to settle for a collection of ragged pieces.
Kind of like squirrel fur. Should make a nice tunic.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Not much sun makes it into this warehouse. It's dank, and dim.
Inside, you've found three corpses. Looks like they're all women, sprawled on the floor. The clothes are torn. Some flesh, too.
You noticed some raiders coming out earlier. Must've hit an enclave, and carted off the women.
Methodically, you start checking corpses. As you approach the last one, you see movement! She's been knocked around, but she's probably feigning death. Face down, she must think you're a raider.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Reassure her. Clean her up. Give her the others' clothes. She's frightened.
Like a scalded cat, she leaps up and rakes her nails across your face. She grabs the water and clothing, then bolts for the door before you can recover.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell her that they've all gone, then step back and give her some space. She'll know what to do.

You back off, and explain that it's over. They've gone.
A lot of good that does. She comes at you, screaming like a banshee. You barely fend her off with your forearm, and she keeps running right out of the warehouse, still screaming.
Traumatized, she may never be the same. Looking over the grisly scene here, you may not be either.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Helping is only asking for trouble. She's still breathing. She'll live. Keep moving.

Good Samaritans wouldn't last a day out here in the wasteland. First person they stopped to help would probably gut them like a fish. Out here, you only help those who can help you.
A busted up, traumatized girl isn't going to be of any use.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hey, free bandages! Take what's left of her clothes.

With her still face-down, you crouch to get a hold of her clothes. But before you can do anything, she lashes out with her legs, and knocks you off balance. She kicks you for good measure, then turns to run.
You manage to keep hold of her clothes, but they just rip as she bolts out the door in full flight. Oh well, some rags are better than nothing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's a tough gig out here if you're not strong, tough, or both. Half of the people you meet see you as chattel, or worse. Out here, if you're not a fighter, all you can do is find one and hang on tight.
Which is probably the nature of the couple's relationship ahead. Or at least, was the nature. You're guessing the dude sprawled in the dirt was the strong and/or tough one. Now he's the one with a gaping hole in the back of his skull. Guess he wasn't enough of the strong, or the tough.
He must've played his part, though. Kept them distracted long enough for her to hide. But not from you. Worried, red eyes peering out from a concealed hole, she knows she's been spotted. Nowhere for her to run.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Help her out. Let her know you're on her side.

You offer words of kindness, but they fall on distrustful ears.
She bolts out of her hidey-hole, a ball of hissing, spitting meanness. Rakes something sharp across your flesh before running off.
Do you look that much like a predator? Is kindness that foreign a concept? Nursing your wound, you wonder.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Rubble scum molls aren't your concern. She can stay in there and rot for all you care.
Why help her? Why bother with anyone? It's the wastelands. You aren't obligated to help. Especially not the rubble scum. Who cares if they won't be sending you a Christmas card this year?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Entice her out. Bet she's got something useful on her.

It takes a while, but you manage to coax her out with words of honey and kindness. She approaches nervously, hesitant, but willing to take a chance on trusting you.
Bad move.
Knocking her to the ground, you roll her over onto her stomach, and quickly frisk her for gear. Found something. And before she realizes what just happened, you're gone.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Drag her out. If she doesn't come good with some useful intel, waste her.

Getting her out is a real ordeal. The only way you manage it is to grab her by her hair, and physically yank her from the rat hole. And man, does she make a racket. After applying a little elbow grease to quiet her down, you ask her, "politely", to tell you where the goods are.
"What goods?"
Some people, you lament, are just plain slow on the uptake. You have a short "conversation" with the lady. Express your desire to get your hands on the goods. Any goods. You highlight your wonderful sense of humor, and how it's in danger of expiring.
Funny thing is, you doubt she's listening any more. Appears to have stopped making breathing sounds. Damn. Gotta work on your interrogation skills.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You've heard it said that some of the enclaves are nothing more than breeding farms. All the surplus kids get sold off in exchange for needed items. Probably just an urban legend.
What you do know is that women found outside enclaves are often rounded up. They're treated as a precious commodity by many. Even looters will pay through the nose for a healthy specimen.
Which might be what you've just stumbled across, though you'll admit the circumstances are a bit odd. There's a woman in this room, hog tied next to the lifeless body of a looter. Doesn't appear to be anyone else here, though. That's the "odd".
You hear some gangers coming down the street, though they don't seem wise to the setup here yet.

table.name: encounters
table.column: No one deserves to be enslaved. Untie her. Get her out of there. There isn't much time.

By the time you've freed her, the gangers are close enough to hear any sound you make. Motioning to her to stay silent, you crawl over to the door, ready to tackle anyone coming through.
But it isn't the gangers who do so. It's a third party. Three of them. Must have had an argument over the girl, the loser lying in the pool of blood over there.
They burst into the room, not willing to let the gangers steal their captive.
You trip the first one, and the other two stumble over each other, trying to avoid all the dead and alive humanity cluttering up the room. The gangers are yelping and hollering, running into the building.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're willing to untie her, but after that, she's on her own.

Untying her takes longer than you thought. The knots are tight.
The young woman slumps to the floor, unable to move after being bound like this so long. The sounds of approaching gangers drifts in through the open window, signaling your cue to leave.
Maybe if the woman stays quiet and still, she won't be seen. Maybe whoever killed the looter won't be back.
Maybe.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Leave her hogtied. It's not the ideal situation, but she'll figure it out.

You'd like to help, but if you hang around, it might not end well. Particularly as the dead looter looks pretty fresh.
Questions ricochet around your head. The woman pleads with you to untie her, promises you the world if you'll only help her. Glancing out the window, it's clear the gangers have already heard her. Ears pricked, heads swiveling, trying to hone in on the sounds of distress.
The woman, now crying, asks what kind of man you are to leave her like this.
Interesting question, that one. As soon as you're free and clear, you're going to sit down and give it some thought.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hide the looter's body. Take charge. Do the deal.

Flagging down the gangers isn't hard. They're probably on the prowl for someone to gank, and your timing is convenient. For now, though, they're willing to play ball. But they want to inspect the goods before purchasing.
You stand to one side as they prod and poke her. It isn't hard to figure out why they want her. The woman is quietly sobbing, beyond screaming. You keep your back to the wall, trying to assess the whole group.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The church door swings idly on its remaining hinge. Inside, a gaunt priest is trying to light a fire. He has that long-distance stare. Eyes that look through whatever he's doing. The mess inside seems to indicate he's been here a long, long while. How has he survived this long?
A discarded blue sash provides a clue. He's a Frogger. Even looters show respect to that lot. There are a lot of them out there. Enough to watch out for their own.
This one's a grade A proselytizer, no doubt. He's giving every indication of launching into a sermon.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hear him out. He's not doing any harm. Of course, you'll have to make a donation.

The sermon issues forth without hesitation.
And without end. It's difficult to sit still that long. Doesn't the man ever take a breath? You start eyeing up escape routes when finally, you receive a blessing. Not sure it was worth it, but who knows? Maybe the Great Frog will watch over you?

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're not into the Froggers. But maybe he needs a hand?

Careful to dissuade him from religious speech, you ask if there's anything you can do just to help?
Of course. He wants food. Now. There is a snarly aspect to his pastoral manner, not at all pleasant.
Checking your pockets, you try and find some food to give him, before his actions catch up with his manner.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Church of the Blue Frog? Best get out of here right now.

As you walk back out through the broken door, he harangues you to return to the security offered by the Great Frog. Shouting about "doomed" and "cesspool of damnation". Something something "purity" and "Frog".
Whatever. Walking through the door in the first place was a mistake.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're not frightened by a bunch of loony cultists. Ignore the old man, and loot the church.

While the old man threatens all manner of nonsense, you pick your way through the piles of junk scattered all over. Most of it is just rubbish, not unlike the polluted river of words issuing from his mouth.
Your ears are starting hurt by the time you come upon the box. It's small, like one used for cigars or stationery, but it feels like something's inside.
Cracking it open, something sharp stabs you, and you recoil with a shout. Damn! What was that? Examining the wound, you find a sharpened fork, its tines puncturing your skin. It looks dirty too, like something's coating it.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Another makeshift church up ahead. Blue Frogs, more than likely.
The Froggers must have a monopoly on religion out here in the wastelands. Not hard to see why, you guess. Ruthless extermination of everything un-Frog.
Always looking for nonbelievers, too. Like the foraging party of enclavers you've just met back there, inside a housing complex.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go back and speak to the enclavers, let them know of the danger up ahead.

The enclavers are skeptical. "Whaddya doing in there, spying on us?"
You assure them that no, you're just looking out for their best interest.
Nobody appears to be listening, though. Too busy imagining your wrongdoings. Trust is a friable commodity in the wastelands. The smallest spider crack is all it takes for opinion to rule, and paranoia to escalate into frenzy. Before you know it, an angry, senseless mob is looking for a target to insult. Or pummel. Plus a few hard kicks to the gonads.
You're still curled into a fetal ball when they leave. Hard to find a part of you that isn't hurting.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go back and speak to the enclavers, let them know of the danger up ahead.

The enclavers are skeptical. "Whaddya doing in there, spying on us?"
You assure them that no, you're just looking out for their best interest.
Nobody appears to be listening, though. Too busy imagining your wrongdoings. Trust is a friable commodity in the wastelands. The smallest spider crack is all it takes for opinion to rule, and paranoia to escalate into frenzy. Before you know it, an angry, senseless mob is looking for a target to insult. Or pummel. Plus a few hard kicks to the gonads.
You're still curled into a fetal ball when they leave. Hard to find a part of you that isn't hurting.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Let nature take its course. It's not your place to interfere.
Why take the risk? Double agents usually end up dead, don't they?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Could be something in it for you. Run down to the Church and alert the Froggers. For a price.

One must do what's necessary to survive out here. Betraying enclavers isn't ideal, but when was the last time they gave you anything but problems?
The Frogger folk, on the other hand, are extremely pleased to hear all about it. Your fake blue sash and your praise for the Great Blue Frog were enough to convince them. Must have struck them on a good day too, 'cause they paid well.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Play middle man. See if you can tip both off for a fee.

Playing both sides is a tough gig, especially when you have to hot foot from one to the other without being noticed. But you manage to pull it off. Dashing into the rubble, you aim for a narrow gap between two collapsed houses, anxious to count your ill-gotten gains. Rounding a corner, you're winded by a sharp impact, followed by stabbing pain and warmth.
A Frogger uses his free hand to push you back, off the end of his knife. Bastard must've taken the same route as you, and caught you double-dealing. He hauls back with his arm, and as he brings it down, a loud CRACK shatters the quiet. His head flaps backward in a violent red mist, and he collapses in a twist.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Two Froggers up ahead, arguing loudly over a stash of food. No brotherly love among fellow worshippers here.
You watch as the argument descends to blows. A feral kid breaks cover from his hiding place, heading for the food. With the Froggers distracted, he has a good chance of stealing it.
But then, so could you. That is, if you yelled out a warning to the Froggers at just the right time. Wouldn't end well for the kid, though.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw rocks at the Froggers. They'll be so busy dealing with you that the kid can safely grab the food.

A couple of well-aimed rocks succeeds in getting the Froggers' undivided attention. The kid darts in and grabs the food. Mission accomplished. Job well done.
Except for the two angry Froggers charging straight at you, weapons raised. Man, those Froggers can move!
Running for your life, you're forced to shed extra weight in order to elude the vengeful fanatics. Was that something valuable? Not anymore.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Jump up and shout at the Froggers. Distract them. Give the kid a chance.

If you ever want to get a Frogger excited, all you have to do is disparage their favorite amphibian. Howling all manner of unspeakable Froggie threats, they come a'running.
As you rapidly depart the scene, your peripheral vision catches sight of the kid. He streaks in unseen, and steals their food. Would've been nice to have savored the moment, but the Froggers are closing in fast, and you have to hustle.
Might have dropped something on the way out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Warn the Froggers. The kid's going down no matter what. Only way you'll have a chance of grabbing the food.

"Kid! Watch out for the kid!"
The Froggers take heed of your timely warning, and manage to scruff hold of the juvenile thief. As you expected, the kid thrashes around and gives them all manner of trouble, biting and kicking both of the Froggers. Time enough for you to make your move.
They see you, of course, but their hands are fully occupied with the wriggling kid. By the time pursuit starts, you're well clear.
Though you dropped most of the food in your haste to get out of there.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait 'til the Froggers are occupied with the kid, then move in and whack the lot of them with that wrench the Froggers dropped. Food plus loot!

Unsurprisingly, the Froggers spot the kid, and grab him. When they do, you sneak in, and scoop up the monkey wrench from where they left it. Luckily, they're too busy trying to strangle the kid to notice your creeping closer.
Just as the kid breathes his last, you bring the wrench down on the nearest Frogger. There's a muffled crumple as his skull gives way. The second Frogger has time to react, but your swing catches him squarely on the cheek before he can draw a broken bladed knife. He slumps backwards, and you ignore the jarring recoil up and down your arm long enough to whack him again.
While you are tidying up, you give the expired kid a friendly tap on the head, watching that there aren't any more surprises.
Thanks, kid.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There's a woman calling to you from above. Two stories up, out of an open window. Wants you to come into the store below. Plenty of cheap, good food, she says. Canned salmon!
You're pretty sure that any salmon would have gone off long ago, nothing now but tinned salmonella.
This reeks of an ambush. The girl's nothing but a lure. That kind of underhanded behaviour really gets you annoyed. Looking around, you notice that there is an awful lot of combustible rubbish drifted up against one wall of the building.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It isn't worth the risk. Leave.

Sure you could burn down the building, but what if there are decent folk inside? Besides, all that smoke and flame is bound to attract unwanted attention.
You give the woman a friendly wave and keep moving.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask the woman to come down to the street, alone. You'll talk to her there.

She doesn't want to. And you weren't expecting anything else. Time to go.
One thing's for certain, though. There must be a decent cache of food in the building. She looks well-fed.
As if on cue, the building's door bursts open. Run!

table.name: encounters
table.column: There's a lighter. Start a fire. Just a little one. Let nature take care of the rest. If it catches and spreads, then it's meant to be.

As the fire sputters, the wind picks up. Within minutes, the building is burning brightly. There are screams inside from behind the door, but you can safely ignore them as you've jammed it shut.
Better not hang around, as this is one heck of an attention grabber. The burning inhabitants won't be deceiving anyone else. You've done your job.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Set fire to the rubbish. Fan the flames. Burn the whole building down, with everybody in it. They aren't going to trick you.

As the flames lick up the walls, the woman starts screaming. You stand near the entrance with some rebar you found nearby. As far as you can tell, there is only one way out. The rats will be leaving the ship any moment now.
Strangely, only the woman and a man run out, their clothes and hair burning. You manage to fell both of them and extinguish the flames. Neither of them look anything like the low life that you thought was inside.
No matter. The man was holding a worn rifle. Hope it still works.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Someone's calling you from the building up ahead. Top floor. You can't see, but it sounds like she's on her own. She's calling out that her foot is caught in a rodent snare.
You remember the canned salmon girl. The one who tried, you suspect, to bait you into a trap. Cynical? Maybe. But you estimate there are more cynics left alive than not.
Moving closer, you notice that the building itself is on its last legs. One decent heave ho in the right spot, and it might all come crashing down.
Still, you can't tell from here if she's telling the truth.
Have to go inside to know for sure.

table.name: encounters
table.column: If you're careful, maybe you can get her out of there without the whole place coming down. Worth a try.

With a head full of gallantry, you enter the building, careful to step slowly and avoid any unnecessary vibrations. You wonder if the stairs are still working, but then, they must be in order for Rapunzel to have made it up to the top floor.
Stretching to avoid a shaky pile of rubble in the corridor, you don't see the crowbar as it arcs down onto the back of your head. You feel it, though. Even if only momentarily.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Won't hurt to poke your head in the door and assess the situation.

Peering through the open door, you can't see much through the gloomy interior. Shards of sunlight highlight rubble and ordinary building detritus. Difficult to form a judgment one way or another.
Cautiously taking a few steps inside, you pause, waiting for your sight to acclimate to the low light. Gradually, you make out the building's interior. There's a corridor, probably leading to the stairwell. Looks like a typical rabbit warren of an old office.
Numerous open-plan wall dividers litter the ground. A faded faux-wood sign reads "Reception". What you weren't expecting were the noises. Subdued breathing sounds. Muted. Close. Hard to tell, but there's at least three, possibly more.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You aren't going to be suckered into another trap. Heave ho! Topple the building. Bye, girl.

You've caught enough rats in your time to know the last place you'd set snares is the roof of a building. All the good rubbish and refuse is on the street. Places like rotting refrigeration rooms, or in the basement.
It's your public duty to clean up this mess. Inspecting the building, you find the best point of leverage, and give it all you've got. Once, twice, thrice you strain, pushing for all you're worth, but to no avail.
Exhausted, you stumble off, out of breath and frustrated. Nothing worse than leaving a job half done.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You'll save her! Sure you will. Insist that she throws down her gear to you first, just in case. And her shirt. You'll need it for bandages.

Out of the open window sails a packet of ketchup and a ripped shirt.
Huh. Not quite what you were expecting.
Assumedly shirtless, the woman renews her pleas for your assistance. Of course you had no intention of doing anything, but you planned on leaving with more gear than just sauce and rags.
The building probably only looks wobbly, half a dozen head kickers just waiting for you to blindly rush in, thinking you've found yourself a wife. Scratching your head, doing your best to ignore the woman's calls, you conclude that the best outcome here is to walk away.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You hear a woman shriek. Trouble up ahead. You've heard a suspicious "damsel in distress" or two before, but this looks different. A girl is being held down by a couple of rubble scum, while another tears off her clothes. Not pleasant-looking, these guys.
You've just found a nice crowbar, and could rush in and whack them in the back, but it's risky. Alternatively, you could hurl the crowbar at them and hope that the girl can break free in the resultant chaos.
Nice crowbar, though. Excellent condition.

table.name: encounters
table.column: That's got to stop. Put your crowbar to good use.

Surprise and Mr. Crowbar are your two best friends. They take down a rubble scum apiece.
You're still hauling back the crowbar for another blow, when vermin number three punches you in the gut, wrestles the crowbar from your hand, and viciously kicks you. Luckily, you land on something soft.
The girl! She screams, and begins clawing at you. Probably figuring you for another thug.
Under attack from two directions, you slam your elbow into her ribcage, and try and trip the vermin up with your foot.
Her screams crescendo, and the rubble scum backs off long enough for you to struggle to your feet. He lands the bar twice more before you stagger clear. Faced with finishing you off, or preventing the girl from escaping he opts for the latter.
Man, didn't that work out well?

table.name: encounters
table.column: That's got to stop. Put your crowbar to good use.

Surprise and Mr. Crowbar are your two best friends. They take down a rubble scum apiece.
You're still hauling back the crowbar for another blow, when vermin number three punches you in the gut, wrestles the crowbar from your hand, and viciously kicks you. Luckily, you land on something soft.
The girl! She screams, and begins clawing at you. Probably figuring you for another thug.
Under attack from two directions, you slam your elbow into her ribcage, and try and trip the vermin up with your foot.
Her screams crescendo, and the rubble scum backs off long enough for you to struggle to your feet. He lands the bar twice more before you stagger clear. Faced with finishing you off, or preventing the girl from escaping he opts for the latter.
Man, didn't that work out well?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Dealing with three of them might be a stretch. Heave the crowbar into the back of one and hope that they'll take off.

Shame about the crowbar, but you can't stand by while someone gets worked over by rubble scum.
The nearest vermin staggers forward as the bar thumps into his back. Down he goes, limp as a sack of potatoes.
Wisely, you don't hang around. Hit and run. When you're confident enough that you're clear, you creep up into a building with a vantage point. Not a lot left to see apart from a dead piece of vermin, and an equally lifeless girl. And they've taken your crowbar.
Long shots, as you're finding out, don't often pay.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Yeah, don't get involved, the cardinal rule of the wastelands. Keep going.
Sorry, lady. I've got to look after myself. Nobody else will.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait around the corner until it's all over. Whatever happens, her clothes will still be lying around. You could do with some new rags.

It's only when the girl's stopped screaming that you judge it safe to investigate.
The vermin have gone, leaving the girl lifeless, bloodied, and bruised. Should you have helped her? Is anyone going to help you when you're next in trouble?
Maybe a better man would've done both, but they went the way of the dinosaurs soon after the apocalypse. Failure to adapt to changing circumstances.
Bending, you gather up what's left of the woman's clothing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Looking dazed and frightened, a chubby, well-dressed man runs towards you. Might be the first time you've seen an overweight person.
He grasps at your clothes as he reaches you, talking ten to the dozen. Says he's from the DMC. Some sort of adventure party, flying around on a hovercraft. But the twin engines both gave out at once.
Or at least that's the story. Claims he's the only survivor, and demands that you take him back to the DMC. He lives inside the gates. Core City, even. He'll pay handsomely.
The trouble is, you know there's no way you're getting chubby chops here back there safely. You're struggling to get there yourself.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Do what you can to help. Surely you've got something he can have?

He grabs what you give him, then launches into a tirade of abuse. Something about how you should consider it an opportunity to help him. How you're obligated to help him. How you-
Enough! He knows which way to go. You've done what you can. You're gone.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell him which way to go, then be on your way.

He's not happy. Really not happy. He demands that you help him, and threatens to report you to the DMC authorities if you don't.
Nice try. Last time you looked, they didn't hold much sway out here.
Let him figure that out for himself.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Shake him off. Porkchops can fend for himself.
Over fed, under-stimulated rich people shouldn't leave the DMC. Time to fend for yourself, buddy. Adios!

table.name: encounters
table.column: Shake him off, then shake him down.

That quiets him down. Not so talkative once you shove a weapon in his face.
You tell him to strip, and lie on the ground. Holy cow! Look at all that flab! Where did he find enough food to stack that on? Core City, DMC must be the land of plenty.
In the meantime, you rummage through his stuff. Hopefully there's something useful.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Another DMC tourist. This one fell into a rivulet.
You pull him out, wet and shivering. Probably plopped out of the sky like the previous one you met. Man, he's got some high-class gear on him! Might even be a bottle of whiskey that he's clutching.
Being the friendly, helpful sort, you inform Mr. Moneybags that the filthy water is contaminated. Might be radioactive. Best if he stripped off, and moved over to that wall, where you'll hose him down.
Of course you will.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Back off from the scare tactics. Assure him that you'll help. Follow me!

There's an immediate problem. Moneybags believed you. He tears off his clothes like they were infested with fire ants, then stands before you, naked.
He wants that decontamination, now! Full-on yelling here. Spittle spraying all over. Absolutely convinced that his body will go into meltdown unless you do your thing. Won't let go, either.
You push him away, trying to leave, but he bounces back and bear hugs you, crying. Blubbering that if he doesn't get decontaminated, then you'll both die together. Smells like...garlic?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Slap him on the back. Tell him you're only joking. All that was in the water were germs. The joke's on you, buddy. Enjoy the wastelands!

It was only when you started laughing at him that he finally believed you. They must live a very cosseted life in the DMC, 'cause it appears that germs are almost as bad as radiation.
Mr. Moneybags dissolves into tears, nothing but a pitiful, distraught, teddy bear lost in the woods. You don't enjoy leaving him there, but what the heck else can you do? Once he's finished crying, he'll come to his senses.
You mention, as you part ways, that he probably won't be alive come sundown. So be smart! Put a smile on! Enjoy what time he has left.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You'll dispose of his clothes just as soon as you've run him through the shower. Right this way...

"There you go, sir. Gear and clothes down here, shower over there. It's all ready, just walk through the door and brace yourself. Yes, sir, that's correct. The decontamination shower is properly maintained. Used it myself yesterday."
You usher him forward, reassuring him. "That's it... through the door... Yes, it is a bit dark, but that's to protect your eyesight... Stand still while I turn it on... Might take a while... if it hasn't started by the count of fifty, let me know."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
This is the third DMC tourist that you've met in recent days. Maybe they all came from the same faulty hovercraft? Maybe it's just raining rich, fat people. Which gives you an idea.
Cannibals would walk over glass to get a hold of all that well-fed stock. Just a matter of delivering the goods. This one's shaking with fright, limping and nursing a head wound. Imploring you to help him. Smart enough to know he won't live long without a guide.

table.name: encounters
table.column: There's no harm in giving him directions. Tell him how to get out of town safely.

You may as well tell him the way to Shangri-La for all the attention he is paying you. Maybe that wound on his scalp is affecting his ability to think clearly? More likely he's just terrified.
That's going to make this difficult. He's a liability as a companion, but at the same time, you don't want to leave him here, clueless and defenseless.
In the end, you tell him to walk straight down the street. Insist that he keeps going until he reaches the end. That's about all the instructions he can handle.
What's at the end of the street? Who knows? At least he'll be on the move. Stay still for too long in the wastelands, and you're looking at early retirement. Sans watch.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Stand on the corner, buddy, with your thumb out. Someone'll give you a ride.

"There are vehicles out here?" he asks. He seems genuinely confused. "W-we didn't see any from the hover craft."
Patting him on the back, you reassure him. "Sure there are lots of vehicles around these parts. Bound to be one passing by soon. Just make sure you don't forget to flag it down."
As you walk off and leave him, you hope he isn't expecting leather seats and cup holders. They aren't standard equipment for shopping trolleys.

table.name: encounters
table.column: No point tying him up with string. You'll have to take him directly to the cannibals.

He might as well have "Eat me" painted on his back. Look at all that wobbly, tender meat! Mr. DMC is nothing more than a giant, uncooked roast.
You lead him down the street, trying to figure out a way to do a deal without the cannibals deciding to eat you as well. You're still mulling it over, when you hear a sudden yelp from behind. Spinning around, you're just in time to see Mr. Eat Me disappear down an open manhole.
Damn! Wasn't he looking? Don't they have open manhole covers in the DMC?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Cannibals like their meat fresh. Smash his kneecaps so he won't be able to run away.

Cannibalism is old hat in a protein-deprived wasteland, provided you're careful in not eating the wrong folk. And Mr. DMC here looks to be Mr. Right. Good diet and all.
It's going to be a whole lot simpler to negotiate a deal if the goods aren't with you at the time. Which is why you ask him to sit down before smashing both his kneecaps with a rusty steel bar. The high-pitched screaming nearly deafens you, and you scramble to jam rubbish in his mouth.
Leaving him inside an old toilet block, you head off to locate some cannibals.
To no avail. Damn, why are there none when you need them?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
They've cornered you. Some lucky gangers managed to back you into a dead-end alley. They're closing in, smelling blood in the water. The future's looking pretty grim.
But then somebody shows up. And he's packing.
The gangers hesitate. As the stranger holds them up, you duck into the door he appeared from.
Then, just as suddenly, the situation shifts. The gangers are no longer scared. Why? They split up, and move in fast. You watch the stranger cock the weapon and aim, but the nearest ganger just keeps coming, unperturbed.
Maybe they're calling his bluff?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Help the man. Stand together, die together.

Before you can reach him, the stranger disappears under a swarm of nihilistic gangers. It's glaringly obvious that he isn't gonna get up.
Spinning around, you dash for the door. A lucky thrown crowbar catches you before you can clear it, though. Staggering, you slam the door shut behind.
With blood obscuring your vision, you thread your way through the apartment, to the exit on the far side. All the while, you try and think of a reason why a complete stranger would put his life on the line to save you. Damn, that was noble.
Maybe one day you can pay the favor forward?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Leave the door open behind you. He might make it. Miracles can happen.

You can't bring yourself to slam the door on your anonymous savior, so you leave it open. Noble? Hardly. But it also means you have to move fast.
Through the apartment, and out the exit, before the gangers finish tearing the stranger asunder.
Good man, that. Damn, did I drop something?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Yell out your thanks. Then slam the door. Slow down the gangers.

You're not sure he heard. Having a gridiron team of nihilists tackling you isn't good for the acoustics. Doesn't matter, in the end. He's gone.
You slam the door shut, and get the heck out of there. Hoping all the while that next time you find yourself up the creek, there will be another like just like him.
Cross your fingers that karma is all crap, 'cause otherwise, you're in trouble.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Jam the door shut behind you, and disappear.

You slam the door behind you, and shove some debris against it, for good measure. Don't want any of those thugs chasing after you.
And the stranger? No point helping a man who's already dead. Sure, he put it on the line for you. But so what? Main thing is that you're still alive.
As you pass through the apartment, you notice a stash of gear. Must have belonged to the stranger. Rifling through it, you hope that he had the foresight to leave you something useful.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The stranger. You still feel bad that he died trying to save you back there. You had almost put it out of mind, but history decided to repeat itself.
You ran into another Samaritan in this old house. He gave you a tin cup of rat gut soup. Not bad, either. Things were going pretty okay, until the gate crashers showed up.
Slavers kick in the front door, probably attracted by the smell.
You jump to your feet and head for the rear exit. But he stands slowly, stretches, and hoists a hefty piece of timber. He's planting his feet, and squaring his shoulders.
Outnumbered, but unperturbed. He's willing to hold the line even while you make your escape.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Stand and deliver. If the man wants to die defending his home, then you're willing to do the same.

In a wastelands devoid of honor and morality, a man like this stands like a towering beacon of... melee violence!
You're forced to stand back against the wall as the old guy takes out one slaver after another, with powerful, sweeping hits. The lump of timber he's holding must have been forged by a dwarven king. But it doesn't last, it never does.
The slavers wise up, and one of them blasts him with a rifle. Flinging the timber overhand, like a vengeful spear of yore, the old man takes out the shooter, before toppling forward.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You'd love to help, but violence doesn't solve anything. Since you can't condone all this fighting, leave.

It would be inappropriate for you to stay and help a man whose only solution is violence. You dart out the back as things come to a head inside.
Man, but that rat gut soup was the tastiest meal you've had in a long time. What was the secret ingredient, ketchup? If you run out through the kitchen, there might be some leftovers.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Hey, thanks, pops! Give them one for me!" Make for the back door.

You bet that pops here watched every western back in the day. A man of few words, and even fewer actions. What kind of balls must it take to just stand there, lump of wood in your hand, facing imminent death and calmly say "Time to go, son"?
You don't need any more reminding.You pump your hand a couple of times, and tell him to sock it to them. If pops is going to slow them down, it's important he does a proper job of it. No point in him sacrificing himself on your behalf if the slavers steamrolled straight through him, right?
So, come on, pops, put some back into it!

table.name: encounters
table.column: If you're quick, real quick, you might be able to loot a few rooms on the way out.

While grandpa reenacts the Alamo, you speed-loot your way through the house on your way out the back door. You grab this and that before jumping out of a gaping window frame, figuring that the back door might be guarded.
Turns out, you were right: the back door *was* guarded. The window, too!
Scrambling to your feet, you dive for the fence, hoping to scale it and lose them in the next yard. A slaver snags your foot, though, and you fall hard on the jagged fence top. Your flesh tears as he pulls at your leg, and you kick out furiously. You land a solid heel to his throat, and slump the rest of the way over the fence.
Forget the loot. Forget whatever you dropped. Holding viscera in with your hand, you hobble away as fast as possible.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
This kid's been following you around for the last hour. Won't leave. He's not talking to you. Just content to tag along behind. Maybe you're the father figure he never had? He's got that semi-cared-for look about him. Probably from the nearby enclave.
You decide to head that direction, to at least get him pointed in the right direction. However, up jumps some rubble scum, and instinctively you run. The kid, unfortunately, twists his ankle on the uneven ground.
Expecting cries of help, you're shocked when he just gathers up a handful of nearby rocks, crouches, and begins methodically lobbing them at your pursuers.
Tough kid.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You can't leave the kid behind. Run back and save him.

"Hang on kid, I'm coming!"
You figure you'll make it to him before the rubble scum get there. But only just. Not enough time to grab him, but you might be able to fight them off together. Kid's pretty good with a rock.
You're almost there, when the sound of a rifle shot brings you to a dead stop. The kid. They've shot him. He's kneeling there, hand over a spurting shoulder. He catches your eye, and a hopeful look crosses his face.
Bang! This one kicks up dirt at your feet. With a last, apologetic glance at the kid, you dive off to the side. It's a tense flight through a maze of ruins, but you eventually gain some distance on them.
There's another shot, but all you can feel is buckets of adrenaline surging through your system. What's that dark stain on your clothing?

table.name: encounters
table.column: You can't leave the kid behind. Run back and save him.

"Hang on kid, I'm coming!"
You figure you'll make it to him before the rubble scum get there. But only just. Not enough time to grab him, but you might be able to fight them off together. Kid's pretty good with a rock.
You're almost there, when the sound of a rifle shot brings you to a dead stop. The kid. They've shot him. He's kneeling there, hand over a spurting shoulder. He catches your eye, and a hopeful look crosses his face.
Bang! This one kicks up dirt at your feet. With a last, apologetic glance at the kid, you dive off to the side. It's a tense flight through a maze of ruins, but you eventually gain some distance on them.
There's another shot, but all you can feel is buckets of adrenaline surging through your system. What's that dark stain on your clothing?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Aw, crap. You wring your hands in frustration. What are you going to do?

That poor kid. If you don't help him, he'll die for certain. But there are so many of them. Jeez!
You wring your hands, but you can't make up your mind. Watching the rubble scum to see what they do next, you fail to notice another pack of gangers, this one coming from the opposite direction. You're caught flat-footed as they charge you.
Bang! Down you go. Boots all around, kicking. A crowbar arcs downward, snapping aside your upraised arm. And again. You feel yourself choking on blood, unable to fend off the blows as your swollen eyes turn everything into flashes of red. Bright, shiny red...

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Go kid! Keep throwing. I'll come for you, maybe."

The kid's going to die, nothing you can do about it. At least he'll get a regular meal, up there in the great rubble pit in the sky. Assuming they let him in through the gates.
Should you yell back at him to aim for their legs and not their heads? Doubt that he'd hear you by now anyway, given how fast you're running.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Circle back later, once the kid's dead. Bet those enclavers will appreciate getting his corpse back for a proper burial.

On one hand, enclavers bring their kids up pretty tough. A chronic scarcity of resources doesn't leave them much choice. Kids are sent out to scavenge, knowing full well they may not make it back.
On the other hand, the kids are valued members. Enough that you turning up with someone's dead boy could merit a reward. Maybe even a meal?
The only hitch in the plan is that the rubble scum decide to take the boy alive. Probably going to sell him on to slavers or cannibals. Kid's worth more to them alive than dead.
Damn. As you walk away, plans deflated, you notice something in the dirt. Kid must have struggled, and caused one of the rubble scum to drop something.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Who knows what they made in this factory back in the day? Nothing now but rusting hulks of metal, corroding overhead walkways, and dark shadows.
A clutch of Froggers are huddled in one corner, over a fire. Tea time for the Church of the Blue Frog believers.
But there's something else in here. Something inhuman. You can tell by the smell. Wet fur, musky scent. A dogman.
You've been crouched here for the past half hour, and you still haven't got a good fix on it. But you think that it's moving in on the Froggers.
Yell a warning, and it could be you who's the target. Do nothing, and you've got cover for an escape. But they'll be guaranteed dog food.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Nobody deserves to be fanged by a dogman. Shout a warning, and cross your fingers.

You hail the Froggers, but they're slow to react. They start looking around, uncertain. There's a flash of movement in the nearby shadows. Crap, the dogman's moving towards you!
Running for the exit, you hear it pounding after you. There's a door up ahead. Maybe the dogman won't follow you outside?
It lunges, and you jig sideways, still moving. Barely a moment later, another lunge. It's touch and go like this for several eternal seconds.
Running full-tilt at the door, you shoulder it open. The dogman makes one final slash at your back, then you're through. Outside.
The dogman's probably circling back for his other prey, 'cause he's nowhere to be seen out here. You're safe, for now. Though your lungs burn, and you're shaking like a leaf.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Nobody deserves to be fanged by a dogman. Shout a warning, and cross your fingers.

You hail the Froggers, but they're slow to react. They start looking around, uncertain. There's a flash of movement in the nearby shadows. Crap, the dogman's moving towards you!
Running for the exit, you hear it pounding after you. There's a door up ahead. Maybe the dogman won't follow you outside?
It lunges, and you jig sideways, still moving. Barely a moment later, another lunge. It's touch and go like this for several eternal seconds.
Running full-tilt at the door, you shoulder it open. The dogman makes one final slash at your back, then you're through. Outside.
The dogman's probably circling back for his other prey, 'cause he's nowhere to be seen out here. You're safe, for now. Though your lungs burn, and you're shaking like a leaf.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Sit tight. It's not worth attracting the attention of a dogman.

The dogman takes his time. The Froggers have almost finished their tea before it lunges into the circle of light.
It tears through three Froggers in quick succession, ignoring the rest. In all three cases, it focuses on immobilizing them first, often biting at their exposed tendons. Then, it slashes open their bellies, forcibly thrusting its snout into their still-pulsing bodies. Feasting on their frantically beating hearts.
You choke down the impulse to vomit. Is this where dogmen get their vitamins and minerals from?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Get the Froggers' attention. They'll come running. Easy meat for the dogman.

"Hi! Hello," you shout.
The Froggers spot you, and as you thought, waste no time in hunting down a non-believer. The dogman is clever enough to take out the tail guard first. It slashes their throat, and then bounds after the rest. Manages to down two more before the others make it out the door.
With the Dogman feeding, you sneak by the fire for a look. It looks like the Froggers left something! You snatch it and get out of there.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You've been looking, but still no obvious sounds nor signs of movement. It's unnerving. This cavernous shopping mall just doesn't feel right.
You spot some sleeping enclavers. Plus a couple of extras standing guard. But that isn't what's making you uneasy. There's something here. Something else. It's too dark to see it, but you get the sense the enclavers are being stalked.
You've been out in the wastelands long enough to know that the enclavers aren't long for this world, anyway. You could probably slip away when it hits them. But should you?

table.name: encounters
table.column: They appear oblivious to the danger. Shout out a warning.

All instincts and action, you call out to the enclavers. They come sharply to attention at the sound of your voice. Up on their feet, they close up, weapons at the ready.
They're a surprisingly tight, well-trained group. Anything that wants to tackle them has a job on its hands. Unlike the one that just broadcast its position. Who could that be, you wonder? Damn.
Whatever it is, it's got better night vision than you. It moves faster, and it's hunting on home ground. You realize you're not going to make the exit. Running straight towards the enclavers is your only hope. Join their defensive circle. Together, maybe you could make it to the exit.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Don't risk becoming a target. Get out of there, now. Run!

It's a big shopping mall. The roof is largely intact, leaving the main pedestrian areas dark and gloomy. You've wandered a long way in, and the closest exit is minutes behind you. Less if you run. Is running a good idea? Probably not, but this THING, whatever is out there, is giving you the cold sweats.
Hoisting your gear, you bolt for the exit. Within steps, you know. It's onto you. Drawn to the frightened, fleeing prey. Damn your fear for overriding your sense. Despite your frantic, heavy breathing, external noises begin to intrude. A deep, rhythmic beating sound. Wings flapping? Damn big ones, if they are. And that smell. An acrid whiff of ammonia.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait until the blood starts flowing, then quietly depart.

When the creature attacks, it does so in such an unexpected manner that you are left momentarily stunned. The enclavers, even more so. They can't comprehend why the severed head of one of their number is rolling around in their midst like a macabre bowling ball.
Damn the plan, fear propels you to your feet and toward the exit before the screaming begins. You weren't planning on running, but they're making such a ruckus back there that nobody will notice you now. The image of that creature drives you on, legs pumping. The damn thing fell out of the air, snapped his body into neat pieces, and then launched itself back into the darkness on massive black wings.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The enclavers have a lot of gear. Wait 'til they're all dead and the creature's gone.

Awfully tempting to sit tight and wait. Nobody else will be coming to loot the leftovers. You'll have it all to yourself. Take your time. Patience.
The instant the creature strikes, however, you decide that patience can take a hike. There is no way you are going to sit there in the dark, when there's some kind of giant f-ing vampire bat chewing people's heads off JUST OVER THERE.
It takes everything you've got to stop yourself bolting straight for the exit. No sir, you are going to sneak your way out of there, quietly and slowly. Peeing your pants the whole way, if need be.
The screams of the enclavers echo wildly around the massive mall. One by one, the screams fall silent. Abruptly, mid-scream.
The exit. Focus on the exit.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You shouldn't have gone into the warehouse. Knew it was a mistake the moment the door swung closed behind you, locking you inside.
It's black in here. You can't discern much apart from the vastness of the space you're in. Barely enough to see your hands before your eyes. You stumble over something soft. Bending, you pick up...ugh. An arm. Torn at the shoulder.
A sudden scream indicates there's at least one other living person here. Then, more muffled sounds of movement. Panting. Intermittent screams. Running. Gurgling noises.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Call out to them. Ask them to wait, you'll be with them soon.

Okay, shouting wasn't the smartest move. Seriously, calling out in a darkened warehouse, with an unknown beast running rampant? Why not stick an emergency siren on your head and sprinkle salt and pepper over your body?
And those two guys? You think they're willing to stand there, stationary and exposed, in the middle of some creature's personal slaughterhouse, while they wait for a stranger to join them? Would you?
It's just that you couldn't help yourself. You had to shout out, and now the die is cast.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Attempt to kick the door down. You're getting out of here, one way or another.

It's a solid door, and you don't have much time. Brute force is your only hope.
Ignoring the jarring pain, you repeatedly throw yourself bodily against it, kicking it near the hinges for good measure. The noise and activity has attracted attention. You can hear the beast snarling, loping towards you.
Desperately, you hurl yourself at the door as if it's the gate to heaven. There's a loud crack, as the timber splinters. But the door holds. With no time for another run up, you kick at it. A hinge gives way, you push and shove, and the door falls outward.

table.name: encounters
table.column: There's a lot of movement. It's confusing. Sit tight until you form a clearer picture.

It's difficult to get a lock on the situation. There's the pair in the middle of the warehouse, and at least a couple of other people running around in the dark. At least you think that they're people. Nobody's screaming. Smart. You wouldn't want to give away your position, either.
There's a loud grunt, and a glimpse of disturbed dust motes swirling around a skinny, tentative shaft of sunlight. One left? Or is that the beast? You can't decide whether to wait or make your move.

table.name: encounters
table.column: There's a lot of movement. It's confusing. Sit tight until you form a clearer picture.

It's difficult to get a lock on the situation. There's the pair in the middle of the warehouse, and at least a couple of other people running around in the dark. At least you think that they're people. Nobody's screaming. Smart. You wouldn't want to give away your position, either.
There's a loud grunt, and a glimpse of disturbed dust motes swirling around a skinny, tentative shaft of sunlight. One left? Or is that the beast? You can't decide whether to wait or make your move.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Let the beast devour them. While it's occupied, make your escape.

It's a dogman. Twice it darts into the small circle of light. Each time, lashing out at the men's legs. Their Achilles tendons. You've seen it do that before, immobilizing their prey prior to feasting on them.
Another couple of strikes, and one man goes down. Alone, the other is unable to cover all the angles. Before long, both of them end up sprawled on the ground, shrieking and unable to stand.
What comes next is awful, but not unexpected. The dogman thrusts its large head inside their stomachs, and tears flesh out, swallowing it while the men's bodies twitch and thrash.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's a long way to the ground from the top of the office building. A section of the floor has recently collapsed.
Frightened screams of a woman echo off the walls. She's dangling in space, held by one arm of another enclaver. Doesn't look like he has enough muscle to pull her up over the ledge to safety.
You could run to help, but you risk the floor giving way under your extra weight. Nearby, you notice the enclavers' backpack, temporarily abandoned in the crisis.

table.name: encounters
table.column: He isn't going to hold her long enough for you to tip toe in. Gotta run in there. Risk it all.

Halfway there, the floor gives way.
You fall to the next floor, onto a pile of plaster and plastic. They, however, aren't so lucky. You hear the screams of the pair as they hit terminal velocity.
Gingerly wriggling your fingers and toes, you hope that everything is still intact. Nasty fall.

table.name: encounters
table.column: He isn't going to hold her long enough for you to tip toe in. Gotta run in there. Risk it all.

Halfway there, the floor gives way.
You fall to the next floor, onto a pile of plaster and plastic. They, however, aren't so lucky. You hear the screams of the pair as they hit terminal velocity.
Gingerly wriggling your fingers and toes, you hope that everything is still intact. Nasty fall.

table.name: encounters
table.column: No. Too dangerous. If the floor gives way everybody will die. Good luck, folks. Nothing you can do.

It's a shame, but no sense having three dead bodies when it can be just one.
You quickly turn, hoping to avoid the sight, and start walking away. An echoing shriek carries on a second or two, then cuts short. Your back and ears tingle at the thought of the mess, and you press on.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Quietly sneak in and take the backpack.

The backpack's heavy. You're about to sneak down the stairwell, when you hear a despairing shriek, signifying the end.
You rush into the stairwell, hoping not to hear the sickening wet thump from there. When clear of the drama, you pause to check the backpack. Damn, nothing there but junk. Well, apart from the pack itself.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
In an ideal world, you could help everybody that needed it.
Like this guy. An enclaver, hanging by one hand from part of a balcony, here on the fourth floor. A group of them were out there when it gave way. He's all that's left. Shouting that he can't hold on for much longer.
Glancing out the empty frame of a sliding glass door, you notice that you aren't the only person who's listening to all the noise. Rubble scum are pouring into the foyer down below.
There isn't much time. You bet they missed the pile of broken bodies, including that backpack, in the mess. But what about Mr. Death Grip here?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Haul him to safety. It's risky and you don't have much time, but you can't leave him.

You've been caught out like this yourself once or twice, and there's no way you're going to leave a potentially friendly enclaver to his grisly fate.
Inching out on your stomach, you reach down and grab him by the wrist. He's got enough sense to let go and do the same. With hands locked, you pendulum him back and forward, trying to build up enough momentum to enable him to get a leg over the edge.
Almost there. The enclaver's swinging through a sizeable arc when, crack! Something gives. Something structural.
The remaining balcony tilts, tipping you over the edge. The two of you fall, arms still locked, for a second. Maybe two. The impact below knocks the wind out of you. There's a taste in your mouth like iron, and your nose tingles painfully.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Haul him to safety. It's risky and you don't have much time, but you can't leave him.

You've been caught out like this yourself once or twice, and there's no way you're going to leave a potentially friendly enclaver to his grisly fate.
Inching out on your stomach, you reach down and grab him by the wrist. He's got enough sense to let go and do the same. With hands locked, you pendulum him back and forward, trying to build up enough momentum to enable him to get a leg over the edge.
Almost there. The enclaver's swinging through a sizeable arc when, crack! Something gives. Something structural.
The remaining balcony tilts, tipping you over the edge. The two of you fall, arms still locked, for a second. Maybe two. The impact below knocks the wind out of you. There's a taste in your mouth like iron, and your nose tingles painfully.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Leave him dangling. If he's still there, he'll keep the rubble scum busy enough for you to escape.

The problem with leaving him here is that, by the time the rubble scum arrive, he might have already plummeted to his death. You need him there, dangling and hollering for help, to act as a diversion. Without him, you're not sure if you'll be able to make it out of the hotel in time.
You call out to him, and tell him to hang in there while you get your rope. With rescue imminent, he'll hang there as long as necessary. Hope does that to you.
You close the door quietly on your way out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Pull him up, and get to work. Break one of his legs. He'll be a better distraction if you leave him like that.

You grab hold of some rotting bed sheets, twist them around, and throw the end within reach of old Death Grip here. He dutifully grabs hold of the improvised rope, and you pull as he hoists himself up and over the balcony.
You urge him inside, and wait until he crawls within reach, then slam a heavy desk lamp onto his tibia. He screams louder than a squealing teenager. Excellent!
You bolt from the room, and into another as rubble scum come charging up the corridor. The floor gives way, though, and you fall to the next with a thud, tangled in low-pile carpet. Rubble scum are shouting from the floor above, and you hear a couple land on the bed near you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're betting it's been a while since most hotels have been the scene of any love-making.
Not that that stops the couple of enclavers in this room. Peering in, you found them rutting like animals on a sagging bed. Busy making the next generation of survivors.
Admirable, apart from the hunting party of slavers sweeping through the hotel. There's time to warn them.
Or you could just steal their clothes, and let them enjoy their last few moments together.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell Romeo and Juliet to get their clothes on, there isn't much time.

You try to warn them. But Romeo and Juliet are too engrossed in their own Shakespearean play. And like most of the immortal Bard's efforts, you suspect that this one is also going to end in tragedy.
A tragedy you may well be a part of, if you don't get moving.
Improvising, you crawl underneath the shaking bed and make like a mouse. The slavers, bursting into the room, are delighted by what they've found. The enclavers, less so.
The subsequent two-act drama is notable only for its innovation and brutality. By the time you crawl out from under, they've gone. Dragging the sobbing girl with them.
The man, or what's left of him, remains on the bed. And a bit on you, too. You feel sick.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell Romeo and Juliet to get their clothes on, there isn't much time.

You try to warn them. But Romeo and Juliet are too engrossed in their own Shakespearean play. And like most of the immortal Bard's efforts, you suspect that this one is also going to end in tragedy.
A tragedy you may well be a part of, if you don't get moving.
Improvising, you crawl underneath the shaking bed and make like a mouse. The slavers, bursting into the room, are delighted by what they've found. The enclavers, less so.
The subsequent two-act drama is notable only for its innovation and brutality. By the time you crawl out from under, they've gone. Dragging the sobbing girl with them.
The man, or what's left of him, remains on the bed. And a bit on you, too. You feel sick.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Politely close the door. Hope the slavers don't bother looking inside.

You pull the door shut, quietly. Will it make any difference? The slavers, you know, are thorough. They'll check every room. Especially one with groans and sighs emanating from it.
So, no, it won't make a lick of difference, but it made you feel better about leaving them.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Jam the door firmly open. Ensure they're found. Nobody is allowed to have that much fun.

You shove some debris under the door to keep it open. Out of spite, as much as anything else. After all, nobody's offering to jump into bed with you.
But why would they? You stink. Your clothes are filthy. And your fingernails look as if they've been doing double-duty as a toilet brush. When was the last time you changed your underpants? Are you even wearing any? The only warm things that feel like cuddling up to you at night are lice.
Still, what you're doing is an act of pure bastardry. One day, you suspect, there'll be reckoning.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Sneak in and rob them blind. Won't be difficult.

Looting these two is a lot easier than expected. You could have run in, jumped up and down, and recited poetry for all the attention they were paying you. Temporarily, they're free of the troubles of the wasteland.
The sound of the approaching slavers only serves to emphasize the "temporary" aspect. Hey, not your problem.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
This is one huge parking lot.
Dead cars, buses, and trucks are jumbled all over. Most of them have been stripped of anything useful. A few serve as shelter to locals. You're caught crossing the lot when the slavers arrive.
Sweeping through the lot, they know there's bound to be people hiding amongst the rusted metal hulks. You stay low, and retreat back to the where the biggest concentration of vehicles are. You see a family huddled in the back of a bus, unaware of the danger.
There are enough hulks between you and the slavers to offer meager concealment, all the way to the remains of the shopping mall. You could make it, maybe, but you'd need a distraction.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Warn the family. Tell them you know a way to safety. The odds are long, but you've gotta try.

Within seconds, they're out of the bus, and following you. Real survivors know when to keep quiet and move fast.
Together, you crouch low, and run from one rusty hulk to the next. You're expecting a bullet in the back at any moment, but miraculously, all five of you make it to the mall without being seen. Without a word, they hive off down an empty corridor and leave you. Smart people. They'll make it.
Hold on. Damn! They've stolen some of your gear.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Get close enough to the bus so you can alert them to the danger, then head for the mall.

You hate it when a plan falls apart.
The family, once warned, are up fast and moving quietly, like cheetahs. Good for them, except they're heading for the same route you were planning on. And worse, just as they reach safety, they're spotted. The slavers go into heightened alertness born of frustration.
With your planned route busted, you're forced to take a more open path. You muster your energy, and sprint for it.
Less than halfway there, you're taking incoming fire. Bullets buzzing past, looking to sting soft flesh. One lands in your back, but not enough to stop you. At the mall, you duck out of sight, and don't stop running.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Get close enough to the bus so you can alert them to the danger, then head for the mall.

You hate it when a plan falls apart.
The family, once warned, are up fast and moving quietly, like cheetahs. Good for them, except they're heading for the same route you were planning on. And worse, just as they reach safety, they're spotted. The slavers go into heightened alertness born of frustration.
With your planned route busted, you're forced to take a more open path. You muster your energy, and sprint for it.
Less than halfway there, you're taking incoming fire. Bullets buzzing past, looking to sting soft flesh. One lands in your back, but not enough to stop you. At the mall, you duck out of sight, and don't stop running.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ignore the family. They're your ticket out of here. By the time the slavers bundle them up, you'll have reached the mall.

The slavers find them without a hitch, and round them up.
By the time you reach the mall, the family is hog-tied and helpless. They served their purpose. Shit happens.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Bus terminal. Rusted, burnt hulks litter the area, tilting on bare metal wheels. Fallen signage, torn seats, dirty, ripped carpets everywhere. And dust. Inches of it.
A man, darting from cover to cover, is heading towards you. Using the wreckage to weave a path to safety. Rubble scum are on his trail. They know that he's close, but they keep losing sight of him. You can hear their howls of anticipation.
You dive under the nearest bus, and wriggle out of sight. The man runs right up to where you are, unaware of your presence. Panting. Tired.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You rasp a warning to him, and gratefully, he slithers in under the bus and joins you. The rubble scum aren't far behind.
To your amazement, they come straight to where you are both hiding. The dust! Jesus. How could you have overlooked the dust? It's caked everything inside the terminal. The rubble scum don't need a tracker to see where Marathon Man has gone.
"Is it safe?" he croaks in a hoarse voice. "Is it safe?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You rasp a warning to him, and gratefully, he slithers in under the bus and joins you. The rubble scum aren't far behind.
To your amazement, they come straight to where you are both hiding. The dust! Jesus. How could you have overlooked the dust? It's caked everything inside the terminal. The rubble scum don't need a tracker to see where Marathon Man has gone.
"Is it safe?" he croaks in a hoarse voice. "Is it safe?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Roll a rock out from under the bus. Trick the rubble scum into thinking he's over there.

You push hard on a rock, hoping it draws rubble scum off from the bus. Instead, the rock plows a nice arrow through the thick dust. An arrow pointing directly towards whence it came.
It doesn't take long for the approaching gangers to reach you. Marathon Man, oblivious to your plight, has run right past you, and kept on going. The thing is, now that he has a head start, you're the nearest target for the gangers.
Run!
By the time you make it out of the terminal, you've taken three solid hits. You're still on your feet, but only just. A nearby ghetto of ruined dwellings is all that allows you to escape. Bending over, hands on your knees, you wonder just how bad the damage is.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Roll a rock out from under the bus. Trick the rubble scum into thinking he's over there.
