You push hard on a rock, hoping it draws rubble scum off from the bus. Instead, the rock plows a nice arrow through the thick dust. An arrow pointing directly towards whence it came.
It doesn't take long for the approaching gangers to reach you. Marathon Man, oblivious to your plight, has run right past you, and kept on going. The thing is, now that he has a head start, you're the nearest target for the gangers.
Run!
By the time you make it out of the terminal, you've taken three solid hits. You're still on your feet, but only just. A nearby ghetto of ruined dwellings is all that allows you to escape. Bending over, hands on your knees, you wonder just how bad the damage is.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're a big believer of hear no evil, see no evil. Let him go.

They catch him, not far from your position. A couple of gangers hold him, while others hog tie him to a wooden pole. Marathon Man, his head hanging upside down, notices you hiding under the bus.
You give him a silent thumbs up, one survivor to another.
He yells. "Over there, under the bus!" So much for survivor solidarity.
Exiting out from the far side of the bus, you make tracks out of the terminal. Hard to say if anyone is paying him attention, but you aren't going to hang around to find out.
The worst of it is that you probably lost some gear in the scramble.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Pull on that old electrical cable. Trip him. Then get out of there, fast.

Tough luck, guy. You pull on the cable, and down he goes. Sprawled in the dust, the rubble scum fall upon him like wolves from the hills.
Discreetly departing the scene, you try and think why you pulled the cable? Have you become so calloused as to automatically discard anyone that buys you a chance?
Maybe you have. But so what? If sacrificing others keeps you breathing, then you aren't going to argue. You start to anger over having to justify your actions to the do-gooder inside.
Memo to self: it's the wastelands, what the hell do you expect?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You've come across a funeral parlor. There's a storage room out back, stacked full of wooden coffins. Most of them have been broken up for firewood, but one or two remain.
You open one to find a man, woman, and child sleeping inside it, enjoying the padded luxury. Surprised, you slam the lid back down, and sit on it while you think of a plan. The rubble scum family frantically bang the lid underneath you.
Are they legit? Or the type to jump you as soon as you turn your back?
As far as you're concerned, there is no worse fate than being buried alive. Being trapped in a coffin must come close. There is, you notice, a lock mechanism on the side of the coffin. Must have been a luxury number.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You can't do it. Not even rubble scum deserve to be consigned to such a horrible fate. Let them out.

Keeping in mind what happens when you kick a hornet's nest, you jump off the lid, and leap to your feet. You don't stop running until you are out the door, through the chapel, and into the street.
Farther away, you slow to a walk. You aren't convinced that you did the right thing. It feels right, but it's rubble scum. Just as likely to rob you, as walk on by. And you just saved them.
Well, you didn't actually save them, did you? More a case of not killing them. Damn confusing either way.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Lock it down. Come back in a few days and loot their corpses.

Closing the latch, you watch to see what transpires.
The lock holds for a minute, but desperate kicking, punching, and pushing from within soon break it apart. The lid flies open, knocking you back.
Off balance, you're unable to prevent the rubble scum family exiting their timber tomb. Both the man and woman belt you around before leaving. Guess you weren't appreciated. On the plus side, they can't have been all that bad to have left you alive.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Lock it down. Come back in a few days and loot their corpses.

Closing the latch, you watch to see what transpires.
The lock holds for a minute, but desperate kicking, punching, and pushing from within soon break it apart. The lid flies open, knocking you back.
Off balance, you're unable to prevent the rubble scum family exiting their timber tomb. Both the man and woman belt you around before leaving. Guess you weren't appreciated. On the plus side, they can't have been all that bad to have left you alive.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Bah! Rubble scum. Lock the lid. Round up some rubbish and that lighter. Set fire to the coffin.

You've been wandering the wastelands long enough to be numb to all forms of brutality. All that matters is that you rid the world of one more threat. If it means burning three people alive to achieve that, then so be it. You're cleansing the Augean stables, one shovel load of muck at a time.
They break the lock, but you had sufficient foresight to stack the lid with enough weight to keep them down. As the flames lick up the sides, the screams reach a crescendo. One high-pitched voice piercing through the racket, "Help us, PLEASE! Help us!"
You're not supposed to enjoy this. That wouldn't be right. No, sir.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You happen across a dense, tangled thicket of forest, where even sunlight treads warily. The vegetation is darker, heavier, almost reptilian in form and nature.
You hear no rustling of leaves, no birds, no scrapings of small rodents through the undergrowth. The wood is soundless, mute, expectant. Like a predator about to pounce, it appears silently poised, anticipating the movement of its prey.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Having no desire to penetrate its forbidding depths, you leave.
As you stride away, shivering, you hear the sound of a woman's voice calling from behind. You pause, uncertain. The velveteen, smoky tones of the woman's voice are inviting. It almost sounds like she's calling your name.
Turning, all you can see is the path. But the voice continues calling, beckoning...

table.name: encounters
table.column: In this dank air, sweat beads on your forehead and streams down your ribs from the exertion. Your heart jack hammers wildly and your skin feels clammy and wet. Continuing on will be thirsty, sweaty work, and you begin to curse your fast metabolism.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Carefully, hesitantly, you proceed down the path and around the bend. Improbably, the vegetation becomes even darker and thicker. And unnatural silence reigns.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You decide that the mysterious, disembodied voice is no more comforting than the creepy forest was originally.
Maybe you'll try the next forest, provided it isn't seemingly designed to frighten people.
As if to punctuate that thought, the path seems to become lost in overgrowth, leaving behind nothing but a barrier of weeds, thorns, and bark.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Misjudging a gap in the dense tangle of underbrush, you fail to stay on the path and are raked by the spines of a large tree. Blood streams from your skin, mingling with the sweat and grime. Proceeding further down the path is clearly not going to be easy with your poor eyesight.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Stepping over and around numerous dangerous-looking plants and obstacles is tiring work. The twisting path forces you to duck and lean. You're beginning to wish you were in better shape.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Looking around, it's clear where the path winds further into the forest. Though the path behind you seems to have disappeared into the slithering undergrowth.
And still, nothing stirs. No sounds nor movement. Dark, clammy vegetation clings tenaciously to your clothing, no matter where you stand.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Determined to not be caught flat-footed, you strike a defensive stance, and put up your guard.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Normally you'd be skirting the path from the safe cover of the wood. However, the foliage looks less than trustworthy here.
You decide to compromise that tactic, and instead use the blind curves and mounds of the path to minimize your exposure.
The dead silence makes it tough, but you hope that same difficulty plagues anything trying to sneak up on you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Without the everyday references of noise and movement, your imagination unwittingly fills in the gaps. All manner of horrors hide behind every bush and tree. You feel queasy and jumpy and regret having continued down the path.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide to press onward, hoping that moving forward reveals something, or at least a way out.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The path shows no sign of either animal or man, but you notice broken stems and crushed undergrowth at irregular intervals adjacent to it.
Something has moved through the area recently. Something big. Something sufficiently nimble and intelligent enough to not leave its spoor on the path.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You recognize none of the plants, but notice that quite a few are equipped with oversized, barbed leaves. Careful to not brush up against anything, you wonder if they're poisonous.
You resolve to eat or drink nothing until you have left the Glade.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The path looks strange. Awkward, convoluted lines, a constant set width.
Something about it tells you that it has been made not by the natural passage of animals but by a deliberate, conscious entity. There is a strange symmetry to the edges. A ragged, repeating pattern that conjures discomforting images of a predator's bite mark.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You notice a distant sound of breaking branches. It jars rudely against the harsh silence.
Cocking your head to hear better, you flinch as it grows in volume. It's heading your way. A rhythmic pounding separated by gaps of dismembering vegetation. Like it's leaping or galloping great distances.
It's coming closer. Much closer. An unstoppable force forewarned by a deep, guttural growling.
Tensing, you realize that whatever hellish abomination this is will be upon you in moments.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Your eyes catch a detail you missed before. There's a shift in the light up ahead. A brightness spilling into the thick air, hinting at a clearing.
You move forward, and the path reveals a sunlit glade. For the first time, you notice color, movement.
Standing before you is a lady. Tall, slender, and dressed in a flowing ethereal white gown. Calling your name, she beckons you forward. Her captivating voice only reinforces your desire to touch, hold, and possess.
As you reach out to take her hand, she vanishes. Angry that you have been denied, fighting back a deep sense of loss, you blink, struggling to come to terms with the abrupt transition.
Left before you, on the ground, are several items. Ahead, a path opens through the dense vegetation.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Throw a rock into the trees ahead.

Ah, rocks. The poor man's scout.
You pry a fist-sized stone from the damp underbrush, and heave it forward. Unfortunately, in the silence of this wood, you make almost as much noise throwing the rock as it does landing in the muck up ahead.
Silence resumes as the stone settles under some plants. Any nearby creatures remain hidden, though now informed that you can throw rocks.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You shout, inquisitively, into the forest ahead. Even if she isn't calling you, maybe your voice will help spur a dialog.
Your voice disappears into the wood, like a pebble in a barrel of motor oil. Worse, the woman's voice seems to have ceased calling.
Nothing but close air and silence now.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Your nose twitches, as it detects the faint odor of rotting flesh.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Stepping over and around numerous dangerous-looking plants and obstacles is far from easy. The twisting path forces you to duck and lean.
Fortunately, you're in good shape. The exercise is more invigorating than taxing.

table.name: encounters
table.column: A narrow path wends its way tentatively into the depths of the forest, disappearing around a bend only a short distance from where you are anxiously standing.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Your foot squelches down on something wet and warm. Nervously jumping backwards, you peer at the squashed fruit you have just trodden on. Strange, you don't recall seeing any tree fruit. Come to think of it, this doesn't look like any fruit you know.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Snapping your head sideways, you wonder if the sudden movement in your peripheral vision was real or imagined? It was fast. Lightning fast.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The dank, moist air forms beads and drips from your eyebrows. A strange spore is irritating your nose, and you feel a sneeze coming on. Gritting your teeth, you hold it in. There are places to sneeze, and this is definitely not one of them.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Defiantly, you whistle. Tentatively at first. Then louder as you gain confidence. The all-encompassing quiet is neither normal nor natural.
Finding your rhythm, you launch into a lively rendition of Yankee Doodle Dandee. Until you hear the *other* whistle. The low-pitched reply sounds as if it's reluctantly seeping out of a grave, filtered by the earth and tuned by Death himself.

table.name: encounters
table.column: There is something peculiar about the oppressive silence. It isn't as if all noise has ceased but more that you have entered a void. A dead space that has never known sound.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Puzzled and confused, your eyes are drawn to the imprints the lady left in the soft ground, all that remains of her alluring presence.
Leaning forward, frowning, you look again. You realize that you must have been mistaken, because the imprints are not those of a human. Perhaps it is the faint, lingering scent of cinnamon that has muddled your mind.
Does that also explain her index finger? The one that...no matter.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Quietly open the door and sneak in.

You sneak up to the door, and reach forward to push the door open.
This door hasn't seen oil for a long time, as the hinges threaten to groan louder than your belly. Pausing, you wait for some ambient noise outside to mask the sound, then push fast to minimize the creak.
Once inside, you leave the door as is. If something's in here, the glaringly bright doorway will work to your advantage.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Without pausing for further thought, you run. Run like one of those hapless people you see in movies, scrambling futilely in the path of a great beast.
Tangles of creepers and vines pull at your limbs, and your pace only slows in the spider web of undergrowth.
And behind you, the beast bounds closer with each heartbeat, jarring your bones each time it lands with tremendous weight.
A feeling of helpless nausea overcomes you as it makes one last leap, pounding against your back, and crushing your innards from your body as you both land.
Your mind immediately starts shutting down, blocking out the horror of your own mutilation.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Sit tight and hide. Maybe it won't see you.

No time to find a good hidey hole, you duck under some exotic canopy and freeze. Maybe it's one of those things that only sees movement.
Peering through the foliage, hope for that outcome quickly fades, as the beast arcs through the air toward you. The gray hulk lands hard, tearing up the mossy floor with three powerful legs as it redirects its landing towards you.
Before you can get to your feet, it rams into you, shouldering your mouth, and sending you back to the ground. Blood saturates your lips, and you lose focus of your surroundings...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Bracing, assuming a combat crouch, you ready yourself for battle. Sudden movement catches your eye. Instinctively launching off your back foot, you propel yourself forward.
It's in mid-air when you catch your first glimpse. Thick muscle, gray hide, three legs, and dark red eyes. It lands with a bone-jarring thud, and leaps again, straight at you.
Your defenses are no match for its momentum, however. Its arc terminates square on your chest, grinding you into the soft floor like a plough.
You swing and claw at it, but it easily keeps you pinned with its forelegs, clawed arms rending your flesh. Your flailing reduces to an absently raised arm, and then nothing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Focusing on the tree above, you wonder why you are so cold? It might be because you are lying on the ground, but you gradually realise that the spreading pool of blood beneath you has more to do with it.
The beast is gone. The damage is done. Of all your limbs, only your left arm is responding. Bloodied, raw flesh dangles before you, as if it has been peeled back from a ripe fruit.
There is no pain, only recognition of the end. Memories flicker, stutter, extinguish. Shivering...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Later, much later, a soft caress coaxes your eyes open. You find a lady smiling down upon you, her hand upon your cheek. Skin tingling, and blood surging, you wriggle your toes. As you struggle to form words, she steps back. Turning, you look for her, but she is gone. All that's left is an unfamiliar item on the ground next to you.
Despite your relief at still being amongst the living, you struggle to dispel the retinal image of the lady's index finger. One moment, it was soft and seductive, caressing. The next...
Does it matter? Was it real? It was so... You could easily have mistaken it for a fungus-covered twig. In fact, on reflection, you are certain that's what it was.
Near-death experiences do not make for clear memories. Vivid, certainly, but not clear. You inspect the item before you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Bracing, assuming a combat crouch, you ready yourself for battle. A sudden movement of foliage catches your eye.
It's in mid-air when you catch your first glimpse. Thick muscle, gray hide, three legs, and dark red eyes. It lands with a bone-jarring thud, and leaps again, straight at you.
You launch at it, grappling just above the ground, and the collision sends you both tumbling into the brush. It's quickly on its feet, and sets about stomping viciously on you.
Gritting through the pain, you throw your weight at a supporting leg, and crumple it to the ground. It shrieks, raking you with a clawed arm, as it tries to separate from you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
One thing this forest has in spades is good cover. Using that to your advantage, you slide up against a hollow, and focus on not making a single creak.
The creature bounds into view, and it's unlike anything you've ever seen before. A gray, hulking beast stoops on three legs, with two clawed arms protruding from its underside. It leaps with an alarming range, quickly covering the area as it searches.
Then, it bounds in the direction it was originally traveling, stopping occasionally to search.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Bracing, assuming a combat crouch, you ready yourself for battle. A sudden movement of foliage catches your eye.
It's in mid-air when you catch your first glimpse. Thick muscle, gray hide, three legs, and dark red eyes. It lands with a bone-jarring thud, and leaps again, straight at you.
You wait for the right moment, then shift your stance to take advantage of its momentum. It lands all wrong, and lets out a piercing shriek.
Its hind leg props it up, and it launches at you with alarming speed, tackling you. Fighting off an animal is no easy task to begin with, but this thing's extra leg throws off your technique.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Bracing, assuming a combat crouch, you ready yourself for battle. A sudden movement of foliage catches your eye.
It's in mid-air when you catch your first glimpse. Thick muscle, gray hide, three legs, and dark red eyes. It lands with a bone-jarring thud, and leaps again, straight at you.
You wait for the right moment, then spring at it, shoulder first. You connect with it, hard, just above the ground. The impact sends both of you into a spin, rolling across the ground.
Its hind leg props it up, and it begins stomping on you as you scramble for footing.
When you finally get your heel under your body, you push up, sending the beast back several meters.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Judging by its thunderous gallop, this thing doesn't spend a lot of time touching the ground. A straight run through this thick foliage is probably a losing game.
You decide to try for higher ground. Maybe it's not a climber.
Pulling yourself from branch to branch, you quickly put distance between you and the ground. At about five meters up, you catch your first glimpse of it.
It's a stooped, hulking gray thing on three legs, with clawed arms and dim red eyes. It ambles a few steps before leaping a good ten meters forward. So much for the climber theory.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Gauging its approach, you find a suitable branch to pin back. In such a damp environment, there's a lot of play in the branches, and you think you might have a chance if you time things just right.
Unfortunately, for this to work, the beast will have to see you.
As it bounds into view, you almost lose your resolve. It's a stooped, hulking gray thing on three legs, with clawed arms to boot. It swings its head around like a pendulum, looking for you.
Gathering your nerve, you shout at it, and its dim red eyes snap towards you, fixated. It shrieks, then leaps with frightening speed.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
When the beast has passed beyond earshot, you notice her: a lady, peering at you from a hiding place of her own.
Tall, slender, and shrouded in an ethereal white gown, she places an item on the ground, as if making an offering.
Then, she turns. You follow her gaze, and notice a path opened through the dense vegetation. It definitely wasn't there before. Was it?
Looking back towards her, she's gone. You spring forward, searching behind the tree she was near. But you find nothing. There are strange imprints on the ground, but your mind must have been playing tricks on you. Definitely no human prints.
Perhaps it's the faint, lingering scent of cinnamon that has muddled your mind? Shaking your head, you inspect the item before you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With the beast arcing through the air towards you, you release the branch at the last possible moment.
It whips forward, a chorus of pitched air rushing around thick and thin branches, and whacks the beast hard in its chest. The beast's fall continues, though, and clips you as it lands, sending the two of you tumbling through the forest floor.
It recovers fast, and rakes at you with its clawed arm, tearing flesh. It stomps on you, and shrieks at your face. Then, it leaps off, clear out of sight within one or two bounds.
Your body aches, ears ringing, and you start to lose focus...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Improvising a plan B, you decide it'll at least wish it hadn't jumped at you if you're far enough out on a limb.
You rise to your feet, and walk the balance beam as quickly as you can manage on the moist branch.
The beast shrieks at you, and the rhythmic galloping thuds resume, coming your way.
Part way out on the branch, you hear it shove off in a great leap, and catch it sailing upward at you.
At the last moment, you drop low, trying to position the branch between you. It collides hard, splintering the tree's limb, and jarring you into a fall.
Beast, human, and battered foliage all fall in a crash, and everything goes dark...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You close the gap, and swing hard at the beast, landing your fist against hard, tough hide. Even as strong as you are, you doubt you'll do a lot of damage this way.
The beast rams into you, and knocks the wind out of you with a stomp, before bounding off with a shriek.
Throbbing with pain, your sight starts to go fuzzy...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With its three legs alternately pinning and pounding you, you do your best to parry the clawing arms. And for an instant, you gain purchase of one of the thinner limbs, wrenching it firmly, which produces a promising "pop."
It rears back, shrieking again, then jams a foot on you once more.
Fortunately, that seems to have been a parting shot, as it bounds off, clutching its arm.
As it leaves view, you slump to the ground, dazed...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It kicks off, and you're on your feet again as it leaps at you. This time, you grapple with its arms as it knocks you down.
It continues using its legs like fists, pounding at your pinned body, when you surprise it by switching from push to pull. Yanking on its arms, you smash your forehead into its mouth, producing a satisfying gurgling noise.
It kicks off violently, pounding you into the ground once more, and bounds off, having lost its appetite for a fight.
You wince as the pain finally sets in, and slump down on the soft, wet ground.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Pushing through the stainless steel door, a rush of warm, greasy air fills your nose, replacing the damp coolness from outside. Your stomach "urps" almost instantly, in anticipation of whatever you smell on the grill.
The decor is somewhat less inviting, however. Despite a number of lights, most of them seem incapable of dispelling the dimness in the space. And sepia-stained curio along the walls seem to capture more of the creepy awkwardness of the diner's history than nostalgia. Padded stools line the long countertop, and booths run the length of the outer wall, sporting ripped vinyl benches. A stark pattern of 1-inch tiles dots the floor.
Not surprising, in retrospect, that the take-out line was so long. Still, an open seat and a warm meal are promised land compared to eating condensed soup in the rain. You shove your stuff into an empty booth, and start paging through the laminated menu.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Order Combo 1: Fried chicken, mac and cheese, and red beans with rice. Price $24.50

For once, fried chicken might be the healthiest thing for you. After days in the wild, a little bit of body fat might actually do you some good!
When it arrives, you can almost taste the greasy spices from its intoxicating scent. Forgoing utensils, you dive into the chicken, and it slides easily off the bone, into your gullet.
The mac and cheese is rich and creamy, and the beans and rice feels like it'll fill your stomach for days. If paradise was a dish, it'd be fried chicken in front of a starving scavenger.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The Red Gnome is an exception in an already exceptional city.
Situated on a busy corner in Gate 11's "Neon Alley", the single-story, streamline diner defies the densely packed high-rises and elevated roads around it. In fact, several adjoining buildings seem to grow over the diner, using the precious space above its roof.
It seems almost untouchable in an otherwise claustrophobic warren of glittering skyscrapers and patchwork overpasses.

table.name: encounters
table.column: On second thought, maybe you aren't so hungry. You head back into the streets.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Order Combo 3: Cadillac burger, mashed potatoes with gravy, and cornbread. Price $32.50

In true diner fashion, you don't have to wait long for your plate. It arrives hot, the aroma of gravy, cornbread, and beef carried by thin wisps of steam.
The burger is more meatloaf than patty, topped with elbow macaroni and ketchup. What this has to do with a Cadillac, you're not sure.
But man, does it ever hit the spot. As you smush the soft food around your mouth, you look around the room at the various photos and decor.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Order Combo 2: Jumbo fried shrimp, collard greens, black-eyed peas, and peach cobbler. Price: $20

Your eyes fixated on the kitchen door, you wait impatiently for the food. Doesn't even have to be your order. You'll gladly accept a misdelivered plate.
When it does arrive, you have to restrain yourself from going feral on the dinner. With some effort, you take a controlled bite of the first piece of shrimp.
Your mouth floods with saliva. There's a stinging sensation radiating from the side of your tongue as flavor drips over it.
Pecking around the plate, you sample the sides, mixing them in your mouth. The savory flavors compliment each other, rounded out by the sweet and sour of the peach.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There are some photos of the diner up there. People shaking hands for the camera. Visitors. News clippings.
As you scoop some more gravy-slathered potato into your mouth, you notice a photo of the still-standing diner surrounded in smoldering rubble.
In another photo, there's some sort of riot going on. An earlier shot of the same scene as above? Soldiers are taking shelter from a throng of angry civilians.
In yet another, an abandoned parade is roped off in police tape.
If the decor seemed weird upon entering, it's downright dark now. You take another look around the diner, half expecting to find yourself being watched.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
But nothing seems amiss. Just a few folks minding their business. Reading a paper, or looking out the window.
Shaking your head, you finish your meal, and admire the healthy roundness of your belly. For once, your fatigue seems to be born of overeating, and it's wonderful.
Sensing you've finished, the waiter comes back with a notepad, scribbles a bit, and informs you, "That'll come to $32.50."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's one of the pricier meals, but you suspect getting real beef in this city is a tall order. And judging by the business this place is doing through take-out, it doesn't have much competition. At least, not out here between Core City and the walls.
You pay for the meal, then a thought occurs to you: do people still tip?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The usual line of people outside the take-out window awaits their turn.
You catch hints of fryer and grill scents wafting across the street.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You consume the entire meal without regard for the world around you. As you pick the last morsel from the plate, you feel a sensation that has eluded you for days: fullness.
You sit back, and the rest of the diner comes back into focus. The waiter scribbles something on a receipt, and places it on the table before you, then clears your plates.
A moment of giddiness strikes you as you realize you've finished a meal without worrying about rain, concealment, or attracting predators.
Flipping over the receipt, it reads $20 below some unintelligible scribbling.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Whether tipping is still the rule or not, you have a feeling you'll be back here again. Can't hurt to leave a good impression.
You dole out a bit extra for the fine meal.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You shrug your shoulders. Guess you'll find out later!

table.name: encounters
table.column: You shrug your shoulders. Guess you'll find out later!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Real shrimp in Detroit, huh? You guess that's not impossible. Shrimp farming is pretty high-density stuff.
And $20 is hardly a cheap plate. But hey, that feeling in your stomach is worth almost any price.
You pay for the meal, then a thought occurs to you: do people still tip?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Even before entering, you get the sense that there is something unusual about the place.
For one thing, despite a prodigious amount of tagging on every surface, the diner is left unmarred. As if those around here know better than to try.
However, that ominous thought doesn't seem to deter anyone's hunger. A line snakes out from a take-out window, under a sign boasting "Real Soul Food! Real Meat!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Whether tipping is still the rule or not, you have a feeling you'll be back here again. Can't hurt to leave a good impression.
You dole out a bit extra for the fine meal.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Kicked Out of the Red Gnome

You turn to look, and his imposing frame is silhouetted in the doorway. His eyes almost seem lit, penetrating your heart.
"You damn RIGHT you runnin'!" he shouts. "Come BACK here an' we'll see. We'll see! You HEAR me?"
Ducking across the street and out of sight, you can hear the look of his crazy eyes in his voice, even though you can't see him in your blind retreat.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Order Combo 2: Jumbo fried shrimp, collard greens, black-eyed peas, and peach cobbler. Price: $20

But you feel someone looking at you. You peer up from the menu, and even in the periphery of your view, you can see him in the window of the kitchen door.
It sends a chill down your spine.
Staring directly at you through the portal, his face is dark, shadowed from the kitchen lighting. And his eyes seem to have a fire of their own.
Afraid to turn your back on him, you grab your things, and back down the aisle to the exit.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Order Combo 2: Jumbo fried shrimp, collard greens, black-eyed peas, and peach cobbler. Price: $20

However, it appears your reputation as a cheapskate has caught up with you.
"You!" comes a bellow from the kitchen door. A man in an apron, who looks like he might just be willing to use his trade's tools on you, storms around the counter toward your table.
You decide to grab your stuff and bolt, since he doesn't look like he's in the mood for negotiating.
You burst outside, clutching your things, and you hear the door fly open behind you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Pushing through the front door, the familiar smells of soul food fill your nose. As usual, there are a few empty booths, and you slide into one, making yourself comfortable.
You pick up a menu.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Whether tipping is still the rule or not, you have a feeling you'll be back here again. Can't hurt to leave a good impression.
You dole out a bit extra for the fine meal.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Boy, it sure was nice of them to feed you. Too bad you're a moocher.
Grabbing your stuff, you start making your way to the door. As you cross the diner, you hear a shout from behind, "Hey!"
You bolt, pushing your way outside, hoping to put distance between you and the waiter chasing after you.
Down the block, you think you've lost him, and start looking around for your next destination.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's a hefty price for a plate, but the brickload of food in your stomach will definitely last a while.
Plus, there aren't a lot of chickens running around out in the wilderness, let alone deep-fryers. Must be some sort of vertical farm around here. No room for anything but.
You pay for the meal, then a thought occurs to you. "Do people still tip?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You lean back, and let out a contented sigh. For once, your stomach is full, the air is comfortable, and there's no rain on your head.
Your server comes by the table, leaves a receipt, and carries off your tableware. Someone just *served* you! It's going to be hard facing the wilderness again after this.
You turn the receipt over, and under some scribbling, it reads $24.50.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A harsh ringing and blinding pain assaults your head, and you reach for a nearby post as you exit.
You crane your head upward to look around, and jump when you notice a small silhouette. It sees you, and sways, then shifts out of view.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Stumbling across the street, the small form appears again, and it lopes frighteningly towards you.
People seem both shocked and disgusted by your performance, seemingly unable to see the fearful humanoid. But you have no energy to explain. All you can do is stagger away through the pain.
Eventually, after collapsing in a heap near some garbage, the pain starts to subside.
Your audience has lost interest, though one final glance proves that the proprietor hasn't. You push to your feet, and vow never to return.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The voice continues, "You are hereby discharged from DMC Gate 11, marked and exiled for a period of 1 year. Failure to comply with this sentence is cause for appended term of exile not to exceed 2 years per infraction."
A door on the opposite wall buzzes, and swings open, blinding you temporarily with the light from outside.
When your eyes finally adjust, you see the cold, muddy streets outside the DMC walls, and the huddling throngs of Sprawl inhabitants going about their business.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You get the feeling you're being stalked. You pause, listening, and straining to make out any signs of movement in the surroundings.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Suddenly, you hear the sounds of something charging at you!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Haggerty Health Clinic is a pretty busy spot. Its proximity to Gate 11, and its mercenary attitude toward clientele, ensures that it has a steady stream of business, from both inside the DMC and Sprawl.
The "Double H", as it's often called, offers a wide spectrum of health services. Those include diagnostics, cleaning and dressing of wounds, therapeutics (including nanorobotic suspension treatments), and prescription drugs.
There is also an on-site augmentation clinic, where patients can elect for prosthetic enhancements. These highly desired services may require special permits, in addition to the significant price tags.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The familiar blast of warm, dry air greets you as you pass through the automatic doors.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you cross the street, you can't help noticing the activity on the rooftop. The high-pitch whines of turbines mark the coming and going of hover vehicles, spraying water from the landing pad into a fine mist that rains around the building.
A large proportion of the vehicles appear to be unaffiliated, private ambulance services.
You huddle your shoulders against the spray, and duck under the brightly lit awning. Staggered automatic doors, forming a crude airlock, shoosh open as you approach.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide to leave the clinic.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Inside, the lobby looks a lot like any other clinic. There are banks of attached seats covering most of the floor, and counters for both receiving patients and dispensing pharmaceuticals.
Dominating the right wall, near a hallway and elevator bank, is an LED sign displaying the currently served customers. Letter and number combinations update at random intervals as nurses escort patients to and from the room.
You head over to the counter, and get your waiting number. It isn't long before the LED lotto calls your number, and you're led away for consultation.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You head over to the counter, and get your waiting number. It isn't long before the LED lotto calls your number, and you're led away for consultation.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patient will receive emergency oral or intravenous rehydration and micronutrition solution, in order to restore fluid and nutrient levels to basal norms.
Cost: $183

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patient will receive a battery of tests, including blood testing, imaging, full physical, and toxicology screen.
Cost: $213

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patient's wounds will be cleaned and disinfected. Open wounds will be staunched, and treated with traditional sutures or Suturefoam. Fractures and broken bones on limbs will be splinted.
Cost: $376

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Unlike the diagnostics practice of old, modern diagnostics can largely be performed without having to frequently change rooms and setups. Improvements in imaging, shielding, and sampling techniques, as well as a greater understanding of biology, have led to a more comprehensive and compact diagnostic procedure.
The process is reminiscent of a CAT scan, followed by extraction of fluid and tissue samples. The results are then processed by a computer, and the technicians interpret the output.
When finished, a nurse reviews your diagnostics with you:

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patient will receive nanorobotic suspension dosage intravenously, which combats several known illnesses and poisons and bolsters the body's immune system and natural healing rate.
Cost: $363

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patients suffering hypothermia will be subjected to gradual core body rewarming and tissue therapy, restoring normal basal temperature.
Patients suffering hyperthermia will be subjected to evaporation heat removal treatment, to reduce core body temperature to basal norms.
Cost: $199

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patient will receive 6 doses of prescription sleeping pills.
Cost: $120

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patient will receive 6 doses of prescription analgesic pills (painkillers).
Cost: $180

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patient will receive a transfusion of compatible blood type or synthetic equivalent, restoring blood pressure to normal.
Cost: $2563

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patient will receive 6 doses of broad-spectrum, prescription antibiotics.
Cost: $300

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Very well. The dispensary should have those prepared shortly."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Is there anything else we can help you with?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Upstairs to Prosthetic and Augmentation Procedures

You begin speaking with an attendant, who reviews your eligibility test results.
Unfortunately, initial testing indicates that you are not a good candidate for any of the prosthetic nor augmentation procedures. This is probably due to either previous surgery, or synthetic rejection complications.
However, you may still browse the procedures.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Very well. The dispensary should have those prepared shortly."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're led to a specialized waterproof chamber about 3 meters high and 1 meter in diameter. A humanoid harness stands in the middle, and the walls are a hard, transparent material like pyrex or plexiglass. There is a drain set into the tapered floor, and a combination of air and fluid nozzles dot the walls at regular intervals.
The treatment takes some time, as the core body temperature has to be gradually changed to avoid inducing shock or other complications.
Afterward, while gathering your things, you're told to watch for persistent symptoms such as thermal instability, as you may need to return to avoid complications.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're escorted to an open bed, and probes are attached to monitor vital signs, blood characteristics, and other metabolic factors.
Then, you're fed gradual amounts of specialized fluids, custom mixed for your level of malnutrition and dehydration.
The process takes a while, since the body requires time to metabolize the nutrients, and show signs of improvement.
However, when done, you feel that most of your strength and concentration has been restored.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Order cleaning and dressing of wounds.

You're led to an operating room, where your wounds are irrigated and sanitized before work begins.
Then, technicians go to work, using a sterile foam-like substance to bind smaller open wounds. Larger wounds are anesthetized, then sutured with a mechanical device that uses a type of bio-degradable staple.
Finally, any broken bones are set and splinted firmly, to allow them to heal faster.
You're given back your belongings, and an attendant reviews the recommendations for keeping the wounds clean.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Very well. The dispensary should have those prepared shortly."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Though one of the simpler processes offered by the clinic, it remains one of the most requested, and takes place in a larger room with many other patients receiving the same service.
You're sat in a chair, similar to those used in blood donations, and an IV is inserted into your arm. The suspension takes a while to be absorbed, but once done, technicians verify that the body has begun processing it, and the nanorobots are active.
Satisfied, the technician directs you to an attendant, who then processes the order.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
An expensive process, transfusion represents a significant leveraging of time, skill, and technology to ensure the safety of the patient, as well as the purchase of a valuable commodity: specifically-tailored, healthy human blood, and its synthetic counterpart.
You're first tested for compatibility, and blood stores and synthetics are screened based on your body's blood type and susceptibilities.
Then, a supply of blood is selected from on-site banks, and prepared to be delivered intravenously. The process is slow, and your body is monitored closely for complications and signs of infection or rejection.
When finished, you make your way to the attendant to retrieve your belongings.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Nothing seems to be there.
Nervously, you resume movement.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patient will be screened for eligibility in laser-assisted correction or implantable collamer lens.
If eligible, the patient's myopia will be corrected, and better-than-normal vision will be achieved.
Cost: $1000

table.name: encounters
table.column:
For the upgrade, you're led to a fitting room, where you sit upright as a technician prepares the materials.
He unlocks a glass display case, and removes a white retail box. Inside are two replacement lenses, consisting of the frontal sclera and adjustable lens components.
Due to the fact that the eye will be unsealed during the procedure, you're subjected to local anesthesia for the procedure. It's relatively quick, however, as it's just a swapping out of parts while your eyes are fixed forward.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
After screening you for existing factors and eligibility, your vision is assessed by computer, and you're guided to an operating room.
The procedure is quick, and done in under local anesthesia. Within an hour, you are back on your feet. You're told that you may experience some dryness in your eyes or mild pain, but the healing period is only a remarkable 1-2 days.
Finished, you make your way to the attendant to retrieve your belongings.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patient will be screened for eligibility in artificial eye replacement, including immunoreactivity.
If eligible, the patient will have their natural eyes removed and replaced with Rose Augmentations RA:037 Human Eyes, which simulate perfect human visual acuity.
The RA:037 eyes are powered by nonlinear piezoelectric harvesters. As such, they require no additional power supply for their operational lifetime, which is expected to exceed their host.
Cost: $5600

table.name: encounters
table.column:
After verifying there is no danger of synthetic rejection, you're escorted to an operating room, given fluid and nutrient IV insertions, and placed under local anesthesia.
The procedure is lengthy and extremely complex, requiring precise manipulation of tissue at a micro scale. Much of the work is done via a computer-aided telesurgery armature.
When finished, there's a brilliant flash of geometry and patterns as the photoreceptors are activated. For several minutes, your vision passes in and out of focus, shifts colors, and goes black again as the devices are calibrated. You feel some anxiety at the lack of control.
Finally, it stabilizes in a hyperfocused, almost unsettlingly crisp image, and your eyes begin their usual movements.
You can see again.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Order the night vision eye upgrade.

For the upgrade, you're led to a fitting room, where you sit upright as a technician prepares the materials.
He unlocks a glass display case, and removes a small dustproof tray lined with foam. Inside are two metallic cylinders, which he removes and prepares to install.
The procedure is a bit uncomfortable, as the technician has to handle your artificial eye to insert the upgrade. However, it's fairly quick, and the lack of pain receptors on the artificial eyes means the sensation is mainly limited to pressure in the eye sockets.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There's a mild aching, and your eye movements feel weaker. What's more, as you walk the room, steadied by a nurse, things seem to move differently around you.
You're told it's a sensation that will pass with time. Your muscles will adjust to the slight differences in balance, and the image will become less unsettling.
After some time resting and working with therapists, you feel able to move again normally.
You're taken to collect your things, and you get dressed.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Upstairs to Prosthetic and Augmentation Procedures

Haggerty Health also offers several elective procedures which involve implanting devices and replacement tissue.
Before receiving any such procedures, the patient must undergo preliminary testing for eligibility, as not all patients are good candidates for synthetic implantation or augmentation surgeries.
Some procedures will require additional testing, and in some cases, special permits or authorizations.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Upstairs to Prosthetic and Augmentation Procedures

You begin speaking with an attendant, who reviews your eligibility test results.
Fortunately, initial testing seems to indicate that you are eligible for further augmentation and prosthesis.
You are given a catalog of procedures currently offered by Haggerty.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patients who have already received the RA:037 Human Eye replacement can have their units upgraded with the Rose Augmentations RA:056 Low Light photoreceptors, which provide normal vision in low-light conditions.
The procedure is fast and simple, requiring only that the additional hardware be installed in the existing units.
Cost: $300

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As he finishes the installation, he explains that it may feel unusual for a while.
The upgrade is primarily a thermoelectric cooling device to reduce thermal noise. The interior of the eye will cool, but as a result, the exterior will become warmer. It won't cause any damage, but it takes some getting used to.
After a few tests with the lab lights dimmed and off, you gather your things.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patients who have already received the RA:037 Human Eye replacement can have their units upgraded with the Rose Augmentations RA:043 Optical Zoom, which increases their visual range.
The procedure is relatively simple, requiring only that the additional hardware be installed in the existing units.
Cost: $200

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As the anesthetics wear off, you're led to an observation lounge, and asked to focus on several distant objects in the Detroit skyline.
It's a surprisingly powerful zoom, even compared to traditional optics like binoculars. You're able to make out detail at a great range, limited more by air density and haze than anything else.
Satisfied the procedure worked, the technician excuses himself, and you gather your things.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As it starts closing the gap towards you, you notice its mantle of blackness dragging on the ground.
Like those tracks at the cryo facility...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Oddly, something strikes you as familiar about this thing. Like you've seen that fragmenting pattern before...
Hatter's? Is this the thing in the security footage Hatter showed you?
As it starts closing the gap towards you, your mind snaps back to the present.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Oddly, something strikes you as familiar about this thing. Like you've seen that fragmenting pattern before...
Hatter's? Is this the thing in the security footage Hatter showed you?
And that mantle of blackness. It would definitely leave a dragging pattern on the floor, like the one in the cryo facility...
As it starts closing the gap towards you, your mind snaps back to the present.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Order Combo 1: Fried chicken, mac and cheese, and red beans with rice. Price $24.50

However, it appears your reputation as a cheapskate has caught up with you.
"You!" comes a bellow from the kitchen door. A man in an apron, who looks like he might just be willing to use his trade's tools on you, storms around the counter toward your table.
You decide to grab your stuff and bolt, since he doesn't look like he's in the mood for negotiating.
You burst outside, clutching your things, and you hear the door fly open behind you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Order Combo 3: Cadillac burger, mashed potatoes with gravy, and cornbread. Price $32.50

However, it appears your reputation as a cheapskate has caught up with you.
"You!" comes a bellow from the kitchen door. A man in an apron, who looks like he might just be willing to use his trade's tools on you, storms around the counter toward your table.
You decide to grab your stuff and bolt, since he doesn't look like he's in the mood for negotiating.
You burst outside, clutching your things, and you hear the door fly open behind you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Order Combo 1: Fried chicken, mac and cheese, and red beans with rice. Price $24.50

But you feel someone looking at you. You peer up from the menu, and even in the periphery of your view, you can see him in the window of the kitchen door.
It sends a chill down your spine.
Staring directly at you through the portal, his face is dark, shadowed from the kitchen lighting. And his eyes seem to have a fire of their own.
Afraid to turn your back on him, you grab your things, and back down the aisle to the exit.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Order Combo 3: Cadillac burger, mashed potatoes with gravy, and cornbread. Price $32.50

But you feel someone looking at you. You peer up from the menu, and even in the periphery of your view, you can see him in the window of the kitchen door.
It sends a chill down your spine.
Staring directly at you through the portal, his face is dark, shadowed from the kitchen lighting. And his eyes seem to have a fire of their own.
Afraid to turn your back on him, you grab your things, and back down the aisle to the exit.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A flash of fur, and the dogman leaps up at the two men. In no time, both men are helpless on the ground. The dogman stops for a moment, ears pricked, nose swinging slowly from side to side. Crap. You might have left it too late.
No point sneaking now. The dogman clearly knows you're here. And the exit is still a distance away.
You bolt, cutting the corner, taking a direct line to safety. The dogman emits a predatory howl, and bounds after you. Putting your head down, you run for your life. There isn't going to be any halfway outcome here: you'll either burst through the door, or be cut down doing it. You can smell the dogman, hear his guttural panting.
You can do it. Move legs, move!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It takes several moments before you can make it to your feet. You're hurt. Badly. The soft landing, courtesy of the enclaver and his pile of dead friends, wasn't enough.
On the other hand, glancing up, you realize that you've just survived a four-story fall. How about that? Better grab what you can and scram, before those rubble scum catch up with you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Don't risk becoming a target cont'd

You're halfway there, when a shadow sweeps over you, claws hooking into your shoulders, hot breath on the back of your neck. Something heavy enough to force you down presses you against the floor as you slide to a stop. A maw snaps shut with teeth sharp enough to sever your spinal column in one bone-crunching bite.
You briefly wonder why your vision is rolling around without any fixed point of reference, until it dawns on you that it's your head.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Running flat out, you cover the distance quickly, straight at the enclavers. You watch, in horror, as they pick up your frantic movement in the dark, and commence firing. Bullets hammer into you. There's a thud as you trip, sprawling across the floor, peppered full of gunshot wounds.
The enclavers quickly break camp, and get out of dodge. In the darkness, the creature bides it time. Watching. Waiting.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Well, damn it, if it's going to end here, you'll go down fighting. Hoisting the severed arm, you swing it wildly around in the dark, hoping to connect. You're still swinging blindly at shadows, when you pick up the musky scent of a Dogman.
Furious with yourself, the dogman, and the all-pervading injustice of the wastelands, you curse at the top of your voice and brandish the arm. You're still doing it when the dogman leaps out of the dark, foreclaws rending your chest.
As it rips your throat open, your last act is railing against your own weakness.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
No, buddy, it ain't. Pushing him violently towards the gangers, you turn and wriggle back out the other side. You're able to duck under the first blow, but catch the second. Slammed back against the body of the bus, you jink sideways and run. Really RUN. Straight out through the massive garage door.
You'll be a lot harder to track over broken ground. They're probably too busy getting Marathon Man strapped into a bus seat to be bothered chasing you, anyway. Just as well, 'cause you don't think you can run much longer.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Let the beast devour them. cont'd

By the time it has devoured most of their internal organs, you've shuffled around the warehouse perimeter to the far exit. It took a while, though. It would have been better, faster, if the light the two men were using had extinguished immediately when they fell.
You're out of the warehouse, but no more comforted by the sounds of the wild outdoors.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait until the blood starts flowing cont'd

Fear-induced adrenaline propels you forward. You feel like your whole body is infused with nitrous oxide, warning lights flashing red, powering into overdrive. You're dropping stuff left and right, but you don't care. The exit. That's all that matters.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Attempt to kick the door down cont'd

But it's too late! The beast has got hold of you. Growling, sharp teeth tearing flesh. You twist and punch the dogman hard on the nose. With a snarl, it lets go, and you fall out into the sunlight. You scramble to your feet, ready to bolt, but the dogman has broken off.
He's got enough food for now waiting inside.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Click! A light flares in the middle of the warehouse. Two men, back to back. Edging slowly toward the far exit, inside their small bubble of illumination.
There's safety in numbers. The three of you might stand a chance. Or you could stay very still and wait for the beast to slay them. Slide round the perimeter to the exit then.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Both you and the remaining slaver dive for the gun. He reaches it first, and cracks you hard with the butt. Then, he swings the barrel toward you, and pulls the trigger.
Except it explodes rearward, shredding his face. Dodgy ammunition? Bent barrel? You don't care. You're hurt. Grab what you can, and go.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Bad Muthas like their meat fresh

You retrace your steps, and find the toilet block empty. Confused at first, concern quickly follows. You turn to look around, and a loud "Bang!" accompanies a hammer-like gash, knocking you and the port-a-potty over.
Scrambling away behind cover, you need to find someplace safe to check that wound. Fast.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Back off from the scare tactics cont'd

He wheezes as you forcibly knee him in the nuts. It knocks him down, but he's still locked onto your foot, like a limpet to a rock. Dude just will NOT let up!
You give him a few vicious kicks to the head, and that does the trick. Just in time to face a gang of rubble scum, attracted by all the commotion. Moneybags does sterling service as a decoy, throwing himself at the scum, demanding they treat him.
Swerving out of their way, you charge off into the ruins, gear flying loose as you go.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You hear shouting behind you, footsteps all around. Things are going to hell, fast. Clutching your wound with your free hand, loot in the other, you stumble away as quick as you can manage.
Doesn't matter where, just away from this rapidly developing carnival of blood.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Won't hurt to poke your head in cont'd

Clearly the building itself isn't the main danger, it's what's lurking within. Carefully, quietly, you back out. That, you realize, striding away, was a close call. The woman calls out after you, still pleading for your help.

table.name: encounters
table.column: No one deserves to be enslaved cont'd

This is getting ugly, fast. Diving out the window, head first, you land badly, rolling straight into a protruding lump of concrete. Behind you, the girl is screaming, now relegated to being the prize of a grand melee.
Hobbling away, you hope that they kill her quickly.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Thing is, you get the sense a couple of them are doing the same. There's an exchange of glances between them, and before you know it, they're all looking *you* over.
Sensing your luck is changing, you start gauging your exit strategy. But it's too late. Outnumbered and out-muscled, they block your escape.
What happens next is surprising, for its creativity as much as its brutality. Staring at a blank section of concrete, you hope that the pain knocks you out soon...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It doesn't take him long to realize you've duped him, and his vengeance is swift. With overwhelming strength, he drags you over to the nearest stocks, snaps the neck of the occupant in an almost casual motion, then replaces the rag doll with you.
The first time the whip slashes through your skin, your sensory systems overload, sending your mind scurrying into a dark place it's never been before. By the twentieth stroke, you no longer scream or writhe. You just hang there limply, your vertebrae exposed, bleached white in the open air.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Something flashes through the dark, and rolls to a stop in the dim cone of light beneath you. It might be a hand. Or a foot? All you can tell is that it's human. Stringy white tendons trail from the jagged teeth marks. Oh boy...
Trembling, you get to your feet and run.

table.name: encounters
table.column: No point tying him up with string cont'd

Peering down, it's obvious that your walking meal ticket has broken a leg. He yells up at you to climb down and help.
Down there? In the sewers? He must be joking. The cannibals aren't the only things that eat humans. Rumor has it that there are rats. Giant rats with fangs the size of steak knives.
Bye, buddy.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The priest has changed his tune, visibly satisfied at your misfortune. That asshole! You give him a solid shove, knocking him into a pile of trash, and he starts up with the ranting again.
Better be something useful inside!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Just when you thought he wouldn't be coming out, he returns with a bundle of cash, thrusting it at you. He stands there. Looking up at you with innocent, brown eyes. All he wants is love. But he's started bleeding. From the nose. Like his dad. Jeez. Sorry, kid. No choice.
You leave him standing there. Alone. Sobbing. Walking away, you feel all of six inches tall. You stomp hard on that thought.
Self-loathing isn't a survival skill.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Just when you thought he wouldn't be coming out, he returns with a bundle of cash, thrusting it at you. He stands there. Looking up at you with innocent, brown eyes. All he wants is love. But he's started bleeding. From the nose. Like his dad. Jeez. Sorry, kid. No choice.
You leave him standing there. Alone. Sobbing. Walking away, you feel all of six inches tall. You stomp hard on that thought.
Self-loathing isn't a survival skill.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Just when you thought he wouldn't be coming out, he returns with a bundle of cash, thrusting it at you. He stands there. Looking up at you with innocent, brown eyes. All he wants is love. But he's started bleeding. From the nose. Like his dad. Jeez. Sorry, kid. No choice.
You leave him standing there. Alone. Sobbing. Walking away, you feel all of six inches tall. You stomp hard on that thought.
Self-loathing isn't a survival skill.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Just when you thought he wouldn't be coming out, he returns with a bundle of cash, thrusting it at you. He stands there. Looking up at you with innocent, brown eyes. All he wants is love. But he's started bleeding. From the nose. Like his dad. Jeez. Sorry, kid. No choice.
You leave him standing there. Alone. Sobbing. Walking away, you feel all of six inches tall. You stomp hard on that thought.
Self-loathing isn't a survival skill.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hard to tell what kind cont'd

Standing well back, you return to the front of the building, and tell him that there's not much you can do. Nervously, anxiously, he pulls a wad of notes out of his pocket, and throws them at you. "Help me, man. Please! Help me!"
"Sorry, buddy, I'm no explosives expert." You wonder how long he can manage to stay upright and stationary? Best not to wait and find out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hard to tell what kind cont'd

Standing well back, you return to the front of the building, and tell him that there's not much you can do. Nervously, anxiously, he pulls a wad of notes out of his pocket, and throws them at you. "Help me, man. Please! Help me!"
"Sorry, buddy, I'm no explosives expert." You wonder how long he can manage to stay upright and stationary? Best not to wait and find out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It's going to be a big job cont'd

Your hands, by now, are slippery with his blood, and you finally give up. All you've done is make a bad situation worse.
Before leaving, you take his shoes. He won't be needing them.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It's going to be a big job cont'd

Your hands, by now, are slippery with his blood, and you finally give up. All you've done is make a bad situation worse.
Before leaving, you take his shoes. He won't be needing them.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Clamoring over debris and carpet, you make your way to the door, and manage to get a head start. Winding through the corridors and rooms, you think you've managed to shake them.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A stretch limo. You don't see many of those now. This one's bare, rusting wheels left, tires long gone.
Two rubble scum are standing guard at the only working door. Crowbars and a take-no-prisoners attitude. Sounds of pain and stress coming from inside.
Before you can sneak off, you're noticed. A third guard appears behind you, and ushers you forward. Holds your head down, and pushes you inside the back of the limo.
There's a woman inside. Mohawk and tribal scars tell you she's one of them. Pregnant, too. Like, delivering now, and on her own. One of the rubble scum pokes his head in. "Can you help?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A merciless grip clutches your shoulder, and you're wrenched forward. Pain shoots through your arm, neck and chest from the crushing metallic claw. A "clunk" sounds from below the machine, and the blade spins in a blur almost instantly.
The spider legs click up and down in a blur, allowing the blade to pass unobstructed, and the arm yanks back, toward the chassis. You scream in horror as your belly is shredded by the spinning rotor, soft guts spraying the wall behind you. The crowd cheering is the last thing you remember before a jarring crack of a blade through your spine.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Try to Outrun the Bot cont'd

It comes quickly, though, and your next dodge cuts it close. The crowd seems to sense your growing fear, and the volume raises accordingly. Running to the opposite side again, you watch for the next opportunity. The chase pattern has worked the robot into the center of the arena, cutting your escape routes dangerously short.
You dive to the side again, and miss your landing, losing precious seconds in recovery. A bone-jarring clank sends agonizing pain shooting through your nerves, as a pointed mechanical leg scores your own. Limping to the far side of the arena, you hardly have time to face the bot before you have to dodge again.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Try to Find a Weakness cont'd

Wait, wasn't the sensor on that arm? Looking closely, sure enough, there it is. That can't be right. You're sure the walking motion followed you before that sensor had a fix.
Testing your theory, you stand adjacent to the wall, and duck below the mesh line. You crawl along the ground for a few meters, watching the robot. Its focus stays on you the whole time.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
That thing moves fast! You hadn't anticipated the follow-up sweep. Fortunately, now you know, and robots are nothing if not predictable.
You scramble back to your feet, just in time to dodge another thrust from the arm, this time jumping back before the follow-up can knock you around.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're funneled through the gate, and manage to land on your feet, crouched with hands down for balance. The gate rattles closed behind you, and you stare at the dirt, waiting.
Then, the sounds of metallic feet jar you from your daze. You can't see it yet, but it sounds like a heavy monstrosity. The steps are staggered too, overlapping in a strange rhythm.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Try Bargaining with Dogman Footage cont'd

He snags the footage with a scratchy glove, and looks up to the announcer's booth, holding it in plain view. A bucket is lowered, and the footage is deposited inside. The bucket starts retracting, and then you're hoisted up anyway.
"Wait!" you shout, but the guards just funnel you through the gate, dumping you on the dirt floor of the arena. As the gate rattles shut, the crowd yells with anticipation.
The sounds of metallic feet march from beyond the garage door. You can't see it yet, but it sounds like a heavy monstrosity. The steps are staggered too, overlapping in a strange rhythm.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Caught in a tight knot of people, you frustratingly push, knocking a couple to the ground. Retaliation is swift, and soon you're pushed down in turn, and kicked for good measure. The tide of people sweeps over you, and you struggle to regain your feet.
Angling your shoulder forward, you press on, the door almost visible now.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
However, the bot's rocking eventually frees it, and it turns to face him again. Crestfallen, the man returns to his original strategy of dodging the robot like a bullfighter, ever more slowly each pass.
It doesn't take long for the robot to wear down its already weakened prey, and it scores its first hit, trampling his leg under treads. The man's cry of pain is lost in a wave of cheering from the crowd, as the robot backs up. The man hardly has time to limp before it rams him again, this time following through and impaling him against the wall.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You vividly recall the alpha male sinking his fangs deep into the neck of the mammoth. Working his big jaw from side to side until blood gushed in a torrential outpouring straight towards the camera.
You bolt for the door, hurling yourself through, slamming it shut behind. In all the excitement you trip and end up in an ungainly heap on the floor.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use a light source to see in darker areas.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Bah. That rooster doesn't scare you. In you go.
Behind the rooster's back, though.
You know. Just in case.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Bah. That rooster doesn't scare you. In you go.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
But as you round Delano St. and turn up Park Dr., things start to feel...off.
One house has some white lace curtains that won't stop moving. Another features a gaping hole in the second-story exterior wall, as if the wall was sucked in by a powerful force. A third has some sort of menagerie or diorama of dolls in the front yard, in varying states of decay.
And at the end of the street, a glaring ten-foot rooster statue stands on the leftmost of a series of brick booths that cross what must be the Fairgrounds entrance. Roosters, you decide, are creepier when they're twice your size and have an army of disfigured dolls as backup.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're back at the Allegan Fairgrounds, and "Rocky Rooster" is still doing his thing.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide that rooster is all the reason you need to not get any closer.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The area around Allegan County Fair is pretty unassuming. Once-sleepy neighborhoods with detached homes make up the bulk of the area, with streets lined by aging trees. Not much different than any other place you've walked lately.

table.name: encounters
table.column: No telling when that rooster will make his move, so you probably shouldn't tarry here long.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Inside, there are heaps of refuse under sagging canopies. It looks like some sort of antique fair or flea market was interrupted here.
Further into the Fairgrounds, you spot a large, permanent hall. Sliding hangar doors frame a yawning black entrance, over which hangs a sign: "Marketplace Exhibitors Building".

table.name: encounters
table.column:
All around you come the sounds of shuffling and items falling off tables, barely audible over a rising chorus of moans and shrill screams. It appears this is some sort of nest of waking, cranky melonheads.
And unfortunately, you're knee-deep in the mob.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You hold still for a few minutes, surveying the area. There's a lot of debris here, and many good places to hide.
But there are no signs of movement, no silhouettes, and no eyes glinting from the shadows. It *looks* clear.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Search for signs of other creatures.

It's not a heavily trafficked place, but the Fairgrounds has had some visitors. Not many animals, though.
The humanoid tracks appear to have left a lot more hastily than they entered. And by the looks of it, whatever spooked them came from the hall.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Look for signs of a trap.

Yep, this place would make for an excellent trap. Scavenger bait, lots of blocked sight lines, and lack of animal activity.
That covers just about all the checkboxes on your list!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The Exhibitor Hall looks about as foreboding as it does promising. The same roof that has protected the building's contents all these years also blocks any light from getting in. You might as well be entering a cave.
Passing through the doorway, your nose is assailed by the stench of stale perspiration, urine, and rotting teeth. The air feels stagnant. Thick. The sounds of the outdoors become muffled, punctuated by the ticking and popping of the metal structure.
You can see some of the tables and booths in the ambient light from the doorway, but shadows pool further back towards the walls.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Something's not right here. Better cut and run while you can.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Resolving to stay vigilant, you start looking through the tents.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You notice a large cardboard box peeking out from under some debris, and pull it out to get a better look.
Inside, under some grimy, wadded newspaper, you find a jackpot! An assortment of old tools and other implements! Were they something for sale at one of these booths? Or perhaps used for setup at the market? In any case, tools!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You know that smell. Your mind immediately goes to a stressful place when you realize what it is: festering patients.
It smells like a field hospital or triage center in here. Something, more likely many things, are in here. In varying states of health. The stagnant air is rife with the scent.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It takes you little time to determine that this place is occupied. The smells and the litter are obvious signs of that.
But the humidity concerns you even more. Something, or likely worse, many things, are breathing in here. Right now.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use Night Vision to Look Around cont'd

Straining to make out more detail, you notice it again. The blanket is subtly moving, as if something is breathing beneath it. You look around the hall, and your skin becomes clammy as you realize the entire hall is draped with blankets, each harboring some living, breathing thing. You're all but surrounded.
The only good news here is that none seem to be stirring. Yet.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use night vision to look around.

When your field of vision finally resolves, you see that most of the hall is filled with folding tables and booths. Signage advertises vendors and craftspeople from a bygone era, and most of their wares appear to be scattered about, though not taken.
An inordinate number of tables seem to be covered or surrounded in blankets, though, and that's when you notice it: one of the blankets moves.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Salvage some tarpaulin from the tents.
If nobody else is going to...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Well, *I'm* gonna take the clown head.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The wrapping paper appears to be a photocopy of a museum brochure, depicting the same, or a very similar, string of beads. The brochure has the following text on it:
"Ziibiwing Center, Anishinabe Tribal Nation, MI"
Looks like someone was doing a little bit of black marketeering in historic artifacts.
Conveniently, the photocopied brochure has driving directions to the Anishinabe Tribal Nation, and Ziibiwing Center, near old Mt. Pleasant, MI.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
However, as with many sidewalk vendors, the view beneath the table is a bit more interesting.
Swaddled in some grimy blue plastic bags, you find evidence that there was something else for sale here. Several loose cords suggest there may have been jewelry, and there are bits of worn, tanned hides.
There's also a heavy, tightly-folded square of paper, taped shut. As you pry open the folds, a string of copper beads pours into your hands. Though different in shape, and obviously more weathered, it's reminiscent of the talisman with which you awoke.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Examine a booth labeled "Genuine Indian Artifacts!"
