"Genuine" is neither the word you'd choose to describe most of the wares in this booth, nor the person who wrote the sign.
Most are obvious fakes, designed to liberate tourists of their burdensome wallets. Things like lucky "rabbit's feet", miniature resin totem poles, and dreamcatchers lovingly made by a machine in east Asia.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Chances are, the good stuff is further in, out of sight. You squeeze between two booths and shuffle into the shadows, feeling around for other display tables or boxes.
Your hand touches a folding table, and you guide yourself towards it. As you approach the table's edge, your foot bumps into something soft and heavy. A sudden cry sends you staggering back, and suddenly, the entire hall starts coming to life.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Shine a light to see better.

Holding the torch above your head, you strain to see into the recesses of the hall. Most of the hall is filled with folding tables and booths. Signage advertises vendors and craftspeople from a bygone era, and most of their wares appear to be scattered about, though not taken.
An inordinate number of tables seem to be covered or surrounded in blankets though, and that's when you notice it: one of the blankets moves.
A frustrated grunt is uttered from one of the hall's corners. And it's immediately followed by a pitched moan.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Examine a pile of blankets and rags.

As a scavenger, you quickly learn that there are two types of blanket piles: those that are created to hide something, and those that are created when something hidden is uncovered. This pile fits into the former category.
Squatting next to the pile, you start peeling back layers of cloth and blanket. Whatever is under here must be pretty large to warrant this many blankets. You do your best to stem your excitement, as you pull back a soiled sheet...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
All around you come the sounds of shuffling and items falling off tables, barely audible over a rising chorus of moans and shrill screams. It appears this is some sort of nest of waking, cranky melonheads, and you're in the middle of it.
And unfortunately, some of the melonheads have already closed you in, blocking the doorway through which you came.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Examine a Pile of Blankets cont'd.

...to find a bulbous, misshapen head. A waft of pungent body odor and halitosis nearly knocks you over, and you immediately recoil from the shock of sight and smell. The head is human-ish, but with a massive, veiny cranium. Its face is distorted from the stretched skull, eyes fixated open and downward in an expression resembling horror.
The head stirs, and its mouth opens halfway, emitting a low moan that rises in both pitch and volume. Before you can get to your feet, the whole blanket pile begins to move in fits. It's trying to get out!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
This place just became a massive beacon for predator and scavenger alike.
Time to move.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
They're closing in, but no match for your speed. In an instant, you jackrabbit for the door, ducking and swerving like a child playing tag with ugly, swollen-headed children for his life.
The cold, fresh air fills your lungs as you pass out of the hall, and you're off to the edge of the Fairgrounds before the disfigured, moaning masses can catch up.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Grab something heavy, and clear a path!

The bastards might've moved in to block your exit, but that doesn't mean you can't *unmove* them.
Grabbing a wooden drawer from a nearby furniture stall, you rush forward, using it to shield bash your way through. Any of those little buggers eager enough to try you gets a wood sandwich and a headache for their trouble.
When you've reached the door, three of the melonheads lie in your wake, cerebral fluid spurting amidst brays of agony.
The rest of the throng is unphased, though. And your drawer skills, formidable as they are, won't even these odds.
Time to go.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Good thing you packed for the trip.
Hoisting your crowbar up, you precariously balance on feet and one handhold while you wrench it into a roof panel. There are some awful metallic creaking noises as flimsy metal bends and strains.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Try to light some blankets on fire!

You start frantically working to get a flame. Hands shaking, you hold the flame to some nearby blankets, but the blanket isn't catching fast enough.
Giving up, you start running for the door, but it's too late. The wailing masses of melonheads have completely encircled you, their horrible, gaping eyes boring into you as they close.
You shove one back as it approaches, but two more tackle you. As you tear at them, trying to free yourself, bites and claws pierce skin all over your body, and you shriek in agony.
The last thing you see is a cinder block held aloft over a melonhead being brought down onto your face.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Could these creatures be hydrocephalitic? Excess cerebral fluid causing lateral ventricle swelling?
That'd explain their appearance. The smell of urine would make sense, too.
If that's the case, they're probably not too sure on their feet. Up might be the safest route.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
No time to lose, run for it!
You push off, toward the exit, and the melonheads shriek and close on you. Two manage to jump on you as you pass, and you shake one loose.
The other manages to get his teeth on you, and starts kicking and tearing at you.
You steer towards one of the melonheads in the doorway, using the attached one as a plow, then shoulder him against the edge of the doorway on your way out.
He cries in pain, and you pivot quickly to try and wrench him free. He falls loose, and you use your moment of freedom to bolt from the scene.
Rabble and moaning fade into the distance as you exit the Fairgrounds.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use the air vent to escape!

Buildings like this, with only one main entrance, usually have some way of venting air. And it'd be up.
You jump up onto a booth, and start scrambling up scaffolding to the rafters.
The melonheads swarm the area below you, but aren't making any moves to climb yet. So you've got a minute.
You don't spot any ducting to the gables up here, but it looks like a chain and pulley further in might be the ticket.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You jump up onto a booth, and start scrambling up scaffolding to the rafters.
The melonheads swarm the area below you, but aren't making any moves to climb yet. So you've got a minute.
But a minute to do what? There isn't much up here to work with, and there appears to be no other escape besides the main door below.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hulk out on the roof panels!

Well, it's not a subtle plan, but it'll do.
Feeling around for a good place to apply force, you wedge yourself between the rafter and roof, and start pushing.
You hear corrugated metal creak and pop, and the panel above you starts to bend outward. Gathering your strength, you push one more time, ignoring all except the effort.
The panel pops loose on one corner, and you're greeted with chilled, fresh air. You pull yourself through the opening, and onto the rooftop.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Try to force open a section of roof!

Anything's better than going back down there, into the embrace of angry, smelly melonheads.
You start pushing on roof panels, looking for any sign of weakness. There isn't much give, though. You're just not that strong.
Next, you try kicking. Hanging from both arms, you attempt kicking upward, trying to pop the roof open. Except your trouble almost earns you a trip down to the ground.
Becoming desperate, you right yourself, and start slamming into the roof with your shoulder and back. Over and over, you ram into the corrugated metal, the whole process bruising and slicing your flesh.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Good thing you packed for the trip.
Hoisting your crowbar up, you precariously balance on feet and one handhold while you wrench it into a roof panel. There are some awful metallic creaking noises as flimsy metal bends and strains.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Actually, what's that over there? Looks like there might be some sort of chain hanging from the ceiling.
You maneuver yourself to get a better look.
Yep, looks like a pull chain for a rooftop vent. That's your ticket out of here!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Carefully climbing across the rafters, you reach the chain, and pull down on it. The force tilts a roof panel open, and you're able to squeeze out onto the rooftop.
Cold, fresh air never felt so comforting.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There's a sudden "pop" as a corner gives way, and the sudden drop in resistance causes you to nearly lose your balance.
You reach for a rafter with your free hand, but drop the crowbar in the process. It falls through the air, thunking into a melonhead with a spectacular spray of cerebral fluid and blood.
Ugh, what a mess down there. The wailing melonheads seem no happier with this new development.
Regaining your balance, you finish forcing the panel open, and squeeze out onto the rooftop.
Cold, fresh air was never so welcome.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There's a sudden "pop" as a corner gives way, and you finish forcing the panel open, squeezing out onto the rooftop.
Cold, fresh air was never so welcome.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're not out of this yet, though. Still have to find a way down.
It'll take the melonheads a minute or so to figure out where you went, so options are limited.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Wham!"
Despite trying to cushion your fall, it feels like every part of you hit the ground in rapid succession. Sharp pains shoot through your body, your nose tingles, and you lose focus momentarily until you hear the melonheads round the corner of the Exhibitor's Hall.
Biting back the pain, you gather your stuff and hobble away, out of the Fairgrounds.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Not much time for anything fancy. Just shimmy as close to the edge as you can, and drop.
You climb to the edge, lower your feet over, and give a little push...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's a long drop, but you think you can manage. You shed your things in preparation, then inch towards the edge.
Sitting, legs over the side, you push off, controlling your angle so you can roll on impact.
You land hard, and the impact is jarring. But you're able to turn some of that momentum into a roll, and when you stop, it feels like all of you is still there.
Scrambling to gather your things, you're gingerly moving away as the melonheads exit the Exhibitor Hall, looking for where you went.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You start running for the door, but it's too late. The wailing masses of melonheads have completely encircled you, their horrible, gaping eyes boring into you as they close.
You shove one back as it approaches, but two more tackle you. As you tear at them, trying to free yourself, bites and claws pierce skin all over your body, and you shriek in agony.
The last thing you see is a cinder block held aloft over a melonhead being brought down onto your face.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The bastards might've moved in to block your exit, but that doesn't mean you can't *unmove* them.
Grabbing a wooden drawer from a nearby furniture stall, you rush forward, using it to shield bash your way through. Any of those little buggers eager enough to try you gets a wood sandwich and a headache for their trouble.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You immediately put a fist through the face of the melonhead at your feet. Her skull gives way, and the sensation is sickening. Like punching a pumpkin full of warm, viscous fluid.
Holding back vomit, you push forward, swinging your drawer wildly. Melonheads are flattened with each swing, but several land on your back, gnawing and tearing your flesh.
You back into a booth, and drop your weight on one, crushing it between you and the wood frame. With your free hand, you pull another from your back to the ground.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Gathering your strength, you bring the drawer to bear, and charge towards the door.
Wood splinters inward as the drawer's base smashes wobbly, gushy skulls. Another melonhead lands a painful bite before you can plant your fist on him.
As you barrel out the door, into the fresh air, the last of the melonheads is thrown to the ground.
You drop the remains of the wooden drawer, and hobble towards the surrounding neighborhood.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
If anyone doubts the usefulness of track and field, you wish they were here.
You push off down one of the aisles, starting a wide arc toward the door. They've cut off direct escape, but they weren't expecting you to go the long way.
Several booths down the aisle, you vault left, over a folding table, and plow into a melonhead. She goes down with a wail, but another was close enough to latch on.
You start moving again, enduring the bites and claws in order to regain momentum.
As you pass the next craftperson's sign, you swing by close, and clip the melonhead from your shoulder.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Once again unencumbered, you dodge and weave more of the scrabbly little bastards. One manages to clonk you with a board, though, and you have to stumble not to fall flat.
Regaining speed, you elbow past the last group of melonheads, out into the open air.
Free of the building, you put the melonheads way behind you with ease.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
They look kinda wobbly, so climb!
You jump up onto a folding table, and start climbing a booth to reach the rafters.
The melonheads are too close, though. They start scrabbling up onto the table with you, and one set of the table's legs gives way. You fall, and slide down the sloped tabletop into a writhing mass of wailing melonheads.
As you tear at them, trying to free yourself, bites and claws pierce skin all over your body, and you shriek in agony.
You lose consciousness from the shock of being rendered into tiny morsels of melonfood.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The tent market looks pretty run-down. Weather and time have done their work over the years. Most everything looks faded, soiled, and waterlogged.
But there is still useful material left here, which is odd. Looters are nothing if not thorough, and you know there's no way some of this would be left behind for long.
Okay, nobody's gonna hurry to carry off this...fast-food clown head or anything. But why hasn't this place been picked clean?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Unfortunately, things are still pretty stirred up from your last visit. Melonhead activity is at an all-time high, and it's best you steer clear for now.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It looks like things may have finally calmed down again at the Fairgrounds. You don't see any signs of wandering melonheads from here.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're a little reluctant to enter the Fairgrounds again, after what happened. It's bad enough that you roasted a few dozen disfigured melonheads in a roaring barnfire, but who knows what else dropped by as a result.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Toss the torch onto some blankets!

This is a bad place. Time to set it on fire.
You toss the flame onto a pile of blankets, and start heading for the door. Three melonheads, silhouetted by the door, begin closing ranks.
Suddenly, there's a burst of orange light, accompanied by a "whoosh!" The three silhouettes are momentarily bathed in the glow, expressions of horror wrenching their faces.
Using the brief distraction, you bowl over one, staggering into the open air, and then resume running from the building.
Squealing and shrieking echo maddeningly in the exhibitor hall as columns of black smoke usher upward into the sky.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You emerge into the cavernous arena of noise and light. The smell of smoke, meat, and sweat fill the air, plus a twinge of ozone from the machines.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Collect Your Things and Go cont'd

Grabbing your things, you sidestep back towards the stairs, and step out into the air. Compared to inside, the outdoors is deadeningly quiet, made evident by the ringing in your ears. You head off again towards the treeline.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Zom Zom's.
Home of angry mobs, loud music, the human rendering pit, and questionably sourced barbecue. It was a narrow escape that delivered you from this place before, but now you're back.
Why are you back, exactly?

table.name: encounters
table.column: I can take care of myself.
It's sketchy in there. But hell, it's sketchy out HERE, too.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Screw the risks. There's a pit in your stomach, and the only thing that can fill it is some double-zed's barbecue.

table.name: encounters
table.column: No, you don't. And it's exactly that kind of thinking that's going to get you killed one of these days.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Up a few wooden plank steps, you step inside the semi-trailer, and hollow sounds of a crowd echo down the narrow corridor from the warehouse. To your right is a chipboard and mesh booth where an attendant is collecting fees, weapons, and stamping people before they walk down the trailer into the warehouse.
"Stock or Spectator," the attendant drones, looking disinterestedly past you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Hand," she demands, reaching for a stamp as you present your hand. She applies a symbol and number, then nods to another grizzly merc, who checks you for weapons.
You receive a chit for your confiscated items, and are ushered down the trailer.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Whatcha got?" Looking behind her, you see iSlabs, shoes, and sundry items. It looks like there are definitely some items they'll accept more than others, at least today.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You stop moving, and start looking carefully into the endless foliage. Your eyes dart from one space to the next, trying to take in all the distant shapes of the forest.
You see nothing unusual, however. And the fleeting images at the edge of your vision, whatever they were, seem to be either gone or invisibly waiting for your next move.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You drop and push off, back the way you came in. Using every fiber in your body, you twist and hurdle through the underbrush.
You think that thing is following you, but it's not gaining.
Around some more trees and over a mound, you see the treeline ahead. You explode into the clearing, foliage trailing behind you, and continue putting distance in until you're sure nothing is behind you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Trying to not show any fear, you act surprised by something on the ground, and pick it up. Then, pretending to have found what you're looking for, you leave the way you came in.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The forest here has eyes.
More than a few times now, you could swear you've seen something in the periphery. You never do catch it, but it's there.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Whatever. This thing can go stuff itself.
You're going in.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You offer your fee, which she stashes in a metal locker. "Hand," she demands, reaching for a stamp as you present your hand. She applies a symbol and number, then nods to another grizzly merc, who checks you for weapons. He tosses your confiscated items into a numbered bin, and ushers you down the trailer.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It's busy, as usual. Whether starved for nourishment or entertainment, it's depressing what people will do to fill that hunger.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's half the reason anyone comes here. Might as well score a skewer or two.
You squeeze yourself up to the counter, and do your best to out-wave, out-glance, and outmaneuver the dirty masses around you.
Minutes later, you sidestep back into the crowd, eating your prize in a guarded hunch.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As the arena is prepped for another fight, you get ready to see what mechanical monstrosity gets carted out next.
And who the victim is.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You've got nothing else going on. Let's see how the next fight goes.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As the arena is prepped for another fight, you get ready to see what mechanical monstrosity gets carted out next.
And who the victim is.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Uh oh. Skeleton bones alert. Looks like this contestant hasn't been eating his barbecue. A greasy, bony man gets tossed into the pit, falling to his knees, with hardly enough energy to stand again.
And what's this? "Wedgebot"?
A low, sharp-edged dome skitters in from the other side, and immediately charges the man.
The fight goes pretty much as expected: a few tiring dodges, a stumble, then "plop-plop", two ankles severed, followed by a high-speed ram into the prone victim.
It may take longer to dislodge Wedgebot from the man's face than the whole fight.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It'll be a couple minutes as they prep the arena. What next?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You decide that's enough flirting with human mutilation and barbecue for one day.
Pressing your way back toward the door, you step into brightly lit trailer, and present your chit to the guard.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Looks like Morning Star is up again. The crowd starts cheering at the sound of its tread well before the crude LED appears around the corner.
And on the other side...that can't be right. They've ushered in what looks like an old lady.
And what's she doing? She's kneeling! Lady! Sympathy ain't a robot attribute! Get up!

table.name: encounters
table.column: Zom Zom's Fight, Morning Star cont'd

Morning Star goes to work quickly, closing the gap and bowling the motionless woman over. Her leg gets caught under the right tread, and causes the bot to veer right before the strain pops it off.
Morning Star straightens again, and accelerates towards the wall, ramming her in a messy, dusty puff of flesh and rags.
Man, these fights are getting shorter.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Well, this is an unusual one. Looks like a combine-turned-wood-chipper, but with a street-sweeping broom? That's confusing.
And facing off against it, T-shirt and jeans guy. Whoa, he looks pissed. I guess he wasn't planning on being the entertainment.
As the gates close, the combine-chipper fires up, and all sorts of things start spinning on it. Big blades, some sort of blower, and that sweeper.
Oh, now you get it! The sweeper runs backwards, and kicks up a plume of dust and high velocity dirt.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Like some mechanical dragon spewing a dusty breath weapon, combine-chipper closes in on the man, who's stumbling and reeling in the sandblasting.
The combine blades suck him under, and a moment later, red mist comes shooting out the top of the bot.
Folks down in the front rows seem to revel in the blood spray, which is kind of disturbing on several levels, now that you think of it. I mean, even just the hygiene angle is...
Anyway, not a trace of the man remains as the combine-chipper trundles back out the door.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Uh-oh, you don't have anything to trade.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Having no desire to penetrate its forbidding depths, you leave.
Maybe you'll try the next forest, provided it isn't seemingly designed to frighten people.
As if to punctuate that thought, the path seems to become lost in overgrowth, leaving behind nothing but a barrier of weeds, thorns, and bark.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Later, much later, your eyes open. Skin tingling, and blood surging, you wriggle your toes.
You're alive, though still in this forsaken forest. You think you can see a way out, though, and start making your way towards it.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
When the beast has passed beyond earshot, you notice a path opened through the dense vegetation. It definitely wasn't there before. Was it?
Time to get out of this place.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You've returned to the site of that unusual forest. However, upon a second examination, it seems much less alien.
True, the density of vegetation here is unusually high. Navigating the foliage would be an arduous task. But you no longer see those reptilian shapes you saw (imagined?) before.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You decide to leave the forest behind.
You do put some distance between you and the forest before you turn your back on it, though.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
That's odd.
You notice a couple sets of tracks approaching the forest, but then disappearing. They're fairly unremarkable tracks for fauna in this area. But the way they just vanish at the forest's edge is not normal, to say the least.
No tapering off, no disturbed foliage, no signs of a struggle, not even doubling back.
Just a complete cessation of tracks beyond a certain point.
That, and absolutely *zero* tracks in the other direction.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Noses are hard to fool, and something doesn't smell right here. Familiar, but wrong.
Every biome has a signature scent. Some may be sweet, almost syrupy. Others are earthy, or floral. Whatever the place, you can often tell what grows there by the scent.
This place... still has a lingering smell, and it doesn't go with what you're seeing. Traces of that thick, almost sweaty air, and rotting flesh, are still hovering about here, as if left by something passing.
The "right" scent is here, too. It's all but overpowered that lingering scent. But there's no mistaking it.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Sweaty palms grasp at the door handle and madly yank at it.
It's locked!
What feels like a subcompact slams you half into the door, and half into its adjoining wall. Both you and tiger bounce back a little, and land on hard, wet floor.
As the tiger rights itself, you scramble forward on hands and feet towards the exit, screaming through the pain.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Falling through, you kick out wildly, and the door slams shut just as the sabre-toothed tiger crashes into it.
Panting, gasping, you concentrate on staying still and calming your racing heartbeat.
It doesn't seem to be coming after you.
Still, better put some distance in, just in case.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You've returned to the mini trash alley that leads to the Isotope Mine.
It doesn't look like anyone's home, though. Or at least, like anyone wants visitors. And you're not keen enough on getting raked by gore-infected claws to knock.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Sweaty palms grasp at the door handle and madly yank at it.
It's locked!
You immediately sidestep, narrowly avoiding a heap of fur and bone as it careens into the wall where you just were. You push off the wall, out into the air, acting purely on adrenaline.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There's something wrong with the way that door is lit. In fact, even the conduits seem out of place there.
It looks more like an interior bulkhead than an exterior door.
Sure, it'd hold up okay out here a while. But nobody'd build 'em like that on purpose.
There's a good chance you're actually standing in what used to be a basement, not a ravine.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Taking a step back, you start scouring the area for any signs of an opening. The ground is pretty level here, so you may just be on a buried rooftop or floor.
That's when you notice it: buried under a tangle of tall grass and dirt, a concrete cistern lid.

table.name: encounters
table.column: That's enough dallying in a trash-laden killzone for one day. Off you go.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use magnetometer to find another way in.

You know, most of these old tablets and smartphones had magnetometers built into them. Pretty sensitive ones, too.
The right collection of small parts, tools, and an iSlab or smartphone, and you might just be able to follow one of these live conduits from above ground to another entrance.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Rig the device to follow the conduits.

Finding a clear spot to work out of sight, you set about wiring up the device to one of the live conduits, charging its deteriorated cell for the task ahead.
Then, you run a bypass to the display so its backlight changes intensity with magnetometer output. A few calibrations later, and you've got a power dowsing tool!
Albeit a short-lived one.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
On your feet, you start tracing the lines from where they disappear into the moss. The walk leads you back over the doorway, and suddenly veers to the side.
After a dozen paces or so, the screen lights up, and you lose the conduit's signal in the noise.
Whatever is below you is bigger than a conduit.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There's a concrete cistern lid here, half-buried under a tangle of tall grass and dirt.
It's gonna take more than optimism to get that thing open, though.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Fortunately, you have arms like an Austrian bodybuilder.
You pull the overgrowth away, and settle down next to the lid. Pushing with your legs, and pulling with your arms, you nearly start shaking from the strain.
But the lid finally budges, and strands of grass tear as the lid swings open.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Fortunately, you have a tool for this purpose.
Threading the crowbar through one of the rusted loops of metal, you position yourself to maximize your leverage, and pry.
At first, it doesn't seem like anything's going to happen. But the lid finally budges, and strands of grass tear as the lid swings open.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Your nose is immediately greeted with warm, dry air from the hole. No moldy or musty smells, which is odd.
An old metal ladder hangs down from the cistern opening, and disappears into impenetrable darkness below.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use a light to see better.

You hold a light as close to the hole as possible without losing your balance.
The ladder leads down to a catwalk, which is suspended over some plumbing and a pumping apparatus. Pipes lead from the pump to the sides of the cistern.
Unfortunately, that's about all you can see.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use night vision to see better.

Shielding your view from the ambient light, you peer into the darkness below.
The ladder leads down to a catwalk, which is suspended over a large, sealed container. Quite a bit of plumbing and a pumping apparatus stick out from the top, feeding pipes into the sides of the cistern.
The container itself extends downward, beyond what your vision can see.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide to leave things alone here, for now.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Grabbing ahold of the ladder, you start your descent.
As you pass through the opening, the air becomes warm and dry, almost artificially so. And the sounds of the outdoors fall away, leaving a claustrophobic humming and ticking from below.
At the bottom, the catwalk creaks when you apply pressure. It's still hard to make out much detail, though. Below, you still only see pipe work, pumps, and the top of an inner cistern.
You do notice an exhaust vent nearby, however.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Within seconds, there's a loud "pop" from the catwalk braces, which resounds through the chamber. Another immediately follows, and the catwalk drops a few centimeters.
More creaking ensues, and you're pretty sure this catwalk's gonna go.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You opt for safety, and grab hold of the ladder again. One of the catwalk's moorings pulls free from the wall with a spout of concrete dust, and the walkway swings downward violently, smashing against a pipe.
With nowhere to go but up, you start climbing, and emerge on the surface again.
Whatever awaits down there will have to wait for someone better prepared.
Or suicidal.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You push off quickly from the ladder, plant a foot hard, and dive for the vent opening.
One of the catwalk's moorings pulls free from the wall with a spout of concrete dust, and the walkway swings downward violently, smashing against a pipe.
You're left, hanging over a black void, bits of concrete and metal pinging as they rain down from the collapse.
Throwing one leg up, you're able to crawl into the horizontal shaft, and catch your breath.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're lying in some sort of exhaust vent leading from the warm, dry cistern.
The ladder you came down on is still there, but it'd be a bit of an acrobatic feat to reach it. You'd have to hang way outside the vent and get a good jump in.
And the drop is pretty unforgiving if you miss.
The vent leads away from the cistern, and two goggle-like, white lights peer at you from the other end.
You don't have a lot of room to move, though. You wouldn't be able to defend your head or feet very well once committed to the shaft.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Take a closer look at those lights.

Peering through the zoom lens, you're able to focus better on the two lights.
In fact, they're two openings in the shaft, probably leading outside. Something lies immediately below them, a nondescript shape rim-lit from the light.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Crawl further into the shaft, towards the lights.

You start crawling into the shaft.
It's hard, slow work, moving in this cramped space. You feel like a worm or caterpillar, inching forward and prone.
Further in, you notice the two lights are exhaust ports: tapered sections of the shaft, about 30cm in diameter each, that lead outside. And upon close inspection, the form under the openings is a decaying body.
A lab tech, by the looks of it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Try to jump to the ladder.

Hanging one leg outside the shaft, you squish yourself sideways to get a look at the jump. You'll have to lean out of the shaft to get any momentum.
Looking down, your heart starts to pound, as you realize that you never really had a plan for escaping again.
There's a very good chance you're going to fall here.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Steeling your resolve, and blinking tears from your eyes, you bend your knees, and push off...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Using one sweaty hand as an anchor against the shaft's ceiling, you lean out as far as you can towards the ladder.
It seems an impossible jump, now. Your skin starts to moisten despite the dry air, and frustration mounts.
The thought of chickening out crosses your mind. You could just climb back in the shaft and wait.
You shake your head. You'll just get weaker the longer you wait.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
...A shock of butterflies wells up in you as you miss your mark, and fall short of the ladder's rung.
You slam into a pipe, and continue falling into the darkness. Air rushes past your ears in a crescendo of noise.
And blinding light, sound, pain.
Everything on your body jars and floods with agony.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You inhale sharply after having the wind knocked out of you. A choking, acrid dust fills your lungs, and you cough weakly.
A burning sensation fills the inside of your throat, chest, and mouth. Your eyes become bleary with pain. Even your hands are starting to blister and sting.
If feels as if every cell in your body is disintegrating as you writhe in pain and darkness, your screams echoing up the smooth-walled cistern...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The rung hits your hand before you see it in this darkness, and you scramble to grab on before it slips away. Pulling with desperation, you manage to hook an elbow over the rung, and catch your breath.
The sounds of dislodged concrete clang from below, disturbed by your jump.
You throw your free arm upward to the next rung, and pull with both arms to get a knee up. And then, it's just a ladder.
You slow your breathing, concentrate on not slipping, and climb back to the surface.
The outside world seems loud and windy by comparison.
But also safe.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's a decent jump, but you think you can see yourself doing it.
Using one hand as an anchor against the shaft's ceiling, you lean out as far as you can towards the ladder.
Focusing on the rung you need to grab, you bend your knees, and push off...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
What's a lab tech doing in here?
They must've come from the same direction as you. The exhaust ports are way too small for a human to fit.
But then, why didn't they just leave again? What caused them to choose to die here?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The body's been here a while, whatever the case.
Most of the flesh has rotted away, leaving dusty, moth-eaten clothes and bones. There are some pill bottles in the pockets, though.
Lots of pills.
In fact, maybe the positioning of this body is less strange the more pills you pull from it.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You finish unloading Mr. PharmaCon here, and shimmy your way back to the edge of the cistern.
You still need to figure out how to get back to that ladder.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Jump Success, Lose Right Hand Item

The rung hits your hand before you see it in this darkness, and you scramble to grab on before it slips away.
You lose your grip on what you were holding, though.
Pulling with desperation, you manage to hook an elbow over the rung, and catch your breath.
The sounds of dislodged concrete clang from below, disturbed by your jump.
You throw your free arm upward to the next rung, and pull with both arms to get a knee up. And then, it's just a ladder.
You slow your breathing, concentrate on not slipping, and climb back to the surface.
The outside world seems loud and windy by comparison.
But also safe.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Jump Success, Lose Left Hand Item

The rung hits your hand before you see it in this darkness, and you scramble to grab on before it slips away.
You lose your grip on what you were holding, though.
Pulling with desperation, you manage to hook an elbow over the rung, and catch your breath.
The sounds of dislodged concrete clang from below, disturbed by your jump.
You throw your free arm upward to the next rung, and pull with both arms to get a knee up. And then, it's just a ladder.
You slow your breathing, concentrate on not slipping, and climb back to the surface.
The outside world seems loud and windy by comparison.
But also safe.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The rung hits your hand before you see it in this darkness, and you scramble to grab on before it slips away.
Your backpack slips loose, though.
Pulling with desperation, you manage to hook an elbow over the rung, and catch your breath.
The sounds of dislodged concrete clang from below, disturbed by your jump.
You throw your free arm upward to the next rung, and pull with both arms to get a knee up. And then, it's just a ladder.
You slow your breathing, concentrate on not slipping, and climb back to the surface.
The outside world seems loud and windy by comparison.
But also safe.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
But as you round Delano St. and turn up Park Dr., things start to feel...off.
One house has some white lace curtains that won't stop moving. Another features a gaping hole in the second-story exterior wall, as if the wall was sucked in by a powerful force. A third has some sort of menagerie or diorama of dolls in the front yard, in varying states of decay.
And at the end of the street, a glaring ten-foot rooster statue stands on the leftmost of a series of brick booths that cross what must be the Fairgrounds entrance. Roosters, you decide, are creepier when they are twice your size and have an army of disfigured dolls as backup.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You've returned to the mini trash alley that leads to the Isotope Mine. You retrace your steps to that cistern lid you discovered.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Return to Broken Isotope Mine Ladder
You've returned to the hole leading down into the cistern. Below, there's nothing but darkness and silence, and with most of the scaffolding collapsed, there's little else you can do but leave.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You've returned to the hole leading down into the cistern.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You vividly recall the alpha male sinking his fangs deep into the neck of the mammoth. Working his big jaw from side to side until blood gushed in a torrential outpouring straight towards the camera.
Backing away slowly, so as not to disturb its... whatever it's doing, you step back outside.
You're careful not to lose sight of that doorway until you're clear of the ravine.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use a light source to look around.

Deciding to bring technology to bear on this problem, you fish out a light, and switch it on.
Your field of view turns white with glare, and instantly, the light is violently swatted from your hand. Fat, cold hands grip your throat, a menacing silhouette all you can see in the spinning shadows.
You try to wrench free, clawing at the hands around your neck. The grip tightens, lifting you and smashing your head against the rafters. A red flash crosses your vision, and you fall suddenly before a sharp snap ends it all...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Up ahead, it looks like there's some sort of abandoned car.
It's covered in filth, and what glass remains is almost opaque with grime, so it's been here a while. Hard to tell if anything's inside from here.
The door on this side is open, though, and it looks like a tattered sleeping bag spills through the opening.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You pick up something you can toss, and lob it at the metal husk, ducking out of sight.
There's a hollow bang and rattle as it hits the roof and rolls off. Things seem to get quieter for a few moments after.
But soon, the ambient critter noise level resumes.
No sign of movement.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You have discovered an abandoned car, showing extreme distress from age.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Not enough charge left in the laptop.
You start up the application, but before long, it becomes clear that the algorithm could run as long as half an hour, and you'll need at least that much charge in the laptop to complete the process.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There was definitely a lot going on here at one point. The vandalism alone is testament to that.
But you see little to suggest this vehicle was recently occupied.
Looking at the sleeping bag, you'd wager, from its orientation, that someone crawled out of it.
Or maybe they were dragged.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You leave the husk of a car behind.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's filthy, and you shudder to think of all the things that might've lived in here over the years.
But it's warmth, and not freezing to death beats hygiene any day.
Note: Sleeping bags must be on the ground or in your camp when ending a turn to have any effect.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Follow the trail from the bag.

On a hunch, you search in the direction the mouth of the sleeping bag indicates. Debris and weeds have covered most signs of a trail.
However, a short ways off, you notice it: the remains of a body.
Most of it has been picked clean over years of decay, ruining any clothes it may have worn.
However, it looks like a boot fell off along the way.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Welcome to NanoSoft Home!
Please choose your desired software from the list below.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
However, thanks to the meddling of the NSA, TSA, CIA, and other three-letter government agencies, there are handy spying backdoors any hacker worth his salt can leverage.
Bingo bango, thank you Uncle Sam!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Not enough charge left in the target device.
You start up the application, but before long, it becomes clear that the algorithm could run as long as half an hour, and you'll need at least that much charge in the device to complete the process.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Choose the app you'd like to launch from the list below.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Choose the app you'd like to launch from the list below.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
****iSl-AK Cracker****
Scanning for compatible devices... Done.
Select target device:

table.name: encounters
table.column: Unfortunately, there probably isn't a customer support center left to call, even if there was a national phone service to call them on.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Destination device unlocked.
Have a nice day!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Destination device unlocked.
Have a nice day!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Br1nG v1.2
Scanning for compatible devices... Done.
Select target device:

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You launch the program, but it doesn't take long to realize you're in over your head.
What does this software even do? Does it work on devices like these? Do you plug the target device in somewhere? Or do you need to start the software first?
You wish there was a tutorial or something.
Or even some menus.
Oh well, no 1337 h4x0r5 for you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
****5MR-7 Cracker****
Scanning for compatible devices... Done.
Select target device:

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Destination device unlocked.
Have a nice day!

table.name: encounters
table.column: You launch the Lamp app, and the iSlab's screen brightens, casting a pale light around you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You launch the Lamp app, and the phone's screen brightens, casting a pale light around you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Even after civilization has crumbled, some of the GPS satellite network remains operational.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Even after civilization has crumbled, some of the GPS satellite network remains operational.

table.name: encounters
table.column: To the average user, laptops could be a beast to get access to without a password. Usually, this involved a unique PIN assigned to the owner, and could often involve contacting the manufacturer if that PIN was lost.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're outside the Detroit Savings Bank's Gate 11 microbranch.
A secure, climate-controlled booth, slightly larger than a covered bus stop, sits on the sidewalk here.
It has the requisite self-serve terminal on the exterior, but looking through the transparent walls, there appears to be an actual human teller inside!

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait for the teller to leave.

You find a position with a good vantage point, and stare at the booth like a psycho for a while.
Fortunately, it appears something has come up, and it doesn't involve calling the police on a stalker.
The teller gathers some things, exits the booth, and locks it behind her.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The microbranch isn't a fortress, but trying anything too overt would attract a lot of attention, and likely warrant a quick visit from the police.
You do, however, notice that the facility lacks a restroom. Between potty breaks and lunch, the teller's going to have to step out sometime.
The trick will be doing it without looking like a creep.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide to leave the DSB microbranch.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're outside the DSB Gate 11 microbranch, now empty and locked.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Under normal circumstances, picking a lock in plain view on some busy sidewalk is a dumb move.
Under these circumstances, it still is. You work your magic on the lock, but by the time you're seated at the terminal, someone outside is already on their mobile. Probably talking to the police.
There's no sign of the teller yet, but you're betting your time here is limited.
Damn that good Samaritan.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Using the login info you pilfered earlier, you unlock the banking terminal.
It takes some time to familiarize yourself with the system. Opaque acronyms litter the interface, and nothing but trial and error eventually lead you to the "Client Services" menu.
Movement outside catches your eye, and it appears multiple witnesses are gathering around, exchanging expressions of shock.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Despite the level of physical security banks typically employ, you're happy to see that banks continue to use outdated software on their teller terminals.
It takes some time to familiarize yourself with the system. Opaque acronyms litter the interface, and nothing but trial and error eventually lead you to the "Client Services" menu.
Movement outside catches your eye, and it appears multiple witnesses are gathering around, exchanging expressions of shock.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Shuddering at the painful interface, you just decide to go straight to the source, and run a DB query on the account.
Better Banking Checking Account (...1117)
McAllen, Cale
Concrete Forest Apartments #3935, Tower 48 23140 Halsted Rd. Detroit, G11 09-01
Balance: $0.00
Huh. Well, that probably explains why your cryo visit came to such an abrupt stop.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait for the teller to leave.

You find a position with a good vantage point, and stare at the booth like a psycho for a while.
The booth doesn't garner a lot of foot traffic, which might explain why there are so few of them around town.
As soreness overcomes your feet, you realize this is going to take long than you thought.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait for the teller to leave.

You find a position with a good vantage point, and stare at the booth like a psycho for a while.
The booth doesn't garner a lot of foot traffic, which might explain why there are so few of them around town.
As you're waiting, you think she spots you, but you can't be sure. Waiting a bit longer, she starts talking on her mobile, and glances your way, looking down again when she sees you.
It appears you've been made.
As you hurry down the sidewalk, faint sirens can be heard echoing through the canyon of skyscrapers.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
When the login screen appears, the teller rattles off some keystrokes, but it's way too hard for you to see from here.
Without some sort of optical zoom to help, this isn't going to work.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait for the teller to return and log in.
Several minutes later, the teller walks back up to the booth, and unlocks the door. She spreads a few personal effects on her desk, and draws the keyboard near.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You find a query tool, and locate the account ID field. Recalling the ID from the cryo computer, you key in the digits, and hit Enter.
You hazard a look outside, and bystanders have started rubbernecking.
On-screen, a turning hourglass seems to mock you as the faint sound of sirens, echoing off skyscrapers, grows louder.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You've got access to the computer now, but not much time. The threatening of a bank employee is sure to be high on the police priority list.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Watch the teller log in with optical zoom.

When the login screen appears, the teller rattles off some keystrokes, and it's almost too quick to discern.
However, you think you have it down to a couple possible permutations. It should be few enough to try manually without a lockout.
Now, to get your mitts on that keyboard...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Screw delicacy. Let's get this done.
You step into the booth, and stride toward the teller purposefully. She is visibly surprised at your brazenness, and stammers, "H-hello, sir. Can I help you?"
You march around the desk, and tell her to get lost, staring at her as she scrambles to get away from you.
She steps outside, and hurries away, rummaging through her purse.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Merging with the line of people and vehicles, you make your way through the exit tunnel into the muddy tent city of the Sprawl.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Detroit Savings Bank turns out to be a surprisingly tricky business to find.
It has a presence, for certain. Self-service terminals are near-ubiquitous, winking at passers-by from countertops, ad-walls, and alcoves. But there's little more to these terminals than signage, lights, and a screen.
There doesn't even appear to be a place to dispense cash, nor insert a card.
After a bit of walking, though, you eventually find a Detroit Savings Bank microbranch with more than a screen.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You pull the transparent door open, and step through. Inside, you're greeted with bright, colored light and dry, tepid air.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The teller, a presentable-looking young woman with straight brown hair, looks up from her terminal warmly.
"Hello," she says. "Is there anything with which I can assist you today?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask about the Gyges Cryo Facility account.

You begin explaining your situation, starting with the cryo facility, your amnesia, and the clues you followed to reach this point.
She feigns interest as you tell your tale, but at the first opportunity, interjects.
"I'm sorry, uh, Mr. Kindred, but do you hold an account with us?"
"I think so," you consider answering, but she continues.
"Or perhaps you have some form of identification?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You hold forward your bracelet, plaintively.
"Oh," she says, switching subtly from attentive to deflective, "I'm afraid we can only service clients who presently hold an account with Detroit Savings Bank, or citizens of Detroit opening new accounts."
"However, you're still welcome to use our payment network at any participating vendor. Your mobile device can both send and receive payments."
She indicates a brightly illustrated placard on the wall, depicting overwhelmingly inoffensive young people conducting transactions in an unnaturally happy fashion.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You smile and thank the young lady, and head back outside. The humid, city air seems palpable after the crisp environs of the booth.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Temporary structures like these are usually wired to an exposed junction box nearby. If you can locate it, perhaps you could power-cycle the booth?
It wouldn't get you the information you seek. At least, not directly. But you could probably sneak a peek at her logging back in if you had a sharp eye.
You'll still need a way to access the terminal to use that info, though.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Sure enough, you spot a stainless pipe snaking its way from one corner of the microbranch. You spot where it connects to the grid, and look for the usual maintenance access.
You make like you're waiting for someone as you watch for the right moment. And then, as traffic hits a lull, you trip the breaker.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The microbranch goes dark, as does a nearby lamp. Nary a person blinks, though, in this city of flashing signage and flying cars.
You quickly reset the breaker, and make for the far side of the microbranch, trying to find the perfect blend of vantage point and inconspicuousness.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Climate-control means this thing has an intake someplace. Finding and obstructing that will make it downright uncomfortable in there.
If she leaves, though, it'll be to await a technician, so your window of opportunity will be short.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Grabbing a couple posters from a nearby wall, you nonchalantly place them on the side of the booth, over the HVAC intake.
Given the number of posters slapped on all surfaces around this part of town, nobody seems to pay you any mind.
There's a slight fluttering as the last poster buffets in the draft, but you smooth it out, and you hear a change in the fan pitch.
Over the next several minutes, you notice the booth start fogging up, and the teller makes a phone call. She gathers some things, exits the front door, and locks it behind her.
Now's your chance.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You pull the keyboard towards you, look at the screen, and...
...it's logged out.
You don't have the slightest idea what username or password to use here. You could probably start trying them at random, but even if the system didn't lock you out, you're pretty sure you don't have the time.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You find a query tool, and locate the account ID field. Recalling the ID from the cryo computer, you key in the digits, and hit Enter.
You hazard a look outside, and the bystanders continue their vigil.
On-screen, a turning hourglass seems to mock you as the faint sound of sirens, echoing off skyscrapers, grows louder.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Search results finally appear, and you click on the lone entry.
Better Banking Checking Account (...1117)
McAllen, Cale
Concrete Forest Apartments #3935, Tower 48 23140 Halsted Rd. Detroit, G11 09-01
Balance: $0.00
Huh. Well, that probably explains why your cryo visit came to such an abrupt stop.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Sirens blare suddenly in the street, in a high, warbling burst. Blue and red strobes light up the area as fan jets scatter moisture and debris around.
A loudspeaker booms across nearby building facades.
"This is SkyCorps security. Step into the street, and place your hands on top of your head."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You step into sight slowly, careful not to give that sky jockey any reason to pull the trigger.
A pinpoint flash of red emits from the skybike's undercarriage, and your body is painted in a flickering cross-hatched pattern.
You're instructed to kneel, and you hear more sirens approaching through the canyons of buildings.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You steel your nerves, and bolt, veering left immediately.
A flash of red emits from the skybike's undercarriage, and your body is painted in a flickering cross-hatched pattern.
You hear a beep, followed by a loud "pow!"
Something slams into you, and you collapse instantly, muscles seizing uncontrollably. Unable to move, see, or even hear straight, the world is an agonizing blur as you flop on the asphalt.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You steel your nerves, and bolt, veering left immediately.
A flash of red emits from the skybike's undercarriage, and your body is painted in a flickering cross-hatched pattern.
You hear the engines change pitch as the vehicle reorients, a beep, followed by a loud "pow!"
Something smacks against the ground near your feet, flashing arcs of electricity as it skitters.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Moments later, an armored, multi-wheeled personnel carrier appears, bearing the same colors and flashing lights as the SkyCorps bike.
Bulky silhouettes emerge from the APC's glaring lights, their shapes defined by heavy riot gear. They approach you, bind your hands, and half-escort, half-carry you up a ramp into the APC's holding area.
All the while, the red beam from the SkyCorps bike traces your moves, only shutting off as you pass through the APC's bulkhead.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Inside, you're stripped of anything useful, and strapped into a restraining seat. The guards then step through another bulkhead, and climb a step or two before sealing you in.
You're left there, sitting in your restraints, looking around a reinforced room with no windows. The sound of duct fans can be heard, but little else.
Nothing seems to happen for an annoyingly long time, and then the APC begins moving. The acceleration is surprisingly subtle for such a big machine, though the ride is still pretty rough back here.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
When your ride comes to an end, the interior bulkead opens again, and the guards emerge to unfasten you. You're lead to an exterior doorway, which blinds you when opened.
The sounds of the city spill in through the door, along with damp exterior air. You're guided down a ramp, and just as your eyes begin to adjust, you're dropped into a seat.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Well, this is familiar. You're back in the beige fortress, awaiting processing by DMC Perimeter Services.
Same old ceiling tiles. Same old filing cabinets. Same old missing persons...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're escorted from the interview area, and brought into an on-site clinic, where you're strapped to a table, and anesthetized.
When you wake, you're on a bench in a painted cinder block room, leaning against a corner. Both your head and right shoulder ache. A piercing bleep fills the room as an intercom comes to life.
"You have been charged as follows: -First-degree criminal trespassing -Unauthorized access to a computer with intent to commit an offense -Fraud and misuse of visas -Conspiracy to defraud the city of Detroit -Consorting with a known felon -Failure to disclose personal information"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
This time, when the case handler arrives, there's no talking. Just scribbling notes, cross-checking a nearby monitor, and a stern glance telling you you're not worth the effort.
A guard grabs your shoulder, and pushes you into the cinder block room with the blaring speakerphone.
A voice blares, "Repeated violation of exile order is cause for term of sentence to be extended by 2 years. Subsequent violations may be subject to penalties including capital punishment, at the discretion of the arresting officer."
A door on the opposite wall buzzes, and swings open to the familiar muddy streets outside the DMC walls.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
At the front of the line, the guard motions you closer. A moment of pregnant silence precedes a satisfying chirp, and the monitor flashes.
"Suspect Flagged: Detain for Questioning."
Your gut suddenly feels like a vacuum. The guard places a heavy-gloved hand on your shoulder. "Alright, buddy, let's go."
You're led to a gray door at the base of the south buttress, alongside a thin slit of mirrored windows.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You take a moment to peer outside at the source of the noise.
Hovering some ten meters above is a skybike, bristling with lights, exhaust nacelles, and a semi-enclosed rider atop.
More concerning is that nasty-looking turret on the undercarriage. It looks like one part sensor suite, and one or more parts muzzle. It's aimed in your general area, but looks to be in some sort of pending acquisition mode.
The thing'd no doubt tag you if you ran, but it might have some trouble with transverse tracking if you moved fast enough crossing underneath it.
You'd have to be damned fast, though.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You steel your nerves, and bolt, veering left immediately.
A flash of red emits from the skybike's undercarriage, and your body is painted in a flickering cross-hatched pattern.
You hear a beep, followed by a loud "pow!"
Something slams into you, and you stagger a few steps as muscles clench near the impact.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You steel your nerves, and bolt, charging directly under the skybike.
A flash of red emits from its undercarriage, and your body is painted in a flickering cross-hatched pattern.
You hear the engines change pitch as the vehicle reorients, a beep, followed by a loud "pow!"
Something smacks against the ground near your feet, flashing arcs of electricity as it skitters.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Instead of collapsing, though, you emit a lung-tearing scream, and resume barreling ahead.
What bystanders had accumulated suddenly flip out and start running in a panic, as you full-tilt in hulk mode across the street.
The skybike winds up, and starts pursuit.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Dodging down a side street, you hear the engines whirring behind you enter a steady crescendo.
You caught the jockey unaware, but this chase is going to be over pretty quick if you don't upgrade your strategy from "outrun the high-performance flying motorcycle".

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Dodging down a side street, you hear the engines whirring behind you enter a steady crescendo.
It was an impressive feat, but this chase is going to be over pretty quick if that thing tags you again.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The street here is open, but there are sources of cover for those trained to find it.
Crowds of people shuffle to and fro on the sidewalks. Awnings, signs, and overhead pedways block whole sections. And a steady stream of traffic, both on the ground and on-level with the skybike, provides an ever-changing screen from view.
Ducking into the crowd, you pass under a canopy, switch back, walk alongside another person, bounce through traffic as a truck passes, and use the temporary lead to disappear in plain sight.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
People on the sidewalk here are thick enough that you could probably make yourself a risky target if you weaved through them.
Dashing towards the sidewalk, you begin bobbing and weaving, though the skybike's flickering red target hashmarks follow you.
You do your best to present as few clear shots as possible, shoulder-brushing one person, side-stepping the next.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Scanning for doorways, there's at least one greasy spoon you could see entering with no fuss. Maybe they have a back door?
You dash inside, pushing past a line of annoyed patrons, then to a set of interior glass doors.
You press through, and end in a mall-like corridor, lined with stores and doors emptying onto either side of the block.
Quickly gauging which way the skybike will guess, you choose the opposite.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use other ground and hover traffic as cover.

It's not bumper-to-bumper, but there are a fair number of vehicles on this street.
Most are at ground level, though enough sky traffic at the skybike's altitude means that it won't have free movement.
You cross at an opportune moment, putting a stream of hover traffic between you and the skybike, forcing it into a high arc to regain a shot.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You duck into an alley.
It's dark, with high walls too narrow for the bike to follow effectively. The bike slows down, instead gaining altitude to vault the buildings and get overhead.
No place to hide in here, though. Not much cover, either.
Maybe this wasn't such a good idea.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You risk a brief glance to see what the bike's doing now.
Its targeting system has switched back to acquisition mode, and it's clear the jockey's lost eyes-on.
It continues to hover in a futile vigil, awaiting backup to flood the streets, but you're gone before they arrive.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Pow!
Something slams into you, this time dropping you like a sack of potatoes to the sidewalk. Your body twitches and convulses from the shock round embedded in your skin, and everything smears into a wash of sound and light.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You managed to buy yourself a few more moments, but that thing's far from shaken off.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You managed to buy yourself a few more moments, but that thing's far from shaken off.
In fact, it seems to have an unshakable bead on you, no matter what you do. Even tracking you through obstacles!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Pow!
Something slams into you, this time dropping you like a sack of potatoes to the sidewalk. Your body twitches and convulses from the shock round embedded in your skin, and everything smears into a wash of sound and light.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The SkyCorps bike continues its vigil, targeting turret twitching for the right shot.

table.name: encounters
table.column: That thing's gotta be tracking you somehow. Check your things to see if something's giving your position away.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You sidle up to the junction box again, watching for the right moment. And then, as traffic hits a lull, you trip the breaker.
Once more, the microbranch goes dark, and powers back up.
You position yourself to sneak another peek at the login, but this time, the teller's not bothering.
Gathering some things, she begins talking on her mobile, and exits the booth. You hear something about "Yeah, again. I don't know!" as she locks the front door, and walks away.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait for the teller to return and log in.

You spot the teller crossing the street towards the bank again, just as a moped slows to a halt on the sidewalk nearby.
The moped is emblazoned with "Descartes Kiosks and Enclosures", and has one of those weather shells looping over the rider's seat. Large, rigid saddlebags protrude from the rear.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The moped rider dismounts, and it appears to be a gangly woman in a drab blue-gray windbreaker and slacks. She pulls a toolkit from the moped's storage, and meets the teller at the door.
They both enter, the teller taking her seat, and the technician begins reviewing something on her tablet.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use Hiding to sneak a peek at the log in.

With two sets of eyes roaming around the bank, *plus* passers-by, this is going to be tricky.
You decide to use timing and confidence here, rather than stealth.
Carefully pacing yourself, you manage to time it just right so that the teller is logging in as you pass by the window.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Positioning yourself for optimal viewing, you await the teller's login.
However, a shout startles you out of your vigil. The technician's checklist goes on hold as she notices your staring, and starts speaking into her earpiece.
The teller's been alerted, too, and is standing up.
Things are about to get pretty hot here. Time to jet.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You return to the site of the DSB microbranch, but stop suddenly when you notice it's gone.
A sign in its place says, "We're sorry. This DSB location has been removed for maintenance. We look forward to serving you again soon!"
Damn. Looks like this trail's cold for now.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Speaking of abrupt, that's the word they'll use to describe your life of crime if you don't get out of here fast. The accumulating number of bystanders and echoing sirens mean it's time to go.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You return to the site of the DSB microbranch, but stop suddenly when you notice it has a new feature: a private security guard.
DSB probably amped up security at their microbranches after your escapades. Looks like you'll need to find another way to locate the info you need.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hide and wait for the teller to leave.

You take up position far enough away to be dissociated from the booth, and find something to occupy your time as you wait.
The booth doesn't garner a lot of foot traffic, which might explain why there are so few of them around town.
As soreness overcomes your feet, you realize this is going to take long than you thought.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hide and wait for the teller to leave.

You take up position far enough away to be dissociated from the booth, and find something to occupy your time as you wait.
Fortunately, it appears something has come up, whether growling stomach or not. The teller gathers some things, exits the booth, and locks it behind her.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Pretend to be a mentally retarded patient.

Striking your best "I don't know what's going on" expression, you feign delight upon meeting the teller's gaze.
Ambling toward her, you fish out something ridiculous, and hold it forward for her, like "ta da!"
"Oh ho ho, what have we here?" she says, turning it over slowly, in mock awe. "Wow! This is impressive! We should deposit this right away."
Reaching for a deposit slip, she asks, "and to which account should we deposit this?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Using your off-hand, you scrawl the account number in child-like handwriting. An idea seems to occur to her, and she starts typing into her console.
A few moments later, she turns to you. "Do you know Cale? Are you looking for Cale McAllen?"
She starts writing on her notepad.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Show the teller your medical bracelet.

You extend your arm, revealing the disposable medical bracelet on your arm. She examines it more closely, turning it side-to-side.
"Hmm," she checks something on her computer, then says, "nope, not there. What about..." followed by more searching.
Then, an idea seems to cross her mind. "Wait, let's see..." and a few more moments pass.
"A-ha!" she exclaims, and you blurt out an excited noise for effect.
She begins writing something on her notepad.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You furtively sneak a peek:
McAllen, Cale Concrete Forest Apartments #3935, Tower 48 23140 Halsted Rd. Detroit, G11 09-01
Then, she picks up her mobile, and starts making a phone call. Already having what you came for, you begin shuffling back towards the door.
"Oh, wait- Mr. Kindred!" she calls after you, "yes, sorry. May I have the number for a Cale McAllen..."
Once outside, you duck out of sight and put a block or two between you and the booth. Never know if someone might actually come looking!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You shrug, smiling.
"Oh, ooookay. I think I see now. Are we lost?" she picks up the phone. "Looks like someone lost their chaperone?"
A few moments pass. "Yeah, hi. Are you possibly missing a patient?"
You get up, and start shuffling towards the door.
"Oh, wait- Sir!" she calls after you, "yes, sorry. I'm at the DSB microbranch. Yeah, Gate 11..."
Once outside, you duck out of sight and put a block or two between you and the booth.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Hm," he says, leaning back in his creaky chair. "Turns out maybe you *are* worth the extra attention you seem to have garnered."
He looks down at a blank spot on his desk, considering something a moment, and starts talking at it. "Your, let's call him 'employer', had a particular interest in you."
He leans forward, and starts interacting with his security console. "Interested enough to open this urn contract with express instructions that it only be assigned to you. Said I'd find you trying to enter the DMC. Said he'd front the cost of the visitor's pass if I got you to do it."
He finishes a keystroke, then gestures to the wall monitors.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
This meat...
It's like good, fully developed veal. Not young, but not yet beef. Yes, very definitely like that, and not like any other meat you've tasted. In fact, so much so that you think no person with a palate of ordinary, normal sensitiveness could distinguish it from veal. It is mild, good meat, with no other sharply defined or highly characteristic taste such as, for instance, goat, high game, and pork have.
The steak is slightly tougher than prime veal, a little stringy, but not too tough or stringy to be agreeably edible. The roast is tender, and in color, texture, smell as well as taste, strengthens your certainty that of all the meats you habitually know, veal is the one meat to which this meat is accurately comparable.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
This meat...
It's like good, fully developed veal. Not young, but not yet beef. Yes, very definitely like that, and not like any other meat you've tasted. In fact, so much so that you think no person with a palate of ordinary, normal sensitiveness could distinguish it from veal. It is mild, good meat, with no other sharply defined or highly characteristic taste such as, for instance, goat, high game, and pork have.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It is good that you've found more of this meat. There is nothing else quite like it. It has a unique, satisfying effect that you cannot seem to supplant.
This, this is the only thing you crave. The only thing that will satisfy your hunger.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It is good. Yes, this meat is good. And it fills the emptiness inside.
It also fills you with fear, though. Is there enough? Will there be enough? Can it keep pace with your hunger?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You place a slab of meat on the scale, and wait as the butcher comes over to verify. He picks up the slab, inspecting it for signs of spoilage, and then freezes.
"Just what the-" he drops the slab, and with his other hand, grabs a scattergun. He begins ringing a bell, its clanging reverberating through the honeycomb of shipping containers.
Everyone stops, turning. Craning their necks to see around the crowd at the commotion.
"Flesh peddler!" he shouts. "Cannibal!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
People begin shouting, some exchanging glances, while others closing rank.
Your arms are grabbed by some of the bigger patrons, and you're held restrained. The crowd immediately starts rummaging through your belongings. Scrabbling and tearing anything of value they can from your body as you're dragged out into the street.
Then, you're thrown to the ground, the muck "splurping" as you land. The scrabbling hands change to fists and stomping feet, as your body begins snapping and twisting from the blows.
Shards of pain stab your body. Flashes of light assault your vision. The shouting of crowds bleeds into watery brown noise as your vision fades...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Devastation on a monumental scale mars the land before you.
It looks as if someone hosed down an entire county with toxic chemicals, set it on fire, then bombarded it with artillery for good measure.
Pools of caustic liquid are everywhere. Most everything that once was here has dissolved, melted, burned, or turned to dust. Hardier materials have eroded more slowly, leaving skeletal evidence of small towns, farmsteads, tree trunks... and creatures.
Toxic miasmas float in some places, clinging to the ground where reactions released them into the air. And warning signs, both official and homemade, litter the boundary.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
And the silence here is deafening. No birds, nor critters. Not even insects. Nothing stirs in this caustic swamp of destruction.
Nothing lives here.
Or at least, nothing is alive here.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Hey!" the butcher's voice booms.
"Didn't I tell you?" The market quiets to a murmur.
"I done told you, didn't I?" He points his knife at you. "I ever see you and human meat together, under this roof..." and he draws the knife across his neck, in a cutting motion.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You take a moment to peer outside at the source of the noise.
Hovering some ten meters above is a skybike, bristling with lights, exhaust nacelles, and a semi-enclosed rider atop.
More concerning is that nasty-looking turret on the undercarriage. It looks like one part sensor suite, and one or more parts muzzle. It's aimed in your general area, but looks to be in some sort of pending acquisition mode.
The thing'd almost certainly tag you if you ran.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
