"Oh," he says, distracted. Then, he becomes more animated.
"Oh! Ya mean the hot bricks! Sure! Sure. Think I've got a spare 'round here..." Boxes are pushed about. Papers displaced.
"Whatchu got ta offer?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: "I think that'll work," he says, handing you the cell. He starts looking for a good place to put your payment, and ultimately just places it in a container on a counter.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "That's a real shame," he says, visibly disappointed. "Could use some supplies."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Turning back to you, he asks, "How about ol' Gerty. Think ya can help 'er?"
He adds, "Be a reeal help, you know?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The Wraith crumples to the ground, its face disappearing as it collapses into a lightless pool. Patches of black continue to fly off the shape, like ash from a fire.
Then, a flash of blue radiates from beneath it, and the blackness starts drawing into itself, leaving no residue behind.
At first, it simply becomes smaller as if pulled into nothingness. But as the edges recede, it becomes clear that it's falling into some sort of portal on the ground.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You peer over the edge, and see steps leading to the floor of a cluttered chamber, as if viewing from its ceiling. Items crowd every surface, though you see no signs of an occupant.
The air intermingles between the two worlds, the other side having a dry, sterile quality compared to the moist, musty air here.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You step forward, and allow your weight to drop onto the hole...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
...and land firmly on the step. Despite your expectations to the contrary, you feel only a temperature gradient where the portal intersects your body. It feels like entering a museum from outdoors.
Inside, you're surrounded by a small chamber, cluttered with items on shelves and work surfaces. It's warm here, and smells of desert and stone. Light spills in from a large opening on one wall, and you nearly stagger from the view.
A vast, open space lies beyond, filled with columns of impossible height. Far below, dozens, maybe hundreds of figures dot the floor. Some are interacting with strange pools of light, others crossing the floor or entering doorways at the base of the columns.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The room resembles an arcane study. Shelves are stuffed with artifacts from ancient to modern, and some completely alien to your eyes. There are also organic samples, possibly mummified or preserved trophies. It looks like one part evidence locker and one part wizard's laboratory.
You take note of some of the more recognizable items.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's hard to discern their shapes, at first. You can see silhouettes, but their edges blur together.
A moment later, however, it occurs to you why. They're more wraiths. Dozens of these frightful things are down there, attending to devices, or passing into and out of columns. Including this one.
You yank your head back before any turn to see you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
They're more wraiths. Dozens of these frightful things are down there, attending to devices, or passing into and out of columns.
Those devices they're using look like pools or globes, each of which shows a distant scene or person. The rest appear to be entering the bases of columns, including this one.
You yank your head back before any turn to see you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You mount the stairs, and push your way up as quickly as you can.
Your head breaches the portal back into Michigan's cold air, and you turn to assess whether you're being followed.
Instead, the gateway shrinks like an old tube television being turned off, returning the area to its original topology.
Even after closing, your mind is distrustful of the ground where you saw it. You decide to keep it in view as you leave, and only turn away when it's out of sight.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Examine the clay and stone engravings.
Fragments of clay with some sort of cuneiform engravings. There's even a small, faceted pillar with writing on each side. They're interesting to look at, but reveal little to your modern eyes.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A book, written in an unfamiliar language, but illustrated in a manner suggesting it was for children.
Imagery seems to be of children fabricating a world of their own imagination. The more friends they involve, the more elaborate the world becomes.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A sheaf of letters from Ambrose Bierce, cataloging creatures and occurrences that lack any rational explanation.
More interestingly, the letters appear to be part of a series trying to draw connections between the events and participants.
The series stops abruptly, however, before any conclusion is made.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Examine the sheaf of old papers.
Sheaf of papers labeled "I.K., Opus Postumum". You don't speak German, so this document is largely opaque to you. However, it appears to be excerpts of a larger work. Whole sections are missing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A 60mm film spool in a canister, labeled "Woodhouse Moor Lodges - Louis Le Prince".
The footage seems rather mundane to you, as you examine the individual frames against the light. Mostly a fascination with capturing passing carts, horses, and people.
However, a shot of fear runs through you when you notice a disembodied, white mask staring at the camera from one of the lodges' windows.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Your exploration is cut short when sounds arise from outside the chamber.
You turn in time to see two figures, each wearing intricate masks, raising some sort of device with a nozzle. A billowing blackness pours out, threatening to inundate the room in seconds.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Examine the large ring with a projection inside.

A ring of polished stone, or metal, stands on one of the work surfaces, with lines of text projected in its center.
As you look closer, the image seems to shift, resolving so you can read. It's in English, and it looks to be a website, of all things. Probably cached from before the crash.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's entitled "The New Earth Ostracon", and it appears to be a collection of cross-referenced, unexplained occurrences.
The entries are not only descriptive, but include links and captures of references in other media, search trends, related entries, and maps of where and when known references were discovered.
It seems to care as much about the propagation of the idea as the subject itself.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Desiring more context, you begin looking for navigation controls. There don't appear to be any, however.
You recall that the image shifted when you looked closer, and a thought occurs to you. Craning your neck, you try to look around the object in the screen. As you picture what might be beyond it, it actually moves correspondingly to the side. But there is only a blank surface there.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Trying a different tack, you imagine stepping back for a bigger picture.
The text view recedes, revealing that the website is part of a chamber rendered in the ring's view.
Huh, that's interesting. Sort of like a thought-driven memory palace as an OS.
As you look around the virtual space, you notice a figure, and other images on vertical surfaces.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Each feature you notice, however, causes your stomach to sink a bit more.
A life-size replica of you stands in the room, staring blankly ahead. Your talisman is in plain view.
Dozens of nearly identical images of you line one wall, apparently taken on different days while you were in stasis.
Even maps which seem to plot your movements...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Each feature you notice, however, causes your stomach to sink a bit more.
A life-size replica of you stands in the room, staring blankly ahead. Your talisman is in plain view.
Dozens of nearly identical images of you line one wall, apparently taken on different days while you were in stasis. Was that what caused the tracks you saw there?
Even maps which seem to plot your movements...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Desiring more context, you begin looking for navigation controls. There don't appear to be any, however.
Whatever this device is, it was designed with another user in mind. One who, no doubt, speaks the arcane language engraved in its materials.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You decide that visiting the homeworld of the frightening murderous creature is contrary to your best interest.
Stepping back from the portal, you watch as it closes on itself, like the image on an old tube TV switching off.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Well, you've got this...thing. It's a long shot, but maybe it'd draw that bike's attention?
You locate a crude power switch, take a deep breath, and flip...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
...and the doll goes ballistic. Almost literally.
Piercing wails echo through the booth, light beams strobe from its eyes, the arms and legs start flailing about, and you drop the thing in a panic.
It wobbles and lurches around the floor, painting the area in dots of light, and causing people outside to backpedal in fear.
Another chirp from outside is barely audible over the ruckus, red patterns appear near the doll, and suddenly the booth's window shatters as a shot from the skybike ricochets off the floor.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Air rushes in through the newly formed hole in the wall, and you burst outside, taking advantage of the commotion.
The skybike is repositioning to intercept, but its turret seems fixated on that doll, unable to break contact.
You duck around the corner, blend with foot traffic, and it isn't long before the bike loses you in the crowd, its main tracking system occupied.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Arriving at Concrete Forest Apartments, you immediately see the resemblance. Towering structures stand at regular intervals, like giant, artificial trees. Criss-crossing laundry lines, string lights, and contra-code balcony modifications complete the illusion.
Below, the ground is an organic patchwork of community gardens and trash heaps; gutted husks of cars and playgrounds; those who call the Forest home, and those who sleep in its shadow.
It feels a bit like a street fair collided with a refugee camp in the ghetto.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There's a canteen truck strategically positioned curb-side near the main walk. People are lined up at the illuminated side window, and a mixture of steam and smoke stream from its openings.
Nearby, music booms from where a crowd has gathered. It's all bobbing shoulders and legs from here, but you do see a car's hatchback sticking up from near the center.
One of the towers has a c-store at ground level. A lonely few are inside, but it doesn't seem very popular.
And there's the ubiquitous knock-off vendor, barking at passers-by.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Judging by the signage, tower 48 is a few rows south of here. You strike off in that direction, weaving your way through the complex network of buildings, people, and detritus.
Deep in the center of the block, you find number 48. The thing is easily 40 stories high, and like all the towers here, has an X-shaped cross-section.
Also like all the other towers, there's a secure entryway. Some sort of card lock, likely to keep troublemakers like you out. And judging by the dents and marks all over the frame and glass, it's done its job handily over the years.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you get closer, you smell fried food. You catch an unfamiliar, savory scent. Spicy, but also a bit sweet. And a bit artificial.
No menu, though. Folks here must be regulars. Just line up, a few words, then pay and go.
Dude in the truck probably makes a tidy profit at the rate he's going.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
In major towers like this, you'll often find a convenience store on ground level. Like what one would find at a gas station, it's filled with things that work in an emergency, but nothing for which you'd dedicate a visit.
The cramped space is filled with bottled drinks, junk foods, over-the-counter drugs, and impulse buys.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The sidewalk is vibrating with bass as you approach, and the scene begins to make a bit more sense.
A wide-body, metallic red hatchback is parked near the center, its doors and hatch wide open to expose an array of lights, speakers, and subs. You can almost feel the air move in time with the beat.
Meanwhile, b-boys are taking turns, mixing moves and styles both familiar and strange. It astounds you how the human body can do these things. How humans still push the boundaries of an art form older than you can imagine.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Whatever's cooking, you want some in your stomach.
You find the end of the line, and take your place. It moves at a pretty good clip, and as you reach the middle, you try to sneak a peek at what's up there.
Looks like combos of fried sprouts, spiced meat shavings, cabbage, and fried tofu sticks.
As you reach the counter, you notice the shaved meat comes from a vertical rotisserie of molded meat. However, there's also a real animal of some sort roasting back there.
"Yowhatchuwant?" Truck guy's already looking impatient.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You shake your head, and back away.
The truck guy's eyes have some choice words for you, but he just lets out an "Aaah, whatever. Whatchuwant?" as he turns to the next patron.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You nod at the back wall. "What's with the roast?"
"Trackrabbit," he says, before you finish. Then, sensing your confusion, "Catch-of-the-day," in annunciated syllables.
So much for licensed food providers, it seems.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Roast up!" he shouts over his shoulder.
His assistant carves some meat from the roast, and they tumble onto the cabbage when cut loose. He hands the plate to the vendor, who almost literally throws a splash of red-colored sauce onto the edges of the meat.
You settle your payment, and step away with grub in hand.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Donner 1!" he shouts at the back.
Taking a long, serrated knife from a metal tray, his assistant saws thin strips of the mystery meat slab onto a bed of shredded cabbage.
"Sauce," the vendor says, grabbing the plate. You choose both the white and red sauces because hey, free calories. Then, you pay the man.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Donner 2!" he shouts at the back.
Taking a long, serrated knife from a metal tray, his assistant saws thin strips of the mystery meat slab onto a bed of browned sprouts.
"Sauce," the vendor says, grabbing the plate. You choose both the white and red sauces because hey, free calories. Then, you pay the man.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Fingers!" he shouts at the back.
His assistant lifts a basket of thick, golden brown sticks, and shakes out a portion.
The sticks are drizzled in a dark juice, probably soy, and you exchange your money for the grub.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The meat has a powerful, mostly pleasant taste. Combined with the sauces, it's spicy, salty, and sweet. Probably engineered that way.
And the texture is homogenous and unoffensive. No fibers, fats, nor bone.
Though after a few bites, you can see where the veggies come in. Roughage, something to chew on, and actual nutrients are not amiss here.
Still, it helps fill the pit inside, and you can see how this might become a habit for locals.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A crispy, salty-sour shell gives way to a softer, more flavor-neutral center. It's a pleasant sensation, the initial flavor and crunch.
However, the plate is gone almost too soon, and you're left feeling about as satisfied as if you'd eaten the equivalent volume of cheese puffs.
At least this was healthier.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The roast isn't bad, in fact. Gamey, to be sure. And a bit milder than the stuff one finds "out there".
There's some stringiness and gristle to it, too. Less desirable in days past, but proof you have actual meat in this case. Meat of what, you're probably better off not knowing.
The cabbage is actually a nice touch, despite its rank among cheap nutrients. Fresh-cooked veggies are not common fare these days.
You gulp down the last bites, and get your bearings again.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The high, positive energy feels so foreign after days in the wild. Everything out there seems to be forgotten in this hot bath of sound and energy.
You stick around a few moments more, soaking up raw culture, then turn back to matters at hand.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide to leave the Concrete Forest Apartment complex.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Pick up items to purchase them.
You cannot sell items here, however.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Inside, it's pretty spartan. Industrial-strength carpeting and tile, and some ugly lavender paint. Good to see the anti-ballistic, fake wood paneling industry is still in business, too.
The elevator bank is pretty impressive, though. Probably has to be with this many people here.
You step into an elevator, and punch the button for floor 39. Dented metal doors slide closed, and you feel the car accelerate.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Hmph. You're not surprised. Low-cost, government housing subcontracted the cheapest security they could find.
It's just an RFID reader, and residents probably carry apps on their smartphones to buzz-in. Printed RFID cards for those too poor to own phones.
Provided you had the right software loaded onto an RFID-enabled device, you could probably just spoof your way through this door, no eyelashes batted.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait for somebody to use the door.
Someone's gotta use that door eventually. You'll just hang out here, and stick to them like glue when they go for the door.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
After some time, when you've almost become desensitized to the elevator dings, something rolls off the elevator. Literally, in fact.
A young man sits in a modified wheelchair, a socket where his legs and pelvis should be. Despite his handicap, he seems quite muscular.
He's handsome, too, though he seems immediately distressed that you're hovering outside his door.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
In a move beyond all reckoning, you forgo fancy security hacks, brute force, and all other illegal entry attempts, and decide to just use the doorbell.
There's a list of names and room numbers on the wall, but you doubt anyone's updated it in years. Some entries are blank, blocked out, or have disparaging graffiti next to them.
No matter, though. You punch in the apartment number you learned from the bank, and wait as the speaker emits a staticky call tone.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The three Ts to door shadowing are targeting, timing, and telegraphing.
Targeting means waiting for the right mark. Someone lost in their own thoughts, or antisocial enough to weigh politeness over making a stink.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait for Somebody to Use the Door cont'd

Sure enough, in a matter of minutes, you spot a tired-looking woman in scrubs coming up the walk.
You push off from the fence, and take up stride behind her.
A few steps later, however, she stops and turns. "The *hell* you think you're doin'?"
She doesn't wait for a reply. "Boy, I *know* you ain't livin' here. So git your ass back wherever you came from, and I better not see you hoverin' out here again."
She had courage to call your bluff, and now the commotion has attracted a few onlookers.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait for her to leave, then try again.

No. No, that's not happening. She isn't leaving. If her stare could will you away, it would. But since it can't, and you're hovering like a creep, she's decided to now make this "official business".
She's just dialed a number. A SHORT number. And she's speaking into the phone while looking at you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Better put some distance between you and tower 48. Let things cool down for a bit.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait for Somebody to Use the Door cont'd

You waiting pays off in minutes.
Shuffling down the walk, you spot your ticket to indoors: drunk dude at eleven o'clock, sporting a shiny shirt that's way too thin for the weather, and following an imaginary wobbly line to the door. His rivet-focused tunnel vision on that cardlock cinches it.
Falling in behind him, you catch an overpowering scent of cologne and whiskey. You apply a bit of sway and swagger to your balance for show, and await his next move.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait for Drunk Guy to Use the Door

It takes a while, though.
Inches from the wall, the drunkard tries raising his hip to the cardlock. But nothing happens.
He does it again. Nada.
This time, with a little hop for added distance, his hip bumps the reader, and he stumbles back a few steps, defeated again.
He's staring at his pocket, and you can just imagine him working out drunken math to get that pocket lined up with the cardlock.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait for Drunk Guy to Use the Door cont'd

Sensing he's not alone, he begins turning his attention from his hip pocket towards you. First on your foot, then slowly lifting his gaze, so as not to lose sight of you with a sudden movement.
His eyes finally reach your face, and he almost loses balance.
"Sorr," he almost whispers, then licks the inside of his mouth. "Sorry," he repeats, annunciating.
Reaching into his pocket, he awkwardly removes a smartphone, and finally connects it with the reader.
"Bzzzzz" goes the door, and a click precedes its opening. You both shuffle inside.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Timing means arriving at the door at just the right moment. You can't give them time to think about it, or they'll be suspicious.
Appearing at the last possible moment puts them into a split-second decision between being polite or not about holding the door.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
And telegraphing means pantomiming your intent to play by the rules. Be fishing in your pocket just too slowly for the keys, so it looks like they're just helping you do what you were already authorized to do.
Fumbling awkwardly for your nonexistent phone, you pretend to be startled by the other tenant. He smiles shyly, holding the door open, and you nod as you pass each other.
Easy peasy.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use an RFID spoofer to open the door.

Taking up position by the door, you fire up the spoofer app in "listening" mode, then take a seat against a wall not too far away. You thumb through some apps on your device, and pretend to be uninterested in the door.
A few folks come and go over the space of several minutes, and you keep an eye on the spoofer to see what it picks up. Once they've passed, you count two verified hits, and slot the second one for broadcast.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use RFID Spoofer to Open Door cont'd

You approach the door, and tag the reader like you're a regular. The door goes "bzzzzzt", then begins swaying open.
You're in.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A "click" interrupts the tone, and there's a pause.
"...H-hello?"
Hm, not much to go on. Sounds like a kid answering the door while his parents are out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait for somebody to use the door.

You might've had a few minutes of luck loitering last time, but suspicious glances are all you're getting now.
People around here have obviously had their fair share of freeloaders, vagrants, and worse. And they're quick to call for assistance.
You'll need to find another way, this time.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Looks like you could probably jam the main, motorized door in order to force folks to prop open the overflow door.
Even if they call maintenance, they'll likely keep the doors open while working on them.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Finding a suitably small, hard piece of junk, you cram it into the main door jamb, out of sight. Then, you take up position nearby, so as to avoid suspicion.
A few minutes later, the first victim arrives from outside, and you hear the "bzzzzzt", followed by a straining hum. He flicks his card again, emitting another "bzzzzzt", but no luck.
There are a few acrobatic attempts to activate the card lock while yanking on the door, but he only succeeds in tiring himself out.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
From inside, another tenant appears. She, too, is foiled by the door. And no combo of pushing and shoulder-checking seems to help.
Both tenants share silent, sympathetic exasperation through the glass, as you think to yourself, "Come ON, already."
There are a few more half-hearted attempts, and then she starts looking around the second door.
"Thaaaat's it," you mutter to yourself.
She reaches down to where the door meets the ground, and works a stubborn latch loose. Then, she pushes the second door open, dropping its foot to keep it open.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
They share a genuine laugh over the spectacle, then continue on their way.
You cross to the door and step inside without missing a beat.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Ignoring the main door for a moment, you look around the area to see what your options are.
There's a fire exit at the end of each wing, but those are likely alarmed. Probably locked, too. So no easier.
You do notice, however, that there is a makeshift pedway that some enterprising tenants slapped together. It runs from an adjoining tower to #48, into a room's window.
Even better, it looks as if someone's moving furniture into the adjoining tower. The doors are propped open.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Waltzing into the other tower, you take the stairs up a few flights, and open the door into the hall.
A few doors down, you notice bits of paper and other trash have visibly collected in the hall around one open door.
You chance a peek inside, and discover an empty room, disused and long-ago charred in a fire. The window opens into a dark tunnel, likely the pedway you saw from below.
Unfortunately, it looks like a dead-end. While this side has the benefit of a burnt-out apartment, the other end looks rather occupied.
What's more, they seem keenly displeased with the pedway, and have gone through great lengths to bar their window.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Although...
Looks like there might be an open balcony within jumping distance from the other end of the pedway.
It's the next floor down, and it'd hurt if you missed. But you could probably jump the gap, and try the room attached to that balcony.
Trying to ignore the pedestrians far below, you focus on picturing the successful jump. You begin rocking back and forth, getting your momentum, then leap!

table.name: encounters
table.column: Jump to an Open Balcony cont'd

There's a "crack!" and some grinding as you land, and the balcony dips threateningly under the impact.
You're alive, though, and you hit your mark. You rise to a crouch, and slip inside the room before anyone sees what all that noise was.
Like the tower you left behind, this appears to be another room with nobody in it. No telling why or how long the government leaves these rooms in disrepair.
But no matter. You're in. Now about that room...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
In the midst of all this, though, you hear sirens approach. And given what's passed recently, you get the distinct feeling they're coming for you specifically.
Trying not to attract too much attention to yourself, you change direction towards the nearest cover you can find: a dumpster near the overpass.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You step into the block, and start looking around.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Is this Cale McAllen?"
Another pause. "Yeah." His tone is getting a bit more confident.
Well, this is it. This is him. You've tracked clues from across the state to end up here. Does he have any answers to your questions? Can he tell you anything?
Does he even know who you are?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I think we have a bank account in common."
That elicits a snicker. "Yeah, THAT figures." His tone is more cynical now. More driven. "You know? Thank you, Mr. Kindred." Something's clicked inside him.
"You have no idea. No, really. THANK you."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Do you know who I am?"
"Yeah." His temerity is pretty much gone now. "Yeah, I know who you are."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"You're... wel-?"
He interrupts you.
"All these years, I had to wonder. My dad," there's a pause. "God. Do you have any idea? I mean, do you have any idea how MESSED UP things were?"
This isn't going well.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"No, it's good that you showed up. It's good, because now I know you're just an ass-hole." He takes the time to sound out that last bit.
His breath catches. "Why my father, huh? Why'd you have to pick him? Why not some other loser on the Deep Web. Your fucking little drama." He's losing it.
"Why are you even still alive? Why couldn't you just, you know, fucking disappear like your asshole friend up in Grayling?"
Whoa, that's news. Grayling?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Actually," he's suddenly driven. "Actually, yeah. You know what?"
He's moving. It sounds like he's across the room. It's unintelligible over the city. But he comes back.
"...exactly what you need. You hear that? You HEAR THAT? Huh? Ass-hole?"
There's some beeping. Sounds like he's dialing. Another pause.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Yeah. Cale McAllen."
This isn't good.
"Police."
It might be time to go, here.
"There's a man outside my apartment building..."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
In the midst of all this, though, you hear sirens. And given what's passed recently, you get the distinct feeling they're looking for you, specifically.
Trying not to attract too much attention to yourself, you change direction toward the nearest cover you can find: a dumpster near the overpass.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You backtrack. "Wait, that came out wrong. I mean-I can't remember anything. Who am I?"
"Oh. Oh, that's nice. Yeah, that actually works pretty well, doesn't it?" He's agitated now.
"A real tragedy that you can't remember. You know. All THIS."
You're guessing there's a gesture you're missing.

table.name: encounters
table.column: No, Really, Who Am I? cont'd

"Meanwhile, the rest of us-you know, out here in REALITY-the rest of us just have to deal with it."
"I don't-"
"You don't remember?" he cuts you off. "Well, let me give you a rundown. You know. A fucking REFRESHER."
This isn't going well.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The ride is several minutes of humming, creaking, and an annoying, synthetic "ding!"
You hear occasional voices and music as you pass some floors, but it's a long, boring ride.
Smells like stale fried food, too.

table.name: encounters
table.column: No, Really, Who Am I? cont'd

"You're nobody. Get it? You're just some asshole who reached out a slimy hand from the Deep Web one day, and decides he needs my dad's help."
"And whatever compels him to agree, fuck if I know. But he does. Whatever hold you had on him, it's enough. Enough to make you his fucking life mission. And the rest of us-"
He cuts himself off. "You know what? Fuck you. You want your past back, you can't have it. It's GONE."

table.name: encounters
table.column: No, Really, Who Am I? cont'd

"I burned that shit way back. To forget about you, my dad, my mom..." He's losing steam.
"Why are you even still alive? Why couldn't you just, you know, fucking disappear like your asshole friend up in Grayling?"
Whoa, that's news. Grayling?

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're on floor #39, outside Cale's apartment.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You don't have time for subtlety, or politeness.
CRACK! The door swings open, shredded moulding where the latch used to be.
You step through, hoping that noise wasn't as loud as you thought.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You knock several times, but there's no answer.
Must be out.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Like the door downstairs, room keys appear to be computerized. Saves a load on re-keying rooms when residents turn-over.
With the proper software and RFID-enabled device, you could probably walk right through this one.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
When you finally arrive on the 39th floor, the doors open to muffled, echoing TVs, music, and the voices of those down the long hall.
You turn right, and make your way to Cale's room. There doesn't seem to be any sound from within, but it's hard to be sure in this noise.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide to leave the Concrete Forest Apartment complex.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Doing your best to look casual, you lean against the wall, and find something to fidget with.
One tenant asks, "Everything alright?" But you nod and say, "Yeah, I'm just waiting for Cale," and that seems to satisfy him.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Spoof Cale's RFID Access Card cont'd

Unlike downstairs, it won't help much up here to wait for a valid card to be used. That'd require Cale showing up, which is something you're hoping to avoid.
Instead, you switch the software to "brute" mode, and just start running codes. It'll take a while this way, but at least you won't *look* like you're trying to break in.
Several minutes pass, and you make your best impatient friend impression as tenants walk by.
Finally, the software registers a hit, and the door clicks.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With the door closed behind you, pale aquarium lights cast a glow on everything.
You flick the overhead switch, and find yourself in a veritable shrine to mer-people. Posters, statuettes, seashells, and other paraphernalia crowd the studio apartment.
One could almost mistake it for a gift shop, were it not for the unmade bed and other personal effects.

table.name: encounters
table.column: There's also an old, spare wheelchair in here, stacks of skin cream, and...some sort of catheter device?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There's also an old, spare wheelchair in here, stacks of skin cream, and a combination colostomy/ileal diversion system.
A hemicorporectomy?
No, there's no way. It'd have to be an accident that- you look around the room again, noting all the mer-people.
...that removed everything below the waist.
A shiver overtakes you, and you wiggle your toes for comfort.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Then, you spot it.
Peeking out from another picture's frame, a photograph of someone pushing you in a wheelchair.
The young man pushing you looks vaguely familiar, and is the same one in many of the photos on this shelf. You can't remember who, though.
The building looks familiar, too. "Saginaw Mental Institution" reads a nearby sign in the photo.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Saginaw? What were you doing up there? And were you on your way in or out?
The idea of a mental institution in your past shakes your confidence a bit.
Your thoughts are interrupted, however, by the door opening.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A young man sits in a modified wheelchair, a broad socket supporting him where his legs and pelvis should be. Despite his handicap, he seems quite muscular.
He's handsome, too, though his face doesn't look so pleasant with the expression he's making at you.
"The fu- What?" There might've been a moment of shock, and then fear, but it's transformed into rage now.
"The HELL are you doing in my apartment?"
He pushes himself through the door.
"HEY!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You hold up the photo towards him. "Maybe I should ask YOU why there's a photo of me in your apartment?"
He yanks it from your hand. "-your hands off that, man. This is MINE, get it? You're in MY apartment!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You decide to walk around his chair, and step into the hallway.
Time to go.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"That's right," you begin, "this is the apartment tied to the bank account that was keeping me in stasis."
You step closer.
"And since I can't remember anything before that, forgive me if I want to piece some of my life back together."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Explain How You Found Him cont'd

"Oh! You want YOUR life back? That's rich." He turns the photo back toward you, pointing to the other man in it.
"You see this guy? Yeah?" He tosses the picture on his shelf. "I have a picture of HIM, asshole, not you. That was my dad, and he probably still would be if it wasn't for your bullshit."
He looks aside for a moment. "Fucking Saginaw. He should've just put you right back in there!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Wait. Why was I there? How did your father know me?"
His head snaps back toward you. "Because you BELONG there! Don't you get it? God, he was such an idiot for bothering."
He stares downward. "Going on about your stupid mission. Your fucking... I don't know what. Babysitting mission?"
"Serves him right, I guess," he mutters, "trolling the Deep Web for kicks."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
His eyes dart back to your face.
"He stopped living because of you! Who does that? I mean, who just drops everything like that? For so long!"
Someone else is at the doorway now. Cale continues, "you're just some asshole. You show up one day, sweep him into some goddamned 'mission'."
"Cale," the man in the hall says. "Cale, you okay?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Cale turns to him. "No, man. This guy needs to go. Call the cops."
You hear more activity in the hall.
"Get the fuck out of here, man." Cale wheels back, out of the way. "Or, you know what? Don't. Get arrested. Do me a favor and get yourself jacked by SkyCorps."
Not really interested in obliging, you step around him. Heads are peeking out of doorways, and you see the man from before on his cell.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The elevator ride is unnerving. Dozens of floors go by too slowly, and you wonder how much time you have before SkyCorps arrives.
Surely they're busy. It'll take a while. And by then, Cale's neighbor will have seen there's no point.
They've probably cancelled the call by now.
The doors slide open, and you step into the empty lobby.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're escorted from the interview area, and brought into an on-site clinic, where you're strapped to a table, and anesthetized.
When you wake, you're on a bench in a painted cinder block room, leaning against a corner. Both your head and right shoulder ache. A piercing bleep fills the room as an intercom comes to life.
"You have been charged as follows: -First-degree criminal trespassing -Unauthorized access to a computer with intent to commit an offense -Fraud and misuse of visas -Conspiracy to defraud the city of Detroit -Consorting with a known felon -Failure to disclose personal information"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
In the hall, you see a man with a phone to his ear, and a murmur of commotion from further away.
Looks like your expert burglary skills stirred up some attention.
And judging by the part of that cellphone conversation you can hear, the party's just getting started.
Better get a move on. You push back through the doorway past the gathering crowd, and hit the elevator call.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Call him out on the bank account.

"Cale McAllen," you begin with confidence. "Made any interesting bank withdrawals recently?" You look around, feigning interest in his apartment. "Doesn't look like you spent it on rent..."
That stops him. "Wha- I- You can't just break in here!"
He's on the defensive now.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Call Him Out On the Bank Account cont'd

"And by recently," you continue, "I mean around the time that my cryo facility ejected me for non-payment."
He looks panicked now. You step closer, menacingly.
"So, tell me, Cale. Tell me why I'm here." Your voice lowers to a growl. "Tell me why I slogged through wilderness, ruins, and dead bodies, instead of staying blissfully unaware of trouble with my bank account."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Call Him Out On the Bank Account cont'd

Cale's bravado has shrunken considerably in the face of your display.
"I-" He seems to be mentally scrambling, looking for a way to placate you.
"I just figured," he starts again.
"I mean, come on! Look around!" He gestures. "The world's gone to shit AGES ago! No way you survived out there in shitstorm central. And hell if I was gonna walk out there and check!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Don't you mean wheel?"
"Huh?" He looks confused.
You nod at his chair. "The surgery. Must've cost a pretty penny."
"What, are you some doctor or something?"
You just stare at him.
"Yeah, fine, okay? I used what was left for surgery. What's it to you?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Call Him Out On the Bank Account cont'd

"Why are you even on the bank account?"
"You tell me!" he barks. "You're the one who reached out from the Deep Web to rope him into your scheme."
"Dude was obsessed with it. With you. Fucking ruined his life! All of our lives! So you tell ME!"
He seems genuinely distressed about it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Call Him Out On the Bank Account cont'd

"What scheme?" This isn't making sense. "Does this have something to do with Saginaw?"
"God, I don't know. He went to pick you up there. And he took you to that cryo facility."
"Gyges?"
"I guess. Yeah, Gyges. But it didn't stop there. You had this 'plan'. You needed my dad to meet you again when you got out."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Call Him Out On the Bank Account cont'd

"Well, where is he?"
"He's fucking dead!" His voice nearly cracks. You're both quiet for several seconds.
"Yeah," he continues, nodding. "Yeah! Because of you! Because of his obsession with whatever shit you needed him for. Whatever fucking hold you had on him."
People are starting to appear at the doorway.
"Just dropped life. His life. Mom. Me! Hell, I don't even know if it registered that I was his kid, except that I might pick up where he left off."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"It's my money to me, for one thing! I doubt I went to sleep and left a bank account for you to go all reverse-Little-Mermaid! Why the hell would I?"
He's stunned. "Wait, how did you-"
"The fucking posters! The statues! You're in a god-damned wheelchair because your pelvis was amputated!"
You glance around. "Where the hell is it, anyway?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"What, the tail?"
"Yes, the tail!"
"It's at work," he says without irony.
"What? Where the- whatever. Why are you even on the bank account?"
"You tell me!" he barks. "You're the one who reached out from the Deep Web to rope him into your scheme."
"Dude was obsessed with it. With you. Fucking ruined his life! All of our lives! So you tell ME!"
He seems genuinely distressed about it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Call Him Out On the Bank Account cont'd

"Well, you know what? Fuck that. I ain't doing shit for you. Or for him!"
"Cale," the man in the hall says. "Cale, you okay?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Cale McAllen," you begin with confidence. "Made any interesting bank withdrawals recently?" You look around, feigning interest in his building, "Doesn't look like you spent it on rent..."
"Wha- I- What do you want?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Call Him Out On the Bank Account cont'd

"What scheme?" This isn't making sense. "Does this have something to do with Gyges Cryo Facility?"
"I guess. Yeah, he drove you to Gyges. But it didn't stop there. You had this 'plan'. You needed my dad to meet you again when you got out."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The dust on the ground makes it easy for your trained eye to pick out one set of tracks in particular.
They seem to belong to a humanoid dragging something, probably a mantle or cloak. It was here fairly recently, probably in the past 24 hours. It entered through the doorway, walked to your stasis tank, went to the control console, and then left.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Punching in the code for the CEO, you rush back to your own tube, and re-seal it.
Tank #6 starts to hum, and the seal breaks with a roaring rush of fluid. The room squeals and flexes with the chilling cold of the liquid nitrogen covering the floor.
Within moments, the nitrogen has boiled off at room temperature, leaving a frozen mansicle on the floor.
Initially, the dogman backs off, unsure of the commotion that just occurred. However, hunger quickly replaces concern, as the smell of thawing flesh catches his attention. He starts dragging the body off, probably to his lair.
Here's one meltdown Lloyd won't escape...

table.name: encounters
table.column: You rummage through your things, looking for something that might help.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You rummage through your things, looking for items that might help.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
This meat...
It's like good, fully developed veal. Not young, but not yet beef. Yes, very definitely like that, and not like any other meat you've tasted. In fact, so much so that you think no person with a palate of ordinary, normal sensitiveness could distinguish it from veal. It is mild, good meat, with no other sharply defined or highly characteristic taste such as, for instance, goat, high game, and pork have.
The steak is slightly tougher than prime veal, a little stringy, but not too tough or stringy to be agreeably edible. The roast is tender, and in color, texture, smell as well as taste, strengthens your certainty that of all the meats you habitually know, veal is the one meat to which this meat is accurately comparable.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It is good. Yes, this meat is good. And it fills the emptiness inside.
It also fills you with fear, though. Is there enough? Will there be enough? Can it keep pace with your hunger?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It is good that you've found more of this meat. There is nothing else quite like it. It has a unique, satisfying effect that you cannot seem to supplant.
This, this is the only thing you crave. The only thing that will satisfy your hunger.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Well, guess I'll keep lookin'," he concedes. "Least you ain't one of those bastards try ta steal my stuff. And no guvmint agent, neither!"
His jovial outburst sobers. "You jus' watch out fer them, I tell ya'."
Bob holds the door open for you, as a sign of good faith. You still can't help stepping hurriedly through the antechamber, though.
Once outside, you cast a final glance over your shoulder, and then exit the ravine.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Vasculhar um galpao de armazenamento trancado.

Locais de armazenamento bloqueados sao um bom sinal. Alguem acha que tem algo de valor dentro, e ninguem mais conseguiu remove-lo ainda.
A questao: voce pode passar do bloqueio?

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Yo I ain't got time fa' this." His words come fast and fluid.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"So, what's your story?" you ask, looking for more info.
"What the- You kiddin' me? Does it look like I have time for stories? Get outta here!"
He walks away agitated, muttering under his breath. "...He kiddin'? Who the hell..."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Wait, I just want-" you begin.
"Son, are you deaf? I ain't lookin' for a friend. Now git!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"What the heck happened in that swamp south of here?"
"Shit's crazy down there, man. Don't matter me none what's goin' on in that place."
"No, I mean how'd it get that way?"
Surprise stalls him a moment. "Yo, man. You been asleep fa' the last, I dunno, few decades?" He seems pretty proud of his joke, but his smile fades.
"Like, really dude. You serious?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Hey, man, I'm not lookin' for no trouble."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Hey, man, you inbound or outbound?" His head is on a swivel, glancing to and fro as he talks.

table.name: encounters
table.column: He gives you a sidelong look. "What now? What you want?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Yeah, I've been in cryo, and it looks like I missed a lot."
His face takes on a serious expression. "Cryo, huh? Where's this cryo place you talkin' 'bout?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Sensing his impatience, you just apologize and let him get back to whatever he was doing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Never mind," you say, anxious to change the subject.
"Oh, yes, I mind," his posture becomes more menacing, "I mind a lot, man. I got, you know, mouths ta feed. Bills ta pay, as they say."
He's taken on all the charm of a snake now. "How about we review our little chat. You mentioned cryo, and now I want to know where."

table.name: encounters
table.column: No way you're giving this scum the keys to your castle, even if it's just a pile of rubble.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You begin describing where the facility can be found.
"Nah-ah. I'm gonna need somethin' a bit more reliable than your word. You feel me?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You hold your bracelet out for him a few moments, and he seems concerned.
"That's Bad Mutha territory," he says, mostly to himself. "Gonna be tricky movin' through there."
He steps back. "Still might be worth a look." Then he looks at you. "An' hell, if YOU made it," he chuckles.
Anxious to start doing something profitable again, he heads off. "See ya 'round, son!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"How about we review my fist in your face," you retort, brushing his threat aside.
"Whoa, dude, easy," he folds like a glove. "I'm just kiddin' wit' ya, right?"
You continue to bore into him with your eyes, for emphasis.
"Right, right. I get it. Ah'm goin'."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Mention you're not from around here.

"I'm not from around here." You're pretty sure that lie stinks out loud.
"Oh, yeah?" He seems to agree. "Where'd you say you's from again?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I didn't," you say flatly.
"Right, right. I get it." Strangely, cold impoliteness seems to set him at ease.
"All you gots to know is, stay away. Ain't nobody goes in there comes back."
Seems likely, given what you saw.
He looks around, continuing, "Agrisanto or some shit. One o' them secret experimental projects got loose. Government hosed the place wit' some nasty-ass chemicals. Killed everything."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Mashugana."
"What?" Was that even English?
"Mashugana, mashugana, mashugana. I ain't talkin' to you. Go."
"Away."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"What you up to?"
"Man, what's it look like I'm doin'," he says, exasperated. He adds, muttering, "talkin' to a retard..."
"Sorry," you offer.
"Sorry, my ass." He continues on his way.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
He looks back to you, and starts laughing. "Still doin' it's job, yo!"
Then, it's back to business for him. "I gots stuff ta find, man." And he's off.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Heard any good rumors lately?"
His brow furrows. "Yo, man, I got shit to do. And this ain't it!"
He storms off.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I came here from down south," you lie.
"The hell you did. Unless you flew. An' like hell you'd be out here askin' stupid questions if you had wings."
He turns in disgust, and leaves. "Suckas be wastin' my time..."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Huh?" You have no context, and no idea what he's talking about.
"Psssh. Whatever." He just leaves.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Outbound," you say confidently.
"Aight, aight." He immediately looks past you and moves on, as if searching for someone else.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Inbound," you say confidently.
His head focuses on you. "Aw, great, man. Great. Hey, if you headin' in, you should take this."
He holds forth a cellphone.
"It's got paydata on it, man. Gotta be at least a couple grand on there. Make you a tidy sum. I'll give it to ya cheap, too. Just need some supplies."
He looks over his shoulder again, then back. "You down?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: You take the hint, and move on.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Who you looking for?"
"Ah, nothin', man. Nothin'." He moves on.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask why he doesn't sell it himself.

"Any reason you're not selling this yourself? Seems an awful shame to give up all that profit."
"Oh, haha," he starts. "I'm not heading in there a while yet. You know. I just need a few things, and I'm not heading in there for a while."
"Besides, you're heading in anyways, right? You're helpin' me out, and you get a little somethin' extra. Everybody wins," he chuckles.
"So, whaddya say?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"How about this," you offer.
"Yeah! Yeah. Thanks! Here, here you go." He hands you the cellphone, and pumps your hand with gratitude.
Leaving, he calls over his shoulder, "Thanks again, man. Enjoy your fortune!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Maybe next time," you say, trying to sound less disappointing.
His face sours. "Wha- there is no next time! You're turning away a profit! This helps you!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"No way, man," you say, firmly.
"Man, what is WRONG with you? I'm just tryin' ta help, is all!" He's all flustered now, and it's getting annoying.
He turns to leave, mumbling to himself. "...'s no kindness out here, man. Just JERKS who don't know ta take a good deal when they see one..."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"How about this," you offer.
"Hm. I guess I can part with it for that. Gonna lose me some profit, but better 'n nothin'."
He hands you the phone, and quickly wraps up his business. "Safe travels back, man. God bless."
He begins walking away.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You look him square-on. "You're right, MAN. There is no next time. I'm tired of your act, AND your petty scam."
"What? What scam? This is a legit dea-"
"You little maggot!" You reach for his wiry neck, and he recoils, dropping the phone.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Better to leave this guy alone, you guess.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "This better be good, yo," he says, impatiently.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask him about any rumors he's heard.

"Heard any good rum-"
"Don't you be askin' me that. Don't you do it. I kill a man who be askin' me that! I got better things to do than this!"

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Never mind," you say, leaving him to his business.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Can you tell me something about the apocalypse?"
He repeats your question in a mocking voice. "Yeah, I can tell you something. Once upon a time, shit went berserk. Now we livin' in the apocalypse. The end."
He wanders off. "...unbelievable..."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Where did the dogmen come from?"
"Dude, where do YOU come from? Seriously, did aliens jus' drop you on this planet? My god, how are you alive this long?"
"I-" you start.
"No, don't. I don't even wanna hear dat." He puts his hand up, stopping you.
"You an alien is what you is." He starts walking away. "Well, alien, we got dogmen here. They gonna eat yo' clueless ass."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"How's it goin'?" He continues before you can answer.
"Look, I appreciate you taking it easy on me and all. There's enough shit going on out here without all the fighting. So, thanks, bro." His thanks seem pretty earnest.
"But I got something I need to take care of right now. I'll catch you later." And with that, he heads off purposefully.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"How did the world get so messed up?"
He laughs. "Yeah, it's pretty effed up, isn't it? I dunno. Been like this as long as I can remember."
He continues. "All I know is, we weren't ready for it. I mean, look at this," he nods over his shoulder for effect. "Place is like a warzone. Except no war."
"People probably just got greedy, man. Too greedy."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Where you coming from?" you casually ask.
"Just another junk-rusher from the Sprawl," he confesses. "You?"
You try to think of the best way to be friendly and cautious at the same time. "Midlands." No, too cautious. You add, "I think."
A bemused grin belies his otherwise gruff voice. "Rough night, huh? I've had a few of those."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Yeah, but what about those dogmen," you ask.
"I dunno, man. Those things are serious business. I hear a lot of them are up north."
Something occurs to him. "Maybe some sort of science experiment? Military?" He's asking as much as telling. "Doesn't explain some of the stuff out there, though."
"I dunno. I just wanna live my life. You know? I don't wanna get involved in that shit."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Listen, I gotta go. My wife's gonna kill me if I don't score something useful out here. Later, bro."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Anything good out here?"
"Nah," you ramble. "Some dirty rags and a piece of rebar."
"Ah, that's too bad. The good pickin's are gone."
"Yeah."
"Well, better luck, eh?"
"Yeah, you, too."
"Later, bro."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Actually, I have a thing." You point over your shoulder.
"Whatever, man. Later." He seems relieved.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Well, it found you just the same," you growl.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I'm fresh out, anyway," you joke.
"Damn," he laughs. "I was hoping for at least a little trouble. Maybe just a little?"
"Okay, maybe I've got a bit here after all..."
"Haha, thanks, man."
"It's no trouble."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Hooooo! Fresh meat off the farm," she cackles.
"This place is gonna pick you cleeeean," she adds, walking past you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Well, well, well. Dis my knight in shinin' armor? Or my dark prince?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I'm your dark prince." You immediately regret how stupid that sounds.
"Huh," she snorts. "Don' look so dark to me." She shakes her head with a scowl, "Mm mm. No."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Neither."
"Ooh, I get it. Gon' tussle wit' the boys, eh? Get a little Kenny Loggins up in 'dere? Mmmm mm."
She laughs as she walks away, "Watch out, boys. Woooo!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I guess I'm your knight." If we're choosing options...
"Oooh. A knight," she exclaims. "You all gonna...lay down your coat fa me? Huh? You gonna...hold open some doors?"
"Nuh uh," she retorts. "Chivalry is dead, yo. You din't get the memo?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: "You just hold it right there," she warns. "That's close enough."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I jus' have two words for you, "she says, then sticks her face forward as if transmitting thoughts into your mind.
Satisfied, she walks away.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Man, I wish these bags had a condition gauge on them or somethin'. You be walkin' along one day, and 'pow!' Thing just falls apart!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"My name's Philip Kindred," you explain.
"Congratulations," is her flat reply.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Sorry," you say. "Just trying not to get killed."
"In that case, good luck." She passes without another word.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Sorry. Can I ask you a question?"
She considers a moment. "Maybe."
Taking that as the best "yes" you'll get, you continue. "Does anyone know what caused the apocalypse?"
She's silent a moment. "Are you for real?"
To her credit, that probably does sound pretty ridiculous.
"No- I mean yes, but, it's just," this isn't going smooth.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask what she's doing out here.

"What brings you out here?"
"Same as everyone else," she says. "Lookin' to get by, is all."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Nobody seems to want to explain how the world ended up this way, is all." There. Just spit it out.
"I see." After a pause, she loosens up a bit. "Probably 'cause nobody knows. Or at least, because they don't like what they know."
"How do you mean?"
"Some places got their own story. Somethin' that fits their needs. Others, well, just bury that shit. Too hard."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"So what's your place say?"
She takes a deep breath. "Little bit of everything, I guess. Far as I can tell from the scraps I read, the seams just started coming apart all over the place. First a little here, then a little there."
She gathers herself, ready to leave. "Doesn't matter now, though. All's matters now is what you're gonna do about it."
She heads off, turning and backpedaling long enough to earnestly say, "Good luck with that."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I've had nighmares nicer than this place," she huffs.
She doesn't seem interested in waiting for a response.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Well, I won't waste any more of your time, then."
After a visibly impressed pause, "Much obliged."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Need a hand?"
"Don't need no friends," she recites. "I can handle myself."
Okey-dokey, guess that's it. "Well, take care."
"You as well."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "I hear they found a cheater up at Zom Zom's. Hooo-boy, that was a party!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Whoever decided that dogs needed to be bigger and walk on two legs needs to DIE!"
She just storms past you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"...was at the fifty-five by the two-oh." He stops speaking into a radio, disappointed at the interruption.
"What you need?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: He laughs loudly. "Ho ho, look! This meat talks!"

table.name: encounters
table.column: "I ain't talkin' to no asshole...I ain't talkin' to no asshole..." he repeats into the air, ignoring you as he passes.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Can't be doin' this, man. I gots stuff to do." He continues on, purposefully.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Honey, I'm tired of walkin'," she admits.
Then, in a lower voice, "but I ain't *that* tired."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "I make it a point not to talk to strangers out here," she cautions. "So you just move along, and we don't need to bother each other none."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Just you keep your nose clean, and we got no trouble," he says through his facemask.

table.name: encounters
table.column: How do I get into the DMC?

"What's it take to get through the gate?"
He responds to his radio, ignoring you for a moment.
"You gonna need a visitor pass," he recites. "Applications at the gate, and processing time is 6-10 months."
His radio pipes up again, and he starts walking away, listening.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Are there any other cities nearby?

"Are there any other cities near here?"
His head is shaking before you finish. "No, no. Closest thing you got is Fort Wayne down below the swamp. Gotta get there by air, though."
"Is it like the DMC?"
"Naw, not like this. Never been there, myself, though."

table.name: encounters
table.column: What's the story with the swamp?

"What's the story with the swamp?"
"Chemical wash," he responds, quickly. "Nobody's permitted down there. Highly toxic."
"Yeah, but why?"
"Some crops got out of control back in the day. Had to burn them with chemicals."
His radio pipes up, and he turns slightly from you. Then, he walks away, speaking into the mic.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Sorry, never mind," you say, excusing yourself.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Okay, thanks."
The guard wastes no time in moving on to other things.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Heard anything interesting lately?"
"Why you people always ask that," he asks, rhetorically. "Seriously. You think we just collect rumors for the first rag-man that wanders into town?"
He leaves, incredulous.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Any work available?"
"Psssh, what're you, nuts?" He shakes his head.
"You think we got some labor shortage in this hellhole? Look around! The one thing we got in spades is filthy immigrants!"
He heads off, uninterested in anything else you have to say.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Any gangs I should be watching out for around here?"
The guard seems suddenly interested. "Yeah, definitely. Could be some crooked Sprawlers 'round, but gangs aren't unheard of around here, either." He looks past you.
"Bad Muthas are the worst of 'em. Damn cannibals, you ask me. We get some Butcher Boys, too."
Looking back at you, "You just keep close to town, though, and you're better off."
A message over the radio calls him away.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Police business," he holds up his hand, "coming through."

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're in a forest and something is watching you. You're almost certain of it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Check the local flora for clues.

You stoop to the ground, and look at some of the plants here. If this is a creature's natural habitat, maybe there will be clues.
At first, you see little that catches your eye. You can't see anything to distinguish this forest from the last.
But then, you notice it: something has pruned some of the fruit-bearing plants here. It's subtle, and you almost dismissed it as critter activity. However, something deliberately and completely stripped these plants of anything edible.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ducking behind a tree, you start looking for escape routes out of sight. But something collides with you, knocking you into the dirt. It has you. You can feel its grip on your arms, its weight on your back.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You make it clear you're not going down without a fight, and wait for its next move.
It doesn't come, though. It continues to stand there, staring at you.
However, whipping leaves and footfalls approach rapidly from the side, and something collides with you in the dirt.
It has you. You can feel its grip on your arms, its weight on your back.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Trying not to tip the scales toward hostilities, you call out to it.
In return, it raises a hand, palm towards you. Simultaneously, several more seem to appear in a wide circle around you, seemingly from nowhere.
"Traveler," says the first, "we cannot let you pass through here. And there is an illness in you that threatens us if you leave."
Uh-oh.
"You will come with us now." It's less an order than a statement of fact. The others begin closing in on you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use forest as cover for your escape!

You slip sideways, putting a thick tree between you and it, then duck down below some undergrowth. Immediately, you begin crawling in an unexpected direction.
Whipping leaves and footfalls approach rapidly, though, and something collides with you in the dirt.
It has you. You can feel its grip on your arms, its weight on your back.

table.name: encounters
table.column: With expert skill, it pins you and begins choking you out. Your vision tints red, then gets spotty, and then you're examining plants in a field... It's raining... There was this cryo facility... and maybe you forgot your...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Your head is throbbing. And your neck's sore, too. Your head is lolling from being suspended from wrist and ankle bindings. You're being carried.
You can't see anything, but the sounds of forest are clear. Whatever's carrying you makes no sound, though. Like, really no sounds.
This can't be good.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Minutes of silent traveling later, you begin to hear sounds. Not forest sounds, but people sounds. Tools being worked. A crack from a fire.
Voices startle you from your strained listening. Your captors are talking, but not in English. Not in anything you recognize.
One of them calls out, and a distant voice responds. It sounds like you're entering a camp of some kind. You smell wood burning. Your arrival causes a stir, and you stop moving for a moment.
More talking.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're turned in place a bit, and then taken away from the heat of the flame for a while.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As the blurriness clears, you find yourself in a room. Figures stand around you, where you rest on a cot.
It's warm in here, and smells of smoke and cedar.
Your captors, white-faced and raccoon-eyed, silently turn and leave you alone, closing a flap of fabric behind them.
Dried roots hang in thatches around this dome-like room, with equal parts animal hide and repurposed junk for walls and flooring.
The smoke you smell trails from a small brazier.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You contemplate making a break for it, but you're pretty sure whoever runs this place has got it locked down. Still, maybe a peek outside is in order.
Before you do, however, the flap opens, and in steps an imposing figure. Her face is painted white like the others, and she stands to the side as a boy enters with a tray.
The boy has no face paint, and looks to be in his teens. There's a hint of disinterest in him as he lays the tray in the center of the room, and then turns to leave.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Thanks."
You mean it, too. This has been a frightening ordeal, to be sure.
Viewed in retrospect, though, everything about it has been calculated, and no harm has come to you. This place may warrant some rethinking.
The teen turns, embarrassed, but the warrior's face softens. "Michelle will explain, when it's time," she says, stepping into the opening.
Then, turning to face you, "Eat. You need it."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Wait," you exclaim. "Wait, who are you? Where is this place?"
The boy stops to look at you, then at the warrior. A faint, insistent scowl appears on her face, like they're having a staring match, and then he continues out the opening.
Her eyes follow him, disapprovingly, then turn to you.
"I'm Misty. Michelle will explain, when it's time," she says, stepping into the opening.
Then turning to face you, "Eat. You need it."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"You can't keep me here," you warn. "I won't be your prisoner."
The boy steps back from the tray. The warrior steps forward, protectively.
"That's the idea," she says. Noting your confused look, she continues.
"This isn't a prison. You're in rehab."
Your confusion deepens, and a hint of anger surfaces.
"Eat," she orders. "Breathe. Cast off windigoo. He is the one imprisoning you." She turns towards the exit flap.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The teen steps back as you approach, and both watch as you look over the tray.
It's a dish, piled high with succulent, fatty meat, with cooked squash, beans, and corn. Strangely, this meat brings your nostrils to life. The meat for which you so desperately clambered seems forgotten momentarily. Your mouth waters as you survey the food.
Even the veggies might offer some satisfaction.
The teen and warrior both leave, closing the flap behind them in silence.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You move towards the tray.
It's a dish, piled high with succulent, fatty meat, with cooked squash, beans, and corn. Strangely, this meat brings your nostrils to life. The meat for which you so desperately clambered seems forgotten momentarily. Your mouth watering as you survey the food.
Even the veggies might offer some satisfaction.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Your hunger sated, you lean back in the warmth of the room. The scent of dinner mingles with cedar and tobacco.
Despite the weight in your stomach, there is a sense of unrest within you.
Anxiety is pulling you toward the door. A fear is trying to convince you that every moment in here is threatening your existence.
But there is a part of you wanting to stay. Instinct is holding you fast.
You're not sure whether laziness and contentedness is putting you in danger, or if addiction is dragging you away from recovery.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Rolling your weight forward, you spring across the room at the warrior.
She's ready as fast as you are, though, and breaks your assault like a stone plowing waves.
Her knee drops onto your torso, and all of the air in your lungs expels in a gasping cough. You're paralyzed with wheezing as she drags you back to the cot, and drops you there.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You lunge forward, grabbing the kid. He lets out a yell, and the warrior is moving at you before you can meet her wild glare.
Her shoulder smashes your mouth, and her weight carries you back several feet to the ground. She shouts in a piercing cry that fills the room, smashing your face with her hand, and then crushing your larynx with her forearm.
The teen crawls towards the opening as other warriors burst in, but your vision blackens in radiating, gasping pain from your neck.
You feel something give way, as she focuses all of her weight one last time...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With only a little breathlessness, she stands.
"You will not hurt us," she begins. "You aren't the one hurting us. The windigoo has taken you and controls you."
She steps back toward the opening. "You will cast off this windigoo. You will heal."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"And if I don't?"
She looks at you for a moment. "The windigoog hurt us all. They threaten our safety. Scare off the animals we hunt."
"The windigoog are not welcome here. We cast them out or we kill them."
She quits the room without another word.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Footsteps approach, and the flap lifts to reveal two warriors. Their faces have the same white paint, and one signals for you to follow.
You're led outside, where you can see that you're in a small cluster of huts away from the main village.
You catch glimpses of others in this camp. Maybe they're like you? The watchful eyes of nearby warriors suggest as much.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You are being led to an oblong dome hut, from which steam emanates into the cool air. A man adorned in bear symbology seems to be preparing the hut.
"Joe's midewinini of nooke doodem. He will help you in your struggle with windigoo."
The warriors stop, transferring your care into Joe's hands.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Inside the hut, Joe situates you near some heated rocks. It's warm in here. Downright hot, in fact. The air is thick with steam and the scent of burning sage.
"Kiishig and wiingash," Joe says, stoking the fire and pouring a liquid onto the stones. There's sputtering as a new cloud of steam rises.
"The windigoo wants you. But it will be driven out by the kiishig. By your fullness." He steps to the doorway.
Wait, what do you do now? Where's he going?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"How long?" You try not to seem ungrateful.
"It will take time." He stops, turning. "Windigoo does not want to leave. You must concentrate on sending him out. It may take many sweats."
With that, he closes the flap, leaving you alone.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
After what seems like a long while, you realize your mind has been wandering. You drifted into thoughts of days past, and the ordeals you suffered on your journey here.
Joe returns, his voice calling from outside before he enters. He guides you out into the cool, empty air.
"Hm," he sighs heavily. "I think windigoo is still with you."
He offers you water. "Take this, and we will try again."
After a few draughts, and once you feel ready to try again, Joe leads you back inside.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You try to focus on casting out windigoo, and soaking up the warmth.
Comfortable warmth soon turns to intense heat. You feel the steam and smoke in your lungs, and sweat begins beading on your skin.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You find yourself thinking of days past, where desperation tempted you.
Those first morsels were a curiosity, but also a call. Was this when you succumbed to and invited windigoo?
As time passed, curiosity gave way to craving. To need.
Is windigoo a weakness you must shed?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Joe's footsteps approach again, and he calls out once more. You meet him at the opening, and he looks carefully at you.
"You look tired," he says knowingly.
"Will it ever be gone?" you ask.
He shakes his head. "You've cast him out, but he will always remember you."
He puts a hand on your shoulder. "You must be vigilant when he returns."
So much for being "cured".

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"What if I am not strong enough?"
Joe presses his lips together. "If you don't have the strength, you are a danger to all."
He turns toward the great fire. "Come."
You both begin walking, leaving the sweat lodge behind.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You turn from the figure, back towards whence you came, and start high-tailing it.
You think that thing may be following you, but you don't take time to look.
Around some more trees and over a mound, you see the treeline ahead. You explode into the clearing, foliage trailing behind you, and continue putting distance on until you're sure nothing is behind you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
One of them produces a blindfold, and fixes it over your eyes. Meanwhile, your hands are bound behind your back.
Despite the restraints, the whole process proceeds without any unnecessary force. You seem to be handled with both caution and respect.
You're turned in place, and led forward through the forest.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Voce deixa claro que nao vai sair sem lutar, e aguarda a proxima jogada.
Nao vem, no entanto. Continua a ficar de pe, olhando para voce.
No entanto, chicoteando folhas e pisadas se aproximam rapidamente do lado, e algo colide com voce na sujeira.
Tem voce. Voce pode sentir seu aperto em seus bracos, seu peso nas costas.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With expert skill, it pins you, and you feel a stabbing pain in your neck.
Warm wetness on your shoulders is the last thing you feel.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I don't mean any harm," you say.
The figure speaks again. "We will take you to speak to one of our elders. You must wear this." It holds out a blindfold and restraints.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're taken to a meeting area near the Great Fire.
In front of you, a portly, middle-aged woman stands by one of the warriors. Her jacket is the color of a sunset, against which is silhouetted a majestic gray crane.
"Hey, man," she says.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Pretty crazy gig we got here, right?" She looks around, as if arriving here with you for the first time.
"Oh," she reaches a hand forward, "Michelle. I usually get roped into talking to foreigners. Sorta comes with the badge." She points her thumb at the crane. "Ajijaak doodem."
"C'mon," she turns toward the village. "Let's walk."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A small entourage in tow, you walk idly towards the fire.
"I gotta ask," Michelle begins. "You know a Philip?"
She's being careful not to telegraph too much, but you can tell this is the big thing on her mind.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"My name's Philip Kindred," you reply. "Does that count?"
