"I KNEW it!" she pumps her fist, like she just won a bet. "Ol' Ghost-Face McStabberson back here had you figured for a grave robber."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Never heard of him," you say, trying to sound as nonchalant as possible.
"Oh? Well, that's a shame," she says. You hear a warrior half snort, half snicker behind you.
"Told you he was a graverobber," he says with satisfaction. His painted face looks scarier when he's pleased.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"So, wait," you interrupt. "You know me?"
"Yeah!" she exclaims. "Well, no. Not personally. Here..." She steers you toward a hut.
Warm light spills from within, and she draws back a flap to reveal a mixture of handmade and recycled furnishings.
Michelle reaches over a cluttered desk, and pulls a frame down from amidst dried roots, photos, and other mementos on the wall.
She hands the frame to you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Ghost Face?" you ask.
"Oh, him? Nah, he's alright. You'd have to be pretty bad for him to slit your throat."
"I see," you say, uncomforted.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Where am I?" you look around. "Who are you people?"
"You got it," she quips.
"What?"
"Sorry, inside joke." Some of the warriors grumble.
"This is the Anishinaabe Tribal Nation." She sweeps her arm grandiosely. "A bit like an alliance of former tribes from the area. Odawa, Ojibwe, and Potawatomi people.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You hold the frame up, examining the yellowed photograph. It appears to be a newspaper clipping, done in that old, small-town print where the colors don't line up.
It's you. Or at least someone who looks just like you.
"You've been here before," she says, looking over your shoulder. "And check out the talisman."
You look incredulously at her a moment, then closer at the photo. Sure enough, you're wearing the talisman.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The photo's caption reads: "Local Website Editor Rekindles Interest in Native History".
You flip the frame over, looking for more, but there is only one thing scrawled on the back:
"September 2019"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Why am I in this photo?

"So," you're trying to process this. "How did I end up in this photo?"
"Man, your brain was really fried, huh? This was, like, your THING back then."
"What's that? What thing?"
"Well," she begins. "It's like the caption says. You used to run a website."
"A website?" You're not sure whether to be relieved or disappointed.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"How long ago was this taken? What year is it now?"
Michelle looks over the features of your face a moment. "Yeah, I figured you might ask something like that. You hardly look a day older."
She turns the frame back over. "You see that guy? That guy there?" She indicates a young man, maybe in his twenties or thirties.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"My turn," she says. "Where you been hiding since this?" She holds up the photo.
"And more importantly, how come you don't look any older?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Lie and say you don't know.

"Honestly, I don't know," you lie. "I can't seem to remember anything."
"Oh, no," she puts the frame on her desk. "No. That ain't gonna fly."
She squares her shoulders and faces you. "I put my neck on the line bailing you out from the bear doodem. The bears'd play pin the boot on Stranger's ass if it weren't for me. So let's cut the bull and try this again."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell her about Gyges Cryo Facility.

"Ever heard of Gyges Cryo Facility?"
Might as well cut to the chase.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You look into Michelle's eyes, and assert your point again. "I told you. I have no idea what happened between that photo and now."
"Also," you add, "I don't appreciate being called a liar."
She snickers. "Psh. Yeah. I don't appreciate talking to one, either."
She steps outside, and you hear her shout to someone.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Sorry," you say. "The bull's helped keep me alive these past few days."
"No, I get it," she offers.
"Ever heard of Gyges Cryo Facility?" Might as well cut to the chase.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Her voice is a bit muffled as she speaks to someone outside, and then the flap opens. One of the warriors.
"You may not look any different, Philip," says Michelle. "But the years have definitely changed you."
She adds, "and not for the better."
The warrior retrieves the blindfold and restraints again...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"So, wait. Do you know anything about the talisman?" This is getting more complicated, not less.
"Know anything about it?" She chuckles. "My man, we MADE it for you!" Then, she adds, "Well, sort of."
You just stare, dumbfounded.
"Oh, this is good." She seems delighted at your confusion. "Lemme 'splain," she begins, faking bad English.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"It's a protective talisman," she starts.
"Some ancestors carried pieces of copper, for both luck and protection."
"This one," she points to yours, "you brought to us. My father said you were hiding from a spirit, and that you needed protection from it."
She continues, "The symbol isn't ours. I don't recognize it. And I'm not sure where you got it," she admits.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Yeah. And like I said, you were INTO it." She starts digging through some papers.
"It was like a huge collection of unexplained happenings. Creature sightings, hauntings, mass extinctions. Like, you know, real conspiracy nut stuff."
Whatever she's seeking wasn't in the first pile. She moves to another.
"Except," she adds, "you treated it pretty scientifically. Like, cross-referenced and fact-checked and stuff."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Here we go," she pulls a three-ring binder from under some papers.
"Not the whole thing, mind you." She laughs, "Thing would take up this room if we printed all that out."
She hands it to you. "This is the entry you had on our tribes' histories."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"But my father asked the midewinini of nooke doodem- you call them medicine man- to give this talisman power to protect you. The spirit wouldn't harm you while it was on."
"It was a powerful ritual," she recalls. "It's one of the events my father recounted on several occasions."
She points at the talisman again, "That thing was a big deal around here."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The other pages are similar, talking about topics relevant to the Anishinaabe people. Things like "Turtle Shaped Island", "Nanabozho", and the "doodem" system of clans.
"And, and," she interrupts, "you were really keen on tracking propagation. Like, you had this whole section connecting dots between similar instances. Timelines. Even correlating rumors to occurrences."
"My father, though," she says, "he was just thrilled that our oral tradition was being shared again. And with everyone in the world."
"That was a pretty big deal to him."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Actually," you add quickly, "if we're choosing between graverobber and Philip, I'll go with the latter."
"Philip," you say, nodding. "Philip Kindred."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I don't rob graves, either," you assert. This is turning sour.
"Maybe not." Michelle stops, and you turn to face her. "Maybe you 'found' that talisman just lying around. I get it. It happens."
You don't believe her, and you get the sense the feeling's mutual.
"But that's an important Anishinaabe artifact. And it came from one of our graves."
"And lately," she looks you in the eye, "I've been having to tell this to way too many strangers."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Feeling a mix of fear and dark satisfaction, you await the inevitable screams as the wraith tears through the village...
But none come.
A while later, having walked through what may be kilometers of forest, your restraints are removed, and you're shoved forward.
You catch your footing before going down, and pull the blindfold away.
Bleary-eyed, you look around, and find yourself at the edge of a forest.
No sign of the warriors, nor the wraith, anywhere.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Interesting story, but this is mine.

"That's an interesting story," you say half-heartedly, "but this talisman is mine."
The warriors start surrounding you. Some of the younger ones actually look anxious for a fight.
Michelle leans closer to you, and almost whispers. "You see this? Look at these guys."
She turns to survey the ring of stern faces, as if on your side. "Do yourself a favor, and don't give them any excuses."
She leans back again. "Besides, maybe it's not the talisman you're lying about?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I guess that 'splains a few things," she ponders.
"Unfortunately," you continue, "I can't tell you much more than that. I can't remember anything before coming out of cryo. It's like the hibernation wiped my memory."
She still looks deep in thought.

table.name: encounters
table.column: I'm not Philip, and this is not your talisman.

"I'm not Philip," you say firmly. "And this isn't your talisman."
"Well, alright," she says in her best if-you-want-it-your-way tone. She starts walking away.
The ring of warriors closes as she steps outside its circumference, and you're apprehended roughly.
The blindfold goes back on, as do the restraints. And before you're led from the camp, you feel the talisman pulled from your neck...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A while later, having walked through what may be kilometers of forest, your restraints are removed, and you're shoved forward.
You catch your footing before going down, and pull the blindfold away.
Bleary-eyed, you look around, and find yourself at the edge of a forest.
No sign of the warriors anywhere.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Fine," you concede. "You got me. I'm Philip. Philip Kindred."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I KNEW it!" she pumps her fist, like she just won a bet.
"See?" she taunts the warrior. "No need to disembowel anyone."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You flip the cover open, and find it filled with musty, yellowed paper. The print is in good shape, though.
"Prophecy of the Seven Fires" reads the first page. Skimming over it, the text refers to the world mythology of the Anishinaabe people, the keepers of the fires, Ojibwe, Odawa, and Potawatomi tribes.
It's an article. Like an academic research paper. Citations litter the bottom, referencing long-forgotten websites and publications.
And up in the left corner, a logo. "The New Earth Ostracon".

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Did I write all this?" you ask. This is a lifetime's work, this.
"Naw. I think you were just the curator. A lot of this was written by readers. To hear my father tell it, you were big into the way these ideas evolved. Had some crazy theory about how they were all connected."
You turn to look at her, expectantly.
"That's when you said you started to run into trouble. You were a welcome visitor here, of course, but you came here for help."
"Oh?" Maybe we're getting somewhere.
"Help with a talisman to protect you from a spirit."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Did you say 'spirit'?"
She holds up her palms, "Hey, man, your words, not mine. My father said you were talking about something hunting you."
"For what? What'd I do?"
"Don't ask me. I don't even know if you told my father."
"Well, then, what was the spirit?"
"Oh, man. My father probably could've told you. You had some pretty specific instructions, and not all of them were, uh, germane to us, if you get my drift."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Germane? What do you mean? Like foreign?"
"Yeah. This thing you were running from. It wasn't ripped from the pages of our history, if you know what I mean. We've never seen or heard of it."
"Still," she concedes, "some spirits are like that. Not everyone sees them the same."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I've run into it once before," you say. "Thing came out of nowhere, and had a body like it was made of black flame. Face was a white mask, though."
"Nice!" she exclaims.
"Yeah. Well, no! But yeah, it was quite a sight."
"So this thing's still out there?"
"Oh, yeah. It's out there. To be honest. I'm a bit afraid it would be in here, too."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Can you help me get rid of it?

"Can you help me get rid of it?" Worth a shot, right?
"Me? Probably not," she concedes. Your hopes take a dive.
"I'm not even sure the people could do it."
"You mean the Anishinaabe?"
"Yeah, sorry," she chuckles. "That's just our word for 'the people'. Anishinaabeg, actually. For plural."
"Anyway," she hurries to add, "this is a spirit from someplace else."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Nah," she shakes her head. "No, I don't think we'd find it here. Call it hooey wooey or whatever, but these guys know their stuff. If it's not supposed to be here, the nooke doodem makes sure it isn't."
"That good, huh?"
"Could be," she offers. "You ask them, though, they'll tell you they don't have to enforce it. Spirits just know where they belong, and where they don't."
"Course," she adds, "just because it isn't here, doesn't mean it can't get you. You'll never truly be safe until you deal with it."

table.name: encounters
table.column: How do I get rid of the spirit?

"So, what now? Suppose I want to get rid of this thing chasing me. 'cause, you know, I DO. What next?"
"Well," she ponders, "somehow you got its attention, right? I mean, something made you seek us out when you did, and not before."
"You're thinking whatever that was might be a clue?"
"Totally." She thinks a minute more. "You did come to us after your work on that website. The New Earth Ostracon thing."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"So spirits don't like the internet?"
She chuckles. "Think about it a sec. You had to knock on a fair number of doors to get that info, right? Probably disturbed more than one spirit digging up that data."
"So," you muse sarcastically, "we've narrowed it down to any paranormal occurrence listed on a website trying to list every single one in history?"
She laughs. "Yeah! Now you're getting it!"
You shake your head.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Seriously, though." She holds up a binder. "WE printed off a section. And this place ain't exactly high-tech, you know? I'm thinking there's gotta be a more complete copy out there somewhere."
"You mean like the cyber cafe down the block?"
"Jeez, man. Stop being such a downer."
"Sorry," you say, more calmly. "Optimism's a lot of work these days."
"So is being mopey all the time."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"It's out there," she says. "Has to be. I mean, this data was on everyone's computer at one point, right? At least, everyone who contributed to it."
"That's true."
"It can't be wiped out from everywhere," she reasons.
"And if it is?"
"Then you're screwed, Philip."
That brings a smile to your face. "Well, at least we agree on that."
"C'mon," she says, "let's show you around." She starts heading towards the Great Fire.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"It's the talisman," she points to your bauble. "We get a few looters stealing artifacts like that. Pisses him right off."
"Lucky for you, though, I know you," she ribs you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"My ancestors were Ojibwe. Though you probably heard it more often said 'Chippewah'. O-ji-be-wuh, if you can picture it being bastardized like that."
"Anyway, as things fell apart in Michigan, the tribes decided to form an alliance on the old Isabella Res. Get back to our roots. Rebuild."
She looks around in admiration. "Nice to have the land back, if ya know what I mean."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're standing in the Anishinaabe Tribal Nation's gathering area, by the Great Fire.
Around you, you see an area where people are sharing a meal together, and a trader of goods.
Further away, you see a cluster of huts near a sweat lodge, where Joe, the Nooke Midewinini, tends to the sick and wounded.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Finally, your journey stops. Your bindings and blindfold removed.
As the blurriness clears, you see that you're in a village. Dome-like buildings surround a great fire, with equal parts animal hide and repurposed junk for walls and shelter.
Around the village, a mix of regular folk and chalk-faced warriors go about their business. Many are more than casually interested in your arrival.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There's the sound of fabric, and then the cool air becomes warm, like you're inside.
You're set upon something soft, and your bindings and blindfold are removed.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Uh, sorry," you stammer. "I didn't know. I'll go back."
There's no protest from the figures, who simply watch you turn and go. After several moments, you hazard a look behind you, but they're nowhere to be seen.
But probably not gone.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Okay," you say. And await further instructions.
One of them fixes the blindfold over your eyes. Meanwhile, your hands are bound behind your back.
Despite the restraints, the whole process proceeds without any unnecessary force. You seem to be handled with both caution and respect.
You're turned in place, and led forward through the forest.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A small entourage in tow, you walk idly towards the fire.
"I'm gonna take you to the Great Fire," she says. "It's sort of a meeting area for the people. Travelers, too."
"You'll find what you need there."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You cross an open field into a ring of huts. Some people watch you closely, while others seem not to notice you.
As you approach, the heat of the Great Fire grows, and Michelle turns to you.
"You'll find food, trading goods, and everything you need here," she indicates.
"Just don't cause any trouble."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"You know," you say, "I think I need a few minutes."
Obviously derailed, Michelle stops a moment. "Oh, okay. Sure."
She looks around a bit, and then gestures toward the fire.
"Let's head over to the Great Fire. You can find whatever you need there."
You both begin walking toward the fire.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The warrior just presses a finger to her lips, signaling silence.
Then, she turns her attention back to the area around you, seemingly stalking something.

table.name: encounters
table.column: She seems to be gauging the surroundings for a moment, but then she turns to you, satisfied there is no danger near.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"This is not the place for talking," he says, paying more attention to something beyond you.
"We may talk later."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I see that you wear a copper talisman. Where did you get it?" she asks.
You idly place your hand on the talisman. "I..." You're not sure how to answer.
"I've had this for as long as I can remember."
There. Honest.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
She considers your story.
"You should speak with Michelle Lavallee, our Ajijaak elder. She is interested in these things, and knows a lot about them."
She explains how to find her enclave.
"Just be respectful," she warns. "Our warriors are accustomed to troublemakers entering our lands."
With that, she gets back to her route. "Wiingezin, traveler."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Aanii, stranger. How are your travels?"
"Psh, easy," you joke. "I wish there were some real challenge out here."
"You're funny," she smiles, just enough to show she appreciates your levity.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
She takes a few steps closer, but then stops suddenly, looking at you.
"We do not speak with your kind," she warns, backing away. "There is no place here for windigoo!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"It's a shame there aren't more out here preferring to talk instead of fight."
"So thanks for that," she says, turning back to the horizon.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"You have a stink of human rot about you," he spits. "The windigoo are not welcome to roam these lands."
He seems ready to fight.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A few steps further, however, and the phantoms you thought you saw suddenly become all too real.
Rushing air precedes a jarring crash onto your shoulders, and you're sent crumpling into the dirt. Something has landed on you. Hard.
The once-quiet surroundings are aflutter with footsteps now, as figures approach from all sides.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The trading post seems to be a place where travelers resupply and offload items which may be of use to the Anishinaabe.
A large portion of the inventory appears to be handmade items from local materials, and some scavenged goods.
Pick up items to purchase them, or drop items to sell them.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You approach the long table, and find an open place on the bench.
The food here is plentiful, and appears to be a mix of roasted and dried meats, roasted corn or maize, baked squash, and beans.
There is also an assortment of berries and other fruit.
Overall, the meal is hearty, with diverse flavors of savory and sweet. It fills your stomach, briefly allowing your mind to wander from minute-to-minute survival.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You head towards a cluster of tents near the edge of camp, by the forest. "Patients" reside here, helping to tend the area, many of whom are in rehabilitation from drug addiction or other conditions.
Warriors are more visible here, keeping the peace in an area where frustration and desperation can overcome the healing.
Ahead is an oblong dome hut, from which steam emanates into the cool air. A man adorned in bear symbology seems to be preparing the hut.
This is Joe, Midewinini of the Nooke doodem.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The feeling here is one of sharing and respect. Visitors to the table are asked to pay respects to the animals that gave their meat, the Three Sisters for their fruits, and all creation.
In the distance, you see fields of crops, but also semi-trailers, sheets of tarp over frames, and other repurposed grow-ops for their food.
You begin to understand the real sense of urgency that perimeter patrols must feel in watching over this place.
The fine line they walk in keeping rubble scum out, but allowing peaceful travelers passage.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Members of the Nooke doodem, under supervision of Joe, have learned how to treat wounds and stop bleeding.
Cuts are irrigated with clean water, and treated with herbal antiseptic if necessary. Fractured bones are set and splinted.
Much of the pain still lingers, and it'll take time for your body to mend. But at least your wounds are stabilized.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
In Anishinaabe medicine, much of the focus is on purifying the body and spirit.
The role of heat, smoke, and steam is to infuse the patient with spiritual energy, believed to be symbolized when smoke and steam emanate from sacred items.
In the sweat lodge, Joe conjures this spiritual energy, the spirit of earth, by pouring water on heated stones. The steam and burning sage fill the room, and your lungs, replacing negative energies with positive.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There is an indirect science to the medicine, as well. Having observed the animal world's interaction with nature, certain plants and animals have been singled out for their healing properties.
Bear root, boiled in water to extract the medicine, can have restorative effects. Some have even reported illnesses waning under its effects.
Chewing on the root and sipping the tannin tea, your body gains a newfound energy for combating illness.
You thank Joe for his time and his help, then leave the lodge.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Gathering your things, you set off for the forest, and the wilderness beyond.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A few steps into the forest, rushing air precedes a jarring crash onto your shoulders, and you're sent crumpling into the dirt. Something has landed on you. Hard.
The once-quiet surroundings are aflutter with footsteps now, as figures approach from all sides.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you walk through the ATN's perimeter forest, you're stopped by one of the patrols.
"Traveler," says the leader, "we cannot let you pass through here. And there is an illness in you that threatens us if you leave."
Uh-oh.
"You will come with us now." It's less an order than a statement of fact. The others close in on you, and restraints are fitted.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're taken into the village's healing area, where you're seated in a tent, and your restraints removed.
In front of you is a dish, piled high with succulent, fatty meat, with cooked squash, beans, and corn. Strangely, this meat brings your nostrils to life. The meat for which you so desperately clambered seems forgotten momentarily. Your mouth waters as you survey the food.
Even the veggies might offer some satisfaction.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"A spirit has taken you," the warrior says. "Windigoo will cause harm both to you and all around you, and must be cast out."
He heads toward the door. "Eat this food. It will prepare you for the sweat you are to endure."
And with that, he leaves.
You begin eating the meal.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Joe takes you across an open field into a ring of huts. Some people watch you closely, while others seem not to notice you.
As you approach, the heat of the Great Fire grows, and he turns to you.
"Be at peace, and wary of windigoo." Then, he gestures toward the fire.
"Please."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you walk through the ATN's perimeter forest, you're stopped by one of the patrols.
"You are no longer welcome here," she warns. "Go."
Other warriors appear in the surroundings, as if to punctuate her demand.
You're outnumbered, and on their home turf. Since doing anything but complying here would be suicide, you leave.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're grabbed by nearby warriors, and dragged roughly from the village.
"We do not welcome your kind. We do not trade in the flesh of our brethren."
You're thrown to the ground outside the forest.
"Go. And do not return."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ah. Why did you ever shun this meat? No matter. You have found it again. You must find more. Always find more, so you never go without again!

table.name: encounters
table.column: Blinding, blue-white light and a rush of dry air signals the return of that nightmarish creature.

table.name: encounters
table.column: He stops a moment, sizing you up. Once satisfied, his attention seems to return to the surroundings.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Hard to believe this place used to be, like, someone's backyard, eh?" He surveys the area, then he begins walking again.
"Take it easy."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
He steps closer, but then stops, and seems to lower his stance with eyes fixed on you.
"You have a stink of human rot about you," he spits. "The windigoo are not welcome to roam these lands."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
She raises her hand with a smile.
"Catch anything good?"
"Boots," you reply.
"Ha ha, lucky!" She waves again as you part ways.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You explain the whereabouts of Gyges Cryo Facility.
"Shit's still got power?" He seems genuinely optimistic.
"Seems to."
"Damn, son! I got a field trip ta make!" And he heads off.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
At the front of the line, the guard motions you closer. A moment of pregnant silence precedes a satisfying chirp, and the monitor flashes.
"Suspect Flagged: Detain for Questioning."
Your gut suddenly feels like a vacuum. The guard places a heavy-gloved hand on your shoulder. "Alright, buddy, let's go."
You're led to a gray door at the base of the south buttress, alongside a thin slit of mirrored windows.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're escorted from the interview area, and brought into an on-site clinic, where you're strapped to a table, and anesthetized.
When you wake, you're on a bench in a painted cinder block room, leaning against a corner. Both your head and right shoulder ache. A piercing bleep fills the room as an intercom comes to life.
"You have been charged as follows: -Assault on a police officer -Resisting arrest -Failure to disclose personal information"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
By the time your case handler arrives, you've counted the ceiling tiles, grouped them into shades of beige, and created an elaborate conspiracy linking all the missing persons.
Your handler leads you to his cubicle, and you're subjected to a battery of tests, including face scan, retinal scan, DNA sampling, fingerprinting, and a blood sample.
The interview is something of a comedy, with questions like "What is your full name, address, and date of birth?"
The handler isn't amused, however.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You head towards the long table, but are surprised when you're intercepted by a younger man.
"You've been making yourself quite at home here today," he says, crossing his arms.
"Maybe you come back later. Save some food for the others." He continues to stare at you, making his point clear until you leave.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You head towards a cluster of tents near the edge of camp, by the forest.
However, your visit is cut short when Joe emerges from a tent on his way to another. He looks towards you, then shakes his head.
"I cannot treat you again. I have too many other patients." He disappears into another tent without missing a step.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you turn to leave the village, you hear a shriek. A voice breaking in alarm and anger rings from the trading post. Warriors and tribespeople alike begin to converge.
"The Windigoo!" he shouts. "He's here!" The man you were trading with points at you. "He tried to sell-" he begins shouting in a language you cannot understand.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Grassy plains ease you in as you follow the silent roads. As steel skies rumble, the wind runs away from where you're headed. You pass dozens of cars turned on their side and bearing war paint: bright slashes of sky blue.
As the road bends in to a small patch of forest, a worn-down sign reads: 'SAGINAW MENTAL INSTITUTION'. From the voids left by missing letters, you make out the words: 'Reaching wellness'. Now all it says is 'aching'.
A clearing opens up ahead. There, a menacing building stretches almost a mile wide with impunity. You see Blue Frogs at the doors, armed to all hell. Two floors. Boarded windows. One entrance. Your choices are few. You hide behind a car and consider how to infiltrate the stronghold of a murderous cult.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Follow a set of hidden tracks to the side of the entrance.

If this cult intends an air of inviting welcome, you're not seeing it.
You search the ground for signs of another way in. The Blue Frogs likely treat the stronghold as a 'temple', and surely that means a secret entryway exists.
There. In the pockets of grass and mud rupturing through the concrete, you find traces of frequent trespass. You follow the trail behind cover of the cars, and hit a window covered by planks. You grip the edges. Sure enough, the boards pop out on a hinge, and you slip into whatever room awaits on the other side.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Approach with confidence as a Blue Frog missionary.

Purpose and belonging weighs down your every step as you approach the Institution's entrance, clad in the same colors as the Blue Frogs. The sky seems to darken the closer you get. Beneath your gas mask, you're sweating.
They nod at you. You nod back.
It looks like the gambit worked. You congratulate yourself. You keep walking, closer and closer to the doors, slow and steady like you own the place.
"Hold it," one guard says, raising an open hand. "Password?"
Damn it.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's a curious spirit of 'oh, what the hell' that overcomes you. The world is in tatters, overrun with monsters and murderers. You spend your days rummaging through the garbage of other men. The most exciting things you do regularly are pocket some bits of string, boil some water, eat a bit. What is it exactly that you have to lose?
If you're miserable, it's best to end it with a bang. Invoking every ounce of heroism, you charge the front gates of Saginaw with everything you have to throw at the guards. You even manage something of a war cry as you hurtle towards doom.
You're rather proud of yourself.
The two guards aim at you, fire, and then discuss cult politics.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A clearing opens up ahead. There, a menacing building stretches almost a mile wide with impunity. Two floors. Boarded windows. One entrance. Your choices are few. You hide behind a car and consider how to infiltrate the stronghold of a murderous cult.
You see an armed Blue Frog sentry at the doors.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Approach while professing a newfound love for the Church of the Blue Frog.

With arms raised high, you cross the driveway towards a dried fountain where granite cherubs frolic without the weight of their heads.
"Halt!" the guards shout, rifles ready.
At the top of your lungs, you confess to having seen the light of the Blue Frog. They exchange looks. Their two rifle barrels stay on you.
"But can you leave your old life behind?" one asks.
You tell them you want nothing more.
"Then shed your old skins," he says. "Enter our sanctuary as a newborn!"
"A naked newborn!" the other guard echoes.
Well. What choice do you have?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Wait for an opportunity to sneak past the guard.

The better part of an hour passes, with the faint sounds of screams occasionally echoing out from the walls.
Then, the guard scurries off around the building to void his bladder. You quickly sneak past him as he lets out a horse-like neigh for some reason.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Approach with confidence as a Blue Frog missionary.

Purpose and belonging weighs down your every step as you approach the Institution's entrance, clad in the same colors as the Blue Frogs. Beneath your gas mask, you're sweating.
The guard nods at you. You nod back.
It looks like the gambit worked. You congratulate yourself. You keep walking, closer and closer to the doors, slow and steady like you own the place.
"Hold it," the guard says, raising an open hand. "Password?"
A second guard emerges, to see what the commotion is.
Damn it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Approach while professing a newfound love for the Church of the Blue Frog.

With arms raised high, you cross the driveway toward a dried fountain where granite cherubs frolic. Headless.
"Halt!" the guard shouts, and another emerges moments later.
At the top of your lungs, you confess to having seen the light of the Blue Frog. They exchange looks. Their two rifle barrels stay on you.
"But can you leave your old life behind?" one asks.
You tell them you want nothing more.
"Then shed your old skins," he says. "Enter our sanctuary as a newborn!"
"A naked newborn!" the other guard echoes.
Well. What choice do you have?

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide not to mess with this place, and duck out of sight.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's a curious spirit of 'oh, what the hell' that overcomes you. The world is in tatters, overrun with monsters and murderers. You spend your days rummaging through the garbage of other men. The most exciting things you do regularly are pocket some bits of string, boil some water, eat a bit. What is it exactly that you have to lose?
If you're miserable, it's best to end it with a bang. Invoking every ounce of heroism, you charge the front gates of Saginaw with everything you have to throw at the guards. You even manage something of a war cry as you hurtle towards doom.
You're rather proud of yourself.
The two guards aim at you, fire, and then discuss cult politics.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Your eyes adjust slowly to the dark indoors. The decay is pungent. Wood rot. Bodily fluids. The guard takes you to a lamp-lit room where a short, pudgy cultist squats on the ground, unmasked. Three frog-shaped sculptures sit around him. Pamphlets and posters litter the floor.
"Welcome, brother," the cultist says as he zips up his pants and hugs you. "Call me Rollo. The King is always delighted when one joins his flock. But before you see him, you must be pure.
"Choose, then. A trial of water, of fire, or," he says as a twisted grin joins his ears, "of light?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Choose the midsize frog, designated the trial of light.

There's a look of disbelief on the cultist's face.
"Too many of the inducted want paradise without sacrifice," he begins. "They choose the trial of water. And I pity them.
"Some dare the trial of fire. They offer more of themselves, but not much more. And I pity them.
"Are you truly righteous, brother? Will you brave the trial of light, tempting Death's hand, for the sake of purity?"
His gleeful smile slides a chill around your neck.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Choose the large frog, designated the trial of fire.

The cultist is mildly amused. He opens the doors at the back of the bronze sculpture. It's hollow.
"Get in," he says.
The guard 'encourages' you with the rifle. As you squeeze yourself into the frog, squatting like the creature itself, you see ashes and firewood underneath it.
The doors slam shut. And for a while, you allow yourself some hope. Maybe it's just a test of claustrophobia. A mental trial. But the rising heat dispels it all.
The cultist's voice rings in the tank: "Let the pain of the brazen frog cleanse this man of sin."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Choose the small frog, designated the trial of water.

The cultist seems disappointed as he takes the small frog to a barrel in the corner of the room. The beam of light coming from a hole in the ceiling tells you it's used to gather rain water. A ring of algae crowns its rim.
"Lie back," he says.
You realize the table it was sitting on is part of the ritual. The guard straps you down. He shoves one cloth in your mouth and wraps your head with another. The table tilts back.
The cultist's voice roars: "Let the pain of the water cure cleanse this man of sin."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You feel wave after wave crash down, turning cotton into rubber over your face. You try not to gag. Struggle as you might, a brook trickles up your nose when you inhale and down your throat when you swallow. You wish death would just take that last step.
When it stops, the taste of filthy water lingers on your tongue. It's all you can do to stop the waters from rising again.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You don't count how many times the cultist pours water over your face. You don't count how many gulps of water you swallow just so you can breathe. You don't count the pleas you make, only how many times they're heard.
When the drowning is done, the light in the room has changed. A lantern flickers and you vomit a small puddle onto the decrepit floor.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're dragged from the room. Voices congratulate you, but as if from miles away. You feel like you're waking with the slowness of surfacing through tar.
You become aware that you're in a large auditorium with a dome structure in the middle. Before it stands a Blue Frog, clad in ornate robes and a gas mask with a crown motif, standing on a dental chair. You hear only the tail end of his sermon.
"...and for your piety, we welcome you, brother. Now speak your name."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The air bites at your bare skin as the guard ushers you inside.
"Wear this." He throws you a hospital gown. Deja vu.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The air leaves the room. All is silence.
"Could it be true, King?" one of the cultists asks. "Could he be the one?"
For a moment, the Blue Frog King is stunned. "Kindred," he repeats. "'Thus shall return our Savior and our sign, bearing a name of brotherhood.'"
Every one of them repeats the passage. They begin chanting praises that rise and blend together in the air, welcoming and foreboding at the same- all except one man in a raven-beaked gas mask, standing still beside the King, his gaze fixed on you like stone.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The crowd of Blue Frogs begins to descend into mania. The King must sense it, too, because he immediately calms them down.
"Brothers and sisters," he says, "for how long have we waited for the savior to deliver us? How long have I waited? And how long had my father before me? Each of us walks this path, the long path of faith, trusting we will reach our destiny. Today we see an end to our journey.
"But as it is written, and as we know, the message lies buried deep in the soul of the Savior. And only I, the King who wields the Book of the Water Lily, can unearth it from the depths.
"Come," the King says to you, "let us perform the Remembrance Ritual."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The King and his second take you to the northern end, passing increasingly more lavish blue banners. Lanterns dot the dark hallway, illuminating cult symbols on the wall. The compound blends the clinical charm of mental hospitals with the blood-smeared piety of a pagan temple.
The King stops at a set of locked doors. "Bishop," he says to his second, "Go take care of the injections."
"But King-"
The King hurls him against the wall with surprising swiftness. After his point is made, the Bishop slinks away.
"I do my best to help," laments the King as you head inside.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The room is barren of life. No symbols, no trophies, no weapons. It covers the necessities: a bed, a table and two chairs, a chamber pot. Otherwise, there is only a stand, a safe, and a lot of empty space.
The King sits you down. "The scriptures say you were wronged, Savior. You had the truth in your hands, and when sinners could not take it away, they buried you inside yourself. But we can bring you back! We can take back the truth that can save this world!"
Fire and tears fill the eyes of the King. Who you are, what happened to you, who was responsible. All could be moments away.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
From a hidden slot at the center of the table, the King pulls up a metronome with a flashing light and continues: "Now just relax, Savior. Let all thoughts flow away. The sinners used to call this Regressive Hypnosis. All you need to do is let the light into your eyes, and my voice into your ears."
You stare at the white circle. A minute passes. Then another. Then another. You don't even realize when it kicks in.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
White clouds blurring. Decay waning. Rising murmurs from the click, click, click, click.
Saginaw. A lifetime ago. Alive with patients and staff.
The entrance foyer. A reception desk. Nurses with hair extensions and powdered noses. A man to the left in a dress shirt under a blue hoodie. A man signing pre-admission papers for patient Philip Kindred. A man signing as Bertrand Farris. A man looking up. A man without a face.
White clouds again. Teeth on leather. Pain and everything. Pain and nothing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
For all the intensity of the images, it just feels like you snapped out of a daydream. The King sits across from you, mask removed, his hollow green eyes desperate for hope.
"Has the truth returned to you, Savior? Do you know what we must do to save our church?"
Suddenly you realize just how much power you have in that moment. You consider your next words carefully.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell him to believe in the Blue Frog.

As soon as you finish speaking, the door behind you flings open. The beaten Bishop barges in as if without injury.
"Don't listen to him!" the Bishop shouts. "Can't you see? He's just as deluded as your father was. Remember our plan, Eli! We are righteous!"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell him the Church needs a new King cont'd

"'But beware they who take false names'," the King says, "'and demand the glory of thrones.'"
The Bishop unmasks just to spit on you. "Disgusting."
The King turns away. "We will have another sacrifice, it seems."
Against all that firepower, you know you have no chance.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell him you have no answers.

The King slumps over. "Worthless," he whispers. Yet you wonder if it's really you he's talking about.
He takes a thick, disheveled book from a fold in his robes. He flips to its last few pages, rips them out, and throws them at you.
"Get out. And take those lies with you." A sullen look crosses the King's face. "There is no savior for us."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell him the Church of the Blue Frog is doomed.

The King's face turns pale. He takes a thick, disheveled book from a fold in his robes and flips to the very last page. "But what of this?" he pleads.
On one side is a crude painting of a vaguely amphibious, black shape in a tall rectangle of blue.
On the other side is the following text: 'Only Frogs will survive the Flood.'

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell him that the Flood has already come.

The King pauses. You can feel your face burning, your heart racing. Did you say the wrong thing? And then he bursts out laughing.
You ask him why.
"One day, Philip, you'll hear the saddest thing in the world and all you'll be able to do is laugh." He tears pages from the big book in front of you. "Take this and go. I put too much hope in disappointments. I suppose I have that in common with my father.
"Go," he repeats. "We're long past saving."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell him that the Flood is a lie.

The door opens behind you.
"Didn't I tell you, Eli?" says the Bishop. "Your father was a pathetic little man possessed by delusions. Why believe anything he said?"
The King takes several moments to consider these revelations. Finally, he unlocks his safe and brings out a small bottle. "You've freed me, Philip. I owe you a great deal." From the thick book, he rips out its last few pages. "This is a single-use cure for Blue Rot. Take it, and take these lies, too. Maybe they'll help you."
As the King leaves with the Bishop, he says: "Get away from here while you can."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you make a beeline for the entrance, you fold the pages under your shirt and don't bother looking back.
The guards begrudgingly give back the items you left with them, and you keep walking until you're sure that when you turn around, you won't see another damn drop of blue.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you make a beeline for the entrance, you fold the pages under your shirt and don't bother looking back.
The guards begrudgingly give back the items you left with them, and you keep walking until you're sure that when you turn around, you won't see another damn drop of blue.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell the Bishop to screw himself.

"My, my," the Bishop says. "Sounds like I hit a nerve. Right, Eli?"
You turn to the King. Suspicion colors his eyes as he studies you. Before you can move again, a crippling blow whips across the back of your neck, and you fall to your hands and knees.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell the King that the truly righteous are always tempted.

You don't stop to wonder where the words come from. They're just there, ready to counter the Bishop.
The King's eyes look at you, then him. "But which is it? Who can I trust?"
The Bishop crosses his arms pointedly at you. "Go ahead, Savior. Your serve."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell the King the choice is his.

The Bishop laughs. "Look at him, trying to pass for pious and righteous and-"
The King throws his mask at the Bishop's face. "The choice is mine!" he yells. "I am the damn King. The Blue Frog is my legacy, and neither of you are anything to me. So you will shut that mouth, Eddie, or I will bring it silence!"
He darts to the mattress and violently lifts it aside.
"You. Both of you. Whispering in my ears. What do I care what you think? I need no man's counsel."
The King pulls two shotguns from a hidden compartment in the floor, a look of divine madness over his face.
"It's time I listen to a different voice."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Challenge the Bishop to a trial of pain.

The Bishop falls silent.
"Oh," the King says. "That's a ballsy idea. Eddie?"
The Bishop nods. "Let's get it over with."
The three of you, along with every Blue Frog in the vicinity flood the hallways and head to the auditorium. Whichever way this goes, at least you'll have an audience.
The King calls his court to order. "Accuser," he says to you. "Mark your Accused."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell the King you can be trusted.

"Spoken like a silver-tongued liar," the Bishop adds. "You are fooling no one. Brothers!"
Blue Frogs fill the room before you can move, their guns trained on your head and heart. You plead for the King to listen to you.
"Lock him up," the King says. "I'll deal with him later. It has now come time for Pilgrimage."
You catch the Bishop's gloating look before a rifle butt knocks you to the ground.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You don't know how long it's been. Exhaustion smears together the hours, conspiring with hunger and the residue of pain. The room looks meticulously prepared, deprived of anything that might give you a chance to escape. Even the walls are scraped down, just as you have been stripped bare. The only thing they've given you is a small bottle of something bitter to drink, which you immediately drank.
All you have is the dread of waiting for the knock of the reaper come. Probably to give you a final, excruciating, ritualistic sendoff by a pack of rabid dogs in gas masks.
As days begin to pass, you realize something both hopeful and unsettling: you haven't heard anything come by in a long time. No footsteps, no voices. Nothing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You blink and the girl is gone, and all of Saginaw-its horrid walls and its smell-gone with her.
You find yourself standing in the wilderness surrounding the asylum with a pile nearby of everything you had when you entered. As you look through your things, you hear something from far away.
"Don't come back, mister!"
And really, that much was implied.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Come outside, mister," says a little girl standing beyond the doorway, with a paper bag over her head. On it is drawn a happy face with Xs for eyes.
You step out into the hallway and smell what's been waiting outside your prison.
"All the bunnies are sleeping," she says. "Sick with the blues, I guess. Except those two that ran away."
Bodies clog the hallway, abuzz with the green-eyed residents of corpses. You hear their hymn echoing in the stillness.
"I'll take you out of here. I think I know where your things are, too."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You regain enough strength to walk over to the door. You rest your ear against it and discover the sound of a million ghosts holding their breath.
You push against the door, but it won't budge. The steel hinges will rust slower than you wither away, and the thought of being outlasted by the asylum reduces you to your knees. This could be it. And what little you have to show for it.
Then, someone opens the door.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The building shakes each time the King fires, the Blue Frog banners pulsing in rhythm. You've lost track of the Bishop.
"RUN, FROGGIE!" the King's voice echoes.
Without warning, the other Blue Frogs just start putting holes in every surface they see. They open fire on leaky ceilings, decrepit walls, broken doors. Anything to pass the time.
Outside, you keep going until the pain in your lungs and legs becomes unbearable.
By then, Saginaw is far away. Yet you swear you can still hear the King laughing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You feel your arm go numb as you point to the Bishop: "Him."
A murmur sweeps through the crowd, swelling into a roar.
"Brothers and sisters," the King tries to shout over the crowd, but it's not enough. He tries again and again, but for once he can't contain them.
You look around at the cultists. You're not even sure what you're seeing. Grief. Outrage. Euphoria. Or some twisted fusion of the three? Whatever it is, it's growing. With mere words, you've set a forest of madness ablaze, and the inferno is beyond all control.
What have you done?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
After a few deafening minutes, the crowd finally quiets enough for the King to be heard.
"Brothers and sisters," the King bellows, "the rites are clear. An Accuser has sired an Accused, and by our creed we shall see who is pure and who is corrupt through a trial of pain.
"Three torments purify us, and three torments give us truth: the Trial of Water, of Fire, and of Light. From these three torments, the Accused shall choose but one. The Accuser may then accept this choice, or invoke the right of one refusal and force the Accused to choose from the remaining two torments."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Accused," the King says to the Bishop. "Make your choice."
The Bishop unmasks, revealing a pale-faced man with beady black eyes and short blond hair. "A Trial of Light," he says.
"Accuser," the King says to you. "Do you accept the Trial of Light?"
You study the Bishop. Does he want this Trial, or is he hoping you veto it so he can choose the one he actually wants? He looks nervous; it could be an act.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Look for tells in the Bishop's body language.

Few people have full control of the volumes their body speaks. What is the Bishop's saying?
You study him for tells, but his whole body seems wracked with anxiety. Then you catch a glimpse of it: a break in the veneer, a pause in his routine like a song skipping a beat. It's an act. He only wants you to think he's gunning for a different trial.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Look for signs of what the Bishop is hiding.

Past his jittery hands and bitten fingernails, his foot tapping and furrowed brow, you sense it: calmness. He isn't worried at all. He's misdirecting your attention to appear fearful of your accepting the Trial of Light, but what he's hiding is the fact that he's sure you will.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Look for signs that the Bishop is trying to trap you.

Anyone in the position the Bishop keeps in the cult is likely to be shrewd. Is this a trap?
His eyes. They're trained on you, never flinching even for a moment at anything else in the room. It's not fear, but impatience. He's watching his prey about to step into a snare, and the Trial of Light is his bait.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Refuse the Trial of Light and force the Bishop to choose another torment.

The Bishop goes into a genuine panic. He tries to hide it, but you see it betrayed by his gaunt face.
"The Accuser has refused the torment," the King says. "Accused: your choice?"
After a time, the Bishop says: "A Trial of Water."
The King nods. "Then the Trial of Water shall commence!"
The Blue Frogs rush. Spotlights flood the auditorium as two pairs of cultists wheel out wooden tables from the dome in the center. To them you and the Bishop are fastened, before one dirty rag stuffs your mouth and another wraps your face.
All together the cultists chant: "Purity holds its light in pain."
You hear a container dunk into a vat of water nearby as the King declares: "May the righteous be the victor."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As soon as you say you accept, all the anxiety in the Bishop's face melts away.
"The Trial of Light shall commence!" announces the King.
The Blue Frogs move quickly. Spotlights flood the auditorium as cultists bring out two electric chairs from the dome in the center. They fasten you and the Bishop in your seats, the straps tight against your body, and scatter electrodes all over you. In minutes, the entire show is ready.
All together the cultists chant: "Purity holds its light in pain."
The King raises his arm to signal. "May the righteous be the victor," he says and he lets his arm fall.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Thought disintegrates in the pain. Consciousness sinks into the senses. A million invisible hammers beat down across your body with a force of vengeance, and the only thing keeping you in one piece is the unfortunate fact that life is only resilient when you wish it fragile.
It stops; it starts. It stops; it starts again. The Bishop has not surrendered. You look out at the crowd, but they only want more.
When the electricity starts again, you feel your bones rattle in their fleshy cage and fracture. You want to believe that holding out will work, that the Bishop is about to give up. But you're almost sure that trying it will get you killed. Whatever they do to false Accusers, it can't be worse than this.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Thought disintegrates in the pain. Consciousness sinks into the senses. A million invisible hammers beat down across your body with a force of vengeance and the only thing keeping you in one piece is the unfortunate fact that life is only resilient when you wish it fragile.
It stops; it starts. It stops; it starts again. The Bishop has not surrendered. You look out at the crowd, but they only want more.
When the electricity starts again, you feel your bones rattle in their fleshy cage and fracture. You want to believe that holding out will work, that the Bishop is about to give up. But you're almost sure that trying it will get you killed. Whatever they do to false Accusers, it can't be worse than this.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Press on, even on pain of death.

When the rattling stops and the voices quiet, you're left alone in a place where you can understand why this is called the Trial of Light. You don't feel anything anymore. You don't taste blood, or hear your own screams. Light alone surrounds you, and you're alone with it.
Then you actually die.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Retract your challenge and admit defeat.

Somehow you manage to tell them you give up. The Blue Frogs' voices swell to deafening heights as the lights and the auditorium and the world spins around and around. The last thing you hear before you lose consciousness is the voice of the King.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The cheers run wild. They loved the Trial. They loved each second so much that they're the last to see the King fall to the ground and Liza rush to help him.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
They keep you in a dank cell while you recover, despite having proven yourself 'pure.' You play the events over again in your head: the King's collapse, his horrid-sounding breaths, Liza coming in to help a bit too quickly. But the King only held on long enough to name her his heir, and he died clutching the Church's holy book. Then they took you away.
The hours pass. When the guards come again, you're too weak to do anything but go with them back to the auditorium. Liza now sits where the King once stood, on the medical chair. They address her as 'Queen.' The newfound silence of the crowd unnerves you.
"For exposing the traitor in our house," she says coldly, "you have earned a reward. Name it."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask to be made a Bishop of the Blue Frog.

"I can see you're devoted to our Church," Liza says, "but 'Bishop' can't be a position in our order anymore. It's too dangerous."
She signals a cultist toward her, whispers something to him, and he scurries out. When he returns carrying a small chest, Liza removes from inside it a pristine sash of an unnaturally vibrant blue, emblazoned with a flower-like sigil. The crowd stirs in quieted awe.
"This is the crest of the Sapphire Lily, and no Blue Frog shall harm its wearer unless provoked. Take it."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask for help in finding Saginaw's old patient records.

Liza says nothing for a minute, considering your words. "To look so hard for your loved ones, even in this chaos. Parents, maybe? Or grandparents? Whatever the case, it's touching to see how dedicated you are. I'll help you find those records myself."
You're not sure what she means, but you say nothing. She rises to her constituents.
"My children. Many hardships wait for us ahead, and dawn will come only if we're prepared to meet it. Before I return, I want you all to take a good look deep inside yourselves and find out what lineage means to you, and most of all, what the Blue Frog means to you."
The cultists drop their heads down solemnly. Liza looks at you and walks out of the room. "Follow me."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask for a cache of medicines and supplies.

"It's done," Liza says. From coldness, her voice turns severe and commanding. "As Queen, my duty is to strengthen our house. And today, its greatest weaknesses are its most barbaric practices. My children, pain is not a gateway to purity, only to more pain. Purity is loyalty. And it is survival. And it is serving something greater.
"Because of this," she goes on, "instruments of the old regime have to be uprooted. Sadistic practices are crimes, and crimes deserve punishment. The Bishop, Edward Kincaid, has escaped. But justice will find him...just as it now finds you."
Liza turns to you. "For your crime of turning against a fellow Blue Frog and invoking the Rite of Challenge, righteous or not, I have no choice but to banish you from the Church. Your deed will be remembered. Your name will not."
And just like that, they drag you out.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"It's done," Liza says. From coldness, her voice turns severe and commanding. "As Queen, my duty is to strengthen our house. And today, its greatest weaknesses are its most barbaric practices. My children, pain is not a gateway to purity, only to more pain. Purity is loyalty. And it is survival. And it is serving something greater.
"Because of this," she goes on, "instruments of the old regime have to be uprooted. Sadistic practices are crimes, and crimes deserve punishment. The Bishop, Edward Kincaid, has escaped. But justice will find him...just as it now finds you."
Liza turns to you. "For your crime of turning against a fellow Blue Frog and invoking the Rite of Challenge, righteous or not, I have no choice but to banish you from the Church. Your deed will be remembered. Your name will not."
And just like that, they drag you out.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Liza leads you to the north wing, through a set of decorated doors and into a barren room. She shuts the door behind you.
"Philip Kindred," she muses. "Well, it doesn't matter. The Blue Frog doesn't need a prophesied savior anymore; I'll make sure of it when I destroy the old order. Still, a deal's a deal."
She seats you at a table.
"It's your memories you really want, isn't it? Then your only shot is Regressive Hypnosis, or what the idiots call the Remembrance Ritual. It might not work. It might only half-work. Or it might just make you whole again."
You can hardly believe it. Who you are, what happened to you. It could all be moments away.
"Are you ready?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You walk away from the Saginaw Mental Institution with some confusion.
Were you made an example? Was Liza threatened? Maybe breaking ties with you was a favor?
Despite everything that's happened, it looks exactly the same as when you arrived. The stronghold shrinks in the distance behind you, but the colors of the cult refuse to recede from memory.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
She clears her throat. From a hidden compartment in its center, she pulls up a light-mounted metronome. "Focus on the light. Focus on my voice."
The light clicks with each soft flash, rhythmic, folding two clicks between your heartbeats. You feel your body ease. You don't even intend to drift away.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
White clouds blurring. Decay waning. Rising murmurs from the click, click, click, click.
Saginaw. A lifetime ago. Alive with patients and staff.
The entrance foyer. A reception desk. Nurses with hair extensions and powdered noses. A man to the left in a dress shirt under a blue hoodie. A man signing pre-admission papers for patient Philip Kindred. A man signing as Bertrand Farris. A man looking up. A man without a face.
White clouds again. Teeth on leather. Pain and everything. Pain and nothing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Are you awake?" you hear Liza ask as your eyes refocus on the present. "I won't ask you what you saw. I don't really care. I'll only say that whatever memories you found, they're likely distorted. So don't take them as is.
"This is all I can do," Liza continues, "That, and give you this."
Liza opens the Blue Frog cult's holy book and tears out its last few pages.
"Take these. They're what's left of your patient files, and we won't need them anymore. Now come on; there's one last thing you need to hear."
You walk with Liza back to the auditorium, folding the loose pages under your clothes. She ascends the central platform, poised to address her flock.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"It's done," Liza says. From coldness, her voice turns severe and commanding. "As Queen, my duty is to strengthen our house. And today, its greatest weaknesses are its most barbaric practices. My children, pain is not a gateway to purity, only to more pain. Purity is loyalty. And it is survival. And it is serving something greater.
"Because of this," she goes on, "instruments of the old regime have to be uprooted. Sadistic practices are crimes, and crimes deserve punishment. The Bishop, Edward Kincaid, has escaped. But justice will find him...just as it now finds you."
Liza turns to you. "For your crime of turning against a fellow Blue Frog and invoking the Rite of Challenge, righteous or not, I have no choice but to banish you from the Church. Your deed will be remembered. Your name will not."
And just like that, they drag you out.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You kneel and place your hands behind your head.
"Good," the Bishop says. "You'd just be a waste of bullets."
The King walks to the door with the Bishop. "Lock him in a cell until I return. The time for Pilgrimage is nigh."
The Blue Frogs cover your head and drag you off to a cell.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You have to admit: desperate as it was, going for a hostage to buy you some time, or even gutting the mastermind before succumbing to their firing squad, was a decent play.
Admitting that, however, is the last thought that zips between the neurons in your brain before a bullet burrows through it. Its buddies have a dance party in your torso.
Well. You had a good run.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You have to admit: desperate as it was, going for a hostage to buy you some time, or even gutting the mastermind before succumbing to their firing squad, was a decent play.
Admitting that, however, is the last thought that zips between the neurons in your brain before a bullet burrows through it. Its buddies have a dance party in your torso.
Well. You had a good run.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"The Church of the Blue Frog welcomes you, brother Isaac. May our creed guide you: purity holds its light in pain."
The crowd echoes his words.
They haul you back down the east hallway and into something of a locker room.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The emptied cabinets against the walls and those forming two short rows in front of you lend the space some semblance of being a locker room. They keep Blue Frog paraphernalia here. Spares, most likely: gas masks, blue arm bands and sashes, and various other treasures like detached fingers.
On the far side, a Blue Frog gently bumps his head against the wooden boards sealing the window.
The doorway leads back out into the east wing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
In the lantern-lit darkness of the east wing, shadows dart between the banners like assassins. More than once you stop to make sure you're imagining things. And you're almost glad you do. You find cultists in the open rooms you pass by, standing completely still, swaying, or convulsing on the floor.
You reach a fork.
An auditorium ends the passage to the east, curtained by more blue banners. A passionate sermon seeps through. The words are muffled, but you can't miss the apocalyptic tone.
From all the rooms you've passed in the east wing, only the one nearby is closed and marked with a Blue Frog symbol. You hear something. Scratching, or tapping.
To the north is a longer hallway. West is the foyer, and the west wing beyond.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You rifle through the cabinets. Mostly you find Blue Frog paraphernalia, worn from overuse and disuse alike. Some still have wet blood on them.
You're surprised to find anything usable at all.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You address the Blue Frog casually. He doesn't respond.
You make up a vaguely Blue Frog-sounding greeting. He doesn't respond.
You ribbit and croak. Nothing.
Tough crowd.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Ruin dominates the interior of the Saginaw Mental Institution. Water damage and mold claim the peeling walls; bits of splintered ceiling, grime, and smashed glass occupy every surface; decades of abuse mark the scattered furniture. The place feels like a monstrous, dead giant, an asylum's carcass sprouting a savage temple, and you're standing in its jaws.
From the bright blue swaths of fabric hanging from the high ceilings to the Blue Frog insignia cutting through the decay, the cult has branded everything. Every so often, a far-off scream interrupts the silence.
From the foyer, dark hallways extend east and west beyond broken gates. You also see a stairwell across the room. If you listen closely, you can hear a commanding voice from the east.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Thin sheets of dust-ridden light cut through the sealed windows and rest on the banners. Lanterns light your steps. The rooms you pass mostly hold either mounds of medical equipment or nothing at all. Only two or three have ceremonially posed, fly-infested corpses. It's quiet here, as if sound is as unwelcome as you.
A set of double doors lie to the west, gated but unlocked. A Blue Frog symbol marks the door, slightly different from the others. Newer somehow. Less angular and sharp.
A regular Blue Frog insignia marks the door of a small room nearby.
To the north is a longer hallway.
East is the foyer, and the east wing beyond.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Blue banners flood the northern hallway more than any other place you've seen in the stronghold, twisting and writhing against each other from gusts of wind that shouldn't be. The smell of stagnant air turns thick. Between the dead yet unbroken fluorescents tracking the ceiling, lanterns lead your eye to a central set of doors.
Cultist engravings run around the doorframe and spill onto the surrounding walls and floor like a fungal growth. It doesn't sound like anyone's inside. You look around before testing the doors.
They're locked.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Blue Frog banners draw you in as if curtains lifting on a stage. The auditorium swells before your eyes, its walls rounding out into the dark infinity on the other side, its ceilings breaching the heavens of the second floor. Hanging beneath the observation deck that circles the room, lanterns throw shadows far and wide.
At the center, in front of a dome structure mantled by a thousand candles, a man in lush blue robes stands on an examination chair like it's an unfit throne. His voice is like thunder.
"It was the Savior himself," the King cries, "who spoke to our Founder! Who told him of the Return! Who told him to believe! And do we believe, brothers and sisters?"
The crowd of Blue Frogs screams.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Remember our creed, brothers and sisters," the King preaches. Everyone says it together: "Purity holds its light in pain."
You don't realize how close you're standing to the King until the crowd starts surging behind you, carrying you forward in its current. The King signals the cultist beside him, and he brings out a chest spilling with thorned whips. Hands reach out from the sea of blue, begging for it. Somehow, your voice and hands join them.
"As acolytes of the Church of the Blue Frog, we are protected from corruption," the King says. "Let us prove to each other how feeble is the rot against the purity we bear."
The King throws the whips into the crowd.
"Let us bring out the light in each other."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The Blue Frog King's wild gestures punctuate his words, conducting frenzy as if it were music. You move closer. Beside the King stands a silent Blue Frog, his raven-beaked mask reflecting no light.
"This world of chaos feeds its own funeral pyre," the King says. "We alone are the last bastion of clarity, built by my father, the Founder, to champion this flock! Persecuted only for having seen a truth the world was not yet ready for!
"What hells, you say? What hells do we now suffer? These are just droplets. A small wave crashing on rocks and wetting our clothes. But the Flood is coming! And in the Ocean of Ends, only the Blue Frog will survive!"
You almost want to hear more. Should that worry you?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The next thing you know, you're outside the auditorium, battered and whipped like a tub of pancake mix. The wounds are biting. Some bleed. Most, you know, will heal on their own. But when you touch the wounds, there's a slick residue that smells something like grapes bathed in chemicals and decomposing flesh. Whatever it is, it's in your system. It's in everyone's system there in that auditorium.
Blue Frogs rush past you. "Come on," one says, "the next one's about to start!"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go west through the gated doors.

Ceiling-high shelves cut the long room into a series of cramped walkways, onto which they spill boxes of decaying files. As you walk through, you find other things squeezed in: jars of dead critters, a few plastic bags of personal items beyond use. You narrowly avoid stepping on a fingerless hand.
The only light in the room comes from outside. Some of the boards meant for the windows lean against the wall. Silhouetted in gray, a figure sits on the other side facing a giant amphibian-shaped mural.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Maybe you need to prepare. Maybe you know another way. Or maybe you just can't stand the idea of staying for another minute. Whatever the reason, leaving the Saginaw Mental Institution is the easiest decision you've ever made.
But you only make it to the guards at the entrance.
"We can't let you leave, brother," one says. "It's the King's sixth mid-afternoon sermon."
"But don't worry if you still want to leave," the other guard reassures. "After all, purity holds its light in pain. We'll drown, burn, shock, or mutilate that impurity right out of you, even if your life goes, too."
He doesn't sound too broken up about it.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're standing on the first step when you feel a markedly cold rush of air hit you. It's strange, though; there aren't any windows up here. You reach the landing at the top of the first flight of stairs, and before you can start up the second, you actually catch yourself shivering. Did you just hear... No. Maybe it's wind slipping through a vent.
You're halfway up.
"Stop," a little girl's voice says.
You're one step away from the second floor.
"Stop," she repeats, a second voice accompanying hers as deep as an abyss.
You're ninety-nine percent sure you're not hallucinating.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Ah, a visitor!" says a Blue Frog cultist squatting on the ground. "Have you come to reminisce with old Rollo, brother?"
It's a strange sight to come upon someone making a room their personal toilet. It's entirely different to see someone doing that while surrounded by three frog sculptures posing in the same way.
"The room where all of us are reborn," he looks around with pride. "This is good work."
Torn posters and pamphlets litter the floor. Upon a closer look, you see that they're for a treatment called ECT. The plastic-happy faces on them are terrifying.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you approach the seated figure, you see long black hair emerge from the dim light. But your eyes are drawn up. A mural spans the wall, depicting a black, frog-like shape swimming up through a solid rectangle of blue as if surfacing from the deep.
"Beautiful, isn't it," she says.
You agree, and it's only a half-lie. Something about the serene simplicity of the image strikes you.
"Our Founder painted this not long after he started the Church."
Your eyes follow the more purple shades along the bottom, and the red spattering encased within it.
"My name is Liza," she says as she stands up. "You're not one of us, are you?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Look through the boxes of files.

You shuffle through box after box, caring little for the mess and noise you're making. The Blue Frog sitting in the room doesn't budge, so you just ignore them.
Patient files comprise most of the shelves' contents, grouped alphabetically. You find the As, the Gs, the Ws. However the Ks are missing, as are the Bs and Ss. Whatever happened to the 'Philip Kindred' file, it isn't here.
A box sitting alone on a shelf, its surface black as night, catches your attention. You find billing information inside it for certain patients who received 'radical treatment.' Many of those costs were paid for in full by PharmaCon, despite- or perhaps because of- the staggering line of zeroes fattening them up.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Pretend you have the wrong room, and leave.

You stop short, feigning surprise. "Oh. Uh, sorry. I think I got the wrong wing."
You slink back into the hall, ignoring his offers to talk.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"You wouldn't be the first to endure a trial and still come out faithless," she says.
"Look. I don't care about that. You're either a true believer, or just another scavenger looking for another score. Either way, we have something to talk about."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"For one thing, you're in this room," Liza says, looking around her for emphasis. "Old records? A nostalgic mural? That, and I'm in here enough to know you're the only other soul this room has seen in a long while."
"But never mind that. There's something important I want to talk to you about."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tackle her before she can tell anyone!

You dive toward her, but she manages to dodge your advance. Your momentum carries you careening into the wall, and she moves quickly to kick you while you're off-balance.
The kicks keep coming, swift and hard, each forcing air from your lungs. One final stomp punctuates the rest, sending flashes of light through your vision, and blurring the footsteps and shouts of incoming cultists...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tackle her before she can tell anyone!

Her alarm is visible as you sail toward her, and her attempt to side-step is too sluggish for your lunge.
Your shoulder slams her chest into the wall, forcing an awkward yelp from her mouth, and you both crumple to the hard ground.
