You right yourself from the tangle, looming over her as she wheezes in confusion.
It doesn't sound like anyone's coming, but you'll be damned if you're going to be found here, having just assaulted a cult member.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Her throat feels warm to the touch, and you can feel muscle and esophagus writhing beneath her skin as you squeeze.
Her face reddens and eyes widen, and you do your best to squeeze with every ounce of strength you can.
Eventually her thrashing subsides, and you wonder how long it takes to make sure.
Not too long, you decide, as you're uncertain of a noise you just heard.
You slip back to the doorway, and into the west wing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Up onto your feet, you rush to the door, listening.
After a moment or two to verify no footsteps approach, you slip back into the west wing.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Silence her, and hide the body.

Her throat feels warm to the touch, and you can feel muscle and esophagus writhing beneath her skin as you squeeze.
Her face reddens, and eyes widen, and you do your best to squeeze with every ounce of strength you can.
Eventually her thrashing subsides, and you drag the body behind a pile of refuse in the corner, tossing some trash on top for good measure.
Moments later, you slip back to the doorway, and into the west wing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Okay," you say. "Shoot."
"If you're here, you've been around Michigan," she says, "must've seen our brethren around. The 'crazy cult folk' and 'bloodlusting lunatics' and so on, right? But how much do you really know about our customs, our values? Exactly none."
"What you've seen are ugly things, but there's a beautiful, noble purpose they're hiding. You know why I spend my days looking at this mural? Because it's how I see the Blue Frog. The truth of it. Beyond the sadomasochistic rituals and bloodletting. We are a house of hope. Or at least we should be."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You can see quiet determination in Liza's eyes.
"The Blue Frog is a mess right now. Gone astray, biting its own leg. But whatever's been done, it's nickels and dimes compared to what *that man* has planned. That viper come slithered into this lake, whispering in the King's ear. The King's too distracted to see it. Most of the rest are, too. But the Bishop standing at his side day and night wants to turn him away from his flock, to destroy our sanctuary, and to put us all to death.
"I need someone who can see that to help," she says.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask her why the lives of murderers are worth saving.

Liza scoffs. "I'm glad you're taking the time to wax philosophical, but my people are not the enemy. We do what we have to, no different than you."
"The torture, though. The meaningless slaughter. Those are what I intend to stop in the Blue Frog. To bring back our true message of hope, of better days ahead, of a dawn beyond this night."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask her what she means to do.

When you ask her what she means to do, she leans in. "All you have to do is go to the dome auditorium and openly challenge the Bishop's purity. He's the man wearing a ravenhead mask, always beside the King. Do that and the rest will take care of itself. The Bishop will be exposed, the King will see the light, and the Blue Frog will become strong again.
"Of course, I don't expect you to do all this for nothing. Clearly you're here, disguised as one of us, for a reason. So if you help me and the job gets done, name it and it'll be yours."
You stare at her a few moments, thinking. There has to be more to it than that, but it might be worth your while.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Liza tenses a bit. "Are you sure you cannot be convinced?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Good," Liza says. "We'll talk more after this is done. For now, hurry to the auditorium and challenge the Bishop. Call him out as the liar that he is. Our laws require that the challenge be met immediately. I'll take care of the rest."
As you make your way out, you notice Liza hasn't moved. You ask her if she's coming.
"Of course," she assures you. "But I can't enter alongside you. Now go."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
She seems genuinely disappointed.
"Oh, well. I guess you can't always get what you want. But that's fine, then. Good luck finding whatever it is you're looking for. I'll be right here if you change your mind." She sits back down and gazes at the mural of the frog.
You're doubtless surprised to find such a reasonable cultist amidst the hellish halls. Who would've thought that a Blue Frog could retain some sanity? You turn around and head for the door.
From behind you, you hear the whistle of sharpened steel through the air preceding a cold stab from behind. The world slips under your feet. Then you feel nothing at all.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
She seems genuinely disappointed.
"Oh, well. I guess you can't always get what you want. But that's fine, then. Good luck finding whatever it is you're looking for. I'll be right here if you change your mind." She sits back down and gazes at the mural of the frog.
Suspicion bubbles up inside you, and you brace yourself for treachery. You feign a turn, and hear her movements just in time to duck a thrown blade.
Using your lowered stance, you launch toward her.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You step into the hall, and make your way back to the west wing.
Is there something she's not telling you? Is this for real?
On one hand, she seemed pretty sincere. And you're not sure what she'd gain by offing a hapless, new recruit.
On the other, however, you'd be putting your neck out pretty far based on her word. And who knows what the political landscape is like here?
In any case, the sermon will be underway in the east wing, through the foyer. And you have a decision to make.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go west through the gated doors.

You step back into the records room, Liza's body a twisted mound on the floor.
It probably wouldn't do to be caught in here like this.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"An instrument of evil!" Rollo says, riling himself up. "A shovel to bury the truth! ECT! Electroconvulsive Thaumaturgy! Ever-Conspiring Therapists! They place flat white leeches at the sides of your head, and pin red and blue snakes to them, and twist seashells and press clamshells to bend your cheeks into a smile! But that doesn't make truthseers happy! And they know it, the devils! Bury, bury, bury! They just wanted them to forget!"
He seems to calm down. "It pains me to remember the plight of our forebears. Could we ever understand what that was like? To walk in the day with only half a mind?"
He shakes his head. "Purity holds its light in pain."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ask Rollo about the three frogs.

Rollo rips the gas mask around his neck and throws it down on the ground.
"You mean, you don't remember?" he asks, violence in his voice. "The most important day for any Blue Frog, over which I have the honor of presiding? The beginning of a new life of purity birthed through righteous suffering in water, or fire, or light? And it just slips your mind!?"
Something seems to click behind his face. "Did Jill put you up to this?" And he bursts out laughing. "Oh, Jill! You almost had me."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Rollo seems to be in the process of maintaining frog-shaped contraptions, humming to himself.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's difficult to explain something you don't see every day, especially when it contradicts things you normally do see. People don't just appear out of thin air; they have to walk from point A to point B and so on. There is a movement there. There is gradation.
But after ignoring the bone-chilling air silently warning away from the second floor, point A is right out. Appearing most suddenly in point B directly in front of you is a tall, gaunt woman in a short white dress, covered in dirt smears and hand prints, with a mess of black hair falling down around her glaring eyes.
All you hear is the sound of biting teeth.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go back down to the foyer as fast as you possibly can.
Uncomfortable about presenting your back to whatever's going on up there, you backpedal as quickly as you can without risking a fall, and return to the foyer.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Saginaw may be a horror show, you decide, but it beats being mutilated by these two.
You head back inside.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As soon as you make clear your intentions to skip the King's sermon, the guards put bullets in your legs. They drag you inside.
"No harm done, brother," one guard says. "Happens to the best of us."
"We'll gladly help you purify," says the other.
"What do you think: Trial of Fire?"
"May have to improvise."
After some bumbling around with wood, lanterns, matches, and a swivel chair, they finally manage to set you on fire. It doesn't end well.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Quickly pick the locked door and head inside.

You wonder why you went through all the trouble of picking the door lock and slipping inside. The room is mostly bereft not only of anything valuable, but even of character. No trophies, no weapons, no history. What few things there are congregate in the far corner, surrounding themselves with emptiness.
There does appear to be a safe, however, flanked by a mattress and a pot.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You can't get too close. As rank as the rest of the place is, something otherworldly brews in this pot. All you can confirm is that there are warm colors in there.
And substances.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Sweat and who-knows-what-else has baked a brown, vaguely human shape superposed in various positions of sleeping on the mattress. You wonder if it could be the bed of some multi-armed mutant, cursed with profuse perspiration.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It's an ordinary- albeit locked- safe. Though you wouldn't be in here if that presented a problem.
Unfortunately, the sovereign void in the safe mirrors the emptiness of the room. However, there are at least a few things worth taking.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Examine the chamber pot's contents with medical knowledge.

As rank as the rest of the place is, something otherworldly brews in this pot.
Upon closer inspection, you find evidence that a significant portion of the contents are actually vomit with traces of blood. Your best guess would be a peptic ulcer, possibly stress-induced. Whoever stays here, something just isn't sitting right with them.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
When a crimson glow pools beneath you and sears your hands and feet, you slam against the ceiling of the bronze frog. You fall into molten metal. The tank's walls stifle you, and you panic, tossing and turning like an insomniac in hell. As tongues of flame peel away at your arms, legs, and back, the smell of roasting flesh almost makes you hungry.
The doors smash open. You're pulled out undercooked.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A searing red light bleeds through the base of the bronze frog and scalds your hands and feet. On reflex you reach for the corners, awkwardly holding yourself up in the tank. The heat mounts, singeing your hair and skin. As smoke thins the air, you feel everything surrendering to fire.
You're about to pass out when the door flings open and you're ripped from the infernal womb.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The current arrests a scream in your throat and sends your whole body into open revolt. The agony is blinding and it's everywhere. You can't tell if it's your muscles pulling against the restraints in seizure, or if it's just you trying to rip yourself out of your own skin. Either way, the restraints lock you in place.
When the volts die down, that's when you feel it. Your body is crippled with pain. Something maybe broken. And that hurt now rules your senses.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You feel a million iron fingers squeeze under your skin and race across your body: between your hands and shoulders, feet and hips, and one side of your nethers to the other. Your bladder and bowels void.
The spread of the pain overwhelms you. You try to focus it and bite down on the leather, but saliva slips and burns and you bite deep into your tongue.
The current stops. Blood flows down your chin. And the pain lingers.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You draw yourself out of your body and roam the outside. You think of the cold floors of Gyges and the smell of cryo fluid. You imagine the jagged teeth of darkened ruins against overcast sky. You flip through what few memories you have, desperately trying to not feel your skin and muscles tear each other apart.
When the electricity stops, the cultist and the guard are in awe. Somehow you're alive, and nothing feels the same.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The two guards laugh as if you'd told some crass joke.
"Now that would be awful."
"Isn't that what they call Jill?"
"Who?"
"Anyway." He clears his throat. "We welcome your return, brother."
And they let you in.

table.name: encounters
table.column: What the hell are you talking about?

The two guards look at each other.
"Didn't you hear? Password ideas? Damn it. That makes how many today?"
"We need a HR."
"A what?"
"You know. Like on the posters in east wing?"
"Anyway." He clears his throat. "We welcome your return, brother."
And they let you in.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The two guards exchange looks.
"Not a bad idea."
"Must have heard it from Steve."
"Who?"
"Anyway." He clears his throat. "We welcome your return, brother."
And they let you in.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
In the dramatic lighting of lanterns, the asylum seeps with new life in a way that doesn't feel right. The decrepit walls seem to bend in the shadows; the glass shards on the floor glisten like ice; furniture piles together in the corners.
Bright blue swaths of fabric hang from the high ceilings, leading your eyes to the east and west. But footsteps come echoing down from both of them. It's likely too dark for them to see you as anything but an intruder to shoot on sight. The stairs in front of you seem a much better option.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Blue banners flood the northern hallway more than any other place you've seen in the stronghold, twisting and writhing against each other from gusts of wind that shouldn't be. The smell of stagnant air turns thick. Between the dead yet unbroken fluorescents tracking the ceiling, lanterns lead your eye to a central set of doors.
And three cultists.
"What the- A heathen intruder!" They bolt toward you, overtaking you in moments.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
In the lantern-lit darkness of the east wing, shadows dart between the banners like assassins. More than once you stop to make sure you're imagining things. And you're almost glad you do. You find cultists in the open rooms you pass by, standing completely still, swaying, or convulsing on the floor.
You reach a fork.
An auditorium ends the passage to the east, curtained by more blue banners. A passionate sermon seeps through. The words are muffled, but you can't miss the apocalyptic tone.
From all the rooms you've passed in the east wing, only the one from where you came is noteworthy.
To the north is a longer hallway.
West is the foyer, and the west wing beyond.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Talk to the busy Blue Frog in the corner.

You call out 'hello' to the Blue Frog numerous times, but he doesn't respond beyond pausing his head-to-wall routine for half a second.
You give up in the exact moment before he responds with: "I love buttons." Then he tends the wall with his head again.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Realize you don't want to be there, and exit the way you came in.

When the inherent creepiness of sneaking into an abandoned insane asylum taken over by sadistic, religious extremists dawns on you, you turn right around and push at the secret passage.
But it's stuck. Is that by design? Did you miss a latch on the way in?
In any case, you're inside now. And it's staying that way.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Before you leave the room, you take inventory of your things one last time.
Hopefully nobody will spot you and kill you on sight. But from the screams you hear every now and then, that'd almost be asking too much.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Ruin dominates the interior of the Saginaw Mental Institution. Water damage and mold claim the peeling walls; bits of splintered ceiling, grime, and smashed glass occupy every surface; decades of abuse mark the scattered furniture. The place feels like a monstrous, dead giant, an asylum's carcass sprouting a savage temple, and you're standing in its jaws.
Every so often, a far-off scream interrupts the silence.
As well as the scuffing of three cultists, stopping in their tracks.
"What the- A heathen intruder!" They bolt toward you, overtaking you in moments.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Blue Frog banners draw you in as if curtains lifting on a stage. The auditorium swells before your eyes, its walls rounding out into the dark infinity on the other side, its ceilings breaching the heavens of the second floor. Hanging beneath the observation deck that circles the room, lanterns throw shadows far and wide.
At the center, in front of a dome structure mantled by a thousand candles, a man in lush blue robes stands on an examination chair like it's an unfit throne. His voice is like thunder.
"It was the Savior himself," the King cries, "who spoke to our Founder! Who told him of the Return! Who told him to believe! And do we believe, brothers and sisters?"
The crowd of Blue Frogs screams.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go east to the auditorium - caught!

His speech, however, is gradually lost in a swell of murmuring. All around you, cultists in their glaring blue sashes and garments are turning to face you.
"Heathen!" one shouts. "A heathen among the flock!"
You're grabbed roughly by the arms and held fast.
"King! We have an intruder!"
A man beside the King, in a long-beaked mask, says something to him before wading through the crowd towards you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're dragged down a hall by muscular arms, and into a lamp-lit room where a short, pudgy cultist squats on the ground, unmasked. Three frog-shaped sculptures sit around him. Pamphlets and posters litter the floor.
"A new inductee?" says an excited-looking man, some sort of caretaker of the sculptures.
"No time," your escort dismisses. "This one has no hope in this life."
The caretaker seems puzzled.
"Purify him for the next."
His puzzlement melts into glee. "Oh, yes. We can do that..."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You dash across the room and ascend the stairs, placing your feet as lightly as you can on every other step. Up the first flight. Past the landing. Up the second flight. And you're clear.
You find yourself missing the creepy glow of the lanterns, because it's dark up here.
"Run."
You see a smallish figure an arm's length to your left. A smiley face with Xs for eyes adorns the paper bag covering her head. She jumps around you- or through you, you're not sure. But you realize you misunderstood her message.
"Run," she repeats, "or he'll find us!"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go down the east hallway, arms raised.

You step out calmly, your arms high, into the sights of the Blue Frogs coming down the halls. You tell them to wait, that you're a mercenary whose outfit was stolen, that would they please kindly not shoot you, and so on.
But you realize that except for the first part, that conversation is only going on in your head after the gunfire severs your spine and then pokes holes in your face.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go down the west hallway, arms raised.

You step out calmly, your arms high, into the sights of the Blue Frogs coming down the halls. You tell them to wait, that you're a mercenary whose outfit was stolen, that would they please kindly not shoot you, and so on.
But you realize that except for the first part, that conversation is only going on in your head after the gunfire severs your spine and then pokes holes in your face.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Stay to see what she's running from.

Straining to see through the darkness, you see something down the hallway coming around the corner with the slowness of a snail. It looks to be a hunched-over figure.
No. That's a nose. You're seeing a pale head the size of a car, inching its way closer to you.
Its eyes, visibly yellow in the absence of light, seethe with malice. They look at you. And it moves faster.
"Come on, mister!" the girl calls from behind you. "Odo likes chewing skin!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You sprint down the hallway to follow the girl, spurred by a low rumble that begins to shake the building. The light coming from her is the only reason you know where you're going, but you're still just slamming your foot down and hoping it doesn't miss the floor.
You glance behind you. The massive head draws nearer and nearer.
"Over here, mister," the girl whispers.
The two of you duck behind a door. You peek back out. The yellow-eyed head floats by, continuing its sluggish glide down the hallway and around the corner. As it passes, you notice it's missing the back of its head. You can see right through to the spheres of its eyes.
"Phew," she says, after it has passed. "Looks like I win again!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Occasionally, certain entities respond to strong wills, to noble intentions, to courageous displays of fear overcome. But Odo is not one such entity.
As the huge face looms over you, its mouth opens up wide, and you actually get to hear the crunching of your own bones for a little while. Then, you hear nothing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The girl hops to the middle of the room. "My name is Ginny, mister," she says. "Can I help you with something? It's not every day that somebody comes up here. The blue bunnies downstairs don't like it here because they think it's haunted and they never let anyone else in. Isn't that funny?"
You're considering telling her everything you know, about your memory and so on. You wonder what kind of help you could get from her. But before you say anything, she speaks again.
"Okay. Nice to meet you, Mr. Phil! How about we play a game? Then I can help you get you back some of your forgetties. Okay?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Ginny doesn't wait for you to answer before she starts: "Let's go outside. This room is stuffy. Don't worry, though; Odo won't be back for a while."
She skips outside and beckons you.
"Ready?" she asks. "Okay! The game is really simple. All you have to do is help me tell the story. And it starts like this:
"Once upon a time, there was an older man named Adam who worked as..."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Yup," Ginny says. "Adam was a famous athlete, and he was as happy as can be. But one day, he got really scared that somebody would steal his fame."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Yup," Ginny says. "Adam worked as a plant doctor, and he was as happy as can be. But one day, he got really scared that somebody would steal his favorite seed away."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Mhm," says Ginny. "Adam worked as a painter, and he was as happy as can be. But one day, he got really scared that somebody would steal his brushes."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Yup," Ginny says. "Adam worked as a doctor, and he was as happy as can be. But one day, he got really scared that somebody would steal his stuffyscope."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Yup," Ginny says. "Adam worked as an electrician, and he was as happy as can be. But one day, he got really scared that somebody would steal his toolbox."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Yup," Ginny says. "Adam worked as a mechanic, and he was as happy as can be. But one day, he got really scared that somebody would steal his hammer."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Ginny skips down the dark hallway, innocently peeking into the rooms like there isn't a brown paper bag covering her head. She goes on:
"Adam was so scared of losing it that he knew he had to do something to protect what was important to him. So he decided to..."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Set a trap for the thief.
"Yup," says Ginny. "He decided to lay a bunch of traps around it so that the thief would get hurt if they came too close."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hire people to protect it for him.
"Mhm," says Ginny. "He decided to hire a bunch of big and scary people to protect it from the thief."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Yup," says Ginny. "He decided to lock it up in a big, huge safe that the thief wouldn't be able to get in to."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Look far and wide for the thief.
"Yup," says Ginny. "He decided to look far and wide every day for the thief so he could see when they were coming."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Find out who the thief could be.
"Yup," says Ginny. "He decided to look up everyone who wanted it so that he could figure out who the thief was."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Install a security system around it.
"Yup," says Ginny. "He decided to put up a complicated compooper thingy so that the thief wouldn't be able to get to it without letting him know."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Yup," says Ginny. "He decided to take it and go into hiding so that the thief couldn't find either of them."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Ginny stands on one leg and hops around the corner. You catch up to her only to see that she's at the far end of the hallway. You hurry towards her before you lose the light.
"But that still wasn't enough. Adam still saw ways the thief could come and take it away from him, and he became more and more scared that that would happen.
Finally, Adam decided it was enough. He had to be very serious if he wanted to keep it away from the thief. So he started to round people up and..."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Yup," Ginny says. "Adam decided that to solve the problem of the thief, he had to starve everyone so that everyone would be too busy stealing other things to steal what he really liked."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Yup," Ginny says. "Adam decided that to solve the problem of the thief, he had to shoot everyone who knew about what he really liked, so that no one would know there was anything to steal."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Yup," Ginny says. "Adam decided that to solve the problem of the thief, he had to cut and stab everyone who knew about what he really liked, so that no one would know there was anything to steal."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Yup," Ginny says. "Adam decided that to solve the problem of the thief, he had to beat and punch and kick everyone who knew about what he really liked, so that no one would know there was anything to steal."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Yup," Ginny says. "Adam decided that to solve the problem of the thief, he had to scare everyone who knew about what he really liked, so that no one else would find out there was anything to steal."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Mhm," Ginny says. "Adam decided that to solve the problem of the thief, he had to be able to change what people knew and thought. So he started spreading lie after lie until no one knew there was anything to steal."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Ginny stops. "And then he lived unhappily for a little while longer."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Ginny lets out a child's laugh that, as it echoes around the second floor, turns heavier and deeper until it sounds like the voice of a living abyss.
"That was fun!" she cries. "I'm so glad you came up to play with me. Let me give you a little present."
Ginny dips down through the floor, leaving you in the darkness. Within seconds, she resurfaces and says: "Here you go!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Ginny scratches the top of the paper bag on her head. Her nails are long and chipped.
"Well," she says, "That was a little boring. But it's okay. At least you played, right?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Now let's see if we can't help you remember a bit about who you are, Mr. Phil. Have a seat!"
You and Ginny sit in the middle of the walkway. She owns this place, you realize. It's her palace. Maybe it's her prison, too.
She lifts a finger and holds it steady in front of you. It begins to pulse with a white light.
"Just relax," she says in a voice that gradually deepens into adulthood, "and listen to my voice. Look into the light. Let it lull you to a safe place."
Your heart rate has been abnormal for the entire walk. But here...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
White clouds blurring. Decay waning. Rising murmurs from the silent halls.
Saginaw. A lifetime ago. Alive with patients and staff.
The entrance foyer. A reception desk. Nurses with hair extensions and powdered noses. A man to the left in a dress shirt under a blue hoodie. A man signing pre-admission papers for patient Philip Kindred. A man signing as Bertrand Farris. A man looking up. A man without a face.
White clouds again. Teeth on leather. Pain and everything. Pain and nothing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As your senses return, you can't help being startled by the figure in front of you. Ginny is no longer a little girl, but a gangly, grown woman with dirt-smeared limbs and scraggly black hair twisting out from under the brown paper bag still on her head. Where a smiley face was drawn, a sad face has replaced it.
"I'm sorry that didn't help much, Mr. Phil," the grown Ginny says. "But maybe it's for the best."
She stands and looks down at her arms and dress. Then she seems to look up over your head. You turn around. Odo is seconds away.
The last thing you hear is Ginny's child-like voice: "Sometimes it's better to forget."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A second later, you find yourself in the woods outside Saginaw. Your eyes can still spot the building, humming with soft light.
"I really like your necklace," Ginny's voice says. "The Anishinabe make really great crafts, don't they!"
Somehow you don't think you'll ever hear her again.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A second later, you find yourself in the woods outside Saginaw. Your eyes can still spot the building, humming with soft light.
Somehow you don't think you'll ever see her again.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You struggle to see in the dark cistern, and finally spot the opening far above. Some sort of white powder clouds your mask and the air.
The good news is that your mask is probably doing its job.
The bad news? Everywhere else on your body is starting to ache. Even your hands are starting to blister and sting.
If feels as if every cell in your body is disintegrating as you writhe in pain and darkness, your muffled screams echoing up the smooth-walled cistern...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Stumbled into patch of black mold

Stumbled into a patch of black mold.
You were hoping to find a hidden treasure, but that old cupboard turned out to be a haven for toxic black mold.
You're certain some was kicked up by your disturbance, but maybe you avoided inhaling too much.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
There is little left to explore in this burnt, toxic swamp. This ruin, however, looks like it might have a few caches that escaped complete destruction.
Getting to them, however, is going to be a trick. Rubble threatens to collapse at the slightest touch, and caustic liquid pools here and there.
The good news? You suspect little scavenging competition in this blasted swamp.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You've stumbled across a crash site.
It looks like a hover truck went down here, crashing through trees and dirt, and scattering it nearby.
There's been a lot of damage in the impact and subsequent fire, but you may find some useful stuff in the wreckage.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You've stumbled across a crash site.
It looks like part of a hover convoy went down here. Vehicle wreckage and containers are spread over the crash site, and peek out of the swamp.
Fire, corrosion, and the crash have taken their toll, but you're betting few scavengers have been through this dismal swamp yet, so the pickings may be good.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The King speaks without looking at you.
"The time for my purpose has come," he trudges onward.
"Go. You best be far away from here and me."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
He seems oblivious to your presence now, showing neither signs of interest nor irritation.
Just pure focus on the road ahead.

table.name: encounters
table.column: King/Queen loots and destroys Clearbone Valley
<us> is looting and destroying Clearbone Valley.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The stairs creak loudly beneath your weight, as if to raise an alarm against a suspected intruder. You ignore your unwelcome. The landing leads you on to an airtight metal door. You peer through the glass window, but it's completely dark inside.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you reach for the door, you hear a click, and the door swings open effortlessly.
When you enter the room, the air changes. Where the house breathes in from its lush environment, you can taste the metal of ventilation fans in here. White lights blast on.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Something is very wrong.
In the distance, you see smoke rising. And when you reach its source, the fires are still puttering out. There isn't a soul in sight.
A bunker sits in a hillside, exhaling smoke from its hatch. Red handprints mark the walls just inside. A small trail of blood leads nowhere.
Someone's been here. And it didn't go very well. You doubt there's much for you to take.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You reach for the door, but it doesn't budge. Worse, there appears to be nothing to work with here. No latch, keyhole, keypad, or other mechanism.
You spend several minutes searching the room, under picture frames, behind studs, under shelves. But nothing presents itself.
You briefly consider trying to open it by force, but you suspect this room may be the strongest part of this bunker.
Dejected, you make your way back upstairs.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You find yourself running out of reasons to continue intruding on the family. You make your way back outside, quiet and without pretense of farewells. You don't belong here. Or maybe this place doesn't belong in the world you've seen outside it.
Paul catches you at the gates.
"Hey, wait," he calls out. "Tell me one thing: was my Dad really a good guy?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Following the directions in the file, you reach a family of hills concealing the valley from the outside world.
You see no errant campsites, no traces of industry, and no buildings aspiring to glean all the attention.
Into this sanctuary, you tread an unbeaten path down through dewy grass and scented trees, following the bends of the ravine.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Eli has reached the DMC, and wants to make a deal.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
This doesn't look good.
Approaching the gates, the usual line-up is replaced by a crowd of agitated people. Even air traffic is being turned away or intercepted.
Up above, the massive signs read: "Health Alert: Human infections with Blue Rot. No visitors during mandatory quarantine."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Liza speaks without looking at you.
"Your service to us will be remembered, but you can no longer be one of us. The fallout from your disloyalty, even to a traitor, is yours alone to reap."
She continues trudging on.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You look at the pages from the Blue Frog book. Two of three are pure drivel. On the third, however, is an old drawing.
Within the solid blue rectangle bounding a frog shape, a figure '5' forms a tattered void in the coloring. Through it, you confirm that it's your discharge form from Saginaw. You make out one item under admitted belongings: 'Warding Talisman, Anishinabe Tribe.'

table.name: encounters
table.column: Set your jaw, and show that bastard what "tough" means.

Every fiber in your body snaps taut, and your senses are pushed aside in a wave of pain.
The roar of onlookers sinks into a watery sound, your vision flashes patterns of red. Your jaw clenches with such force that it feels as if your teeth may split. It seems impossible for such a piercing pain to exist so uniformly across your body.
In your last moments of resistance, the straining stops. You're freed from the table, but collapse in a shaking heap. When you look up again, cultists are dragging the unconscious Bishop away.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The rags turn thick and heavy on your face, and it's almost impossible not to gag. The water pounds down again and again, trickling in through your nose. You swallow through the cloth just to clear a breath, and another downpour comes. You tell yourself to keep fighting. And you do. You tread the very doorstep of drowning for as long as you can.
In your last moments of resistance, the water stops. You're freed from the table in time to throw up until you start dry-heaving. When you look up again, cultists are dragging the unconscious Bishop away.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The cheers run wild. They loved the Trial. They loved each second so much that they're the last to see the King fall to the ground, and a woman rush to help him.
"Liza," you hear him gasp. The auditorium blurs and wobbles while you're removed from the room.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You stop dead in your tracks when a scattering shadow appears before you, resolving its formlessness from thin air, making and unmaking itself along its fringes. Below a pale mask on what looks like its head, a bronze light burns. And there is fury in the light.
With a movement no human body could make, the wraith hurls something at you, then vanishes. You nearly fall back at the force, but manage to stay upright.
You look down. It's a crumpled gas mask with a broken beak.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The Queen's Help II - no hypno

Liza leads you to the north wing, through a set of decorated doors and into a barren room. She shuts the door behind you.
"Philip Kindred," she muses. "Well, it doesn't matter. The Blue Frog doesn't need a prophesied savior anymore; I'll make sure of it when I destroy the old order. Still, a deal's a deal."
Liza opens the Blue Frog cult's holy book and tears out its last few pages.
"Take these. They're what's left of your patient files, and we won't need them anymore. Now come on; there's one last thing you need to hear."
You walk with Liza back to the auditorium, folding the loose pages under your clothes. She ascends the central platform, poised to address her flock.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You check your items before moving on.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're halfway up the stairs to the second floor, where an unnatural girl's voice has warned you to stop.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Holding your giizhik stick out like a torch, you proceed up the remaining stairs. The scent of cedar smoke dissolves your anxiety some, and the chill has abated.
"Cool!" you hear the girl again. This time, the abysmal undertone is gone. "I didn't know you had that trick. You're pretty smart!"
You finally see her. She's a fairly unremarkable girl, save for a paper bag over her head with Xs for eyes.
That, and the fact that this seems like a terrible place for little girls to hang out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Enter the house at Seven Gables.

You climb the few steps to the front door, and realize it's been forced open just enough to let a person through.
Taking a deep breath, you press through.
You're on a landing between floors, and stairs go to the main floor on your left, and to the basement on your right. You have a slight uneasiness about this place.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The downstairs is disappointing, and mostly a graveyard of old refuse.
Checking through the dryer husk and the few waterlogged boxes, there doesn't appear to be anything of value.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Leave the house at Seven Gables.

You reach the barricaded front door, and start squeezing your way back outside. You're caught for a moment, but finally unwedge yourself and stumble down the steps, onto wet, peaty ground.
The house lay quiet behind you, no sign of anything beyond the door.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Climbing over debris up the stairs, you reach a T intersection, with the living room opening up to your right. There is a musty smell up here, with a faint, sickening sweetness.
Across the living room, you see a hutch surrounded by broken dishes. And atop it, a silver urn.
You cross the moldy room to the hutch, retrieve the urn, and look closely at it. Doesn't seem like much, but to each there is a treasure.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're upstairs again, and can see the familiar, musty living room from which you saw the urn. Not much there.
A hallway extends to the left.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you approach the end of the darkened hallway, there are doorways on either side.
To the left are piles of twisted rags and cardboard. Unfortunately, the only other exit is a window with a sheet of sturdy plywood over it, studded with countless nails.
You turn to check the other room.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A silhouette startles you, but you soon realize it's not going anywhere.
It's slumped over on a dilapidated bed, facing the door you just came through. There is a shadow of fine soil around it, where flesh has fallen off and rotted on the old sheets, and a burlap sack over its head.
Beyond it, on the opposite wall, a window shrouded in cheap faded curtains and criss-crossed by planks of wood.
Nothing moves, however, and the stillness is making you nervous.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Steeling your nerves, you tentatively reach for the burlap sack over the corpse's head. Though it looks tightly wound around his neck, it comes off with relative ease.
The head beneath is a hideous sight to behold, with uneven rot where the sack touched the flesh.
The sack itself is rough, dry, and has eye holes cut into it. Thick twine is threaded through the opening like a drawstring.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Before long, your nose and lungs begin to burn, and a heat washes over you like sun on burned skin.
It's your giizhik stick, and it is radiating blinding pain.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You rummage through your things, looking for a way to stop the pain.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Get back to what you were doing.

Finally! Relief!
You return to what you were doing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Before long, your nose and lungs begin to burn, and a heat washes over you like sun on burned skin.
It's your giizhik stick, and it is radiating blinding pain.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Enter the house at Seven Gables.

You climb the few steps to the front door, and realize it's been forced open just enough to let a person through.
Taking a deep breath, you gather your courage and press through.
This time, something cold and damp grips your leading arm, and pulls hard. You feel your body slam against the door jamb, and you start slipping through to the inside.
As your head nears the opening, another grip chokes you violently, sending shooting pains behind your ears and waves of red across your vision.
Something breaks inside you...

table.name: encounters
table.column: You black out from the pain.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go west through the gated doors.

You step back into the records room, and your blood drains when you see Liza getting to her feet.
"Help!" she screams without pause. "Help, intruder!"
Rollo comes immediately from next door, and you hear footsteps from the halls nearby.
You try to run, but Liza's call has drawn too many cultists into the halls.
"That's him, "she gasps. "He's the one who tried to kill me."
In moments, cultists surround you, and something strikes you on your back, knocking you to the floor. The blows rain fast and hard after that.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Look through the boxes of files.

You shuffle through box after box, patient files comprising most of the shelves' contents, grouped alphabetically. You find the As, the Gs, the Ws. However, the Ks are missing, as are the Bs and Ss. Whatever happened to the "Philip Kindred" file, it isn't here.
A box sitting alone on a shelf, its surface black as night, catches your attention. You find billing information inside it for certain patients who received "radical treatment". Many of those costs were paid for in full by PharmaCon, despite- or perhaps because of- the staggering line of zeroes fattening them up.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A whisper snaps your attention from the ledger, and a group of shocked-looking cultists has assembled at the door.
Their expressions transition into grim determination, however, as they pile into the room.
In moments, cultists surround you, and something strikes you on your back, knocking you to the floor. The blows rain fast and hard after that.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go west through the gated doors.
You step back into the records room, where you hid Liza's body.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"What exactly does this challenge entail?" you ask.
She takes a breath before answering. "It won't be easy," she admits. "It basically amounts to a pissing match in machismo."
You furrow your brow, inquisitively.
"You and the bishop compete to see who can endure more pain."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
She seems genuinely disappointed.
"Oh, well. I guess you can't always get what you want. But that's fine, then. Good luck finding whatever it is you're looking for. I'll be right here if you change your mind." She sits back down and gazes at the mural of the frog.
You turn, and hear her movements. Instinct tells you to duck just in time to miss a thrown blade.
Using your lowered stance, you launch towards her.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go down the east hallway, and hope your disguise holds.

Stepping around the corner, you encounter the owners of the aforementioned footsteps: three cultists striding down the hall.
Upon seeing you, the middle one nods. "Purity brings its light in pain." His two buddies mumble hurriedly to echo.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go down the west hallway, and hope your disguise holds.

Stepping around the corner, you encounter the owners of the aforementioned footsteps: two cultists are having a hushed discussion.
Upon seeing you, they straighten up and turn mute, nodding as they go. It's not until you turn the corner out of sight that their whispers renew.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go down the east hallway, and hope your disguise holds.

Stepping around the corner, you encounter the owners of the aforementioned footsteps: three cultists striding down the hall.
Upon seeing you, all three nod and make way for you, closing rank again after you pass.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Trying to look as innocuous as possible, you smile and nod, then hurry on your way.
They've stopped walking, though.
A few steps later, and the trio is in tow, gaining speed behind you as you quicken your pace.
When you reach the doors at the hall's end, it's nearly a footrace. You push through the doors, and stumble into what has to be the largest gathering of Blue Frogs in existence.
Your interruption stops a sermon in progress, and a sea of blue sashes turn to you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Repeating their words, they seem appeased and continue their walk past you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The central cultist stops, his eyes glaring at you through his gas mask. His two cohorts snap to attention, looking to him for cues.
"Have you forgotten your rites, brother?!" His voice booms, even from within the mask.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"NO!" his voice shatters into a gurgling fury. "No! You must be reeducated!"
The two supplicants jump you, and wrestle you to the ground, where your garments are rent from your back.
Drawing his wiry arm way back, he thrashes you with a barbed implement. Skin is flayed and torn with each stroke, and radiating pain shoots across your back.
Others enter the hall, and are transfixed by the proceedings, chanting and cheering the righteous purification...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Our creed is what gives us strength and protection!" he booms. "Don't you forget it!"
He resumes his stride, with supplicants in tow.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Patient Ewing, Meredith Age 26, graduate student of Sumero-Akkadian cuneiform studies at Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago
- Uncharacteristic decrease in school performance, frequent truancy, social withdrawal. - Patient exhibiting impairment in reality testing. - Speech is distracted. Periods of extreme agitation accompanied by obscure speech. - Behavior considerably influenced by delusions and hallucinations. - Hallucinations focus on black apparition with white face appearing at her window, and conspiring with hospital staff. - Unresponsive to Chlorpromazine and Haloperidol antipsychotics. - Suggest Clozapine followed by weekly blood tests.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Return to Saginaw, Blue Frogs destroyed and looted
Saginaw has nothing left now but rotting human meat and crumbling walls.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Return to Saginaw, Blue Frogs destroyed

What once was a church is now a graveyard. Where vigilant blue sentries once stood vigil, crows and other carrion scavengers are what greet you now.
Blue Rot has swept through Saginaw and made it a tomb.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You're unsure what spirits may linger in this place, but you decide they're not worth upsetting.

table.name: encounters
table.column: If not you, then someone else will clean this place out. Better get started.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Return to Saginaw, Ginny Stops Him

On the silent roads to Saginaw, you dart behind one overturned car to the next, just in case the place is still occupied. But you only get close enough to see the asylum's name plaque before something stops you in your tracks.
"Don't come back here, mister," cries the voice of a little girl you can't see. "I won't let you."
A force is stopping you from taking another step closer. Seems like she means it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Return to Saginaw, Blue Frogs dying

You check in on Saginaw, interested to see how things are developing.
But something's different. The King has gone, and with him, the fire. The direction.
Saginaw now has a faint whiff of decline and despair. You still see signs of activity, but there are also signs of death. Bodies, consumed by the eponymous Rot, are starting to collect. Flagellations have escalated in futile attempts to "pain the disease away".
You decide to give this place a wide berth during its death throes.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
On the roads to Saginaw, you dart behind one overturned car to the next, just in case.
And well you did. Saginaw, if a church before, is now a fortress. A citadel.
A newfound fervor has swept through the institution; cries of torture have swelled; and the sentries look meaner than ever.
Whatever happened, the beast in Saginaw has awakened, and you decide to give it a wide berth.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Returning to Saginaw, it's still an imposing fortress. The walls still tower, the bars still criss-cross windows, and the gatehouse is still manned.
However, you see subtle changes marking the Queen's reign. The Lily has made its way into more imagery, the atmosphere of torture is no longer evident, even the sentries seem more tasked with maintaining order than an imposing front.
That, however, doesn't mean you're more welcome.
"Halt, exile," one says, sternly. "Purity is loyalty, and your deeds are not forgotten."
The message is pretty clear. This is no place for you anymore.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
She seems oblivious to your presence now, showing neither signs of interest nor irritation.
Just pure focus on the road ahead.

table.name: encounters
table.column: On second thought, let's not infiltrate a torture-happy cult stronghold.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Look in King Eli's address book.

The address book is primarily a list of notes on other cultists. While some are surely juicy, few offer any actionable info.
However, one entry stands out from the others:
Clearbone Valley
No names are listed, just a location. You make note of its direction relative to where you are.

table.name: encounters
table.column: As you round a corner, you nearly miss it: a reinforced door inset into a brush-covered slope nearby. With the exception of a white button next to the door, there are no other signs of life nearby.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
An intercom comes on, and you hear a woman's voice.
"Hello?" she asks. "Oh. You must be..."
And just like that, a buzzing noise is followed by the door opening a little bit. You pull it open and walk to the hall. At the other end, a woman, a teenage girl, and a boy emerge.
"Is it true?" the woman asks you as you approach. "It is, isn't it."
Immediately the girl and boy, sullen, go back inside.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You get no response from whoever it is in the compound, no matter how many times you press the button. Clearly you failed some test. Could there be a way to pass it?
You consider your options as you make your way out of the valley, vowing to come back one day.
If you feel like it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You rummage through your things before proceeding.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide to leave Clearbone Valley behind.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You sit down on a bench in the hall. The woman, Samantha, sits across from you. She fights back tears a few moments before speaking.
"Elias told us this day would come," she begins. "'One day, it won't be me at those gates,' he'd tell me. Of course you say these things, given how everything is right now. But I just never thought so soon..."
You feel like an intruder on her grief. Even though you came for a reason, you wonder if talking to her might be of some help.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"You know, we met out in the wilderness," she replies. "Some wreck of a small town. I was seconds away from walking into a building when he, a strange man in a strange-looking gas mask, stopped me and bet me that the place would collapse before we finished dinner. I took him up on it. 'Lo and behold,' he said."
You get the sense she is living out that moment again right in front of you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
She quickly regains her composure. "Now what am I doing going on and on like that. I'm sorry. Elias told me what to look for when he-"
She continues, "when someone else came by. You'll see the stairs to the basement right when you come in the door. There'll be little paintings on the wall. Little frogs. Just follow them down."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Erin will be all right; she's a tough one," Samantha says. "She's probably in the back now cutting firewood."
"It's her brother I'm worried about. There was a little bit of tension there. I mean it wasn't serious. Fathers and sons, and all. But they could've used one more time to talk it out. They loved each other, Elias and Paul. Something else just got in the way."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Elias was a bit of a strange man, I admit," Samantha says. "But he was good to us, and he was always so happy to see us. He could only come home once or twice a month, and for no more than a day or two at a time. But when he was here, he was really here, you know? And he never took his work home with him."
She pauses. "Then again, why would he? Being a medicine courier hardly seems that taxing."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Samantha looks at you, perplexed. "Is that a kind of poisonous critter?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Go on in," Samantha says. "I have to get dinner started anyway."
Grief builds up like lead in her movements. That she hasn't just given up altogether is a good sign. Or could she be waiting until there aren't any guests in the house to let herself feel the loss?
You enter the house.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You excuse yourself, and make your way back to the door.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go to the main living space.

A cozy little living space opens up in front of you, awash in warm light from the wall lamps. Picture frames adorn the walls accompanied by the odd sorts of ornaments you'd expect to find: an owl sculpture, deer antlers, a wolf pelt. Nothing in the house is blue.
Ahead, a stairwell leads down into a sublevel. Framed pictures of frogs descend from the landing.
A living area extends to your left. You see the teenage boy, Paul, sitting there.
Past the stairwell you see a door leading to a back room, where the girl, Erin, is cutting firewood.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The label reads: "YPC, 020.6". The glass container sits inlaid on a pedestal, secured and cushioned on all sides. Glass vials fill its volume, each filled to the brim with a clear fluid.
Etched to the side of the pedestal, you see the word: "BIOHAZARD".

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A waft of sawdust washes over you as you step into the back. Erin manages a smile.
"Hello, sir," she says. "Don't mind us. We know how important Dad's work was, delivering that medicine to the poor folk outside the cities and out in the wilderness. Or is there something I can help you with?"
This far away from all the ugliness outside, you doubt there is anything she can do. And it's a good thing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Paul visibly recoils when you enter the living room.
"What do you want?" he asks as he tries to casually wipe under his eyes and steady a breaking voice.
And for the life of you, you don't know. Whatever it is you intend to do here, you find no reason to violate the wishes of a child trying to grieve invisibly.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"My old man?" Paul scoffs. "You probably knew him better than I did. He probably liked you better than he liked me." He recoils further, drawing his crossed arms in closer. "Why are you even here? The stuff is downstairs. Can't miss it."
He says nothing for a while and you're ready to leave him alone when he speaks up. "Hey, did-did you know him? Know what he was-no, forget it."
The passing interest vanishes in an instant.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Erin holds the hatchet still for a moment. "Dad was a good man. A good father. I've learned a lot from him. And I'm going to miss him." Her smile is gone. "Sorry. I have a lot of work to do," she says. And she continues splitting logs of wood.
As you leave, you see the handmade necklace she's wearing, painted a bright baby blue.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A white chamber extends before you, divided in the middle between barrels on one side, and a glass container on the other.
An incinerator occupies the far wall.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Place a vial into the incinerator.

You carry the container to the incinerator. With some satisfaction, you watch the fires break apart the glass and burn away the liquid within. The flames rise pale beyond the glass. In minutes, there is nothing but ash.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The barrels read: "YpcV". All are in pristine condition. They're quite heavy, but you could move them around on a sled or a cart.
You suddenly realize what kind of treasure trove the family is sitting on. The entirety of these stores is likely worth a fortune if you sell it off bit by bit, with some effort. But they could also do a lot of good in the right hands, unabated by your greed.
You have some thinking to do.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The barrels read: "YpcV". All are in pristine condition. They're quite heavy, but you could move them around on a sled or a cart.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell him that Elias was a good man.

He seems to take what you say with a grain of salt. He nods in silent thanks. As he returns to his home and family, you see a shadow of his mother's burden cross him.
You leave the valley, and the world that greets you is somehow more bleak than you remember.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell him that Elias was the leader of a bloodthirsty cult.

Paul stares blankly at you for a while, unsure what to make of it. The blunt truth, you decide, has its own curative effects. Whatever pain it causes, it's for the best.
A grin spreads across Paul's lips. "Awesome," he says darkly.
You leave the valley. Everywhere you look, you see bright blue shrouds billowing in the wind.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell him that nobody is exactly who they say they are.

His quickness in accepting what you say makes you think he might have suspected as much already. Maybe that makes both you and he cynics. But all you had intended was to say an honest thing that's as true now as it's ever been.
You leave the valley and all its beauty behind, wondering how long it will last before the rest of the world finds it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You turn away, trying to put this place behind you.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Though you decide to try your luck, approaching the charred remains of the bunker diminish your hope. You find a few things here and there outside the dominion of the flame.
When you're done, you leave the compound to let the elements reclaim it. You hurry before you get another look at the scorched beam hanging out from where the doorstep used to be. Maybe what you saw on it wasn't a small shoe.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You make your way back outside quietly, so as not to disturb any more than you already have.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You stand at the gates of the compound, feeling justified for imposing on the family trying to live out an impossibly simple life. You press the button, a moment passes, and the door clicks open.
Inside, the door is ajar, but no one is there to greet you. Not that you expected anything more. You head straight downstairs.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As the King of the Blue Frog cult lies dead at your feet, a blast of pallid light infests and dries the air with a sudden roar. You feel something coming from behind you. And you turn.
A surge of blackest shadow twists out of itself before you, swelling with such intensity that shards of darkness are shed from its being. A bone-white mask with hollow eyes crowns the being. An eerie yellow light glows beneath it, rumbling with rage.
An instant later, it folds upon itself and disappears.
When you can see your surroundings again, you find the King's body unmoved. A few feet away, a gas mask is torn in half, right down its beak.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
All semblance of civility is gone when you approach Hatter's office now.
When the guard sees you approaching, he calls out as if to save you the trouble of getting any closer.
"Time to find a new gig, buddy. Hatter ain't interested in rubble scum like you."
He positions himself in front of the intercom to punctuate his warning.
Looks like this bridge has been burned.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Try to broker a deal for the Blue Rot materials.

The junk market might pay a nominal fee for biotech, but this sort of thing goes much further in the right hands.
Fortunately, you know just such a set of hands.
Once the guard has helped you get situated in the elevator, you begin the trundling passage to the upper floors.
Stepping off the lift, Hatter's already eyeing you up, to see what this is all about.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You turn the drum so the label faces him. He rises from his desk, and takes a closer look, noting the label, seals, and looking for damage.
"Is this what I think?" His eyes stay fixed on it.
You nod.
He makes a clicking noise with pursed lips, considering it a moment longer. Then, he returns to his desk, but remains standing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You furnish the small vial, and place it on his wooden desk. Hatter leans forward, plucks it delicately from the desktop, and turns it over in his hands.
"Is this what I think?" His eyes stay fixed on it.
You nod.
He makes a clicking noise with pursed lips, considering it a moment longer. Then, he places it firmly down again.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You furnish the small vial, and place it on his wooden desk. Hatter leans forward, plucks it delicately from the desktop, and turns it over in his hands.
"That's an interesting find." His eyes stay fixed on it. "Can't say I know many folks looking to buy such a sample. But I could probably move it eventually. And it's small enough not to be a burden."
He puts it down, and looks up at you.
"I could give you two fifty for it."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Suddenly getting cold feet, you press the button labeled "Lobby", and the cage reverses direction.
A tingling heat of embarrassment washes up your ears and head as you notice Hatter glaring at you from across the room.
At street level, the guard is speaking into the intercom. He looks at you, then turns back to the speaker.
"Yes, sir."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Offer to sell both the drum and the vial.

You turn the drum so the label faces him. Then, you place the vial on top, as if it were a maraschino.
He rises from his desk, and takes a closer look, noting the labels, seals, and looking for damage.
"Huh," he exhales in an uncharacteristically frank surprise.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hatter had a feeling about PK

"I had a feeling about this one," he says of you, apparently to the guards in the room. Then, looking at you, "I know a good resource when I see one."
"How much?" he says, settling back into his chair.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "How much?" he says, settling back into his chair.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Hoooo!" he exclaims, chuckling. The guards even break a smile. "You think there's a buyer out there for that?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I might be able to get a thousand for it," he begins. "But I'd want some of that for myself."
He leans forward again. "How about six hundred?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Hatter gives it a few moments thought, then nods.
"I think we can do that."
Hatter has one of his guards settle the debt, then begins assembling some of his things.
"I have some business to attend to, however, so please excuse me."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You agree, and Hatter has one of his guards settle the debt.
"It's a pleasure doing business, Mr. Kindred."
He begins assembling some of his things. "I have some business to attend to, however, so please excuse me."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You put your foot down, and Hatter looks at you for several seconds.
"I get the feeling negotiation isn't your strong suit," he says. "I can offer six fifty. Otherwise, I've got things to do."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"You've done this before, then." Hatter smiles. "I'll tell you what. Seven fifty. I'll meet you a little over halfway."
You agree, and Hatter has one of his guards settle the debt.
He begins assembling some of his things. "I have some business to attend to, however, so please excuse me."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Well," he resumes what he was doing, "I wish you luck finding your buyer."
The elevator rattles open.
"I have some business to attend to, however, so 'good day' to you."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Glad we could make an arrangement," he says.
"Elon," he speaks to a guard, "would you settle our account with Mr. Kindred, please?"
He begins assembling some of his things. "I have some business to attend to, however, so please excuse me."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hatter's guard informs you that Hatter's on important business right now, and isn't expected back soon.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"No," you pause for effect. "I think there are *millions* of buyers out there for that."
Hatter's smiling. "I really should learn to stop being surprised by you, Kindred."
"Elon," he speaks to a guard, "would you settle our account with Mr. Kindred, please?"
He begins assembling some of his things. "As you might imagine, I have some business to attend to now. So please excuse me."
He shakes your hand. "Good day."

table.name: encounters
table.column: I know what I've got here.

Hatter's nodding before you finish. "Yes, I think we both know what you've got."
He taps the vial. "However, what you don't have is a buyer lined up. And having the right connections is an investment I've paid for over time."
He looks up at you. "I'll tell you what. Thirty-five. You'd get more placing it into the right buyer's hands yourself. *But*," he emphasizes, "then you'd have to know who they are, and have the means to reach them."
"The way I see it, that'd end up costing you the difference anyway."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Glad we could make an arrangement," he says.
"Elon," he speaks to a guard, "would you settle our account with Mr. Kindred, please?"
He begins assembling some of his things. "I have some business to attend to, however, so please excuse me."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hatter chuckles. "Well, that is optimistic, I'll give you that."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Well," he resumes what he was doing, "I wish you luck finding your buyer."
The elevator rattles open.
"I have some business to attend to, however, so 'good day' to you."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You agree, and Hatter has one of his guards settle the debt.
"It's a pleasure doing business, Mr. Kindred."
He begins assembling some of his things. "I have some business to attend to, however, so please excuse me."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"You've done this before, then." Hatter smiles. "I'll tell you what. Three fifty. I'll meet you a little over halfway."
You agree, and Hatter has one of his guards settle the debt.
He begins assembling some of his things. "I have some business to attend to, however, so please excuse me."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hatter had a feeling about PK

"I had a feeling about this one," he says of you, apparently to the guards in the room. Then, looking at you, "I know a good resource when I see one."
"How much?" he says, leaning on his desk.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "How much?" he says, leaning on his desk.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Hoooo!" he exclaims, chuckling. The guards even break a smile. "You think there's a buyer out there for that?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Hatter gives it a few moments thought, then nods.
"I think we can do that."
Hatter has one of his guards settle the debt, then begins assembling some of his things.
"I have some business to attend to, however, so please excuse me."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I might be able to get five grand for it," he begins. "But I'd want some of that for myself."
He leans forward again. "How about thirty-five?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hatter chuckles. "Well, that is optimistic, I'll give you that."

table.name: encounters
table.column: I know what I've got here.

Hatter's nodding before you finish. "Yes, I think we both know what you've got."
He points at the drum. "However, what you don't have is a buyer lined up. And having the right connections is an investment I've paid for over time."
He looks at you. "I'll tell you what. Sixty-five. You'd get more placing it into the right buyer's hands yourself. *But*," he emphasizes, "then you'd have to know who they are, and have the means to reach them."
"The way I see it, that'd end up costing you the difference anyway."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"No," you pause for effect. "I think there are *millions* of buyers out there for that."
Hatter's smiling. "I really should learn to stop being surprised by you, Kindred."
"Elon," he speaks to a guard, "would you settle our account with Mr. Kindred, please?"
He begins assembling some of his things. "As you might imagine, I have some business to attend to now. So please excuse me."
He shakes your hand. "Good day."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Glad we could make an arrangement," he says.
"Elon," he speaks to a guard, "would you settle our account with Mr. Kindred, please?"
He begins assembling some of his things. "I have some business to attend to, however, so please excuse me."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You put your foot down, and Hatter looks at you for several seconds.
"I get the feeling negotiation isn't your strong suit," he says. "I can offer thirty-seven fifty. Otherwise, I've got things to do."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You agree, and Hatter has one of his guards settle the debt.
"It's a pleasure doing business, Mr. Kindred."
He begins assembling some of his things. "I have some business to attend to, however, so please excuse me."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"You've done this before, then." Hatter smiles. "I'll tell you what. Four grand. I'll meet you halfway."
You agree, and Hatter has one of his guards settle the debt.
He begins assembling some of his things. "I have some business to attend to, however, so please excuse me."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Glad we could make an arrangement," he says.
"Elon," he speaks to a guard, "would you settle our account with Mr. Kindred, please?"
He begins assembling some of his things. "I have some business to attend to, however, so please excuse me."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"This is basically a ready-made clinic," you offer. "Literally no production. Just distribution."
"Yeah, no kidding, huh?" Hatter still seems surprised. He steps toward his desk, and rests against it.
"And a bigger outfit," you continue, "could probably ride this drum until they reverse-engineered it from samples."
You pause a moment, to let that sink in.
"I think we're looking at franchise-level customers," you finish.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Know any doctors?" you half-joke.
"Yeah, no kidding, huh?" Hatter still seems surprised. He steps toward his desk, and rests against it.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Hatter thinks motionlessly a bit longer, then snaps back to life.
"Okay," he starts. "I think I know where to start." He steps back around his desk, and starts looking something up.
"I think I have a contact that can take this to the next level. I'll need to press a few palms in the DMC, and they'll probably want to come out here to examine the goods."
He pauses to look up. "Can you leave it here?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Well," the wind is visibly gone from his sails.
"In that case, I wish you luck finding your buyer."
The elevator rattles open.
"I have some business to attend to, however, so 'good day' to you."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Excellent. Give me a few days to see what I can negotiate, then meet me back here."
He reaches an open hand over his desk. "You're a rare find, Mr. Kindred. I look forward to doing business with you."
You can't help but feel giddy on the elevator ride down. Could this be it? Could dragging that beast of a miracle cure barrel across the state be your ticket to "normal" life again?
You'll have to survive a week to find out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Return to Hatter after finishing big Blue Rot deal

For the first time you can recall, another client is ushered out to make way for you. Once they're rattling down the old elevator, Hatter breaks the silence.
"I have some good news," he says, clearing some things from his desk.
"Turns out there was a *very* enthusiastic buyer in the DMC. They were skeptical at first, but upon examining the materials for themselves, they made an offer that instant."
"Seriously," he adds. "We're talking cash in hand, and a hover transport on standby."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I'm not sure what they did to clear customs with it, but not our problem."
"*Our* problem," he jests, turning a tablet to face you, "may be what to do with their payment." He indicates a number. "Our not insignificant payment, as you can see."
He turns the tablet back, and starts flipping menus. "I suspect this might change a few things for you, Mr. Kindred. Indeed, it will for me, too."
He has his guards arrange your payment.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Be sure to invest wisely," he concludes. "A windfall like this is a once-in-a-lifetime occurrence."
He extends his hand and shakes yours. "Always a pleasure, Mr. Kindred."
Your elevator ride back to the street feels different, somehow. When you emerge onto the muddy streets of the Sprawl, and turn to the towering DMC walls, they seem less oppressive.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Return to Hatter after being paid for big Blue Rot deal

Hatter's guards treat you differently now. Instead of the stand-offishness of yore, they greet you as if a regular.
"Mr. Kindred," he nods. "Hatter's not in. May not be for a while, in fact. I'll let him know you stopped by, though."
Vacation, perhaps?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Hatter thinks motionlessly a bit longer, then snaps back to life.
"Okay," he starts. "I think I know where to start." He steps back around his desk, and starts looking something up.
"I may have a contact that can work with this. I'll need to meet with a few in the DMC, and they'll probably want to come out here to examine the goods."
He pauses to look up. "Can you leave it here?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Excellent. Give me a few days to see what I can negotiate, then meet me back here."
You can't help but feel giddy on the elevator ride down. Could this be it? Could dragging that beast of a miracle cure barrel across the state be your ticket to "normal" life again?
You'll have to survive a week to find out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Return to Hatter after finishing Blue Rot deal

For the first time you can recall, another client is ushered out to make way for you. Once they're rattling down the old elevator, Hatter breaks the silence.
"I have some good news," he says, clearing some things from his desk.
"Turns out there were a few buyers in the DMC. They were skeptical at first, but upon examining the materials for themselves, they made an offer that instant."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"The best offer turned out to be pretty generous," he says, turning a tablet to face you. He indicates a number. "Our not insignificant payment, as you can see."
He turns the tablet back, and starts flipping menus. "I suspect this might change a few things for you, Mr. Kindred. Not a bad payday, by any standards."
He has his guards arrange your payment.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Be sure to invest wisely," he concludes. "A windfall like this is uncommon, to say the least."
He extends his hand and shakes yours. "Always a pleasure, Mr. Kindred."
