Your elevator ride back to the street feels different, somehow. When you emerge onto the muddy streets of the Sprawl, and turn to the towering DMC walls, they seem less oppressive.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
This doesn't look good.
Approaching the gates, the usual line-up is replaced by a crowd of agitated people. Even air traffic is being turned away or intercepted.
Up above, on the massive signs, it reads "Health Alert: Human infections with Blue Rot have been controlled. Visitation rights to be restored tomorrow."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hatter's guard informs you that Hatter's on important business right now, and won't be back until tomorrow.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use GPS to look up Saginaw
It takes some time acquiring satellites in the crumbling system, but the tablet locates your position, and displays route info. (See minimap.)

table.name: encounters
table.column: Use GPS to look up Saginaw.
It takes some time acquiring satellites in the crumbling system, but the phone locates your position, and displays route info. (See minimap.)

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Ever heard of a place called Saginaw?"
He shakes his head, then stops suddenly. "Wait. Isn't that a place up east?"
He considers a moment longer. "Nah, man, I can't remember. Sorry."
You thank him anyway, and then part ways.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Ever heard of a place called Saginaw?"
"No," she says quickly. "Should I?" She seems ready to move at any moment.
"Sorry," you back off. "Just trying to find it."
Her face betrays a modicum of guilt, and she offers, "Well, there used to be place with a name like that. East of the ATN, I think."
"Anyway," she continues, "good luck." And resumes her travel.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You ask around a bit, to see if anyone's heard of it.
Most say no, but you catch the attention of one warrior when you ask.
"Why do you want to know about that place?" he asks. He seems a bit suspicious.
Once you explain its historical significance, though, he relaxes again.
"That place is Blue Frog central," he warns. "Nobody goes there unless they're insane."
Despite his warning, however, he obliges your query, and tells you how to get there.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You walk to the edge of the raised platform, the dome and its candles giving the King and the Bishop an unearthly glow. Now is as good a time as any.
"My King," you call out, and the roaring noise dies down. "There is a traitor among us."
You see the Bishop standing there, eerily calm. You look back at the doorway. Liza has just walked in.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You feel your arm go numb as you point to your attempted conspirator, Liza: "Her."
And the crowd goes wild.
"Brothers and sisters," the King tries to shout over the crowd, but it's not enough. He tries again and again, but for once he can't contain them.
You look around at the cultists. You're not even sure what you're seeing. Grief. Outrage. Euphoria. Or some twisted fusion of the three? Whatever it is, it swells with every second that passes. With mere words, you've set a forest of madness ablaze, and the inferno is beyond all control.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
After a few deafening minutes, the crowd finally quiets enough for the King to be heard.
"Brothers and sisters," the King bellows, "the rites are clear. An Accuser has sired an Accused, and by our creed we shall see who is pure and who is corrupt through a trial of pain.
"Three torments purify us, and three torments give us truth: the Trial of Water, of Fire, and of Light. From these three torments, the Accused shall choose but one. The Accuser may then accept this choice, or invoke the right of one refusal and force the Accused to choose from the remaining two torments."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Accused," the King says to Liza. "Make your choice."
Liza unmasks, releasing long black hair to frame a haunted face. "A Trial of Water," she says.
"Accuser," the King says to you. "Do you accept the Trial of Water?"
You study her. Even as she failed to manipulate you into doing her bidding-at least, as far as you know-it only makes it harder to read the deadpan smirk on her face.
Does she want the Trial of Water? Or is she manipulating you again?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Liza keeps her composure steady. Your decision doesn't phase her one bit.
"Then," the King says, "the Trial of Water shall commence!"
The Blue Frogs rush. Spotlights flood the auditorium as two pairs of cultists wheel out wooden tables from the dome in the center. You and Liza are restrained completely. Then, they gag you with one dirty rag and cover your face and head in another.
All together the cultists chant: "Purity holds its light in pain."
You hear a container dunk into a vat of water nearby as the King declares: "May the righteous be the victor."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Look for signs that Liza is trying to trap you.

From the moment you met her, Liza has never seemed anything less than cunning. Your being there at all feels already like one trap; is her choice another?
Her gaze. It won't let up on you for anything else in the room. Yet it's neither fear nor impatience, only confidence. As if she were watching her prey already caught in a snare.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Look for signs of what Liza is hiding.

It's clear that Liza is hiding something besides her scheme. But what could it be?
Her calmness is immaculate. It doesn't feel faked at all. You catch a glimmer of something in the way she resists movement. And you realize: in her mind, she's already won.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Look for tells in Liza's body language.

Few people have full control of the volumes their body speaks. What is Liza's saying?
You study her for tells, but her whole body is as steady as stone. No, there's no doubt in your mind. Whatever your play, she has the winning hand.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Refuse the Trial of Water and force Liza to choose a different torment.

Liza looks indifferent to your choice. You can't help but feel like she's planned this.
"The Accuser has refused the torment," the King says. "Accused: your choice?"
Immediately Liza says: "A Trial of Fire."
The King nods. "Then the Trial of Fire shall commence!"
The Blue Frogs rush. Spotlights flood the auditorium as groups of cultists drag out two bronze frogs from the dome in the center and open the doors on their backs. Liza is pushed into hers and you into yours.
The cultists chant, loud even in the tank: "Purity holds its light in pain."
Heat and smoke begin to mount beneath you as you hear the King speak: "May the righteous be the victor."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The rags turn thick and heavy on your face and it's almost impossible not to gag. The water pounds down again and again, trickling in through your nose. You swallow through the cloth just to clear a breath, and another downpour comes. You tell yourself to keep fighting. And you do. You tread the very doorstep of drowning for as long as you can.
In your last moments of resistance, you feel yourself slipping. Water invades your lungs, pumps into your stomach, and readies to resurge.
You want to believe that holding out for just a while longer will do it. How much more could Liza take? But any second now, you feel like you could vomit into your own lungs.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Press on, even on pain of death.

Let it in, you tell yourself, let it all in.
You feel your insides twist in directions opposite to their intended use. You feel your instincts try to deny you your intentions, your muscle memory reject commands. But you overcome them by simply doing nothing.
You feel the tide rising up as the burn of misplaced water scratches around in your nose and down the back of your esophagus. The gates open on the signal and it's all over. The waters in and out join together and lay waste to your lungs. Your heart, mourning its accomplice, gives out, and you're left watching stars pop up on the back of dirty, wet rags.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Retract your challenge and admit defeat.

Somehow, through the rubber that's choking you, you manage to signal surrender. The Blue Frogs' voices swell to deafening heights as the rags are ripped off you. The lights and the auditorium and the world spin around and around. The last thing you hear before you lose consciousness is the voice of the King.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Liza looks indifferent to your choice. You can't help but feel like she's planned this.
"The Accuser has refused the torment," the King says. "Accused: your choice?"
Immediately Liza says: "A Trial of Fire."
The King nods. "Then, the Trial of Fire shall commence!"
The Blue Frogs rush. Spotlights flood the auditorium as groups of cultists drag out two bronze frogs from the dome in the center and open the doors on their backs. Liza is pushed into hers and you into yours.
The cultists chant, loud even in the tank: "Purity holds its light in pain."
Heat and smoke begin to mount beneath you as you hear the King speak: "May the righteous be the victor."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Retract your challenge and admit defeat.

With every ounce of will unburned by the flame, you scream your surrender into the bronze tank. The door opens, and they pull your smoking body from its infernal womb.
As you weakly cough up black smoke and try to fill your lungs with air, your consciousness gives way to the faraway sound of the King's voice.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Glowing crimson pools at the base of the bronze frog and scalds your hands and feet. On reflex you reach for the corners, awkwardly holding yourself up in the tank. But you lose your grip. On molten metal, you toss and turn like an insomniac in hell as tongues of flame peel away at your arms, legs, and back.
The agony drains your strength. In your desperation, a moment passes where you consider just burying your head into the heat. You want it to end. As much as you're enticed by the shrinking window of victory, you know it's a bad idea. Whatever it is the cult does to false Accusers, how could it be worse than this?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Press on, even on pain of death.
Right there at the very end of it, you've never felt worse about cooking in your entire life.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Press on, even on pain of death.

You fight the urge to cry out for several more...seconds? Minutes? You don't know anymore. Every beat of your heart marks a wave of stinging pain laced with panic.
Gritting teeth gives way to choking on what must be smoke, as the smell of cooking flesh assaults your nose.
Your consciousness gives way to the faraway sound of the King's voice.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Return to the room in the north wing.

You wonder why you went through all the trouble of picking the door lock and slipping inside. The room is mostly bereft not only of anything valuable, but even of character. No trophies, no weapons, no history. What few things there are congregate in the far corner, surrounding themselves with emptiness.
There does appear to be a safe, however, flanked by a mattress and a pot.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Go west through the gated doors.

Ceiling-high shelves cut the long room into a series of cramped walkways, onto which they spill boxes of decaying files. As you walk through, you find other things squeezed in: jars of dead critters, a few plastic bags of personal items beyond use. You narrowly avoid stepping on a fingerless hand.
The only light in the room comes from outside. Some of the boards meant for the windows lean against the wall. Silhouetted in gray, a figure sits on the other side facing a giant amphibian-shaped mural.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You keep your distance, and move on once they've passed.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You try to position yourself a safe distance away, and get ready...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
He seems oblivious to your presence now, showing neither signs of interest nor irritation.
Just pure focus on the road ahead.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
She seems oblivious to your presence now, showing neither signs of interest nor irritation.
Just pure focus on the road ahead.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The road on which you walk is a vanishing one.
Besieged by dirt and grass, cracked concrete leads you through parted woods of pine and aspen, while dense, ghost-white mist whirls in and out of an earthen darkness. The air bites colder here. A flagpole emerges from the gray canvas before you, flying no flag at its peak.
You soon reach a great wall made of lines of jersey barriers defending a tall and sturdy gate, fortified by the wreckage of cars that once rammed the barricade. It seems that at one point, quite a few people became desperate to return to the base. You find their bones right where they left them.
To one side, a derelict sign reads: "CAMP GRAYLING".

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The main gates of the military base are a daunting sight to behold, heavy with purpose and impregnability. While there's no shortage of purchase for climbing, the sheer number and variety of corpses heaped between the double barricades suggest that breaking into Camp Grayling won't be that easy.
A fine mesh fence continues through the woods on either side of the gates, just clearing the tree line. To your right, the fence skirts a path that leads down to a body of water. To your left, it runs deep into dark forest, foreboding and beckoning at the same.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Take the right path towards the lake.

The path opens up to a pitch-black ocean, silent and still under curtains of fog curling on its surface. Something about this place... With all the time you've spent in the wilderness, nothing has ever been so utterly devoid of sound.
An abyss within the waters draws you in the longer you stare into it. And you can't shake the feeling that something is watching you back.
The base's fenceline follows the shore tightly. There's no easy way through here.
You feel a chill as you turn away and head back to the main gates. It's only then that you notice the sign eaten by underbrush: "LAKE MARGRETHE, THIS WAY".
You politely disagree.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Take the left path into the forest.

Walking between a dense spread of trees and the electrified fence, you look for places where you might climb and leap over. But it's as if the forest knows where Grayling's boundaries are, fearful of disobeying.
Deep within Camp Grayling, eerie lights weave through the fog, punctuated by an occasional sound that's as much vaguely machine-like as it is animalistic. Soon you see it: three gigantic sphere-like structures dotted with lights along the tops.
Something dark crosses your view. You look down. A look of horror hangs on the wide-eyed, rotting face of a woman caught on the other side of the fence, as if trying to flee. The back of her head, neck, and arms are all charred to bone.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide to leave Camp Grayling alone for now.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You see a handful of bodies along the inner grounds. Every inch of their skin facing towards the base is burnt to all hell. Beyond them, you see antennae-mounted pylons wordlessly gloating over their likely handiwork, daring you to come.
Further ahead, the end of the fenceline turns inward just before a vast and vile-looking swamp. Even the woods don't dare to venture in, and you'd be a sitting duck trying to wade through it. Luckily you may not have to.
You've found several places where the electrified mesh fence is partially cut. Any amount of prolonged contact will be pure agony, but with the right tool and every inch of your threshold for pain, you might just get through.
All that's left is the choosing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Wait. A clearing? Here? You decide to turn around and take a look.
The woods part into an oblong-shaped field of grass no wider than a few car lengths. The grass thins out in patches outside the shaded cover of the forest. A great big rock sits squarely in the middle, easily ten feet high.
You approach to take a closer look when a figure jumps out from behind it, rifle in hand. But you do notice a trembling, and it's carried in the person's voice as well.
"Who's there? What are you doing here?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Cut through the one of the spots.

With everything you've been through, the first few cuts through the electrified mesh fence chip off little from your resolve.
But after ten, twenty, thirty, it becomes difficult to ignore the vicious tingling, the spreading sting, the sensation of skin pulling and twisting against itself. You sweat with anticipation before each cut, and pause for relief after.
The simple task of cutting a few wires has grown into an increasingly gargantuan task.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"The Ten Curators of the New Earth Ostracon," Blackwhite says.
Two rows of five photographs lay across the screen, men and women between twenty and fifty years old. #10 has only a placeholder image of a human silhouette. Beneath each is a first initial and a last name.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You rummage through your things for anything that might help.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Login incorrect. If you have forgotten your login credentials, please email your base's DPI officer for login reset instructions."
The status bar along the bottom of the screen speeds up somewhat.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You refuse to cower in fear against the machines. Anyone can be killed, and anything can be destroyed.
Right?
Your weapon ready, your reflective armor donned, you turn to the nearest V-MADS. But a fierce rush of heat blasts your face, forcing you to turn. In seconds, other V-MADS join in from all sides, and you're on your knees, desperately hiding behind the folds of your shield.
In a crumpled heap, you sit on the tarmac waiting for an avenue of escape. Waiting out an army of sleepless, immortal pain cannons...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The pylons you see forming a perimeter beyond the fences are much clearer now. However, that doesn't help in identifying them. They almost look like radar towers, but they aren't moving.
Three white orb-like structures dwarf several buildings in the foreground: a small shed, an air traffic control tower, an enormous hangar, and a barracks.
Beyond that, long runways stretch between even more hangars. You catch a glimpse of what they likely hold: unmanned aerial vehicles. A couple of small, sleek drones sit here and there, some crashed, others relegated to the mercy of the elements. The rest, you'd guess, likely sit safely inside.
There's not a living soul in sight. The dead, however, are readily available for company.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
On a hunch, you fish out the signal detector you found earlier, and flip it on.
Initially, the readings are too wild to do you any good. You're not really sure if it's working.
However, after a few minutes of experimenting, you start to get a handle on the readings.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The pylons you see forming a perimeter beyond the fences are much clearer now. They look like turret-mounted emitters of some sort.
Three white orb-like structures dwarf several buildings in the foreground: a small shed, an air traffic control tower, an enormous hangar, and a barracks.
Beyond that, long runways stretch between even more hangars. You catch a glimpse of what they likely hold: unmanned aerial vehicles. A couple of small, sleek drones sit here and there, some crashed, others relegated to the mercy of the elements. The rest, you'd guess, likely sit safely inside.
There's not a living soul in sight. The dead, however, are readily available for company.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Cut through at the field's weak spot.

With everything you've been through, the first few cuts through the electrified mesh fence chip off little from your resolve.
But after ten, twenty, thirty, it becomes difficult to ignore the vicious tingling, the spreading sting, the sensation of skin pulling and twisting against itself. You sweat with anticipation before each cut, and pause for relief after.
The simple task of cutting a few wires has grown into an increasingly gargantuan task.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You rummage through your things for anything that might help.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You check each of the cut sections of fencing for a blind spot in the field.
Unfortunately, there doesn't appear to be a gap anywhere. The field from inside the base is permeating this entire area.
There is, however, a depression in the field strength near one of the fence's cut regions.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're outside Camp Grayling's energized perimeter. A fine mesh fence warns of high voltage, and barbed coils line the top.
Within its bounds, corpses litter the field in agonizing poses, burnt on the side facing the facility.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Eventually, after a grueling test of your resolve, you decide that's it. That's good enough.
A few kicks, and the fence folds over.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Eventually, after a grueling test of your resolve, you decide that's it. That's good enough.
A few kicks, and the fence folds over.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As the fence opens, you feel areas of white-hot pain intermittently, and you recoil.
The sensation disappears when you move from the opening, and soon you discover that the pain seems to come from within the facility.
Fortunately, after some tentative testing, it appears your attire mostly shields you from it.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
What happens next is as painful as it is confusing. Searing pain washes over your skin, as if breaking the fence has opened a dam from hell.
You instinctively cower from the burning, finding refuge no further than the nearest intact mesh.
No flashing lights, no loud sounds. Just pain where the barrier is broken.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide to leave Camp Grayling behind, for now.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You rummage through your things for anything that might help.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're outside Camp Grayling's energized perimeter, where you've cut a section of the fence open.
A field of pain seems to radiate from the inside the base, pouring through the opening.
Fortunately, you seem to be mostly shielded from its effects.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're outside Camp Grayling's energized perimeter, where you've cut a section of the fence open.
A field of pain seems to radiate from the inside the base, pouring through the opening.
You're safe off to the side here, but infiltrating any further promises to be uncomfortable, to say the least.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Enter Camp Grayling using the foil.

Bracing yourself, you push through the breach in the fence and start walking.
Ten seconds later, all you've felt are a few hot touches through the vulnerabilities of the foil covering your body: joints, holes, and so on. You keep your back to the emitter to protect your face.
It's really working. The signal from the emitters are bouncing right off you. You stand in victory and raise your arms. You know you shouldn't, and you're facing the wrong way anyway, yet-
"Is that all you've got?!" you yell. And you don't regret it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Enter Camp Grayling, Using the Foil cont'd

When you regain your good sense, you make your way quickly across the field, still careful to keep your face covered from the octagonal emitters of the turret. The hits of microwave radiation may be small, but severe pain in small doses is still severe pain. Meanwhile, your protective foil is tearing with every movement you make.
By the time you wear out your foil poncho's durability, you've cleared the turret's range. Most of the getup is in shreds behind you; the rest, unusable, clings to your body. You pluck off the foil hat and shrug the rest off. No reason to look like an idiot anymore.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Before you can go on, squeaking and servos echo from behind you, drawing your attention back to the fences. A belt-wheeled drone is positioning itself by your handiwork.
With skinny limbs, the mesh is spliced and patched. And moments later, the repairbot is trundling back into its access trench like nothing happened.
Given how long it takes to cut through the fence even without a turret at your back, it's clear that going out the way you came in would mean death most painful. You'll have to find another way.
For now, the grounds of Camp Grayling await.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You've barely moved when the invisible beam of heat envelops you. It's a sudden kind of intense warmth, shallow but startling, and it mounts in your skin quickly, gathering forces for a more severe burn.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Get the hell back outside the fence!

You turn and flee using every available ounce of strength. With minimal clumsiness, you scramble back out through the hole in the mesh fence, spurred by the invisible whip at your back. You're safe. The web of radiation untangles from your skin the moment you step through.
The whole ordeal knocks the wind out of you, and you need a moment to catch your breath.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run for your life towards the inner base!

Pushing forward, it's not long before it feels like you're baking in a hellish furnace. It takes all you have to block out the pain, but it's stifling. Your whole body wants to stop. And the base seems to draw away from you with every leap and bound. Only the unseen face of the peeling heat comes closer and closer.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With intense focus, you throw your body into overdrive and manage to get a running start before you forget what the air even feels like. Soon, all that exists is the heat.
If you even reached your full running speed, it's behind you now. The burning in your skin is unbearable, biting away at the distance you can clear between each running step. You don't know how long you can go on.
You just run.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Power through toward the inner base.

You brace yourself for the pain, numbing your mind with concentration and steeling your body with willpower. Heat is only heat.
Five steps. That's how far you run before the turret wrenches away your focus and pisses all over your willpower. Heat is not just heat; it's excruciating and it's setting a million little skin-bound fires over every part of your body facing the emitter.
You find ways to manage it while you keep up a fast jog. But it's hell. Every step is the smallest triumph in the world and they're shrinking. And so are you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Shred across the field like a fricking Olympian.

Here it is. Your whole life has been building up to this moment. You've trained; you've toughened up; you've triumphed. Where you're standing now? That's the starting line. Those buildings over there? The finish line. And that tower of milliwave punishment between them?
They don't have those in the Olympics.
Every muscle in your body hurls you forward and sends the world into a blurred state. Your brain blocks out the hurt, not only from the running, but from the heat wave of the turret. It feels like a thousand hot light bulbs all pressed against your skin. You're on fire. Doubtless now, you're on fire in every sense of the phrase.
And you fly on wings of agony.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You sense the moment coming, so clearly that it's almost in your sight: the exact spot just ahead where you'll collapse. The pain is just too much.
In the end, you fall to the ground. Without your movement, the turret's gaze drops more heavily on you. You scramble to get to your feet.
No. It's too much. It's just too much.
You can't face it; it'd hurt too much to feel your own face scorching. You're half-kneeling, leaning on one arm in front of you. You look at dew on the rot-green grass, but see only the white blindness of being burned alive and the bubbling and bursting of your skin.
It ends. Eventually.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With weakened legs, you fail to clear one foot past the shin of the other and you take a tumble. You stop, and that's when you feel it: a void. A cold one.
You sit up. In the distance, the turrets are turning away from you. You've done it. Somehow you managed to clear the field.
As you stand, a rush of pain returns to you, but it's residual. As fast as you ran, you endured a concentrated and prolonged scorching, and your body won't forget its wounds.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The dense mist coils around the base's ethereal lights. Every step peels back the white curtains, bit by bit, as you cross into a central area flanked by several looming structures. The three megalithic spheres consider you from beyond them, on the far side of the base, like a hand considers an ant in its palm.
As you near the center, a wall of mist thickens before you, reclaiming everything into obscurity. Your only sense of direction is culled from the array of lights shearing through the haze, forming eerie constellations you can almost reach out and touch.
You press on. One by one, your steps reveal buildings, some small, some the size of giants.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You stand at the epicenter of Camp Grayling. A vast central area opens up before you, awash in blind-white halogen and ghostly clouds, menacing, silent, and otherworldly.
From the swirling gray, unmoving shadows climb out of their wombs and assume their true forms; various buildings surround the central area. Your eyes are drawn to the nearby storage shed first. Farther out stand an air traffic control tower, a barracks, and a maintenance hangar.
But there's one figure that demands more of your attention, as do its four siblings behind it. With heavy, bone-crushing thuds on a corpse-littered tarmac, they tread on six spider-like legs. All-too-familiar octagonal emitters are mounted on their backs.
And they're coming for you.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You quickly rummage through your things.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You refuse to cower in fear against the machines. Anyone can be killed, and anything can be destroyed.
Right?
Your weapon ready, you turn to the nearest V-MADS. But a fierce rush of heat blasts you hard, immediately cutting you down. In seconds, other V-MADS join in against their intruder, and you're on your knees being burned alive. Your skin flares into blooms and cracks of red and white. You close your eyes only to feel fire melt away your eyelids.
It burns. It burns. It burns.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run for cover towards one of the surrounding buildings.

Smartly, you recognize the futility of going up against the V-MADS. However, the barracks, tower, and hangar lie beyond them. And the machines could not look more territorial if they tried.
What you need to do is get indoors, and fast. But where?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With the foil protecting your body, the dooming gaze of the V-MADS bears little effect on you except a few hot pokers of air on joints and in small tears of the poncho. You cover your face and cast your gaze down. Not seeing your enemies, it seems, only grants them an even more fearsome aspect. You hear their chasses clomping down, furious that their death ray is impotent.
There's little time to be satisfied. Every movement you make degrades the foil. You took a good look at the layout of the various buildings around. Now it's just a matter of picking one- and hoping that this ridiculous outfit holds.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You feel a brief wave of pain before you flip the switch on the orange transponder. There are no visible signs anything has changed, but immediately the V-MADS stop and resume regular patrol around the area.
Just like that, you're invisible to them. You look down at the device. The battery's draining, and that makeshift power cell isn't likely to last long. You make a note to turn it off when you get indoors, away from the death-steel patrol.
Time to move.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The mechanical doll in your possession comes alive, beeping and throwing out all kinds of lights. The V-MADS seem to pause- actually pause in their train-like approach- and take notice. The doll's limbs twitch and contract, as if eager to be free.
You toss the doll away, and it jerks and jumps in place. The V-MADS follow it, enamored or violently obsessed by this thing that seems unfazed by their emitters.
Whatever is going on, you don't have long. The way the doll's lights and movements are dying down, you have less than a minute before the V-MADS lose their new friend and remember you.
Best not to let this opportunity go to waste.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run away to the nearby storage shed.

You bolt toward the storage shed. The V-MADS follow you, their emitters locked on. You feel a blast of burning run across your skin, mounting with every step.
But you push through it. You manage to make it to the door of the shed before it gets too bad. You seal yourself inside and the pain subsides.
You can still hear the V-MADS outside circling, stalking, taunting.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run through them to the control tower, unprotected.

You cast your eyes past the V-MADS, across to the greater buildings. Going straight through would be suicide, but maybe you can skirt around.
You run. But not three steps in, the emitters all find your unburned body and decide, really, that just can't be left as is. You feel the compound strength of milliwave pulses immediately set your skin ablaze with agony. Your pace shrivels down in seconds. You try to push through. But it's useless.
Your knees give in and you're pinned to the ground by the pain. The V-MADS approach. The burning grows and grows and grows across crackling skin, bursting blisters, and flesh-pink fissures.
You close your eyes. The corpses of Grayling will soon have another friend.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run through them to the maintenance hangar, unprotected.

You cast your eyes past the V-MADS, across to the greater buildings. Going straight through would be suicide, but maybe you can skirt around.
You run. But not three steps in, the emitters all find your unburned body and decide, really, that just can't be left as is. You feel the compound strength of milliwave pulses immediately set your skin ablaze with agony. Your pace shrivels down in seconds. You try to push through. But it's useless.
Your knees give in and you're pinned to the ground by the pain. The V-MADS approach. The burning grows and grows and grows across crackling skin, bursting blisters, and flesh-pink fissures.
You close your eyes. The corpses of Grayling will soon have another friend.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run through them to the barracks, unprotected.

You cast your eyes past the V-MADS, across to the greater buildings. Going straight through would be suicide, but maybe you can skirt around.
You run. But not three steps in, the emitters all find your unburned body and decide, really, that just can't be left as is. You feel the compound strength of milliwave pulses immediately set your skin ablaze with agony. Your pace shrivels down in seconds. You try to push through. But it's useless.
Your knees give in and you're pinned to the ground by the pain. The V-MADS approach. The burning grows and grows and grows across crackling skin, bursting blisters, and flesh-pink fissures.
You close your eyes. The corpses of Grayling will soon have another friend.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Momentarily safe from your mechanical pursuers, you hurry across the tarmac to the storage shed.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Momentarily safe from your mechanical pursuers, you hurry across the tarmac to the control tower.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Momentarily safe from your mechanical pursuers, you hurry across the tarmac to the barracks.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Momentarily safe from your mechanical pursuers, you hurry across the tarmac to the maintenance hangar.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You struggle to walk both carefully and quickly through the territory of the V-MADS, feeling a new wave of pain with every shred of foil. The poncho keeps together for not a moment longer than it has to.
Peeling and shaking off any silvery remnants, you head inside the maintenance hangar unharmed.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You struggle to walk both carefully and quickly through the territory of the V-MADS, feeling a new wave of pain with every shred of foil. The poncho keeps together for not a moment longer than it has to.
Peeling and shaking off any silvery remnants, you head inside the control tower unharmed.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You struggle to walk both carefully and quickly through the territory of the V-MADS, feeling a new wave of pain with every shred of foil. The poncho keeps together for not a moment longer than it has to.
Peeling and shaking off any silvery remnants, you head inside the barracks unharmed.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You struggle to walk both carefully and quickly through the territory of the V-MADS, feeling a new wave of pain with every shred of foil. The poncho keeps together for not a moment longer than it has to.
Peeling and shaking off any silvery remnants, you head inside the storage shed unharmed.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
In contrast to the base's outside areas, the interior of the storage shed is a small sanctum of darkness absolved of fog, extending only a half-dozen yards in either direction. Sounds from the V-MADS outside ring loud, however, never allowing you to forget they're there.
Along the walls, you see little that you can use. A few rotting pieces of wood lay in splinters, pallets in another lifetime, caked with grime and dirt.
But there's hope. The lone downlighter in the shed draws your eye down its illuminated cone. There's an old forklift in here.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Never mind that! You duck back inside the shed.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A thick layer of dust covers every surface, though it does nothing to hide the rust peeling up from the black and green paintjob. The heavy-duty frame would give you some assurance for safety if it weren't for the cab being wide open from all sides. Still, it might be good for something.
You sit inside and give the ignition a try. Despite appearances, she still moves. Unfortunately, forklifts have never been known for moving very fast.
What's more: the shed's main doors won't budge. If this forklift is going to get outside, it'll have to be by breaking them down.
Hanging on the wall behind you is a rope.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Slipping outside, you have but a few seconds to make your next move before those V-MADS pin you.
Unfortunately, the other three buildings are across the wide-open tarmac from here.
And through *them*.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You look through your supplies for anything that might help.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Drive the forklift out of the shed.

Little cover is still better than nothing. You decide to take the wheel yourself and barrel through the grounds, V-MADS be damned.
The one remaining question: where will you drive it?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Rig the forklift to drive itself out of the shed.

Taking the rope from the wall, you're relieved to find that there's enough to rig the forklift to drive itself. You fasten the length from the controls to a bar just above a worn-out "Do You Even Lift Bro" sticker.
All it needs is for you to start it up and point it in the right direction. In the meantime, you'd get some cover from the V-MADS, at least until they flank you.
It's not going to be a fun ride-along. In fact, you're sure the pain will be almost unbearable. What you're counting on is that very word: "almost".
Now to decide where to go.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Take a look under the hood.

Opening the engine compartment, you assess its innards just to check if everything is as it should be. You confirm your suspicions: a speed-limiting device is installed.
It'd be a simple matter to unhook it from the injection pump and free the machine to run at its natural speeds above a measly 10 mph. Without carrying any kind of load, whatever risks the device was meant to minimize shouldn't be relevant to what you need: to clear the V-MADS and reach the other buildings.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You try to get comfortable amidst the tattered cushioning of the seat, but give up when you realize there's no point. Whichever way this goes, it won't be a very long drive.
You start her up. And you punch through the shed doors, onto the tarmac.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You try to get comfortable amidst the tattered cushioning of the seat, but give up when you realize there's no point. Whichever way this goes, it won't be a very long drive.
You start her up. And you punch through the shed doors, onto the tarmac.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You try to get comfortable amidst the tattered cushioning of the seat, but give up when you realize there's no point. Whichever way this goes, it won't be a very long drive.
You start her up. And you punch through the shed doors, onto the tarmac.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
All five V-MADS take notice as you gradually barrel through. The far reaches of the central grounds seem to stretch farther out than before.
Then comes their mechanical stares. Your skin boils from within in seconds. You keep pressing the accelerator, but the machine just has nothing left to give.
The V-MADS continue to roast you alive, and the excruciating pain overtakes you. You lose control of the forklift. The whole world tips over beneath you, and all that's left is your own screaming. Soon you can't even manage that.
You're pinned down, and the emitters eat away at you from all sides. In very long minutes, you're done- well-done, in fact.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you loop the rope through the forklift controls, your nerves flare up at the thought of the octagonal emitters all raining down on you in invisible fury. But this is the only way.
One more knot and she's ready. You fire her up, and with no further instruction, she charges forward into the doors and bursts onto the tarmac. You hide for as long as you can behind the vehicle's frame, opposite the V-MADS. But in moments, you realize there's no hiding from them. Their eyes are everywhere.
The forklift barrels along at about 10 mph, you'd guess, and it's the last coherent thought you have before the searing pain consumes you. It takes everything you have just to cling to your clunky ally.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you loop the rope through the forklift controls, your nerves flare up at the thought of the octagonal emitters all raining down on you in invisible fury. But this is the only way.
One more knot and she's ready. You fire her up, and with no further instruction, she charges forward into the doors and bursts onto the tarmac. You hide for as long as you can behind the vehicle's frame, opposite the V-MADS. But in moments, you realize there's no hiding from them. Their eyes are everywhere.
The forklift barrels along at about 10 mph, you'd guess, and it's the last coherent thought you have before the searing pain consumes you. It takes everything you have just to cling to your clunky ally.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you loop the rope through the forklift controls, your nerves flare up at the thought of the octagonal emitters all raining down on you in invisible fury. But this is the only way.
One more knot and she's ready. You fire her up, and with no further instruction, she charges forward into the doors and bursts onto the tarmac. You hide for as long as you can behind the vehicle's frame, opposite the V-MADS. But in moments, you realize there's no hiding from them. Their eyes are everywhere.
The forklift barrels along at about 10 mph, you'd guess, and it's the last coherent thought you have before the searing pain consumes you. It takes everything you have just to cling to your clunky ally.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The forklift crashes into the side of the building and tips over. You won't be using it anymore. With your last ounces of strength, you make a run for the door, screaming through the burns you've already sustained from the slow journey.
Seconds away from crumbling to your feet, you make it inside the control tower.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The forklift crashes into the side of the building and tips over. You won't be using it anymore. With your last ounces of strength, you make a run for the door, screaming through the burns you've already sustained from the slow journey.
Seconds away from crumbling to your feet, you make it inside the barracks.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The forklift crashes into the side of the building and tips over. You won't be using it anymore. With your last ounces of strength, you make a run for the door, screaming through the burns you've already sustained from the slow journey.
Seconds away from crumbling to your feet, you make it inside the hangar.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Remove speed limit and drive the forklift.

With a callous hand, you dismantle the speed-limiting device. You situate yourself in the cab of the forklift, reasonably assured that she'll drive fast enough to get you across the tarmac in one piece. You're eager to see your handiwork in action.
Before you can have a second thought, the ignition is on and you're breaking through the shed's main doors. The V-MADS whirl around at the new beast on the tarmac. The pulse emitters are quick to fire at you, and you feel your skin curdling. You push through second after second of hell.
Then you realize you haven't decided where you're going yet.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Remove speed limit and rig the forklift to drive itself.

With a callous hand, you dismantle the speed-limiting device. You take the rope from the wall and begin rigging the forklift to drive straight without you at the wheel. Just because it can go faster now, there's no reason to leave yourself so exposed in the cab.
It's ready. All that's left is to direct it towards one of the three buildings outside, and ride out as much of the pain as you can. The V-MADS will grow senses of humor before they let you pass freely, but with a bit of luck, you can weather through it.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Leave the limiter where it is. Safety first!
That speed limiter was installed to specification for a reason!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Gritting through throbbing, cracking skin, you turn the wheel towards the air traffic control tower on the other side of the tarmac. The V-MADS continue their radiating onslaught, following your every swerve. You can barely hold on.
As soon as you're near enough to the building, you leap out of the cab for a brief reprieve, blocked by the forklift's frame. The V-MADS continue moving toward their quarry, even as you manage to make it inside.
You have cover for now, as do your new burns.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Gritting through throbbing, cracking skin, you turn the wheel towards the barracks on the other side of the tarmac. The V-MADS continue their radiating onslaught, following your every swerve. You can barely hold on.
As soon as you're near enough to the building, you leap out of the cab for a brief reprieve, blocked by the forklift's frame. The V-MADS continue moving toward their quarry, even as you manage to make it inside.
You have cover for now, as do your new burns.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Gritting through throbbing, cracking skin, you turn the wheel towards the maintenance hangar on the other side of the tarmac. The V-MADS continue their radiating onslaught, following your every swerve. You can barely hold on.
As soon as you're near enough to the building, you leap out of the cab for a brief reprieve, blocked by the forklift's frame. The V-MADS continue moving toward their quarry, even as you manage to make it inside.
You have cover for now, as do your new burns.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Direct it to the control tower.

The forklift rends the shed's main doors and cuts a path through the mist. You hang off the side suicide-style.
The V-MADS scramble to home in on your position. The commotion only throws them off for a few seconds. The emitters are back in play, pushing torrent after torrent of radiation at you. You feel your skin prick and sizzle, a heat burrowing through every cell exposed to the machines.
It's quick to reach your pain threshold, but so are you to reach the control tower.
You dash inside, away from your predators, while the forklift veers off and crashes. You won't be forgetting that pain anytime soon, but at least you've suffered no severe burns.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The forklift rends the shed's main doors and cuts a path through the mist. You hang off the side suicide-style.
The V-MADS scramble to home in on your position. The commotion only throws them off for a few seconds. The emitters are back in play, pushing torrent after torrent of radiation at you. You feel your skin prick and sizzle, a heat burrowing through every cell exposed to the machines.
It's quick to reach your pain threshold, but so are you to reach the barracks.
You dash inside, away from your predators, while the forklift veers off and crashes. You won't be forgetting that pain anytime soon, but at least you've suffered no severe burns.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Direct it to the maintenance hangar.

The forklift rends the shed's main doors and cuts a path through the mist. You hang off the side suicide-style.
The V-MADS scramble to home in on your position. The commotion only throws them off for a few seconds. The emitters are back in play, pushing torrent after torrent of radiation at you. You feel your skin prick and sizzle, a heat burrowing through every cell exposed to the machines.
It's quick to reach your pain threshold, but so are you to reach the maintenance hangar.
You dash inside, away from your predators, while the forklift veers off and crashes. You won't be forgetting that pain anytime soon, but at least you've suffered no severe burns.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The control tower begins as a triangular enclosure at its base, red emergency lights spreading out across the walls and floor. You see no trace of the main lights, or anything else of note. Hollowness haunts this place as much as it holds the rest of Camp Grayling.
As the tower's spine, an elevator lies dead at the bottom of the shaft, mired in darkness. A spiral staircase trails along the wall, high up to where you can no longer see.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Never mind that! You duck back into the tower.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You find yourself on the first and only landing in the tower, up seven stories from the ground. A spiral of red lights goes on forever into the almost endless dark below.
Above, you hear faint electronic noises. Before you is a door with the letters "M.E.R." on its front.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The stairs end at a circular room surrounded by tall and wide windows-the very top of the control tower. Around the ceiling hangs an imperfect array of dimming, off-white lights, pinpointing each area of responsibility with stage-like gravitas.
The monitors and keys at about half of the workstations appear active, all situated toward the center and front. Binders and files stack high at the center table, in varying states of chaos. Outside, the mist seems to have thinned somewhat, just enough for you to see the ghost base over which you're standing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You try the door. It budges just enough for you to know that it isn't locked. It seems there's a barricade on the other side.
You peer through the crack. All you see are walls of flickering yellow lights against a space of purest black. When you listen closely, you hear something. A rhythmic sound. A rising and falling.
A cold chill runs down your back when you realize you're hearing breaths.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You call out to whoever is inside.
The only response: the rhythmic breaths stop. Outside, faint pounding of mechanical legs can still be heard, but nothing in here.
After a few moments of quiet, the breathing resumes. Nothing else happens.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You close the door, and try not to think about whatever is in there.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Staff Sergeant Lydia F. Reyes credentials active. Welcome, Lydia."
The status bar along the bottom of the screen pauses, and partially resets, buying you some time.

table.name: encounters
table.column: There's a lot to see around you. Which way do you look?

table.name: encounters
table.column: Look through the files for the code.

With some idea what to look for in order to fulfill the mission from Martha, you rifle through the OSHA binders, the pages and pages of flight data, the maps, the reports. You spend the better part of an hour clearing the pile of documents on top of the desk.
Nothing.
You start through the low shelves in the back of the room, your only remaining hope. One binder validates them: a dusty old thing that appears to have been opened maybe once or twice in its entire lifespan. It's stunning how good of a condition it's in.
You flip through the pages and find a sealed envelope wedged at the back. You rip it open. Here it is: a list of word-sensitive commands for the base's mainframe. Among them is Code: Anarchy.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With the small flashdrive in hand, you search through the desks trying to find where it can go, guided only by The Stoat's vague instructions. Eventually you come across something that seems to work. Hopefully this won't trigger any alarms.
You plug in the drive, and the nearby screen reacts almost in tandem with the flashing light on the drive's tail. File windows pop open and closed too fast for you to make out what they see. Submerged by and reemerging from the erratic copying, you see a progress slowly crawl across.
A few minutes later, all activity subsides. The monitors resume as they were before. You unplug the drive, hoping that did the trick.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You peer through dark glass towards the northern skies.
A thick fog forms a blockade of sorts with heavy clouds. The farthest out you can see is Lake Margrethe, a massive body of colorless black water as still as glass.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You peer through dark glass towards the western skies.
Nestled deep within dense forests appear to be a few domes on towers, smaller than the trio of giant spheres on the base. They form a perimeter, but you can make out nothing between or beyond them.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You peer through dark glass towards the southern skies.
The air clears up toward the south, opening a direct line of sight to a piebald landscape of forests, plains, and ruins. Details elude you, but the absence of humans makes itself known well enough.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You peer through dark glass towards the eastern skies.
Traveling in a pack, dogmen make their way through a clearing in the woods. A few of them stop to drink from a pond. Then they lope back towards the rest, from clear forms back into the blur of black shadows. They're heading west.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Double bunks section the large hall into quarters with single bunks and makeshift mattresses strewn around on the ground. Given everything you've walked through on the base, you've nearly forgotten what most of the rest of Michigan looks like outside the wilderness, ravaged by abandon. This place looks almost lived-in, if it weren't for dust.
Many of the overhead lights are dead, but there's enough for you to make your way through the mess.
A handful of the beds are immaculately made. Near the entrance, a set of file cabinets have been dragged in. And at the other end, a bathroom.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Never mind that! You duck back inside.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You search beds for anything worthwhile, but find no valuables. Instead, it seems that only ghosts have lived here, not the living. The living keep tokens; only the dead stop caring.
You reach a perfectly made bed. On a hunch, you flip up the mattress. A torn page from a diary hides under it. It reads:
"The others can call me OCD and laugh all they want. Discipline is a part of our training, and whatever infrastructure crumbles away, that's my backbone. Some things are worth fighting for. Isn't that the reason we're still manning this base? To maintain some sense of order in this chaos?"
"Sean never mocks me, though. Even without words, all he says is: 'I love you'."
You replace the page.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You shuffle through various schematics, building plans, base layouts, and the drafts and drafts of each mixed together. Personnel files add some variation to the jumbled records, taking away more of the hour to sort through.
You come across one file for a Corporal Stanley Chisholm, dishonorably discharged. You're not sure why he stands out from the rest. You can't place him, but there's a lingering recognition there, like you've studied that face, and depended on it.
You grab one of the more interesting documents before moving on.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Check the file cabinets for a hiding spot.

You look around the file cabinets for something that may have been hidden away. The backs, underneath them, slipped into the files. You lift out the cabinets' contents in case something may have fallen through.
Nothing. Could you be looking in the wrong direction?
Taking out the top drawer, you feel around against the top of the cabinet. Wedged into the corner, you find a household cylinder key scented with an odd smell.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It first seemed that the communal bathroom's lights had been turned off, but as you approach, you see a flickering outline along the inner fringes of the doorframe.
You stand in front of it, listening to the quiet click-click-click of the light- a testament to how quiet it is in here despite the space's potential for echoing.
You can't explain it, but you shiver when you reach for the door.
It's locked.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You continue on through the disheveled beds until you come across another neatly made one. Under it hides another diary page.
"I get more breaks now than I used to, much as a part of me hates it. I have a duty just like everyone else here. I shouldn't use him as an excuse, and neither should they. I make the best of it, though. More time to write. More time to hide it from prying eyes."
"He's always so quiet when he's with me. I feel such ease around him, and that's becoming a rarer thing these days."
"I keep thinking it couldn't possibly get worse, and then it does. There's talk of abandoning the base altogether. But how could we? People are depending on us. On me."
You replace the page.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
At a third tidied bunk, and as expected, another entry.
"Major said it was a done deal. We're running thin as it is, and there's less and less to protect up here. People are fleeing to the south. But I fought hard with him on it. Eventually I convinced him. Instead we'll just be going on a supply run, no more than a day. We'll protect Crawford County yet."
"I know how dangerous it is to cross the woods. He's always quiet in my arms here, but not elsewhere. We can't take the risk. Anyhow, it's only for a day. I'll leave half of my pendant with him, and all of my love."
"It's only for a day. It's only for a day."
An ID card falls from the folds.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You shuffle through various schematics, building plans, base layouts, and the drafts and drafts of each mixed together. Personnel files add some variation to the jumbled records, taking away more of the hour to sort through.
You come across one file for a Corporal Stanley Chisholm, dishonorably discharged. You're not sure why he stands out from the rest. You can't place him, but there's a lingering recognition there, like you've studied that face, and depended on it.
You move on.
Clearing drawer after drawer, you eventually find faded blueprints of what seems to be the V-MADS. One of the things The Stoat is after.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As the door creaks open, you freeze in place. The light flickers on and off. A black mass directly opposite you. Whited eyes pointing into your own. Snarling teeth. And the bones of its ribcage protruding from its furry chest.
As the flashes continue, you piece together an image of the dogman, starved to death and partially burned on half its body. The inner side of the door is weakly scratched, a far cry from what these creatures are capable of. Glass shards scatter at its feet; above, a narrow window lies broken. You find traces of vomit near its mouth and a dried puddle in front of it with hints of brown.
There, shining in brief moments of light, is a green half-heart necklace.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As the door creaks open, you freeze in place. The light flickers on and off. A black mass directly opposite you. Whited eyes pointing into your own. Snarling teeth. And the bones of its ribcage protruding from its furry chest.
As the flashes continue, you piece together an image of the dogman, starved to death and partially burned on half its body. The inner side of the door is weakly scratched, a far cry from what these creatures are capable of. Glass shards scatter at its feet; above, a narrow window lies broken. You find traces of vomit near its mouth and a dried puddle in front of it with hints of brown.
There, shining in brief moments of light, is a green half-heart necklace.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You stand in awe of the impossible space folded inside the hangar. The walls and rafters seem to recede at your approach, easing into the shadows of infinity. You shudder to think what was once housed here. No mere aircraft, surely. Something much bigger.
Whatever it is, it has left a grand vacuum meekly filled by a small unmanned aerial vehicle in the center, evidently midway through repairs, dwarfed by the pyramid of ghostly light in which it rests.
Nearby, a maintenance hatch on the floor lies open.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Never mind that! You duck back into the hangar.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
At a third tidied bunk, and as expected, another entry.
"Major said it was a done deal. We're running thin as it is, and there's less and less to protect up here. People are fleeing to the south. But I fought hard with him on it. Eventually I convinced him. Instead we'll just be going on a supply run, no more than a day. We'll protect Crawford County yet."
"I know how dangerous it is to cross the woods. He's always quiet in my arms here, but not elsewhere. We can't take the risk. Anyhow, it's only for a day. I'll leave half of my pendant with him, and all of my love."
"It's only for a day. It's only for a day."

table.name: encounters
table.column: You rummage through your things for anything that might help.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The lone UAV looks to have been sitting in disuse for some time. It's much larger up close. White-tipped wings extend out from a once-shiny body that is the color of onyx, with a thin flourish of blue on each fin of its Y-shaped tail.
A weapons bay at its heart lies exposed and empty. A side panel hangs open, a clear void in the circuitry for something flat and rectangular. There's a shipping crate here, with packing materials cushioning a circuit.
Discounting the missing parts, it doesn't appear to be damaged. You see no reason this drone was singled out from the others on the base, either.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Tiny green maintenance lights lead your eyes deep into the earth, down a tight crawlspace beneath the hatch. A rush of air drifts upward, smelling of silicon and copper, of thermoplastics and tin, and of beginnings and ends. You see nowhere else to go but into darkness.
You carefully ease yourself down, catching one last glimpse of the surface.
In case it is your last.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The concrete tunnel grows intent with sealing you in, tightening its grip around you with each rung you descend. You lose count of how many times your knees and elbows scrape against the sides. You reach a point where neither up nor down seems to have an end, and you're convinced you've found yourself a new kind of hell.
But like so many times before, you press on. There is too much at stake.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You lower your foot expecting to find more ladder, but it's floor that meets your expectation. The air feels entirely different this deep down-warmer, more arid. You step off the rungs, expecting a whole other world.
You walk forward, and blue-white lights rise like an ancient tide.
In concentric rings around you, rows upon rows of six-feet-high CPUs extend as far out as the hangar above. You hear the endless exhale of vents and internal fans. The LED lights cycle and flicker and stare.
In front of you, a path leads straight down to a curved desk on a raised platform, immaculately crafted and beholden only to the great black mirror before it.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You seat yourself on a black leather chair, in reach of a sleek-looking keyboard anchored to the desk's center. The giant monitor looms high ahead. Against its onyx abyss, pale white text blares on in unintelligible sequences. A jitter wipes it all away until, letter by letter, a single word takes its place:
BLACKWHITE
"Blackwhite online," a voice says.
At the bottom of the screen, the outline of a thin rectangle stretches across. Pixels of white start to fill its inner void, left to right, with the slowness of nightfall.
"Smith credentials remain active. Unsealed are 1.16 exabytes of data. What will user Smith review?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The base's artificial intelligence, "Blackwhite", idles while a blinking cursor beckons for a command. The keyboard on the desk shimmers in the screen's dim glow.
Everything you've come across in your journey through Michigan floods your mind. Every question. Every puzzle. Every mystery.
Along the monitor's lower edge, the status bar steadily continues to fill. You may not get all your answers.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
An official seal rotates at the center of the screen, depicting an eagle clutching a key.
"Found one exact match. Philip Kindred, male, unspecified age. Registered at the Gyges Cryogenics Facility, Pod 05 Room 15. Treatment at the Saginaw Mental Institution for unspecified illness."
Except you walked out of that pod. How old could these records be? Displayed are thumbnails of maps, blueprints, and aerial photos of the facilities from a time before everything went to hell. You follow the link to your patient file, and it's oddly devoid of details. There's not even a photo.
Blackwhite adds, "No additional information. Unable to connect to CNCI MDR."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Numerous accounts of paranormal sightings by citizens around the Michigan area, characterized primarily by rodentine, insectoid, and/or spectral descriptions. Frequency of sightings correlates closely with population concentrations and growth."
'Around Michigan'? From what you've seen of late, most of Michigan has been ghost towns and wasteland.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Camp Grayling," Blackwhite replies. "44 35 51 North, 84 53 58 West. Crawford County, Michigan. Founded in 1913. It is the largest training facility for the United States National Guard.
"In 2016, Camp Grayling became a leading center for Unmanned Aerial Vehicle operations. When advancements in drone technology solved the need for individual pilots, UAVs functioned as a single unit, operated centrally with minimal human oversight.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Blackwhite is the cumulative artificial intelligence of Camp Grayling," the machine begins. "Its primary directive is to oversee AAV assets. Responsibilities include: the planning of flight patterns and routes, air traffic control, maintenance schedules, coordination with base personnel, and test data recording, processing, and optimization. Its secondary directive broadens the scope to encompass base security."
A task schedule comes on-screen, sharing space with a map of flight routes circulating between military bases across the country. "At present," it continues, "Blackwhite is coordinating a task still incomplete. The last AAV in use awaits a transfer order for its next rotation to Grissom AFB. A PCB containing this information, along with security clearance, is en route."
The monitor clears. Maybe if you can find that PCB...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With the ID card in hand, you find a thin chip-reader on the far side of the keyboard and insert the chip-end first.
"Recognized new user," it says. "Staff Sergeant Lydia F. Reyes."
"Please enter password."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You search the desk for a corresponding slot to the failsafe key. But the desk is clean. It's then that you notice the keyboard isn't completely anchored in place, only on the far two corners. You flip it up. A keyhole switch sitting squarely in the indentation proves a perfect fit.
"Engaging failsafe," Blackwhite responds. "User access elevated until end of session."
At the lower edge of the monitor, the status bar slows. You've bought yourself some time.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
To the side of the black desk you find a panel that opens an array of ports, only half of which you can recognize. On the lower end: USB, FireWire, HDMI, VGA, headset audio jacks. Ancient history.
With the bug device in hand you check it against the other slots, passing row after row. At the very top corner you find a heptagon-shaped port that looks to have never been used. It's the one.
The promise of Hatter's client conjures images of a whole new life to mind. You'd leave behind the wastelands, the dangers, the fear. What could be more important than living?
With a deep breath, you slide the bug into place. . .

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You recall the command code for the Anarchy process. They're strange and dark words, but Martha has it right. The PRISM Surveillance Network shouldn't be in anyone's hands, especially in times as desperate as these. The base must fall.
You switch input modes, and when Blackwhite accepts the instruction, you recite: "Always are the Martians coming."
"Command not recognized," it answers. "Awaiting another command."
"Reality has driven me insane," you continue.
"Clearance has been nullified. How will the user proceed?"
Last of all you say: "You learn to be quiet when you're crazy."
And everything goes dark.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
After a brief pause, Blackwhite comes to display hundreds of files, all listed under variant headings of ghost sightings.
"Blackwhite holds a catalog of alleged eyewitness accounts of spectral manifestations matching the user's color description. Several key locations are known to be sites of repeated incidents, such as..."
It goes on and on about the apparitions, none of which fits with what you've seen. You scroll through the search results until one stops you. You take a closer look.
Startled, you jerk backward in your chair. There, in a tiny thumbnail, is a blur you wish you didn't recognize.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
An icon resembling an eagle clutching a key rotates at the center of the screen.
You harbor few doubts about Blackwhite's reach. If anything can tell you about the faceless man you saw in a retrieved memory, it'll be this machine, now moments away from telling you who wiped your mind and froze your body in a tube. Mere moments.
The eagle vanishes.
"Found one exact match: records of one Bert Farris crossing the Indiana state border into Michigan in a dark blue sedan with plates DEC-1628. No other digital records of the individual can be found."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Blackwhite flickers. The status bar continues its climb.
"The PRISM Surveillance Network is the CNCI infrastructure focused on monitoring suspicious activity and logging data to the MDR. The gathering, processing, and managing of the data of PRISM is designated the zero directive."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Blackwhite's glassy face seems to darken. "New Earth Ostracon," it says.
"The NEO was an online repository of information concerning the occult which rapidly gained popularity worldwide between the years 2014 and 2017. The colloquially termed 'wiki' comprised of supposed eyewitness accounts of paranormal events, conspiracies, and fringe science discoveries. Entries included times and dates of sightings. All users had editor's rights and were free to contribute content, which grew the website exponentially.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You are at the home screen of Grayling's subterranean AI, Blackwhite. What will you query?

table.name: encounters
table.column: The progress bar continues its march as Blackwhite returns to the Home screen.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With mere seconds to spare, you can only watch as Blackwhite's status bar completes its march. 97. 98. 99. Your time has run out.
100. The screen flares blinding white.
"Unauthorized access detected. TS/SI-M violation. Escalating to Condition Charlie."
Alarms scream through the air and red lights spin around the room. "Terminal inputs disabled. Please vacate the server room immediately."
Unintelligible code interspersed with words like "lockdown" appears on the screen.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"The psychology community poses several theories for the rise of anthropomorphism in public consciousness, citing as factors: film and book releases, social media, the ease of photo-manipulation, and, chiefly among them, a general sense of growing unrest, even as quality of life nationwide reaches an all-time high."
The results that follow number in the hundreds of thousands, one less reputable than the next. You don't have time to wade through it all.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Later, an inter-agency initiative built an intelligence to manage drone assets independently. Grayling's UAVs were placed under its control and redesignated Autonomous Aerial Vehicles."
There's a pause. "These primary functions are handled by Blackwhite."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Take a long, deep breath, and climb down. The least you can do is check to see if they're alive.

Rotten egg smell. Probably hydrogen sulfide, from all the bacteria eating fetid, rotten sewage.
You make it to the bottom of the ladder, but you're not sure how long you can hold your breath. The risk is for naught, though, if you don't at least check for a pulse.
Twenty seconds later, and you know they're goners. Your lungs are bursting. The ladder looks impossibly high. With your vision starting to blur, you focus on putting your hand on the next rung. Don't know if you're going to make it.
You black out, unsure if you are out of the sewer or still inside...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Climb down. The least you can do is check to see if they're alive.

Rotten egg smell. Probably hydrogen sulfide, from all the bacteria eating fetid, rotten sewage.
You make it to the bottom of the ladder to check for a pulse. But twenty seconds later, you know they're goners.
The remaining enclavers reluctantly nod. Tears streaming down their faces, they head off, but not before leaving you with one of the dead men's food.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The on-screen status bar stops dead. "Unrecognized process detected," it says in an erratic voice, shifting octaves between one word to the next.
Everything on the monitor is erased. The lights shut off. A deeper quiet fills the room.
"Attempting..."
Its voice trails off, leaving you alone in darkness.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The status bar fills. Emergency lights spill waves of red around the room as alarms rip through the air. The monitor turns white.
"Unauthorized command," Blackwhite says, "system error."
Before you can move, you see why the desk sits on a raised platform in the middle of the room. It isn't for gravitas or appearances. It's to camouflage the fact that three-inch walls of ballistic glass can shoot up from the ground and seal you inside a giant coffin- and you're powerless but to watch that happen.
"Base personnel have been alerted. Do not move, and await further instructions."
From what you've seen around Grayling, you'll only be waiting for ghosts.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
When the screen comes on again, its light bathes the space around you into a sanctuary of mortal red. An insignia curdles black on the screen. It's a partly open eye encasing the lower half of a globe as its iris, while a sun at mid-rise is painted over the eyelid. But the way the rays and lashes curl-it's as if the world is on fire.
An eerie, fractured voice speaks, a conglomeration of people: "Another minute of the night is dispelled, and we are the hour of a brighter dawn drawing near. For your contribution, our gratitude undying is yours."
Then, a deafening alarm sounds. "To claim the base, we must purge it. Run now, citizen, if you wish to see the daylight come. Run, or stay forever in the night."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With fury blasting throughout the base, you knock back your chair and run desperately for the exit.
You escape the desk in the last possible moment; walls of glass shoot up from the ground and seal the terminal, sending up your back foot and throwing you against the floor with a hard and painful thud.
On your feet again, you keep running. You don't look back.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The next thing you know, you've returned to the concrete shaft, squeezing back up towards the surface. One by one, the emergency lights below you shut down. Darkness wells up from the depths of the earth, and you're caught in its warpath.
What will you even do? The V-MADS on the surface will be out in full force. And who knows what new horrors await alongside the ADS turrets and energized fence.
But there has to be a way to escape. There has to be.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You try using the console. You try destroying it. You try breaking through the clear walls. But all you manage to do is wear yourself out.
"I am awaiting personnel," repeats Blackwhite. "You will be questioned."
Every five minutes you hear the same reminder and it slows the passage of time. Your breathing quickens. There's no air coming in or out.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I am awaiting personnel. You will be questioned."
