The hours bleed together beneath a crushing headache. You can't focus. Sparks fill your blurring eyes. Your legs can no longer hold you.
"I am awaiting personnel. You will be questioned."
Gasps. Choking. Fear. Let it end, you hear someone beg. Let it end. No one is there but you.
"I am awaiting. . ."
And the darkness comes.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The glass reverts to darkness. You catch yourself holding your breath. Your whole body turns tense as drying bones.
Traffic cam footage plays. Nighttime. Three in the morning. An intersection, grainy and dark, spotted with streetlight orange and ambient maroons. A traffic light turns red. Car lights lead your eye to an oncoming SUV slowing to a halt.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Then, a blur of static. And you see it. There. Moving to the car. Tires turn. A burst forward. Fast. Desperate. And soon, helpless.
The static clears. Black skid marks now lead your eye up. The SUV is wrecked, overturned and half-buried into a building. On the empty street, the tires keep turning. Until they stop.
A few more pieces of footage follow, all with the same outcome.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Blackwhite loads a map of Michigan state, and on it begins drawing a path through several cities: north to Sturgis, then east through Coldwater, northeast to Jackson, and finally east to Ann Arbor. Until the last stop, the driver never spends more than a day at each location.
Three days after arriving, the path continues north through Brighton, then Burton, and comes to rest at Saginaw.
An on-screen prompt then indicates that a week later, the vehicle was towed away.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Blackwhite splits the screen into three.
On the left, you see a patchwork of aerial images and fixed-camera footage of various sites across the state: Detroit's high-rises, suburbs, restaurants, open roads, even wilderness. Most of the signals appear to be noisy, inactive, or dead, but for those that are live, it's shown with unbelievable clarity.
The middle panel shows text communications, a mix of clear text and jibberish, logged with identifying info where available. Times, frequencies, latitude and longitude are all listed.
A dwindling amount of more traditional info such as email addresses, phone numbers, and IPs accompanies older data.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The right panel shows a spectrum visualizer that matches snippets of conversations being played. Like a hybrid of the other panels, whole channels appear dead or garbled, and tagging is incomplete. However, those that are still live are myriad in nature: patrol check-ins, business birthday messages, filthy travelers' banter, voicemails, children phoning their parents.
The system is merely a shadow of itself. The infrastructure and protocols upon which it relied now fading. But from what you've seen here, at one point it simply monitored everything in the region.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Ten curators with administrative rights to the NEO have been identified in the US.
"After a security violation was traced to these curators, various agencies of the United States government formed a taskforce to apprehend these individuals on charges of espionage. The NEO was subsequently shut down, although users repeatedly created mirror sites to keep it alive."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"The violation involved the following components: a comparison algorithm, a native dataset, and a foreign dataset.
"A fourth component, the output of the algorithm itself, has been redacted from Blackwhite and all storage devices."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"The comparison algorithm was developed by the National Security Agency. Its purpose: to analyze vast amounts of communications data in order to extrapolate common patterns and deduce the presence of national threats and terrorist plots prior to execution.
"Input can take the form of multiple formats in any and all known human languages. Coded communications can also be deciphered at runtime. The output of the algorithm includes: lists of persons of interest, potential targets, possible scenarios, and suspected factions coordinating attack.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You spend some time studying the faces, the names. But you can recognize none of them with any certainty. Strangers. Family. You'd just be guessing.
"Reports are available for neutralized members. Read now?"
The euphemism rings in your ears.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With the status bar marching onward, you try to cycle quickly through the files.
At first everything seems normal. Basic information precedes summaries of their manhunt, documenting cat-and-mouse chases of various lengths. But a strange phrase terminates the accounts: "Contractor intervention. Ordered to withdraw."
What follows the pages is a grizzly sight: a crimson mosaic of crime scene photos. Torn-up rooms, car accidents, nature trails. Everywhere. But there's no police tape, no micro rulers, no detailed shots in any of them. It's as if there was only an interest in showing the damage, not finding who or what spilled all the blood.
That's when you notice: you're only at #9.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You find the report on the tenth member thin of any tangible information. Peter Karl Davidson, male, no date of birth or photograph given. No descriptors of height, weight, hair or eye color. A blank slate.
You scroll through. Only the very next page has anything written, and you skim past the first line even though something about it bugs you. Below it, you find a series of brief leads across the country essentially following the footsteps of the contractor. But all meet dead-ends. The final line reads: "Currently missing. Last confirmed location: southern Indiana. Contractor gone. Possible intervention."
You read the first line again.
"Missing. Known to use many aliases."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Blackwhite plays a recording on the monitor. It shows only a bird's-eye view of a diner out in the middle of nowhere. But it's picking up audio. You hear forks and knives cutting against plates, and two people locked in hushed conversation.
"Because they can't do that," a male voice says. "CPL S. CHISHOLM, MOS 15-E" appears at the bottom while he speaks. "I didn't sign up to spy on my own people."
"But you don't have proof," says UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER. "You can put it on NEO, sure. But who's going to believe baseless conspiracy allegations?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"The native dataset included CNCI MDR datasets.
"Foreign dataset estimated to be many times smaller than the native dataset."
"Additional information unavailable: unable to connect to MDR."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Maybe." Chisholm seems to think a moment. "You know? Maybe I do. I have AAV flight plans. Transfer schedules. Their damned mainframe is under our base."
There's a pause.
"I could get in."
There's a long silence. Clinking and murmurs continue in the background.
The unidentified voice replies, "You sure you want to do that?"
"Yeah..." He doesn't sound sure. But then his confidence renews. "Yes. I'm sure. Beats doing this shit another day."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Camp Grayling's war cry shatters the air. Alarm lights pulse red, drawing in the walls of the hangar to surround you. Its vast emptiness only serves as a paper fortress. Your options are few.
Crossing the hangar, you make your way to the side door. The V-MADS have gained reinforcements and they dominate the grounds, patrolling at a faster pace than before. The thought of slipping past them crosses your mind. But as if the base's sensors catch wind of it, the V-MADS all immediately turn to face you.
You slam shut the door. Not on foot.
Nearly lost in swellings of red, the cone of pale light still directs your eyes. The AAV.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You estimate that you can just fit into the empty weapons bay. You'd be shielded from the V-MADS, but they would out-wait you.
Maybe this thing could still fly? Could you escape inside it? Even so, no machine can run without all its parts, and the square absence in the drone's exposed side panel hangs agape. Is that crate holding the right part?
The hangar doors hum to life, creeping open. Your time may be up.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Search the body on the left.

On the body's fatigues, you read the name "SMITH" just above a small, irregular hole. Exit wound? One hand clutches an old pistol. You find nothing in the pockets. But when you move the carcass, something shifts beneath the shirt.
Sealed in plastic, you find two printed circuit boards roughly the right size.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Search the body on the right.

The fatigues on this one read "SHEPHERD" near the breast pocket, a bullet hole in the skull. Apart from a pistol by its hand, you find nothing until you check under the remains.
Two printed circuit boards, miraculously shielded from human decay by plastic coverings, now rest in your hands.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Pulling the PCB from the packing materials, you return to the AAV. Alarms rage. Seconds slip away. The V-MADS deathsquad awaits hangar doors with predatory patience.
A prayer catches in your throat. It's just you here. You and death.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With the PCB slotted in, the drone breathes once more, a shrill whine of life in its engine lungs. It throttles up.
Enduring sections of the hangar doors groan through decades of rust as they ease open, V-MADS now marching through.
You climb inside the drone. It starts gaining momentum across the floor of the hangar, closer and closer towards the deathly gaze of the V-MADS.
You dare not hazard a look, but you can hear the crushing steps grow louder and then distant again as the AAV taxis outside. It turns almost in place, and then catapults down the runway.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With the PCB slotted in, the drone breathes once more, a shrill hum of life in its engine lungs. It jolts forward.
The V-MADS break through.
Enduring sections of the hangar doors groan through decades of rust as they ease open. You climb inside the drone. It starts gaining momentum across the floor of the hangar, closer and closer towards the crushing steps and deathly gaze of the V-MADS.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With the PCB slotted in, the drone breathes once more, a shrill hum of life in its engine lungs. It jolts forward.
The V-MADS break through.
Enduring sections of the hangar doors groan through decades of rust as they ease open. You climb inside the drone. It starts gaining momentum across the floor of the hangar, closer and closer towards the crushing steps and deathly gaze of the V-MADS.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You take flight.
The AAV sails through the mist, higher and higher above Camp Grayling. Frost seeps into the air. Without any way to fasten yourself, you push hard against the sides, a ghost inside a machine clinging desperately to his shell.
The drone levels out before reaching much of an altitude. It turns. When it feels safe to poke your head up, you see that you're headed south. North past the tail fins, you see the small base silhouetted in red emergency lights, the three spheres of Grayling standing helpless against the escape of their prey, and the endless darkness swallowing all of Michigan.
You lie back again and look up through dense clouds at stars you cannot see.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You startle awake.
No, it hasn't all just been a dream. You're still sitting in the AAV as its payload when a sudden jerk wakes you from the slumber of trauma-induced exhaustion.
When you look out the top, all you can see of your former surroundings is a lake of mist far to the north. Below: the Great Black Swamp. To see it sprawl from east to west, an antithesis of life, the necrosis of civilization- it's a haunting view beneath.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The drone hits something hard, the weightless rebound ringing in your ears for a moment before smashing and grinding through what sounds like rocks and water. Parts rip away, and sludge sprays into the hold from the openings they leave.
The fuselage twists right suddenly and flips over, throwing you hard into a debris-filled pool. Wrenching metal and cracks of composites echo over the next mound as the drone becomes just another part of the desolate landscape.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
In a fit of coughing, you crane your neck away from the sludge, and pull yourself weakly onto an embankment.
For several wheezing moments, you cling to the earth, gathering your senses.
After more coughing, you plant a hand in the cold mud, push the ground away, and stagger to your feet. A brisk, acrid wind bites through your soaked clothes, and you turn to face away from it.
Ahead, miles of lifeless, muddy terrain, punctuated by toxic pools and shells of old buildings.
And beyond that, Indiana.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Another "crack!" accompanies a smell of burning plastic as you duck into your compartment again.
The engines are failing, and there's a ragged whistling noise coming from the tail. The drone is no longer flying but in a controlled fall.
You hazard a peek outside. More and more of the swamp passes below. You glide past the rotting lands, the sinking roads, the crumbling buildings, the toxic fumes- but you're falling too fast to make a full crossing.
You duck inside, and brace for the inevitable...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Okay," says Unidentified. "Don't do anything yet. Let me talk to some people."
There's another pause, then Unidentified continues. "You're going to need some help."
The recording cuts out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You are querying NEO as Blackwhite's progress bar ticks away.

table.name: encounters
table.column: See if you can escalate your user credentials.

It's an unfamiliar system, but you see some hints that betray the kernel's origins. Maybe some of your old tricks still work...
Blackwhite responds. "User access elevated until end of session."
At the lower edge of the monitor, the status bar slows. You've bought yourself some time.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"The Comprehensive National Cybersecurity Initiative (CNCI) is a multi-agency security initiative which coordinates network defense and counterintelligence efforts.
The Mission Data Repository (MDR) is the central data store in support of the CNCI. Sufficient storage for all regional CNCI facility feeds is maintained at the data center.
The MDR is maintained by the National Security Agency, and is located at Camp W. G. Williams in Utah."
Huh, Utah. Better find some decent walking shoes.

table.name: encounters
table.column: See if you can figure out what's causing that pain.

Trying to make sense of the invisible field of pain, you're willing to bet it's those emitter pylons in the midfield. And judging by the way the fence blocks it, it's probably some EM field they emit.
In fact, the fence is probably tight mesh for exactly this reason. A lot like the mesh window in a microwave.
And like a microwave, mere cloth isn't going to shield you from it. Something more reflective, however...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Getting through the fence and around the base is going to be hard enough with your hands free, let alone with a cumbersome vehicle.
You're going to have to leave the vehicle outside the fence.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Enter Camp Grayling using the foil.

Getting through the fence and around the base is going to be hard enough with your hands free, let alone with a cumbersome vehicle.
You're going to have to leave the vehicle outside the fence.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're back at Camp Grayling's imposing gates.
A fine mesh fence continues through the woods on either side of the gates, just clearing the tree line. To your right, the fence skirts a path that leads down to a body of water. To your left, it runs deep into dark forest, foreboding and beckoning at the same.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Login incorrect. If you have forgotten your login credentials, please email you base's DPI officer for login reset instructions."
The status bar along the bottom of the screen speeds up somewhat.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "The security incident, designated security violation, occurred at 40 28 24 North, 111 56 40 West," Blackwhite begins. "Evidence of two perpetrators discovered. Investigators confirmed that one of the two had TS//SI-M/TK-L clearance.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
But the stillness of Blackwhite only lasts a short while. The machines and lights return to life as before, surrounding you in a rising tide. But it seems louder than it once was.
When the monitor returns with name and status bar, Blackwhite speaks in a voice twice as loud. "Code: Anarchy initiated. All assets will be terminated, all data will be erased, and all functions will cease. Blackwhite must now invoke Condition Charlie to ensure the command's execution. All defenses are authorized to use lethal force against intruders."
A screeching alarm pulses through your ears. "The terminal will lock down any attempts of access while awaiting executive confirmation."
You stagger away from the desk. Something's gone wrong.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The status bar fills. Emergency lights spill waves of red around the room as alarms rip through the air. The monitor turns white.
"Unauthorized command," Blackwhite says, "system error."
Before you can move, you see why the desk sits on a raised platform in the middle of the room. It isn't for gravitas or appearances. It's to camouflage the fact that three-inch walls of ballistic glass can shoot up from the ground and seal you inside a giant coffin- and you're powerless but to watch that happen.
"Base personnel have been alerted. Do not move, and await further instructions."
From what you've seen around Grayling, you'll only be waiting for ghosts.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
'Suspicious activity' strikes as the most nebulous phrase in its explanation. And you shudder to think how broad its definitions have been before.
What exactly was seen as suspicious?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The woman lowers her gun a bit. "Oh. Well, you should move along. It's dangerous here. If you have no business with Camp Grayling, I suggest you leave.
"Did you hear me? Go!" she says, stepping forward with the gun.
Something about her...
In any case, she won't let up. You return to the fenceline.

table.name: encounters
table.column: I've come here to scavenge from the base.

Your answer surprises the woman, not in defiance of expectations, but confirming them. She aims. "Then you are an enemy of Martha's Army."
You turn and run before she can fire. But you don't get far before shots ring out.

table.name: encounters
table.column: I want to burn Grayling down.

The woman holds still. "You're lying," she says, her voice steadier than the mist.
"No," you plead. "This base has to be destroyed. I have committed to that, and it is the only reason I've come here, dangerous as it is."
She eases forward, never pointing her gun away. You stand still.
When she's close enough that you can see the hazel of her eyes surrounded by blue and orange dazzle facepaint, she asks: "Are you really telling the truth?"
You nod.
She all but drops her gun. "Oh, thank god."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You return to where the trees yield to grass, and a large stone stands defiantly.
However, no one else is here anymore.

table.name: encounters
table.column: As you approach, you can't help staring at his face paint. It looks like someone tested an entire shape stencil sheet on his face.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"You carryin'?" he asks, stopping a short distance away.
You look at him, confused.
"Tracking devices," he exhales. "Bugs. Hardware. Got anything switched on?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: "We move without *them* watching," he nods upward. He doesn't stop to talk.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Are there any cities around here?

"Hmph," he snorts, "cities. Cesspools of Big Government, tracking the sheeple, is more like it."
He squares off with you. "Let me give you a bit of advice. Stay out of any so-called cities, if you know what's good for you."
He starts walking past you. "Their 'security' is something you buy with your freedom."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"My identity is my own," he says confrontationally. "No government needs to track me."
Okay. "Who's tracking you?"
"Nobody. That's the point," he asserts, before walking off.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You look down at yourself. "No, I...don't think."
"Jesus," he huffs, "get your act together. Do you really want to be tracked everywhere you go?"
He mutters and gives you a wide berth.

table.name: encounters
table.column: What do you do out here?

"Mind my own business," he says, looking askew at you.
"Sorry," you offer.
"Privacy is what keeps us alive." He starts walking on, adding, "pity our forebears didn't feel the same."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Why are you so obsessed with being tracked?

"Are you kiddin'? Do you have any idea how we got here?" He gestures around him.
"Where? Michigan?"
"Does this look like Michigan to you?" He looks genuinely disturbed. "See anyone playing in their backyards here? No? 24-hour quick marts? Air traffic?"
You admit that you don't.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Ever wonder why?" he asks.
"You have no idea."
"'Cause they knew right where to hit us."
You're both silent a few moments. That's a new one on you.
"Get it? They had tabs on everyone they saw as a threat, and," he snaps his fingers. "Taken out like that."
"And the rest?" he continues. "The rest of the sheeple? Corralled into tightly monitored pens where they can be controlled."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Out here," he starts walking. "This is all we got left. They see you out here..."
He leaves without another word.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Privacy is our greatest asset," he recites as he passes by you.
"Anonymity is our greatest weapon."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Ao viajar no mundo do NEO Scavenger, voce notara alguns hexagonos com caixas ou lupas sobre eles.
As caixas significam que o hex possui itens para retirar. Um contorno de ouro significa que ha itens novos desde que voce esteve por la.
A lupa significam que o hex pode ser vasculhado atras de itens. A maioria das coisas que sao uteis deve ser encontrada vasculhando os hex.
No entanto, vasculhar leva tempo e energia, e voce arrisca toda vez que voce vasculhar.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Voce esta no estacionamento do Gyges-Cryo-Facility, mas tudo parece estar em desuso e em falta. As plantas seguiram o pavimento e as instalacoes.
O pior e que nada parece familiar. Voce nao se lembra deste lugar, nem mesmo de quem es voce. Sua frustracao se monta, mas voce o coloca sob controle. Podendo assim dar uma olhada ao redor.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The distant report of a gun disrupts your thoughts. You cock your head, listening, but it's over as quickly as it started.
Obviously you're not alone out here. Though that doesn't necessarily comfort you.
You snap out of it. "First things first," you tell yourself. "Let's make sure we've lost that...thing."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"These are dark times," she greets you.
You nod. "You could say that."
"Though," she adds, seizing upon your willingness to talk, "sometimes darkness can be on our side."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "You'll have to excuse our manners," she concedes. "Us conspiracy-types tend to wax poetic. Comes with the territory."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Where there is security," she opines, "there is no liberty."
She doesn't stop to talk.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Privacy is our greatest asset," she recites as she passes by you.
"Anonymity is our greatest weapon!"

table.name: encounters
table.column: He eyes you suspiciously for a moment. "We'll see. It's on you if you're lyin'." And with that, he heads off.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
He grabs it from your hands, and throws it to the ground.
"What the-" you start, but he's already smashing it to bits with a stone. "What are you doing?!"
"Doing you a favor," he says, thumbing upward towards the sky, as if someone were there. "Best clear outta here before big brother makes its move."
He starts to leave.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I mean darkness can be a shroud. A mantle against prying eyes."
Your look is not one of apprehension.
"Used to be they could see everything. Everyone. They could manipulate us."
They?
"But their eyes are gone now, and we are truly free." She seems relieved.

table.name: encounters
table.column: How did things get this way?

"I'm glad you asked," she replies. "We did it to ourselves, sadly."
She looks upward for a moment, "we wanted security. We wanted it more than we did our liberty." She turns her gaze back towards you.
"There's a thing that happens when one gives up freedom for security," she says. "We give up privacy. We give up anonymity." And, pausing for effect, "We give up control."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"We must be vigilant, though." Her face hardens. "We cannot return to those times. The times of constant tracking and control."
She pulls out a smartphone, and holds it out. "There is always someone searching. Watching us."
She places it on the ground. "And if we let them, they control us." She slams her foot onto it, cracking its face.
"Break your shackles. Keep your liberty!" She parts ways.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"We kept prying and recording, building tools to watch and control."
She steps back, "until those tools controlled us."
Turning to leave, she parts with one final thought. "Martha's Army pledges to never let that happen again."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"What is it you do?" you ask.
"We dismantle the tools of slavery, mainly. Though not slavery as you may think of it."
She scratches her cheek with her shoulder. "The slavery we fight is that which nobody sees. The slavery of ourselves to those in control."
"Who's in control?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: Why are you guys always smashing electronics?

"It's a bit more complex than that," she starts. "The smashing is mainly for show, and to make a point."
"We still use tech, of course. It's just," she thinks a moment. "Some tech tries to use us, if you get my meaning. By using tools that broadcast our positions and keep our darkest secrets, we make ourselves vulnerable to those who control the tools."
"Unless," she counters, "we shun those tools."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Martha's Army actually has sophisticated hardware, too. We've just gutted the parts that keep tabs on us."
"Though," she admits as she leaves, "the smashing does feel good from time to time!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Never been a person of faith," she starts. "Been stalling here, though, hoping I wouldn't have to wait much longer."
"What are you doing here?" you ask.
She looks at you. She doesn't seem older than twenty. "I'm the contact. From Martha's Army? I take it one of our friends finally found someone to accept our job commission?"
"Oh," you cover, "no, of course. I meant, why alone?"
She shrugs. "A joke, I guess? Among the new recruits. Test of bravery. All because of my name."
"Which is?"
She gives you a look.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
No way.
She sees the recognition in your eyes. "Yeah. You got it."
"But you're not..."
"'The' Martha? 'Course not. But enough about that. You want to know what your mission is, right? Then listen up."
"Took a lot of hard work for us to uncover this intel, but here it is: there's actually a way to fry everything in Camp Grayling. Code: Anarchy, it's called, built right into the system. Once it's used, the entire base will just be a scrap heap of metal and tin. No circuits, no hardware, no software. Nothing. And the PRISM Surveillance Network will have a permanent blindspot. It'll never be used against the people here again."
"Isn't that a wonderful thing?" she says, eyes filled with hope.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"All you need to initiate it," Martha begins, taking a key from a half-filled pocket at her side, "is this failsafe key, and the right command codes. From what we gather, there's likely an OSHA binder somewhere with every command that can be issued. Check the control tower first. If it's not there, keep looking around."
"Once you know the command code, you'll have to find the system mainframe. Where that is, not even we know for sure. It's big, though. You can't hide something that big easily."
"One last thing: make sure you trigger the failsafe key first, and then issue the command code. In that order. Otherwise, it won't work. Got it?"
You nod.
"Good luck, friend," she says, almost with genuine worry.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Head back to the fence, but beware where you look.

As you move away from Martha, an admitted 'rookie' member of a group, alone in the wilds, entrusted with what could be its most valuable find, you consider what you glimpsed briefly when she took out the failsafe key from her pocket.
A pocket half-filled with identical keys.
You also refrain from looking back through the trees on the other side of the rock, cautious that the dozens of shadows lurking there need to stay unseen for you to be let go.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Oooooh, a counter offer," Stoat says, stroking his chin, "Hm. Hm."
"Okay. Tell you what," he snaps into action. "I got a thing. Some place that needs, uh, certain items 'liberated'," he makes air quotes. "You trade the bracelet, I'll let you in on the haul. Here's what's up."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Camp Grayling-you heard of it, right? Big ol' military base somewhere in Michigan? No? Guess you have to be in certain circles." He flicks something invisible from his coat.
"All sorts of rumors about the place. The one thing that's sure: it's full of tech and no one to tinker with it. Meanwhile..." he knocks the combine bot, producing a hollow ring. "Sucks, right?"
"Your part is simple." He places a hand on your shoulder. "Maybe you've seen a bot around here. Tall, tin fellow? Six legs? Mauling some guy? That's the one. Well, wherever he came from, there's gotta be more. And if I'm doing this with farm machinery, imagine what I could do with old spidey maulers." He pantomimes an explosion while puffing up his cheeks.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"But," Stoat waves a finger at nothing, "I don't expect you to pilot these babies out of there. What I need you to do is get inside the base and bring back everything you can find on them. Schematics, blueprints, test data. The more the better."
"Be warned: it's a deathmachine nest. You think these are brutal?" Stoat gestures around the prep yard. "Drunk, angry teenagers compared to trained assassins.
"In return," he says, scratching his chin, "Iiiiii'm thinking the power structure will be shifting a bit around here. And the new one will be of the 'I owe you' variety," he points at your chest.
"So? Deal of a lifetime, dude."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Nice!" he laughs.
He extends a hand. You meet it with yours.
"Okay. Like I said, it's a deathmachine nest. But I've got some goodies for that. Let's say it's an advance payment? Or a signing bonus? Either way."
"Step one," he says, counting it out with a finger, "that bracelet. Still need me some cryo goodness, after all."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
The look and manner you've been getting used to fades into disinterest.
"Ah, well" he says. "Bummer, though. Guess I'll be a millionaire all on my own."
"Exit's that way. Going along the fence is your best bet, like those other two did." He thumbs towards the fence where the patron and mechanic escaped. He passes a glance over your shoulder. "And you'll want your stuff, right?"
A familiar face walks up and drops a lockbox with your checked items.
"Warning ya, though. If you do end up seeing Grayling, you're going to kick yourself," he says as he makes his way to the warehouse.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Unsure whether you want to give up the strap, you self-consciously fidget with it a moment, then read it over once more. Instead, you decide to share the facility address, but keep your name to yourself.
"Smart," he says, tapping the side of his head with his index finger. "You're a smart dude. Tell you what," he starts unlatching a flightcase near the combine bot. An array of electronic parts and gadgets fill the case. Scanning his hand across the range of parts, he selects one, then closes the case again.
"Here, " he hands you some sort of measuring device. "It'll keep you healthy. Remember it when you get there."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You snap the printed bracelet from your wrist, and hand it to him. He slides it through his fingers, reading the lettering on the strap.
"Niiice, dude," he bobs his head, "I may have to do an expedition there. And, and! Nice naaaame, ha ha." He starts unlatching a flightcase near the combine bot. An array of electronic parts and gadgets fill the case, and he tosses the bracelet inside. Scanning his hand across the range of parts, he selects one, then closes the case again.
"Here, " he hands you an orange box, with screw mounts on it. "Insurance for when you get there. Hold onto it."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
He looks over your shoulder. "Oh, also, you'll probably want these back."
You turn, and see a familiar face from the front gate. She drops a lockbox with your checked items.
You cast a glance back at The Stoat, and he shrugs, "What? I can't do this alone."
"Your safest bet is to go along the fence, where they went," he thumbs over his shoulder, indicating the route the mechanic and patron followed. "Unless you're still hungry," he laughs, mocking a vomiting motion.
"See you around, dude!" he calls over his shoulder, walking back to the warehouse.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"As for me, I may have to check into your fancy clinic soon. I think I'm coming down with a little something," he fake coughs and clears his throat, grinning.
"Step two? Get inside. The goodish-baddish news is that your new toy will help, but you'll likely need to supplement with tricks of your own."
"Nobody's come back from there, though rumor has it some protesters managed to embarrass the brass at Grayling back in the day."
"You'd probably have to rummage through some old newspaper stories to verify that, though."

table.name: encounters
table.column: You cross the muddy street towards the old flophouse.

table.name: encounters
table.column: On second thought, maybe you don't have anything to discuss right now.

table.name: encounters
table.column: See if Hatter has any work for you.

You step off the familiar lift, and Hatter turns to look at you, finishing his conversation.
"Private call with a client, boys," Hatter says to his hired guns. "Don't worry if this one kills me; your pensions are nil either way."
He circles behind his desk. And when the guards shut the doors behind them, he says, "We have to talk."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Some people have reached out to me. Some very powerful, very dangerous people who made it abundantly clear that I'm to tread lightly with this. Hence the privacy."
"I can't tell you too many details, not until I know you're taking it on. What I can tell you is that it pays well. Frankly, given the compensation package, you may never need for a thing again."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"The catch is, well, as you might imagine. This is no cakewalk. The target is well-protected, and you're expected to infiltrate rather than assault. Otherwise, I'd be having this conversation with a merc company."
"And, of course, your discretion is implied in the price."
"I should tell you: risks being what they are, I can only offer this to you once." He sits back, giving you a few moments to take this all in.
"Can I count on you?"

table.name: encounters
table.column: No way. Leave me out of this.

Hatter seems relieved, then surprised at his own reaction. "Honestly, I don't blame you. Some things are just worth more than money," he concludes.
"And I'll admit, I don't mind if this client's watchful eye finds another fixer."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Hatter scratches his head. "I wish I could be more forthcoming. I have no doubt that they're motivated, with the financing to match. I wholly expect they'll pay upon delivery."
You press him for more.
He leans in. "Let's just say there's a group out there who doesn't get a lot of credit. Paranoid luddites, seeing monsters in the shadows where there aren't any, and the like. Fearing something coming."
"My client? They may be the feared thing. As real as you and me."
Hatter dons a strained smile. "So. Interested?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Hatter seems more stressed than relieved. "I was afraid you'd say that. But for the record, I chose you for a reason. Resourcefulness is a valued trait these days."
From the reigning mess in his office, he takes an atlas nearly fallen apart and pages to a map of Michigan. "Up here," he says, circling an area in the far north, "there's a military base. Camp Grayling, it used to be called, before the National Guard abandoned it."
"But don't get your hopes up. It's said they left behind a state-of-the-art security system. All unmanned, of course. Just machines without masters who, as far as I know, have let no trespasser live. Ever."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Hatter's guard informs you that Hatter's on important business right now, and isn't expected back soon.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"But," Hatter exhales in a chuckle that's one part defeat, the other bemused. "Mind over matter, right?"
He takes out a small device from his pocket. "Your job, besides infiltration, is to plant this right into the base's intelligence mainframe. The software'll do the rest, I'm told. Where that mainframe is, however, remains unclear. But the databanks they used in those days were huge. Look for the biggest building, and expect the doorway to be unobvious."
"The most important thing: do NOT insert the bug without finding an ID badge on-site first. The barracks might be a decent bet for that."
"Once the bug is in place, all you have to do is make your way back here and we'll- well, begin operation 'easy living', so to speak."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Well," Hatter smiles, "not *together*. But yes, I'll be taking my usual cut. And it'll do well enough for me, too."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Hatter shrugs. "Can't say I know. There was a bit of a stink back in the day about that place. That so-called PRISM surveillance network."
"But dwelling on that might be dangerous, to be honest. As I've said, these folks are serious business."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Wow," Hatter says, some of his tension dissipating. "That really is the spirit, right there. And here I was wishing I could have had the backbone to refuse their deal. Hah!"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"But enough about that." Hatter buzzes the guards back in. "You have work to do. And I? Well, I have a million things on my bucket list in case you really don't make it back."
The guards allow you through, and before long, you're bracing yourself against the chill air of the Sprawl's streets.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"That's the good news, in fact." He leans back in his chair. "Take your time on this one. Do some reconnoitering. Gather the resources you need first."
"The client wants it done sooner than later, but they don't have an immediate deadline. That it's done is more important to them than when."

table.name: encounters
table.column: You move away from Martha, back towards the fence. Casting a glance back over your shoulder, you're unsurprised to not see her there.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With weakened legs, you fail to clear one foot past the shin of the other and you take a tumble. You stop, and that's when you feel it: a void. A cold one.
You sit up. In the distance, the turrets are turning away from you. You've done it. Somehow you managed to clear the field.
As you stand, a rush of pain returns to you, but it's residual. As fast as you ran, you endured a concentrated and prolonged scorching, and your body won't forget its wounds.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Slipping outside, you have but a few seconds to make your next move before those V-MADS pin you.
The tower is closest, with the barracks beyond that. And across the open tarmac, the shed.
However, even the tower is far enough away that you doubt you'd make it alive.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Slipping outside, you have but a few seconds to make your next move before those V-MADS pin you.
The hangar and barracks are closest, flanking the tower, and across the open tarmac is the shed.
However, even the nearest buildings are far enough away that you doubt you'd make it alive.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Slipping outside, you have but a few seconds to make your next move before those V-MADS pin you.
The tower is closest, with the hangar beyond that. And across the open tarmac, the shed.
However, even the tower is far enough away that you doubt you'd make it alive.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run through them to the storage shed, unprotected.

You cast your eyes past the V-MADS, across to the greater buildings. Going straight through would be suicide, but maybe you can skirt around.
You run. But not three steps in, the emitters all find your unburned body and decide, really, that just can't just be left as is. You feel the compound strength of milliwave pulses immediately set your skin ablaze with agony. Your pace shrivels down in seconds. You try to push through. But it's useless.
Your knees give in and you're pinned to the ground by the pain. The V-MADS approach. The burning grows and grows and grows across crackling skin, bursting blisters, and flesh-pink fissures.
You close your eyes. The corpses of Grayling will soon have another friend.

table.name: encounters
table.column: See if you can disable those V-MADS bots.

You look over the workstations for any signs of what controls those V-MADS. Unfortunately, it looks as if they're coordinated from some other location. Most of the stuff up here is for human-operated vehicles.
What you do find, however, is a security request system. Operators in this tower could apparently request a security check in specified sectors of the base. Probably in response to or anticipation of activity seen from the tower.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Skimming the logs for past examples, you start composing a new request. Then, you check the windows for possible sectors.
Given the base's layout, there are few choices. You can probably draw some extra attention to the far side of the barracks, giving you a chance to dart into the maintenance hangar safely. But that's about it. All other routes are too exposed, putting you at risk.
Do you want to submit the request?

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide to hold that thought for now.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You finish inputting the sector and event code, and hit "Submit". It looks like it went through okay, so you check the windows to be sure.
After a few moments, it's clear the search patterns of the V-MADS are adjusting to your submitted request.
If you hurry down now, you can probably reach the maintenance hangar safely.

table.name: encounters
table.column: See if there's something up here to stop those V-MADS.

You look over the workstations for any signs of what controls those V-MADS. Unfortunately, it looks as if they're coordinated from some other location. Most of the stuff up here is for human-operated vehicles.
Though that probably means base personnel have some way of interrupting automated operations.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Changing your search accordingly, you manage to find the Emergency Services Request System. Tower personnel can designate an area open to emergency services, such as fire or medical teams, which might just give you the space you need.
However, given the base's layout, there are few choices. You can probably open up the section between here and the maintenance hangar, giving you a chance to dart across to it. But that's about it. All other routes are too exposed, putting you at risk.
Do you want to submit the request?

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A moment of rushing air and fear is all you experience before the V-MADS lock onto you, painting your entire body in white-hot pain.
You nearly stumble when it hits, but set your jaw and plod onward instead. This may be the most excruciating pain you've felt, but this wouldn't be the first time you've toughed out the hurt.
You slam into the hangar's personnel door, clawing at the handle...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A moment of rushing air and fear is all you experience before the V-MADS lock onto you, painting your entire body in white-hot pain.
You nearly stumble when it hits, but force yourself to focus on your goal, and plod onward barely in control.
You slam into the hangar's personnel door, clawing at the handle...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Momentarily safe from your mechanical pursuers, you hurry across the tarmac to the maintenance hangar.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A moment of rushing air and fear is all you experience before the V-MADS lock onto you, painting your entire body in white-hot pain.
You nearly stumble when it hits, but set your jaw and plod onward instead. This may be the most excruciating pain you've felt, but this wouldn't be the first time you've toughed out the hurt.
You slam into the barracks' door, clawing at the handle...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A moment of rushing air and fear is all you experience before the V-MADS lock onto you, painting your entire body in white-hot pain.
You nearly stumble when it hits, but force yourself to focus on your goal, and plod onward barely in control.
You slam into the barracks' door, clawing at the handle...

table.name: encounters
table.column: ...and as the door opens, you feel the burning trail off until the door slams behind you, leaving you in darkness and throbbing aches.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run to the barracks unprotected, cont'd
...and as the door opens, you feel the burning trail off until the door slams behind you, leaving you in darkness and throbbing aches.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run towards the control tower, unprotected.

A moment of rushing air and fear is all you experience before the V-MADS lock onto you, painting your entire body in white-hot pain.
You nearly stumble when it hits, but set your jaw and plod onward instead. This may be the most excruciating pain you've felt, but this wouldn't be the first time you've toughed out the hurt.
You slam into the tower's door, clawing at the handle...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
A moment of rushing air and fear is all you experience before the V-MADS lock onto you, painting your entire body in white-hot pain.
You nearly stumble when it hits, but force yourself to focus on your goal, and plod onward barely in control.
You slam into the tower's door, clawing at the handle...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run to the tower unprotected, cont'd
...and as the door opens, you feel the burning trail off until the door slams behind you, leaving you in darkness and throbbing aches.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run past the tower to the hangar, unprotected.

A moment of rushing air and fear is all you experience before the V-MADS lock onto you, painting your entire body in white-hot pain.
You nearly stumble when it hits, but force yourself to focus on staying on your feet. Forget the hangar, your body has decided it's had enough.
You slam into the control tower's door, clawing at the handle...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run past the tower to the hangar, unprotected.

A moment of rushing air and fear is all you experience before the V-MADS lock onto you, painting your entire body in white-hot pain.
You nearly stumble when it hits, but set your jaw and plod onward instead. This may be the most excruciating pain you've felt, but this wouldn't be the first time you've toughed out the hurt.
You push past the control tower, regretting every step towards your goal. Vision narrows to a tunnel as you slam into the hangar's door, clawing at the handle...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run past the tower to the barracks, unprotected.

A moment of rushing air and fear is all you experience before the V-MADS lock onto you, painting your entire body in white-hot pain.
You nearly stumble when it hits, but force yourself to focus on staying on your feet. Forget the barracks, your body has decided it's had enough.
You slam into the control tower's door, clawing at the handle...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Run past the tower to the barracks, unprotected.

A moment of rushing air and fear is all you experience before the V-MADS lock onto you, painting your entire body in white-hot pain.
You nearly stumble when it hits, but set your jaw and plod onward instead. This may be the most excruciating pain you've felt, but this wouldn't be the first time you've toughed out the hurt.
You push past the control tower, regretting every step towards your goal. Vision narrows to a tunnel as you slam into the barracks' door, clawing at the handle...

table.name: encounters
table.column: Leave the Blackwhite terminal, and return to the hangar.

You cross to the latter, and midway up the shaft you hear Blackwhite's voice, distant and echoed.
"Unauthorized access detected. TS/SI-M violation. Escalating to Condition Charlie."
Sounds like that progress bar must've finished. Alarms start blaring below and above, and you scramble for the surface.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
With weakened legs, you fail to clear one foot past the shin of the other and you take a tumble. You stop, and that's when you feel it: a void. A cold one.
You sit up. In the distance, the turrets are turning away from you. You've done it. Somehow you managed to clear the field.
As you stand, a rush of pain returns to you, but it's residual. As fast as you ran, you endured a concentrated and prolonged scorching, and your body won't forget its wounds.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Once cheap and ubiquitous at roadside stops, these pocket roadmaps have become something of an archeological tool for modern scavengers.
You carefully unfold the giant leaf, and try to make sense of where you are.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You recognize Detroit, even if everything else in your memory is missing. As cities go, it's one of the bigger ones.
You trace a route from where you are to the city. (See minimap.)

table.name: encounters
table.column: You carefully fold the map again.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You try to locate some landmarks both here and on the map, then trace your route to Saginaw.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You try to locate some landmarks both here and on the map, then trace your route to Grayling.

table.name: encounters
table.column: It takes some time acquiring satellites in the crumbling system, but the tablet locates your position, and displays route info. (See minimap.)

table.name: encounters
table.column: It takes some time acquiring satellites in the crumbling system, but the phone locates your position, and displays route info. (See minimap.)

table.name: encounters
table.column: Discover nearby hexes and scavenge sites.
After acquiring satellites, the phone locates your position, and displays cached map data. Not all of it is up-to-date, unfortunately, but it's better than nothing.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Discover nearby hexes and scavenge sites.
After acquiring satellites, the tablet locates your position, and displays cached map data. Not all of it is up-to-date, unfortunately, but it's better than nothing.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It takes some time acquiring satellites in the crumbling system, but the tablet locates your position, and displays the nearby area.
You recognize Detroit, even if everything else in your memory is missing. As cities go, it's one of the bigger ones.
You trace a route from where you are to the city. (See minimap.)

table.name: encounters
table.column:
It takes some time acquiring satellites in the crumbling system, but the phone locates your position, and displays the nearby area.
You recognize Detroit, even if everything else in your memory is missing. As cities go, it's one of the bigger ones.
You trace a route from where you are to the city. (See minimap.)

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You startle awake.
No, it hasn't all just been a dream. You're still sitting in the AAV as its payload when a sudden jerk wakes you from the slumber of trauma-induced exhaustion.
When you look out the top, all you can see of your former surroundings is a lake of mist far to the north. Below: the Great Black Swamp. To see it sprawl from east to west, an antithesis of life, the necrosis of civilization- it's a haunting view beneath.
Another "crack!" accompanies a smell of burning plastic as you duck into your compartment again.
The engines are failing, and there's a ragged whistling noise coming from the tail. The drone is no longer flying but in a controlled fall.
You hazard a peek outside. More and more of the swamp passes below. You glide past the rotting lands, the sinking roads, the crumbling buildings, the toxic fumes- but you're falling too fast to make a full crossing.
You duck inside, and brace for the inevitable.
The drone hits something hard, the weightless rebound ringing in your ears for a moment before smashing and grinding through what sounds like rocks and water. Parts rip away, and sludge sprays into the hold from the openings they leave.
The fuselage twists right suddenly and flips over, throwing you hard into a debris-filled pool. Wrenching metal and cracks of composites echo over the next mound as the drone becomes just another part of the desolate landscape.
In a fit of coughing, you crane your neck away from the sludge, and pull yourself weakly onto an embankment.
For several wheezing moments, you cling to the earth, gathering your senses.
After more coughing, you plant a hand in the cold mud, push the ground away, and stagger to your feet. A brisk, acrid wind bites through your soaked clothes, and you turn to face away from it.
Ahead, miles of lifeless, muddy terrain, punctuated by toxic pools and shells of old buildings.
And beyond that, Indiana.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You quickly rummage through your things.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Anyway. That's step two: figure out how to get in. Step three: find schematics. Somewhere convenient for personnel to get to, day and night. Step four: test data, downloaded off the control tower, using this." He hands you a small flashdrive. "Plug-and-play. Easy. Step five: bring it all to me. Got it?"

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"I have heard a rumor, though," he interrupts himself. "Maybe I read it? Anyway, I seem to remember hearing some protesters got around the defenses, back in the day."
He thinks a moment. "It was something embarrassingly low-tech, too."
He shakes his head. "I'll be damned if I can remember what, though. You might rummage through some old newspapers, to see if you can find that story."
"It'd beat getting chewed up by whatever they've got running up there."

table.name: encounters
table.column: Stay away from areas with a high risk of collapse or other accidents.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're standing outside the "Last Chance" Canteen.
Originally named for its location on the outskirts of the Sprawl, locals often joke that the "Last Chance" Canteen is, in fact, a warning to prospective patrons.
Known for serving whatever is "available", as well as a few suspect staple dishes, the "Last Chance" is a venue for those hungry and not too fussy about their food's origins.
Still, the old fifth-wheel draws lines enough to keep its grills hot, so nobody must've died from their food.
Yet.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Didja know seagull's a land bird?" the cook shouts over the fans and sizzling. "Easy to catch, too!" he guffaws.
"Yeah, and easy to overcook," you add, under your breath.

table.name: encounters
table.column: What you get isn't far from what you imagined: smallish; amorphous; fried; tender.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Despite your inquiries, you fail to learn anything more about the non-committal stew.
The flavor is just as perplexing as the name. Better than dirty socks boiled in MSG, but only just.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Feeling more adventurous, you opt for the extra protein sprinkled over the mixed veggie bowl.
While the blackened, cornflake-like objects don't address the lack of flavor in the original dish, you can't argue that it doesn't change the texture.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Being the safest dish on the menu, it's arguably the most popular. Not for lack of trying, though.
A mix of sprouts and shredded carrots, lettuce, and turnips fried in oil, if it had a flavor, you'd describe it as savory with a sweet-yet-pungent aftertaste.
If it had a flavor.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
She keeps firing. "We are freedom! We watch back!" she cries out between bullets. "The watchmen will not watch us!"
On and on you run until you've escaped Camp Grayling, winded.

table.name: encounters
table.column: On second thought, maybe you'll use your "last chance" after all.

table.name: encounters
table.column: The food may be sketchy, but at least the bottled water is legit.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
As you step around a muddy tarp shanty on the edge of the Sprawl, you stumble across an old fifth-wheel with smoke streaming from a stove pipe.
People are lined up outside, taking turns ordering at a window.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Down here, squeezed between the DMC's southern walls and the Great Swamp's proverbial "hard place", you finally find a place boasting vacancy: St. James Parkade.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
St. James Parkade is what it sounds like: a pre-apocalypse parking garage. Except in this case, repurposed to berth humans. Someone had the bright idea to leave all the cars in a parking garage, hook them up to an unlicensed power tap, and charge occupancy by the night.
A patron could rent an open pickup if they're down on their luck (and own a sleeping bag). They could rent a hatchback if they have a little extra to spend on heat and shelter (and door locks). Or, if they have the taste for finer living, splurge for a full-size van with its own chem-toilet.
It's no Ritz Carlton. However, it's also not sleeping exposed to anyone who wanders by. And that's what counts.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
When you find your stall, there's a maroon pickup truck in it. The bed's more than big enough to stretch out, maybe for two or three people if you really wanted.
The cab, on the other hand, is pretty minimal. No sleeping in there, unless you're a fan of sore neck and back.
It'll do for a place to safely stash your stuff, though. And the parkade's roof at least stops the rain.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You find your assigned stall, and there's an emerald-colored hatchback there, covered in dust.
Inside, some of the seats have been removed, but the rear bed offers just enough room to stretch out.
There are no amenities inside. No blankets, TV, or running water. However, the old electric engine's been wired to the grid, so you have ample climate control and light. Combined with door locks and windows, this beats most beds you've made while in the wild.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Rent a full-size van for 24 hours - $120

When you arrive at your stall, you find a large, gray conversion van parked there.
With an extended roof, built-in porta-potty, and comfortable appointments, this is as top-of-the-line as you're gonna get in this place.
You toss your things inside, lock the doors behind you, and draw the curtains. With the heat just right, and the lights dimmed, you stretch out in your temporary mansion.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide to leave the Parkade for now.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You're alerted to the sound of a cart approaching. A guy in a hoodie pushes his cart to a nearby car, checks for occupants, and unlocks it. He makes quick work of taking anything of value left in the car, and throws trash into a big bin.
Then, he starts wheeling towards you. "Time's up, buddy."
Better get your stuff together and go, lest any of it end up on that cart.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Grabbing what you can, you head for the exit.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Visit the St. James Parkade office.

You walk down to the Parkade ticket office: a booth with bullet-proof glass situated in the parkade's old entrance.
The booth's inside is awash in pale light, highlighting a girl reading with her knees propped up against the wall.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Extend your pickup rental to 24 hours from now - $20

Despite her headphones, she seems to hear you just fine, takes your fee, and resets your timer to 24 hours on a beat-up iSlab.
Then, she gets back to reading as if nothing happened.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You decide to leave the booth alone for now.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Extend your pickup rental to 1 week from now - $120

Despite her headphones, she seems to hear you just fine, takes your fee, and resets your timer to 1 week on a beat-up iSlab.
Then, she gets back to reading as if nothing happened.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Extend your pickup rental to 4 weeks from now - $400

Despite her headphones, she seems to hear you just fine, takes your fee, and resets your timer to 4 weeks on a beat-up iSlab.
Then, she gets back to reading as if nothing happened.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Despite her headphones, she seems to hear you just fine, takes your fee, and zeroes your timer on a beat-up iSlab.
Then, she gets back to reading as if nothing happened.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Extend your hatchback rental to 24 hours from now - $45

Despite her headphones, she seems to hear you just fine, takes your fee, and resets your timer to 24 hours on a beat-up iSlab.
Then, she gets back to reading as if nothing happened.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Extend your hatchback rental to 1 week from now - $300

Despite her headphones, she seems to hear you just fine, takes your fee, and resets your timer to 1 week on a beat-up iSlab.
Then, she gets back to reading as if nothing happened.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Extend your hatchback rental to 4 weeks from now - $1000

Despite her headphones, she seems to hear you just fine, takes your fee, and resets your timer to 4 weeks on a beat-up iSlab.
Then, she gets back to reading as if nothing happened.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Extend your van rental to 24 hours from now - $120

Despite her headphones, she seems to hear you just fine, takes your fee, and resets your timer to 24 hours on a beat-up iSlab.
Then, she gets back to reading as if nothing happened.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Extend your van rental to 1 week from now - $800

Despite her headphones, she seems to hear you just fine, takes your fee, and resets your timer to 1 week on a beat-up iSlab.
Then, she gets back to reading as if nothing happened.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Extend your van rental to 4 weeks from now - $3000

Despite her headphones, she seems to hear you just fine, takes your fee, and resets your timer to 4 weeks on a beat-up iSlab.
Then, she gets back to reading as if nothing happened.

table.name: encounters
table.column: <us> didn't have the goods, so no deal.

table.name: encounters
table.column: <us> is brokering a deal at the DMC.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Of course." He starts assembling items from various drawers, then buzzes the guards back. "If you'll excuse me, I have some mercifully more trivial errands to attend to."
The guards let you pass before entering the room. And before long, you're rattling down in the elevator car to the cool air of the sprawl.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Try to broker a deal for the Blue Rot materials.

"I do have a question for you, though," you add. The junk market might pay a nominal fee for biotech, but this sort of thing goes much further in the right hands.
Fortunately, Hatter may be just such a set of hands.

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Oh hell no. I heard of you. You stay the hell away!"

table.name: encounters
table.column: "You's dat slipp'ry son bitch, ain't ya? Yeah, I heard of you."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"You know," genuine concern replaces his exasperation. "I used to think *they* be the monsters. But now? Psh. I heard some dude's out there tearing shit up."
"Man, I don't know *what* the hell is goin' on no more."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"Yo. Why can't you be like that elusive man an', like, disappear from my life."
He stares at you a moment, wide-eyed, to make his point. Then he walks off.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You glare at her, unimpressed.
"Oh shit," she says calmly. "You him, ain't you? You 'dat guy?"
She backs off. "Okay, I get it."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "My bad. You got things to, uh, pummel." She gives you a wide berth.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"You hear 'bout this 'elusive man' givin' everyone the slip?"
He shakes his head as he passes, "dude's like teflon. Like the Teflon Don."

table.name: encounters
table.column: "Keep your eyes open, bro," he warns in earnest. "Been some dude out there tearin' shit *up*."

table.name: encounters
table.column: He just nods at you, in deference, before moving on. Knowing these guys, that's a big deal.

table.name: encounters
table.column: He just nods at you, in deference, before moving on. Knowing these guys, that's a big deal.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
He squints at you a moment, then relaxes.
"Sorry. Been talk of some guy slippin' through all the wrong cracks lately." He continues on.
"If you see something, say something."

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Relief at the sight of civilization almost overtakes you, until you realize you still have to make it there.
That, and scavenging promises to get a lot harder near the city, as nearby ruins will have been picked over already.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You hear them before you see them: people.
Lots of 'em.
Pushing branches aside, you're presented with the city you saw from afar. A hybrid between shanty town, refugee camp, and RV park skirts the massive walls to the city.
Everywhere you look, people navigate the winding, muddy roads. Carrying supplies, patching holes in shelters, or arguing over property.
Smoke from a thousand camp stoves and barrel fires trail upward, and the scent of cooked food elicits a gurgling from your stomach.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Nary an eye pays any attention to you, just one of dozens of ragtag corpses shuffling in from the wasteland. Beggars. Customers. Hopefuls. Prey.
Welcome to DMC's Sprawl.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Leaving Through the Back Door cont'd

Stoat's friend waits as you gather your things from the lockbox. Better make sure you empty that locker while you have the chance.
Once ready, you head along the fence, back to the relative sanity of the wastelands.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Stoat's friend waits as you gather your things from the lockbox. Better make sure you empty that locker while you have the chance.
Once ready, you head along the fence and return to the wastelands, towards a higher measure of normality.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Tell him the Church needs a new King.

You stand and stare down the King. "The truth is that the crown is too heavy for your doubt-filled head. This Church needs a new King, and that King is me."
The King kicks back his chair. "No," he shouts, returning to a voice for sermons. "'The Savior's head bears no crown, for he is Brotherhood, and he stands amongst the flock.'"
The Bishop, vindicated by your treachery, leads some cultists into the room.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You take a moment to check your things.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Try bargaining with dogman footage cont'd.

You turn to face it, looking it over desperately for angles of approach, when the music suddenly stops. Everyone starts looking around in confusion as lights dim.
"Awwwww, I gotta treat for y'all right here," the announcer croons. Hope wells up inside you again. "Feast your eyes on THIS!"
An image appears on the wall over the garage door, and as it comes into focus, you exhale in relief.
Larger than life, your battle with the dogman plays out for all to see. Patrons start belting out comments, and audibly wince as you pummel the beast. You hear a "GodDAMN, son!" from nearby.

table.name: encounters
table.column: Try to outrun the bot cont'd.

You change tactics, using the pillars to your advantage. Biting back pain, you begin hobbling from pillar to pillar, keeping the robot in a steady, square chase pattern. It hurts like hell, but at each corner, you get a brief respite as you wait for the bot to clumsily navigate around the pillar.
It's a boring pursuit, and the audience voices as much. Shouts of "Boo!" and "Next!" rise from the crowd, and a horn blows. You've managed to buy your life with boredom, for once. That, and a nasty gash on your leg.

table.name: encounters
table.column: A Happy Crowd is a Safe Crowd

The audience lets out a roar of approval. Somebody got gored AND a robot thrashed. Good day at the pit!
The pit gates open, and as a clean-up crew enters the field, you decide to make for the door, before you get lucky and win another lotto.
Forcing your way back toward the door, you step into brightly lit trailer, and present your chit to the guard.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Audibly disappointed, the MC does his best to distract the booing crowd as the robot is deactivated and cleared from the field.
The pit guards open the gates, and for a moment, you worry you'll be pressed into another fight. However, nothing happens for a few moments, so you decide to make for the door while you can.
Pressing through the crowd, you fish out your chit, and present it to the guard at the weapons check.

table.name: encounters
table.column:
You quickly scan the arena for potential snares. It's slim pickings here, however. The arena is mostly flat, with smooth walls. About the only thing you have to work with are the occasional pillar, and the robot itself. You decide to try and leverage one of those pillars.
As the robot scuttles toward you, you veer to the side, and put the pillar between you and it. Unsurprisingly, the robot arcs its path accordingly. Must be able to pathfind around obstacles. Should've figured.
Closer now, you've got a better idea of the scale of the bot, and a new plan forms in your head. You stick to the pillar, aiming to keep it between you both. Predictably, the robot continues to arc into a clear path. However, as it closes, it has to sidestep further to clear the pillar. As it approaches melee range, it spends more time sidestepping than approaching.

table.name: encounters
table.column: You head down one of the crowded aisles...

table.name: encounters
table.column:
Hardware/Software: If hardware/software is not switched on and unlocked, vendors will only pay the hardware's value as if it were empty. Items will then be appraised by a specialist, and resold at full price.
Medicine: Vendors will only pay a nominal fee for unidentified pills. Pills will then be identified and sold at full price.
When in doubt, verify the vendor's purchase price before surrendering items to them. All sales final!

table.name: encounters
table.column:
"That was my dad," she says. "He's had time to raise me, grow old, and pass on since then."
She's probably in her forties, if you had to guess. What's that make it? Fifty years ago? Ish?
Sensing your confusion, she lets out a "psh, yeah. Wild, huh?"
